口语和识字能力

Orality and Literacy

沃尔特·J·翁 (Walter J. Ong) 的经典著作对口头、书面、印刷和电子技术的社会影响及其对哲学、神学、科学和文学思想的影响提供了令人着迷的见解。

Walter J. Ong’s classic work provides a fascinating insight into the social effects of oral, written, printed and electronic technologies, and their impact on philosophical, theological, scientific and literary thought.

这本三十周年纪念版——恰逢翁诞辰一百周年——完整转载了他最著名、最具影响力的著作，并更新了文化作家兼评论家约翰·哈特利 (John Hartley) 的两篇新的探索性文章。

This thirtieth anniversary edition – coinciding with Ong’s centenary year – reproduces his best-known and most influential book in full and brings it up to date with two new exploratory essays by cultural writer and critic John Hartley.

哈特利提供：

Hartley provides:

  • 场景设置章节将翁的作品置于战后美国主义的历史和学科背景以及传播和媒体研究的兴起中
  • a scene-setting chapter that situates Ong’s work within the historical and disciplinary context of post-war Americanism and the rise of communication and media studies
  • 最后一章跟进了 Ong 关于与不断发展的媒体形式相关的口语和读写能力的工作，讨论了最近对 Ong 方法的批评，并评估了他的“意识进化”概念
  • a closing chapter that follows up Ong’s work on orality and literacy in relation to evolving media forms, with a discussion of recent criticisms of Ong’s approach, and an assessment of his concept of the ‘evolution of consciousness’
  • 广泛参考了近期关于口语、读写能力和知识技术研究的学术成果，追踪了我们了解知识的方式的变化。
  • extensive references to recent scholarship on orality, literacy and the study of knowledge technologies, tracing changes in how we know what we know.

这些富有启发性的文章将翁置于最近的思想史中，并展示了他的作品在文学与媒体以及心理学、教育和社会学思想之间关系的持续研究中的持续力量。

These illuminating essays contextualize Ong within recent intellectual history and display his work’s continuing force in the ongoing study of the relationship between literature and the media, as well as that of psychology, education and sociological thought.

沃尔特·J·翁（Walter J. Ong，1912年11月30日至2003年8月12日）是美国圣路易斯大学的名誉教授，此前他曾担任该校的英语教授和精神病学人文教授。他的许多出版物对意识进化的研究具有很大影响。

Walter J. Ong (November 30 1912–August 12 2003) was University Professor Emeritus at Saint Louis University, USA, where he was previously Professor of English and Professor of Humanities in Psychiatry. His many publications have been highly influential for studies in the evolution of consciousness.

约翰·哈特利 (John Hartley)是电视、新闻、大众媒体和创意产业的历史和文化影响方面的教育家、作家、研究员和评论员。他是西澳大利亚科廷大学文化科学教授兼文化与技术中心主任。

John Hartley is an educator, author, researcher and commentator on the history and cultural impact of television, journalism, popular media and creative industries. He is Professor of Cultural Science and Director of the Centre for Culture and Technology at Curtin University, Western Australia.

总编序言

GENERAL EDITOR’S PREFACE

毫无疑问，第三本总编的新口音序言似乎很难证明其合理性。还有什么好说的呢？二十五年前，该系列以非常明确的目的开始。它主要关注的是新近陷入困境的学术文学研究领域，其中充斥着被称为“理论”、“语言学”和“政治”的忙碌怪物。它特别针对那些正在学习适应新发展或正在受到严厉警告的本科生或研究生。

No doubt a third General Editor’s Preface to New Accents seems hard to justify. What is there left to say? Twenty-five years ago, the series began with a very clear purpose. Its major concern was the newly perplexed world of academic literary studies, where hectic monsters called ‘Theory’, ‘Linguistics’ and ‘Politics’ ranged. In particular, it aimed itself at those undergraduates or beginning postgraduate students who were either learning to come to terms with the new developments or were being sternly warned against them.

新口音故意站在一边。因此，1977 年的第一篇序言阴暗地谈到了“一个快速而激进的社会变革的时代”，以及“对文学研究至关重要的假设和预设的侵蚀”。它宣称，“从过去继承的模式和类别似乎不再适合新一代所经历的现实”。每卷的目的是通过将对新思想的具体阐述与对相关概念发展的清晰详细解释相结合，“鼓励而不是抵制变革的过程”。如果神秘化（或彻头彻尾的妖魔化）是敌人，那么清醒（对不可避免的妥协表示认可）就成了朋友。如果“未来的独特话语”向我们招手，我们至少希望能够理解它。

New Accents deliberately took sides. Thus the first Preface spoke darkly, in 1977, of ‘a time of rapid and radical social change’, of the ‘erosion of the assumptions and presuppositions’ central to the study of literature. ‘Modes and categories inherited from the past’ it announced, ‘no longer seem to fit the reality experienced by a new generation’. The aim of each volume would be to ‘encourage rather than resist the process of change’ by combining nuts-and-bolts exposition of new ideas with clear and detailed explanation of related conceptual developments. If mystification (or downright demonization) was the enemy, lucidity (with a nod to the compromises inevitably at stake there) became a friend. If a ‘distinctive discourse of the future’ beckoned, we wanted at least to be able to understand it.

随着世界末日的到来，第二序言开始了虔诚地担心任何可能从废墟中蹒跚而行的粗暴野兽的本质。它抱怨道，“我们如何才能认识或应对新事物？”尽管如此，它还是报道了“一系列几乎不值得尊敬的活动，但我们没有令人放心的名字”的令人沮丧的进展，并承诺在“世界边界”实施谨慎的监视计划。是有先例的，而且是可想象的极限”。它的结论是“不可想象的事物毕竟秘密地塑造了我们的思想”可能是一条不言而喻的真理。但就它在一个摇摇欲坠的确定性世界中提供某种可用的购买而言，它并不值得脸红。

With the apocalypse duly noted, the second Preface proceeded piously to fret over the nature of whatever rough beast might stagger portentously from the rubble. ‘How can we recognise or deal with the new?’, it complained, reporting nevertheless the dismaying advance of ‘a host of barely respectable activities for which we have no reassuring names’ and promising a programme of wary surveillance at ‘the boundaries of the precedented and at the limit of the thinkable’. Its conclusion, ‘the unthinkable, after all, is that which covertly shapes our thoughts’ may rank as a truism. But in so far as it offered some sort of useable purchase on a world of crumbling certainties, it is not to be blushed for.

在这种情况下，任何后续的、当然也是最终的编辑都只能谦虚地回顾过去，惊叹该系列仍然存在，并且不无道理地祝贺自己为这些年来变成了一些独特的作品提供了最初的出路。文学研究中的声音和主题。但现在重新展示的这些卷不仅仅具有历史意义。正如他们的作者所指出的，他们提出的问题仍然很有效，他们所提出的论点仍然令人不安。简而言之，我们没有错。学术研究确实发生了迅速而彻底的变化，以适应甚至帮助产生广泛的社会变革。一套新的话语被开发出来来应对这些剧变。这个过程也没有停止。在我们这个潮解的世界里，

In the circumstances, any subsequent, and surely final, editor can only modestly look back, marvelling that the series is still here, and not unreasonably congratulating itself on having provided an initial outlet for what turned, over the years, into some of the distinctive voices and topics in literary studies. But the volumes now re-presented have more than a mere historical interest. As their authors indicate, the issues they raised are still potent, the arguments with which they engaged are still disturbing. In short, we weren’t wrong. Academic study did change rapidly and radically to match, even to help to generate, wide reaching social changes. A new set of discourses was developed to negotiate those upheavals. Nor has the process ceased. In our deliquescent world, what was unthinkable inside and outside the academy all those years ago now seems regularly to come to pass.

我很难说《新口音》卷是否为这一新地形提供了足够的警告、地图、指南或推动。也许我们最好的成就在于培养了它就在那里的感觉。不情愿地第三次尝试写序言的唯一理由是相信它仍然如此。

Whether the New Accents volumes provided adequate warning of, maps for, guides to, or nudges in the direction of this new terrain is scarcely for me to say. Perhaps our best achievement lay in cultivating the sense that it was there. The only justification for a reluctant third attempt at a Preface is the belief that it still is.

特伦斯·霍克斯

TERENCE HAWKES

在 ONGISM 出现之前

BEFORE ONGISM

“为了成为我们想成为的人，我们必须决定我们是谁。” 1

“To become what we want to be, we have to decide what we were.”1

约翰·哈特利

John Hartley

“朋友们，罗马人，同胞们，请听我说” 2

“Friends, Romans, countrymen, lend me your ears” 2

2012 年是 Walter J. Ong, SJ 诞辰一百周年（11 月 30 日），但他仍然被阅读并被视为当代学者。他写的关于自己曾经的老师马歇尔·麦克卢汉的一些话，与翁自己的学术时间旅行产生了共鸣：他的“声音始终是现在呼唤过去的声音，他用过去的方式与现在做出热情洋溢、富有说服力的反应”读者心中的现实”（Ong 2002：307）。Walter Ong 自己的出版物跨越了 70 年，一直持续到 2003 年他去世的那一年。3他的兴趣范围从古代苏美尔书写系统到现代计算机——他指出，两者都使用数字代码（2002：527-49）。他沉浸在历史研究中，但始终保持着前瞻性。他的最后一本书（Ong 2002）是在他临近 90 岁生日时出版的，其副标题是“进一步探究的挑战”。

2012 marks the centenary of the birth of Walter J. Ong, SJ (November 30), but he is still read and regarded as a contemporary scholar. Something that he wrote about his own one-time teacher, Marshall McLuhan, resonates for Ong’s own scholarly time travels: His “voice is always the voice of the present calling into the past, a past that he teases into reacting ebulliently and tellingly with present actuality in his readers’ minds” (Ong 2002: 307). Walter Ong’s own publications spanned 70 years, continuing to 2003, the year of his death.3 His interests ranged from ancient Sumerian writing systems to modern computers – both using digital code, he noted (2002: 527–49). He was immersed in historical scholarship, but remained forward-looking throughout. His last book (Ong 2002), published as he approached his 90th birthday, is jauntily subtitled “ Challenges for Further Inquiry.”

这里不是评价 Ong 的生活和作品的地方。对于爱好者和专家来说，有现成的好资料，包括托马斯·法雷尔（Thomas Farrell）对已经提到的收藏的介绍（Ong 2002：1-68；并参见 Soukup 2007）。在提请您注意 Ong 最著名的书《口语与读写能力》的新版本时，我既不要埋葬他，也不要赞扬他。相反，我想向他的书的非专业读者讲话，对于他们来说——从亚马逊网站上的客户评论来看——他的历史和思想轨迹背后的连贯性可能不会立即显现出来。4对于新生的“读者思想”来说，也许需要重新连接当前现实与过去想法之间的“热情洋溢且富有说服力”的联系，我将这种联系称为“翁主义”。5

This is not the place for an appraisal of Ong’s life and works. For the enthusiast and the specialist, there are good accounts readily to hand, including Thomas Farrell’s Introduction to the collection already mentioned (Ong 2002: 1–68; and see Soukup 2007). In bringing to your attention a new edition of Ong’s best-known book, Orality and Literacy, I seek neither to bury nor to praise him. Instead, I want to address the non-specialist reader of his book, for whom – judging by customer reviews on Amazon.com – the coherence underlying his historical and intellectual trajectories may not be immediately evident.4 For newly minted “readers’ minds,” perhaps, there’s a need to reconnect that “ebullient and telling” link between present actuality and past ideas, a connection I’m going to call “Ongism.”5

鉴于他自由的时间旅行，追踪翁主义与更广泛的思想史上各个历史时期的联系可能会有所帮助。思想体系和与之相伴的表达媒介的历史，通过这些媒介来组织思想，如下：

Given his free-ranging time travels, it may be helpful to trace a line that connects Ongism with various historical periods in the broader history of ideas; the history of systems of thought and concomitant media of expression through which ideas have been organised, as follows:

–古代和中世纪修辞学（大约公元前 500 年至公元 1500 年），

– Ancient and medieval rhetoric (roughly 500 bce to 1500 ce),

因为修辞学——一种口头艺术——“最终将所有知识纳入其管辖范围”（Ong 1971：vii）；通过

because it was rhetoric – an oral art – that “ultimately took all knowledge as its province” (Ong 1971: vii); via

– 欧洲宗教改革(1500–1700),

– the European Reformation (1500–1700),

以印刷品为基础的拉米主义（Ong 1958）改革了知识和宗教；这一举措将宗教与资本主义的兴起联系起来（Tawney 1998），并为（新教）卫理公会和（科学）方法创造了路径依赖（Ong 1953）；和

where print-based Ramism (Ong 1958) reformed knowledge as well as religion; a move that linked religion with the rise of capitalism (Tawney 1998), and created a path-dependency for (Protestant) Methodism and (scientific) method alike (Ong 1953); and

– 随后的启蒙运动（1700-1900），

– the ensuing Enlightenment (1700–1900),

科学和苏格兰（参见 Berry 1997；Phillipson 2010）；

both scientific and Scottish (see Berry 1997; Phillipson 2010);

– 由于这些影响了美利坚共和国的发展，

– as these impacted the growth of the American Republic,

直接通过本杰明·富兰克林（Atiyah 2006）和间接通过托马斯·杰菲特森（McLean 2011）；从那里到

directly through Benjamin Franklin (Atiyah 2006) and indirectly though Thomas Jefiterson (McLean 2011); thence to

–现代知识的技术决定（1900年至今），

– the technological determinations of modern knowledge (1900– date),

根据翁的思路，写作和印刷品读写能力“改变”了人类的整体意识，而“第二口头语言”则随着数字媒体的出现而出现。

where, according to the Ong line of thought, writing and print-literacy have “transformed” human consciousness as a whole, while a “secondary orality” has emerged with digital media.

《口语与识字》是他 30 年工作的总结，使 Ong 的思想受到广泛关注，引起了那些人的共鸣。对通信技术（语音、写作、印刷、屏幕、计算机）对人类思考和认知方式的影响感到好奇。这种好奇心并不总是出于良性动机，因为有些人担心当代技术，尤其是最受欢迎的广播和屏幕媒体（尤其是电视），是知识的破坏者而不是创造者，特别是与印刷帝国相比，印刷帝国是无可争议的现代性所有伟大的现实主义知识体系的交流媒介——科学（论文）、新闻业（报刊）和富有想象力的小说（小说）。

Orality and Literacy, the summation of 30 years of his work, brought Ong’s thought to wide attention, striking a chord with those who were curious about the impact of communication technologies – speech, writing, print, screen, computer – on how humans think and know. That curiosity was not always benignly motivated, because some feared that contemporary technologies, especially the most popular broadcast and screen media (television in particular), were destroyers rather than creators of knowledge, especially in comparison to the empire of print, which was the unchallenged medium of communication for all of the great realist knowledge systems of modernity – science (the paper), journalism (the press) and imaginative fiction (the novel).

这种真实的三方划分与更古老的分类相对应。这些作品的出现正值印刷品作为一种媒介在十六世纪末和十七世纪初的欧洲开始占据主导地位的时候：这是翁最喜欢的印记地。弗朗西斯·培根爵士（Sir Francis Bacon，1605 年）是现代经验科学的奠基人（被一些人称为“归纳推理之父”），6 也是“学习进步”的迫切倡导者，他试图根据知识对知识进行分类。沟通形式与人类能力之间的关系。正如戴安娜·阿尔特戈尔（Diana Altegoer）所写：“培根声称所有人类学习都源于记忆、想象力和理性这三个源泉，历史、诗歌和哲学都从中产生; 不可能有其他人”（Altegoer 2000：22）。培根将他所谓的“人的心灵能力”视为两种：“一种是人的理解力和理性，另一种是他的意志、欲望和情感”；想象力在两者之间充当了“代理人或信使”（Bacon 1605：第二册，第十二节）。因此，“诗歌与想象力相结合，在培根促进学习的计划中占据着关键地位；通过将理性与意志和欲望联系起来”（Altegoer 2000：22）。

This tripartite division of the real corresponded with much older classifications. These emerged at the very time when print’s ascendancy as a medium began to be asserted in late sixteenth and early seventeenth-century Europe: very much Ong’s preferred stamping ground. It was Sir Francis Bacon (1605), founding philosopher of modern empirical science (dubbed by some the “father of inductive reasoning”),6 and urgent advocate of the “advancement of learning,” who tried to classify knowledge on the basis of the relationship between forms of communication and human faculties. As Diana Altegoer writes: “Bacon claimed that all human learning flows from the three fountains of memory, imagination and reason, from which emanate history, poesy, and philosophy ; there can be no others” (Altegoer 2000: 22). Bacon saw what he called “the faculties of the mind of man” as of two kinds: “the one respecting his understanding and reason, and the other his will, appetite, and a affection ”; and it was imagination that acted as an “agent or nuntius” [messenger] between the two (Bacon 1605: Book II, section XII). Thus, “poesy, aligned with the imagination, held a pivotal place in Bacon’s scheme to advance learning; by linking reason with the will and appetite” (Altegoer 2000: 22).

培根的图式继承自早期的修辞学和逻辑的口头传统，尤其是通过翁的学术核心人物彼得·拉穆斯（Peter Ramus）继承的。也许不自觉地或不自觉地，7它继续充当现代印刷文化的三个现实主义文本系统的基础认识论，我们可以将其空间化如下：

Bacon’s schema was inherited from earlier, oral traditions of rhetoric and logic, not least via Peter Ramus, the central figure in Ong’s scholarship. Perhaps unselfconsciously or unwittingly,7 it has continued to serve as the underlying epistemology of modern print culture’s three realist textual systems, which we might spatialise as follows:

值得注意的是，培根的图式将真理视为历史、诗歌和哲学这三种知识形式共同作用的奖品。后来的专业化迫使“科学”和“小说”进一步分离，至少在原则上如此，但培根希望在“科学理解和情感诗学之间建立一种共生关系”（Altegoer：23）——当代科学正在慢慢回归的这一愿望，例如 EO Wilson 呼吁创造性人文学科与自然科学之间的“一致性”（1998）。

Be it noted that Bacon’s schema saw truth as the prize of all three of these forms of knowledge, history, poesy and philosophy, working together. Later specialisation forced “science” and “fiction” ever further apart, at least in principle, but Bacon wanted to broker a “symbiotic relationship between scientific understanding and affective poetics” (Altegoer: 23) – an aspiration to which contemporary science is slowly returning, as for instance in E.O. Wilson’s call for “consilience” (1998) between the creative humanities and natural sciences.

翁的专长在于运用文学史研究和考证技巧来梳理前现代知识艺术——逻辑、修辞和辩证法——在印刷术出现后发生的转变。这些艺术（虽然可能很容易将它们分配到相应的列，但并不完全映射到上面的模式），在中世纪时期被部署用于组织和传播知识的严肃业务。翁的工作是现在所谓的“科学的科学”的早期例子——研究的不是我们知道什么，而是我们如何知道。与他同时代的马歇尔·麦克卢汉 (Marshall McLuhan) 一起，8 岁翁创造了“媒介就是信息”的口号，他推广了这样的观点：知识是语言的产物，而语言交流的媒介——通过语音、书写、印刷——让我们沿着某些路径依赖的路线思考。Ong 更进一步：他认为“写作可以重构意识”（口语和读写能力：第四章）。

Ong’s expertise lay in using the skills of literary-historical research and textual criticism to tease out the way that the pre-modern arts of knowledge – logic, rhetoric, and dialectics – were transformed following the emergence of print. These arts (which don’t quite map onto the schema above, tempting though it may be to assign them to the respective columns), were deployed in the medieval period for the serious business of organising and distributing knowledge. Ong’s work was an early example of what is now called the “science of science” – an investigation not into what but how we know. Along with his contemporary, Marshall McLuhan,8 who coined the slogan “the medium is the message,” Ong popularised the idea that knowledge is a product of language, and that the medium in which language is communicated – by voice, writing, print – makes us think along certain path-dependent lines. Ong went further: he contended that “writing restructures consciousness ” ( Orality and Literacy: Chapter 4).

因此，“翁主义”是心灵由媒介决定的地方。在方法论上，它使用语言分析——“从在中世纪经院哲学时代，盎格鲁-撒克逊世界已经产生了大量的思想”（Ong 1958：4）。这种分析将修辞与科学（知识）重新联系起来。此外，尽管他对文字的发明很感兴趣，但可以追溯到几千年前，翁自己的学术研究主要集中在文艺复兴和宗教改革时期，在此期间，欧洲文化因内部宗教冲突而震动，外部加速了扩张主义。在这样的时刻，“语言分析”与现代化西方的宗教和帝国（权力）的伟大主题联系在一起。翁格主义利用看似神秘的过去，为漫长的现在投射出意想不到的光芒，“热情而生动地”利用文本研究将权力和知识联系起来，跨越“历史的连续性（也是心理的连续性），口语和识字能力：162），当然是 Ong 自己的估计。

Thus “Ongism” is the place where mind is determined by medium. Methodologically, it uses linguistic analysis – something that “from the time of the medieval scholastics, the Anglo-Saxon world has been generating a good deal of thought around” (Ong 1958: 4). Such analysis reconnects rhetoric with science (knowledge). Further, although he was interested in the invention of writing, going back several millennia, Ong’s own scholarship was chiefly preoccupied with the Renaissance and Reformation periods, during which European culture was convulsed with religious conflicting internally, and accelerating expansionism externally. At such a time, “linguistic analysis” connects with the great themes of religion and empire (power) in the modernising West. Ongism used the seemingly arcane past to cast unexpected light on the long present, “ebulliently and tellingly” using textual studies to link power and knowledge, across “historical continuities (which are also psychological continuities),” far exceeding those theorised by Foucault ( Orality and Literacy : 162), certainly in Ong’s own estimation.

这是《口语和读写能力》在当代具有非凡影响力以及翁在许多跨学科领域产生影响的背景。兰斯·斯特拉特将后者列为：“修辞学、传播学、教育、媒体研究、英语、文学批评、古典学、圣经研究、神学、哲学、心理学、人类学、文化研究、历史、中世纪研究、文艺复兴研究、美国研究、性别研究、生物学和计算机科学”（Ong 2002 年前言：ix）。斯特拉特将这种影响力归因于翁对“思维学、知识和我们的认知方式”的掌握，这是一种“专业知识包含专业知识本身”的学术追求。这是一个精明的观察，但翁的影响力至少还有两个进一步的原因。第一个，历史性的，与第二个（纪律）相比，很少被评论——尽管它可能告诉我们更多信息。

This is the context for Orality and Literacy ’s extraordinary contemporary reach and for Ong’s influence across many interdisciplinary domains. The latter are listed by Lance Strate as: “rhetoric, communication, education, media studies, English, literary criticism, classics, biblical studies, theology, philosophy, psychology, anthropology, cultural studies, history, medieval studies, Renaissance studies, American studies, gender studies, biology, and computer science” (foreword to Ong 2002: ix). Strate puts that range of influence down to Ong’s mastery of “noetics, of knowledge and our ways of knowing,” a scholarly pursuit where “expertise encompasses expertise itself.” That’s a canny observation, but there are at least two further reasons for Ong’s influence. The first, historical, is less often commented on – although it may tell us more – than the second, disciplinary.

美国主义的思想起源

Intellectual origins of Americanism

从历史上看，翁的学术成就出现在美国力争并取得世界领导地位的时代。第二次世界大战后明确出现了所谓的“美洲和平”。美国的全球霸权地位不是直接通过帝国征服而被假定的（在两种意义上——被接受和被认为是理所当然的），而是通过思想，基于这些思想的道德和民主优越性的假设，而这些思想只需颁布即可对所有，无论你是美国人还是...说...越南语。因此，翁研究的“认知方式”和“专业知识”不仅具有历史意义，而且具有历史意义。他们变得更加重要，因为他们已经成为美国人。

Historically, Ong’s scholarship emerged in an era when the USA reached for and achieved world leadership; explicitly after World War II with the so called pax americana. US global hegemonic status was assumed (in both senses – taken on and taken for granted) not directly through imperial conquest, but through ideas, on the presumption of those ideas’ moral and democratic superiority, which only had to be promulgated to be binding on all, whether you were American or... say... Vietnamese. Thus, the “ways of knowing” and the “expertise” that Ong investigated were not just of historical interest; they were newly important because they had become American.

美国主义者在王自己的学术导师佩里·米勒（Perry Miller，1939；1953）所称的“新英格兰思想”中寻找美国优越性的思想根源——一种新教的、“彻底的”、民主的、“朴素的”思想。受到米勒的启发，翁将这种思维方式直接追溯到十六世纪的法国辩证法家彼得·拉穆斯（Ong 1958：4-7）。他关于拉米主义的工作是一项重大成就，但如果不是因为它的写作背景是在美利坚共和国的第一所大学哈佛大学，那么它可能无法逃脱研讨会或神学院的影响。

Americanists sought the intellectual origins of US superiority in what Ong’s own academic mentor, Perry Miller (1939; 1953), called “the New England Mind” – a Protestant, “downright,” democratic, “plainstyle” mind. Inspired by Miller, Ong traced that way of thinking directly back to the sixteenth-century French dialectician Peter Ramus (Ong 1958: 4–7). His work on Ramism is a major achievement, but it might not have escaped the seminar – or seminary – had it not been for the context of its composition at Harvard, the American Republic’s first university.

佩里·米勒在英国秘密战时服役后返回哈佛，被认为与发展美国在心理战新艺术方面的能力有关。9他指导 Ong 获得博士学位（1948-54 年），该博士学位由哈佛大学出版社出版。翁在那里承认了米勒（1958：x），并在哈佛、美国主义和拉米主义之间建立了联系：

Perry Miller returned to Harvard after secret wartime service in Britain, thought to be connected with developing American capabilities in the new art of psychological warfare.9 He supervised Ong’s doctorate (1948–54), which was published by Harvard University Press. Ong acknowledges Miller there (1958: x), and makes the connections between Harvard, Americanism, and Ramism:

当前[1958年]对Ramus的兴趣浪潮可以追溯到1935年和1936年，当时塞缪尔·艾略特·莫里森教授出版了他的哈佛三百年纪念卷《哈佛学院和哈佛在十七世纪的建立》。莫里森……将新英格兰的第一批果实追溯到知识之树上的树枝，而知识之树在美国遗产的传统记载中早已被遗忘。

The present [1958] wave of interest [in Ramus] dates from 1935 and 1936, when Professor Samuel Eliot Morison published his tercentennial Harvard volumes, The Founding of Harvard College and Harvard in the Seventeenth Century. Morison... traced New England’s first fruits back to branches on the tree of knowledge long forgotten in the traditional accounts of America’s heritage.

（1958：3）

(1958: 3)

在大约一页的时间内，这种“美国遗产”已经变得普遍：“在莫里森和米勒的作品之前，没有太多关于拉米主义在人类思想史上的更全面影响的著作”（1958：5，我的重点）。因此，对于 Ong 来说，“当今英语世界对拉米主义的兴趣是……共同的；它倾向于将拉米主义……视为一种现象或症状……可能会产生有关思想史和现代思想形成的有用甚至令人震惊的信息”（1958：6我的强调）。

Within a page or so, this “American heritage” has become universal: “Before Morison’s and Miller’s works, there was not much written concerning the fuller implications of Ramism in the history of the human mind ” (1958: 5, my emphasis). Thus, for Ong, “Present-day interest in Ramism in the English-speaking world is... communal; it tends to regard Ramism... as a phenomenon or symptom which... may yield helpful and even startling information concerning intellectual history and the formation of the modern mind ” (1958: 6 my emphasis).

哈佛大学不仅是美国最古老的高等教育机构（成立于 1636 年，正值拉米斯特方法的鼎盛时期）；它也是美国最古老的高等教育机构。也是最富有的大学，几乎经常被评为世界顶尖大学。10它过去是、现在仍然是美国主义的扩音器，尤其是通过哈佛商业出版社，其使命是“通过最大限度地扩大其基本产品——思想的影响力来影响现实世界的变化。” 11后者的观点是，“现代思想的形成”发生在语言的严酷考验中——这个严酷的考验被文学和戏剧加热，同时也被“平实的风格”和“直截了当”冷却。

Harvard is not just the oldest institution of higher education in the USA (founded in 1636 at the height of Ramist method); it is also the richest and has almost routinely been rated as the top-ranking university in the world.10 It was and remains a kind of megaphone for Americanism, not least through Harvard Business Publishing, whose mission is “to influence real-world change by maximizing the reach and impact of its essential offering – ideas.”11 Among the latter was the idea that the “formation of the modern mind” occurs in the crucible of language – a crucible heated by literature and drama even as it is cooled by “plain style” and “downrightness.”

例如，与 Ong 同期在哈佛大学工作多年的是阿尔弗雷德·哈巴奇 (Alfred Harbage，1941；1947)。哈巴奇是一位著名的文学史学家，他将莎士比亚的观众视为现代美国民主的先驱和典范，因为他的戏剧涉及社会各个阶层，从朝臣到交际花再到鞋匠。12随着时间的推移，环球剧院和其他剧院吸引了相当大比例的人口。Andrew Gurr (2004: 50) 估计每周有 25,000 名游客，从 1580 年到 1640 年总共接待了 5,000 万人次。“木 O”中的大众观众实际上正在制定一种现代政体——在学徒和工匠的心目中——即使在舞台上的戏剧与新兴现代性的痛苦和紧张作斗争，美国民主是现代性的继承者。

For instance, working for many years at Harvard, contemporaneously with Ong, was Alfred Harbage (1941; 1947). A notable literary historian, Harbage saw Shakespeare’s audience as the precursor and model of modern American democracy, because his plays addressed all sections of society, from courtier to courtesan to cobbler.12 Over time, the Globe and other theatres attracted a sizable proportion of the entire population. Andrew Gurr (2004: 50) estimates 25,000 visitors a week, totalling 50 million admissions from 1580 to 1640. The popular audience in the “wooden O” was literally enacting a modern polity forming itself – in the minds of apprentices and artisans – even as the plays onstage wrestled with the pains and tensions of emergent modernity, to which American democracy is the heir.

不想夸大它（例如美国至上主义），政治哲学的脉络贯穿于本世纪中叶的美国文学史学术界。这种情绪远远超出了哈佛的范围。在全国范围内，文学学术界似乎决心为沃尔特·惠特曼的内战后美国“民主愿景”愿景提供实质内容；13二战后世界新近紧迫的愿景。我想到了俄亥俄州的理查德·阿尔蒂克（The English Common Reader，1957）和斯坦福大学的 RF Jones（《英语语言的胜利》 ，1953）。14最引人注目的也许是耶鲁大学，该校的美国研究中心是在同一时期成立的，尤其是出于政治原因。美国研究是：

Without wanting to overstate it (as American supremacism, for instance), there is a vein of political philosophy running through the literary-historical scholarship of mid-century America. The mood extended well beyond Harvard. Across the country, literary scholarship seemed determined to give substance to Walt Whitman’s post-Civil War vision for America’s “democratic vistas”;13 a vision newly urgent in a post-World War II world. Richard Altick at Ohio ( The English Common Reader, 1957) and R. F. Jones at Stanford ( The Triumph of the English Language, 1953) come to mind.14 Most notable, perhaps, was Yale, where American Studies was established in the same period, not least for political reasons. American Studies was:

这项事业除其他外，将成为意识形态斗争的工具，其中一些人称之为冷战中的美国十字军东征，而另一些人则认为这场斗争实际上是第二次内战。

an enterprise that would be, among other things, an instrument for ideological struggle in what some among them termed the American crusade in the Cold War, and what others among them saw as virtually a second civil war.

（霍尔兹曼 1999：71）

(Holzman 1999: 71)

这一事业的领军人物是诺曼·霍姆斯·皮尔逊（Norman Holmes Pearson），他与哈佛大学的佩里·米勒（Perry Miller）一样，都是二战期间 OSS（战略服务办公室）（中央情报局的前身）的特工。佩里在哈佛的门生包括耶稣会神父沃尔特·翁（Walter Ong），而皮尔逊在耶鲁的门生则包括詹姆斯·耶稣·安格尔顿（James Jesus Angleton），他在那里学会了对脱离语境的文件进行实际批评的技巧。安格尔顿随后将其运用于中央情报局反情报部门的负责人，并在那里待了一代人（Holzman 2008）。正如特伦斯·霍克斯（Terence Hawkes）所指出的，在耶鲁大学期间，安格尔顿深受新批评的影响，尤其是威廉·恩普森（William Empson，1930）的实践，他的表达的不可约模糊性理论为安格尔顿寻找双重意义作为证据提供了很好的帮助。中央情报局内部的苏联“双重间谍”。在约翰逊和尼克松担任总统期间，他对间谍的痴迷搜寻转向了国内嫌疑人，其中包括美国社会的自由派和反文化精英，包括马丁·路德·金和爱德华·肯尼迪。霍克斯将文学批评与反情报进行了类比：

A leading figure in this enterprise was Norman Holmes Pearson, who, like Perry Miller at Harvard, was a secret agent for the OSS (Office of Strategic Services) – precursor of the CIA – during World War II. Where Perry’s protégés at Harvard included the Jesuit priest Walter Ong, Pearson’s at Yale included James Jesus Angleton, who learnt there the craft of practical criticism of decontextualised documents. Angleton went on to apply it as chief of counter-intelligence at the CIA, where he remained for a generation (Holzman 2008). While at Yale, as Terence Hawkes has pointed out, Angleton was much influenced by the New Criticism, especially as practised by William Empson (1930), whose theory of the irreducible ambiguity of expression served Angleton well in his search for double meanings as evidence of Soviet “double agents,” within the CIA itself. His obsessive search for spies turned to domestic suspects during the Johnson and Nixon presidencies, among them the liberal and countercultural elite of American society, including Martin Luther King and Edward Kennedy. Hawkes draws the parallel between literary criticism and counter-intelligence:

当主体被认为是“转变”时……它们本身就变成了需要复杂分析的“文本”。对模糊性的敏感度就成为了至关重要的武器。现代文学批评对现实政治的不可能但不可否认的影响没有更好的模型，安格尔顿后来将他的反情报工作描述为“对模糊性的实际批评”。

When agents may be recognized as “turned”... they themselves become “texts” which demand complex analysis. A sensitivity to ambiguity then becomes a crucial weapon. The improbable but undeniable impact of modern literary criticism on practical politics has no better model, and Angleton later described his work in counterintelligence as “the practical criticism of ambiguity.”

（霍克斯 2009）

(Hawkes 2009)

奇怪的是，常春藤盟校对修辞学、文学理论的研究，以及对神秘文本的实用批评，在个人和制度上都与美国主义在全球崛起的关键时期的高风险政治生涯产生了交叉。作为一名耶稣会士，翁大概没有参与像佩里、皮尔逊和安格尔顿这样的活跃间谍大师的反间谍恶作剧，但他在文学史、语言分析和美国的扩展学说的知识环境中崭露头角。 “昭昭天命”已成为一致。

Strangely, it seems, the study of rhetoric, of literary theory, and the practical criticism of arcane texts at Ivy-league colleges, intersected both personally and institutionally with the career of high-stakes political Americanism during the crucial period of its global ascendancy. As a Jesuit, presumably Ong was not involved in the counter-espionage shenanigans of active spy-masters like Perry, Pearson and Angleton, but he was brought to prominence in an intellectual environment where literary history, linguistic analysis and an expanded doctrine of the USA’s “manifest destiny” were brought into alignment.

这是一种寻求复兴或维持（即构建）古典西塞罗修辞与现代大众之间联系的哲学。民主和美利坚共和国，就像美国前总统约翰·昆西·亚当斯在 19 世纪初所做的那样——担任哈佛大学第一任修辞学教席的拥有者（Rathbun 2000）。15翁本人将哈佛学术的文学和修辞传统结合在一起，也许通过追随米尔曼·帕里和阿尔伯特·洛德的著作，他们学会了将前现代欧洲文化形式普遍化和美国化的习惯，两人在《口语和识字》中都被广泛引用。正如托马斯·法雷尔所指出的：

This was a philosophy that sought to revive or maintain (i.e. to construct) a bond between Classical Ciceronian rhetoric, modern mass democracy, and the American Republic, much as US ex-President John Quincy Adams had done in the early nineteenth century – as the occupant of Harvard’s first chair in Rhetoric (Rathbun 2000).15 Ong himself yoked the literary and rhetorical traditions of Harvard scholarship together, and perhaps learnt the habit of universalising and Americanising pre-modern European cultural forms, by following the work of Milman Parry and Albert Lord, both extensively cited in Orality and Literacy. As Thomas Farrell has noted:

帕里是哈佛大学的古典学家，对 20 世纪 30 年代的南斯拉夫故事歌手进行了实地研究。洛德是一名研究生，曾与帕里一起工作，后来根据他们的实地研究结果撰写了博士论文……随后于 1960 年出版，名为《故事歌手》，这是一项具有里程碑意义的研究。

Parry was a classicist at Harvard University who undertook field studies of Yugoslavian singers of tales in the 1930s. Lord was a graduate student who worked with Parry and later wrote his doctoral dissertation on the findings of their field studies... subsequently published in 1960 as The Singer of Tales, a landmark study.

（法雷尔，Ong 2002：2）

(Farrell, in Ong 2002: 2)

试图回答“我们对口语的理解有哪些新内容？”这个问题。（其中“口头性”应该被理解为一种人类特征，而不是属于特定文化、时间或地点的特征），翁写道：“美国古典主义者米尔曼·帕里（Milman Parry）比任何早期的学者都更成功地削弱了…… ……文化沙文主义，以便以诗歌本身的方式进入‘原始’荷马诗歌……”（口语和识字：18）。至于阿尔伯特·洛德（Albert Lord），他“以令人信服的技巧延续并扩展了帕里的工作”；此外，“那些在哈佛与他[米尔曼·帕里]和洛德一起学习的人……已经将帕里的思想应用于古英语诗歌的研究”（口语和读写能力：27）。Ong因此将自己的作品置于哈佛的学术传统，即美国在古代（荷马）和现代（塞尔维亚-克罗地亚）诗人中发现的“口头-听觉思维模式”（Ong 2002：301），被迅速应用于英语经典文学和进而影响到整个文化和文明；以及修辞学，然后是哲学和一般知识。其假设是“美国人的思想，尽管是多方面的”（Ong 2002：294）可以等同于人类的思想。这种逻辑在《口语与读写能力》一书中表现得很清楚，翁在其中总结了“初级口语文化的现代发现”一章（第二章）。他直接从米尔曼·帕里（Milman Parry）发现的口服方法中推断出来。荷马的作品（口语和识字：21），通过洛德、哈夫洛克等人（27-8），到麦克卢汉和翁自己的作品（28-9），进而通过以下作品对人类意识进行研究：心理学家朱利安·杰恩斯 (Julian Jaynes) (29-30)。当然，杰恩斯在耶鲁大学获得心理学博士学位之前曾在哈佛大学学习过本科课程。16

Seeking to answer the question “what is new in our understanding of orality?” (where “orality” should be understood as a human characteristic, not one belonging to a given culture, time or place), Ong writes that: “More than any earlier scholar, the American classicist Milman Parry... succeeded in undercutting... cultural chauvinism so as to get into the ‘primitive’ Homeric poetry on this poetry’s own terms...” ( Orality and Literacy : 18). As for Albert Lord, he “carried through and extended Parry’s work with convincing finesse”; moreover, “those who studied with him [Milman Parry] and Lord at Harvard... were already applying Parry’s ideas to the study of Old English Poetry” ( Orality and Literacy : 27). Ong thus places his own work in a Harvard tradition of scholarship, where the American discovery of an “oral-aural cast of mind” (Ong 2002: 301) among preliterate poets, both ancient (Homer) and modern (Serbo-Croat), is rapidly applied to Anglophone canonical literature and thence to culture and civilisation in general; and to rhetoric and thence to philosophy and knowledge in general. The presumption is that the “American mind, although a many-faceted thing” (Ong 2002: 294) can be equated with the human mind. This logic is clear in Orality and Literacy, where Ong concludes his chapter on “The modern discovery of primary oral cultures” (Chapter 2). He extrapolates directly from Milman Parry’s discovery of oral methods of composition in Homer ( Orality and Literacy : 21), via Lord, Havelock and others (27–8), to McLuhan and Ong’s own work (28–9), thence in turn to the study of human consciousness in general through the work of the psychologist Julian Jaynes (29–30). Jaynes, of course, had studied as an undergraduate at Harvard before taking his doctorate in psychology at Yale.16

尽管这一传统因不断变化的环境和学术时尚而被遮挡，但它不仅在美国研究中制度化，而且更根本地在传播文学批评的美国独特的“言语”、“修辞”和“交流”流派中制度化（Ong 2002：74）随着新教、科学和有说服力的散文的“朴素风格”遍布西方不断扩张的校园，例如圣路易斯等地，沃尔特·翁在那里攻读硕士学位，随后任教。17修辞学受到重视，是为了让公民为律师、神职人员或政治家的公共生活做好准备，并巩固商业和科学人口的普通教育（Bedford 1984）。如何让政体充满民主原则和编组部署能力为公民和私人目的有效地获取知识？在一个日益通过知识组织并依赖通信媒体技术化的社会中，这个问题从来都不是远离表面的。对于 Ong 一代人来说，答案也并不遥远：“知情公民”（Schudson 1998）必须懂得修辞。正如 Ong 在 1970 年所写的那样，“直到今天，修辞史的大部分工作仍然是由美国人完成的，他们对识字的极端承诺已经远远脱离了欧洲教育基础的旧修辞或演讲文化，首先将其有趣的现象”（Ong 2002：74；参见 Ong 2002：294）。

This tradition, however occluded by changing circumstance and academic fashion, was institutionalised not just in American Studies, but more fundamentally in the uniquely American (Ong 2002: 74) schools of “Speech,” “Rhetoric” and “Communications” that spread literary criticism along with the “plain style” of protestant, scientific and persuasive prose across the campuses of the expanding West, to places like St. Louis, for instance, where Walter Ong studied for his MA and subsequently taught.17 Rhetoric was valued in order to prepare citizens for public life as lawyers, clergy or politicians, and to underpin the general education of a commercial and scientific population (Bedford 1984). How to pervade the polity with both democratic principles and the ability to marshal and deploy knowledge effectively, for civic as well as private purposes? In a society increasingly organised through knowledge and dependent on the technologisation of the communications media, this question was never far from the surface; and for Ong’s generation the answer was never far away either: the “informed citizen” (Schudson 1998) must understand rhetoric. As Ong wrote in 1970, “To this day most of the work on the history of rhetoric is still done by Americans, who in their extreme commitment to literacy have been far enough removed from the old rhetorical or oratorical culture underlying European education to first its phenomena intriguing” (Ong 2002: 74; and see Ong 2002: 294).

对于万维网一代来说，与二战时期的一代不同，其中一些知识渊源需要重建。“自由”——“美国方式”——建立在赢得争论的能力之上。那么，“知道我们如何知道”的思维学就处于冷战议程的首要位置，无论是偏执形式（反情报）还是乐观形式，其中包括知道如何证明美国主义的优越性比如说赫鲁晓夫的俄罗斯。18

For the World Wide Web generation, as opposed to the World War II one, some of this intellectual provenance needs to be reconstructed. “Freedom” – the “American way” – was built on the capability of winning an argument. The science of noetics, then, of “knowing how we know,” was at the top of the Cold War agenda, in both its paranoid forms (counter-intelligence) and its optimistic forms, which included knowing how to demonstrate the superiority of Americanism over, say, Khrushchev’s Russia.18

在宏观层面上，美国的霸权不仅建立在其军事实力的基础上，还建立在其媒体、文化和科学的力量之上。随着冷战愈演愈烈，世界各地的人们都被美国主义的媒介愿景所吸引，这些愿景以莎士比亚式的大众娱乐为幌子，令人信服。这现在被称为“软实力”；中国共产党不仅在外交和治国之术的最高层面上支持这一点，而且还认为美国人也能做到这一点：

At the macro level, American hegemony was founded as much on the power of its media, culture and science as on its military might. As the Cold War heated up, hearts and minds across the world were wooed with mediated visions of Americanism, in the convincing – the Shakespearean – disguise of mass entertainment. This is now called “soft power”; and the Chinese Communist Party not only espouses it, at the highest level of diplomacy and statecraft, but also reckons that the Americans are still up to it too:

在最新一期的执政的共产党顶级理论期刊《求是》中，胡锦涛主席警告说，国家必须弘扬自己的文化，而不是敌对势力推动的“西化”。他写道：“我们必须清醒地认识到，国际敌对势力正在加紧实施西化、分裂我国的战略图谋。” “思想文化领域是他们长期渗透的重要领域。我们必须清醒地认识这场斗争的严重性和难度，敲响警钟……并采取有效措施应对。”

In the latest issue of the ruling Communist Party’s top theoretical journal, “Qiushi,” which means “Seeking Truth,” President Hu [Jintao] warned that the country must promote its own culture over “westernization” promoted by hostile forces. “We must clearly be aware that international enemy forces are stepping up their strategic plots to westernize and split our country,” he wrote. “The fields of thought and culture are important sectors they are using for this long-term infiltration. We must clearly recognize the seriousness and difficulty of this struggle, sound the alarm bell... and take effective measures to deal with it.”

（路透社 2012 年）

(Reuters 2012)

这就是中国对好莱坞电影实施严格进口配额的（表面上）理由。对某些人来说无害的娱乐活动对另一些人来说却是敌意渗透。“民主远景”是“战略阴谋”，正是因为正如沃尔特·惠特曼在 1871 年所说的那样，“我将使用美国和民主这两个词作为可转换的术语。” 19

This is China’s (ostensible) rationale for imposing strict import quotas on Hollywood films. Harmless entertainment to some is hostile infiltration to others. “Democratic vistas” are “strategic plots,” precisely because, as Walt Whitman had put it back in 1871, “I shall use the words America and democracy as convertible terms.”19

在微观层面上，个体公民需要心理软件来参与日益文本化的世界。在这种认知中，知识依赖于技术传输的信息，而这些信息是从其上下文根源中抽象出来的，就像书写和印刷品是从言语的即时性中抽象出来的一样。也许这种抽象概念比老欧洲的本土文化更适合美洲的移民和定居者社会。当然，不仅律师和领导者需要修辞技巧来操纵思想和知识，还需要“对歧义的实际批评”技巧来抵制对他人信息的操纵。成为成功的公民和消费者，维持进取的经济，并知道如何为了让我们的娱乐性和启发性社交媒体免受敌意和侵入性垃圾邮件的影响，每个人都必须运用知识的“软实力”。

At the micro level, the individual citizen needed mental software to engage in an increasingly textualised world; one where knowing relied on technologically transported information that was abstracted from its contextual roots, just as writing and print are abstracted from the situated immediacy of speech. Perhaps such abstraction suited the migrant and settler society of the Americas more comfortably than it did the autochthonous cultures of Old Europe. Certainly, it wasn’t only lawyers and leaders who required rhetorical skills to manipulate ideas and knowledge, and skills in “the practical criticism of ambiguity” to resist manipulation in the messages of others. To be successful citizens and consumers, to sustain an enterprising economy, and to know how to tell our entertaining and enlightening social media from their hostile and invasive spam, everyone must exercise the “soft power” of knowledge.

当代传播与文化研究

Contemporary communication and cultural studies

从翁格主义影响的历史原因转向学科原因，同样的“理性”传统当然是当代传播研究的重要根源之一。这里的萌芽人物不是翁在哈佛的博士生导师，而是他在圣路易斯的硕士导师——一位加拿大英语教授，与翁同龄， 20岁，从剑桥急忙来到圣路易斯教授莎士比亚。他的名字叫赫伯特·马歇尔·麦克卢汉。麦克卢汉为对修辞学感兴趣提供了不同的理由。一种将其影响力从历史和政治的“新英格兰思想”扩展到一般思想的思想，将通信技术的研究与个人（和普遍）认知心理学联系起来，没有放弃“昭昭命运”的进步主义宏大叙事，而只是将其向后投射到整个人类身上。

Turning from historical to disciplinary reasons for the influence of Ongism, this same “noetic” tradition was, of course, one of the great taproots of contemporary communication studies. Here, the germinal figure is not Ong’s doctoral supervisor at Harvard but his master’s supervisor at St Louis – a Canadian professor of English, much the same age as Ong,20 who came to St Louis, hotfoot from Cambridge, to teach Shakespeare. His name was Herbert Marshall McLuhan. McLuhan provided a different rationale for taking an interest in rhetoric; one that extended its influence from the historical and political “New England mind” to the mind in general, linking the study of technologies of communication to individual (and universal) cognitive psychology, without abandoning the progressivist grand narrative of “manifest destiny”, but simply projecting it backward in time and outward to humanity as a whole.

正如马歇尔·麦克卢汉后来的职业生涯所证明的那样，这个更加抽象和雄心勃勃的议程非常适合六十年代（Wolfe 2000）。事实上，由于军事必胜主义在越南被彻底击败，美国主义只有在思想、知识、媒体和文化领域才能占上风。在越南时代，美国主义从爱国主义转向抗议；从“美国方式”到对“美国”的批判21——这通过流行音乐、亚文化和20世纪60年代的“新社会运动”征服了世界。将人类思想重塑为媒体的产物，将中世纪的修辞从神学院中带出来，并将其置于现在所谓的“广告狂人”（来自麦迪逊大道的广告商）的世界中。22正是在这种背景下，媒介能够塑造和改变意识的想法开始流行，就像越南、性、毒品和摇滚乐在校园中点燃了意识应该以各种方式改变的想法一样。尽可能快地利用现有的任何符号学或化学援助。

This even more abstract and ambitious agenda suited the sixties very well, as the subsequent career of Marshall McLuhan demonstrated (Wolfe 2000). Indeed, because military triumphalism was decisively defeated in Vietnam, it was only in the realm of ideas, knowledge, media and culture that Americanism could prevail. In the era of Vietnam, Americanism shifted across from patriotism to protest; from “the American way” to critique of “Amerika”21 – and this conquered the world, through popular music, subcultures, and the “new social movements” of the 1960s. Recasting the human mind as a product of media took medieval rhetoric out of the seminary and put it in the world of what are now known as “ Mad Men ” (advertisers from Madison Avenue).22 It is in this context that the idea of a medium being able to shape and transform consciousness took popular hold, just as Vietnam, sex and drugs and rock’n’roll were setting campuses alight with the idea that consciousness ought to be changed in various ways, as soon as possible and with whatever semiotic or chemical assistance was to hand.

很难将 Walter Ong, SJ 视为现在总结的先知术语“六十年代”（Gitlin 1987）。尽管如此，他在《口语与读写能力》一书中的结束语是“口语与读写能力的动态整体进入了意识的现代进化，朝着更大的内在化和更大的开放性发展”（口语与读写能力：176）。海特-阿什伯里一代（蒂莫西·利里、Playpower和小野洋子以及伊利奇的僵化）可能会认为这同样具有强烈的意义全球媒体扩张的企业家（Wolfe 2000）。哲学、抗议、思想扩张和商业流行文化在这个时候都是一体的，这在一定程度上解释了口头话题被视为“酷”的原因（并不完全像麦克卢汉所说的那样）。翁本人在“心理动力学”一章中指责德里达的逻辑是“迷幻的”，其效果是“由于感觉扭曲”（口语和读写能力：76）。但他真正的影响并不是对德里达；而是对德里达的影响。这是关于当时的年轻人：

It’s hard to see Walter Ong, SJ, as a prophet of what is now summed up in the term “the sixties” (Gitlin 1987). Nonetheless, his closing statement in Orality and Literacy is that “orality-literacy dynamics enter integrally into the modern evolution of consciousness toward both greater interiorization and greater openness ” ( Orality and Literacy : 176). This might be heard as intensely meaningful equally by the Haight- Ashbury generation (Timothy Leary, Playpower and Yoko Ono with a stiffening of Illich) and the entrepreneurs of global media expansion (Wolfe 2000). Philosophy, protest, mind-expansion and commercial popular culture were all of a piece at this time, which partly accounts for the topic of orality being seen as “cool” (not quite as McLuhan might have put it). It was Ong himself who accused Derrida’s logic of being “ psychedelic,” its effects being “due to sensory distortions” ( Orality and Literacy : 76), in a chapter on “psychodynamics.” But his real influence wasn’t on Derrida; it was on the youth of the day :

电子舞台在将人类探索延伸到体外的同时，也催生了探索个体内心世界的欲望。一个例子是人们对迷幻物质的广泛兴趣。许多摄入了这些化学物质的美国人赞同麦克卢汉和翁的理论。他们表示，他们的迷幻情节带来了“时间和空间的同时性感”和“与世界上所有人的团结感”。另一些人聚集在毒品或“嬉皮士”亚文化中，在这种亚文化中，举行部落仪式，穿着鲜艳的印度服装和原始的身体标记，并且经常会产生强烈的社区意识。

At the same time that the electronic stage is extending man’s exploration outside the body, it is creating a desire for exploration of the individual’s inner world. One example is the widespread interest in psychedelic substances. Many Americans, having ingested these chemicals, echo McLuhan’s and Ong’s theories. They state that their psychedelic episodes bring about “a sense of simultaneity in time and space,” and “a sense of solidarity with all the people in the world.” Others gather into drug or “hippie” subcultures, in which tribal rites are enacted, in which bright Indian clothes and primitive body markings are worn, and in which an intense sense of community often develops.

（克里普纳 1970）

(Krippner 1970)

在《口语与读写能力》一书中，翁探讨了当时其他一些很酷的理论——酷理论是这本书出现的新口音系列的存在理由——通过寻求协商自己在形式主义、结构主义、解构主义等，以及语言学和社会科学的某些方法。这些立场、辩论和理论方法构成了当代媒体和传播研究知识渊源的重要组成部分。

In Orality and Literacy Ong deals with some of the other cool theory of the time – cool theory being the raison d’être of the New Accents series in which the book appeared – by seeking to negotiate his own position in relation to formalism, structuralism, deconstruction, etc., as well as certain approaches from linguistics and the social sciences. These positions, debates, and theoretical approaches form a significant part of the intellectual provenance of contemporary media and communication studies.

翁的影响力至少部分可以通过他驾驭当代文学理论和后现代哲学潮流的能力来解释（而不是淹没在“理论”中）。他通过利用自己在知识史上无与伦比的专业知识来实现​​这一目标，同时保持一条似乎直接从这些学术高度进入当代流行媒体喧嚣混战的路线。他的见解为那些调教、兴奋、退学的学生的直接感官体验提供了解释和不在场证据，他们的智力里程碑更有可能来自音乐、电影、媒体和药物，而不是拉丁文学或智力传统。翁自己的著作中没有一丝迷幻的味道，他主持了现代媒体研究中一个改变思想的时刻。读者心目中。它是否总体上解释了人类思维的转变是另一个问题，我将在翁的口语和识字之后的第二章中再次讨论这个问题。

Ong’s reach and impact are at least partly explicable by his ability to navigate contemporary currents of literary theory and postmodern philosophy (without drowning in “Theory”). He managed this by calling on his own unrivalled expertise in the history of knowledge, while maintaining a course that seemed to lead directly from these scholarly heights into the midst of the noisy melee of contemporary popular media. His insights provided both explanation and alibi for the immediate sensory experience of the tuned in, turned on, dropped out student, whose intellectual landmarks were more likely to come from music, movies, media and medications than from Latinate literature or intellectual traditions. Without a whiff of psychedelia in his own writings, Ong presided over a mind-altering moment in modern media studies. Perhaps this is what made his theory seem so cool at the time – it messed enlighteningly with readers’ minds. Whether it explained the transformation of the human mind – in general – is another question, to which I shall return in my second additional chapter below, following Ong’s Orality and Literacy.

笔记

Notes

1引自大英博物馆馆长尼尔·麦格雷戈 (MacGregor 2010: 409)。

1 Quotation from Neil MacGregor, Director of the British Museum (MacGregor 2010: 409).

2 William Shakespeare (1599) Julius Caesar, III.ii.52. Online: shake-speare.mit.edu/julius_caesar/julius_caesar.3.2.html; and see note 12, p. 221, below.

3从 1929 年到 2003 年他去世后：完整参考书目见：academic.slu.edu/ong/Full_Ong_bib_complete_Oct2008.pdf。

3 From 1929 till after his death in 2003: see a full bibliography at: academic.slu.edu/ong/Full_Ong_bib_complete_Oct2008.pdf.

4 Amazon.com 客户评论范围从一星到五星：“只有在别人强迫你这样做的情况下才阅读这本书。即使这对我来说也没有效果……如果你想要一个昂贵的点火器或其他东西来阻止一些烦人的桌子摇摇欲坠，那么就买这个“（一颗星）；“作为一名读者或识字者，我从未考虑过主要口头世界中固有的差异。本书对此进行了解释。多么美妙的看待事物的新方式”（五颗星）：www.amazon.com/Orality-Literacy-New-Accents-Walter/dp/0415027969（2012 年 1 月访问）。

4 Amazon.com customer reviews range from one to five stars: “Read this book only if you are forced to do so by someone. Even that didn’t do it for me... If you want an expensive fire starter or something to stop the teetering of some annoying table then buy this” (one star); “As a reader or literate I never considered the differences inherent in a primarily oral world. This book explains them. What a wonderful new way to see things” (five stars): www.amazon.com/ Orality-Literacy-New-Accents-Walter/dp/0415027969 (accessed Jan 2012).

5 “Ongism”不是我的新词。它可能是由 Dell Hymes (1996: 34) 创造的，他用它来指代技术决定论在传播理论中。另请参见：lulu101.typepad.com/theory_i_f08/2008/09/walter-ongism-w.html，其中支持“文字即事物，版式如活”的主张（加州艺术学院的设计理论）。

5 “Ongism” is not my neologism. It may have been coined by Dell Hymes (1996: 34), who used it to refer to technological determinism in communication theory. See also: lulu101.typepad.com/ theory_i_f08/2008/09/walter-ongism-w.html, where it backs the claim that “Words are things, typography as alive” (Design Theory at CalArts).

6例如，请参见《英国文学简传词典》（Cousins 1910）中的这一经典条目：“培根的智慧是人类有史以来最强大和最具洞察力的智慧之一，他对归纳哲学的发展彻底改变了未来的思想。人类。” 这种从已知（培根的出版物）推断未知（“人类的未来思想”）的习惯是一个老问题，沃尔特·翁（Walter Ong）也未能幸免：见新章节“翁主义之后”。

6 See for instance this classic entry in the Short Biographical Dictionary of English Literature (Cousins 1910): “The intellect of Bacon was one of the most powerful and searching ever possessed by man, and his developments of the inductive philosophy revolutionised the future thought of the human race.” This habit of extrapolating from the known (Bacon’s publications) to the unknown (“the future thought of the human race”) is an old problem, from which Walter Ong was not exempt: see new chapter “After Ongism”.

7我在这里要找的词是“不知不觉”，爱德华·吉本在《罗马帝国的衰亡史》中经常使用这个词来描述在有意识的意志之下缓慢发生的历史变化；例如，他写道“意大利[不同地区]的当地人……不知不觉地合并成一个伟大的国家……”（1910：第 1 卷，第二章，第 41 页）。

7 The word I’m looking for here is “insensibly,” as used frequently by Edward Gibbon throughout The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire to describe historical change that occurs slowly, beneath the threshold of conscious will; for instance where he writes how the “natives of [different parts of] Italy... insensibly coalesced into one great nation...” (1910: Vol 1, Ch II, p. 41).

8 Ong (1958: x) 认为麦克卢汉激发了他对拉穆斯的兴趣；Farrell（Ong 2002：12）声称，Ong 的书促使麦克卢汉写了《古腾堡星系》（The Gutenberg Galaxy，1962）。因此，虽然翁正式是麦克卢汉的硕士生，但他们的相互影响是同龄人的影响。

8 Ong (1958: x) credited McLuhan with inspiring his interest in Ramus; and Farrell (Ong 2002: 12) claims that Ong’s book prompted McLuhan to write The Gutenberg Galaxy (1962). Thus although Ong was formally McLuhan’s MA student, their mutual influence was that of peers.

9 “1942 年，米勒辞去了哈佛大学的职务，加入了美国陆军；战争期间，他驻扎在英国，在战略服务办公室工作。米勒可能在创建战略情报局心理战部门方面发挥了重要作用。当然，他在战争期间为公共预算局工作。（他到底做了什么以及他如何度过时间从未被披露；在战后世界，政府官员可能将其视为国家安全问题。） 1945 年之后，米勒回到哈佛大学任教。（维基百科：“佩里·米勒”。）

9 “In 1942 Miller resigned his post at Harvard to join the U.S. Army; he was stationed in Great Britain for the duration of the war, where he worked for the Office of Strategic Services. Miller may have been instrumental in creating the Psychological Warfare Branch of the O.S.S.; certainly he worked for the PWB for the duration of the war. (Precisely what he did and how he spent his time has never been disclosed; it may have been regarded in the postwar world by government officials as a matter of national security.) After 1945 Miller returned to teaching at Harvard.” (Wikipedia: “Perry Miller”.)

10哈佛大学只有在失去第一名时才具有新闻价值。参见，例如：www.bloomberg.com/news/2011–10–06/harvard-loses-top-worldranking-to-caltech.html。

10 Harvard is only newsworthy when it loses the #1 spot. See, e.g.: www.bloomberg.com/news/2011–10–06/harvard-loses-top-worldranking-to-caltech.html.

11参见：harvardbusiness.org/about。

11 See: harvardbusiness.org/about.

12哈巴奇显然觉得有必要向美国读者强调这一点，他为美国版的《皆大欢喜》添加了前言：“莎士比亚的观众数量庞大且多元化，他们来自不同的国家和地区。”公众，但选择性原则正在发挥作用。除了环球报之外，还有其他剧院，以及环球报本身的其他作家。莎士比亚和他的观众找到了彼此，在某种程度上也创造了彼此。他是一位面向优质读者的优质作家。很难看出我们如何得出任何其他结论。莎士比亚的伟大发现是，品质是垂直延伸到社会层面的，而不是水平延伸到上流社会、经济和学术层面的……在比我们意识到的更大程度上，莎士比亚和他的观众创造了后代的人道氛围。 ，包括我们自己的希望”（Harbage 1947；1961 年美国版前言）。

12 Harbage clearly felt the need to press this point home for American readers, adding a foreword to the US edition of As They Liked It: “Shakespeare’s audience was large and heterogeneous, drawn from the general public, but a selective principle was at work. There were other theatres than the Globe, and other writers for the Globe itself. Shakespeare and his audience found each other, in a measure created each other. He was a quality writer for a quality audience. It is difficult to see how we can reach any other conclusion. The great Shakespearean discovery was that quality extended vertically through the social scale, not horizontally at the upper genteel, economic, and academic levels.... To a greater extent than we are aware, Shakespeare and his audience created the humane climate of subsequent generations, including, one hopes, our own” (Harbage 1947; foreword to the 1961 US edition).

13参见 xroads.virginia.edu/~hyper/whitman/vistas/vistas.html。

13 See xroads.virginia.edu/~hyper/whitman/vistas/vistas.html.

14参见：histsoc.stanford.edu/pdfmem/JonesRF.pdf；以及： www. telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1584760/Richard-D-Altick.html。

14 See: histsoc.stanford.edu/pdfmem/JonesRF.pdf; and: www. telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1584760/Richard-D-Altick.html.

15另见：www.shakespeareinamericanlife.org/identity/politicians/presidents/pick/jqadams.cfm；请注意，总统家族的后裔小约瑟夫·昆西·亚当斯 (Joseph Quincy Adams Jr.) 是华盛顿福尔杰莎士比亚图书馆的创始馆长：www.folger.edu/template.cfm?cid=795。

15 See also: www.shakespeareinamericanlife.org/identity/politicians/ presidents/pick/jqadams.cfm; and note that Joseph Quincy Adams Jr., a scion of the Presidential family, was founding director of the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington: www.folger.edu/template.cfm?cid=795.

16参见：www.julianjaynes.org/about-jaynes.php。

16 See: www.julianjaynes.org/about-jaynes.php.

17 SLU 仍然提供“传播研究+言语传播与修辞学”硕士课程：“该课程专注于对各种形式、媒体和背景下的人类传播进行科学、人文和批判性研究。包括人际、团体、组织、专业和跨文化沟通的理论和实践指导；口语和听力；言语和非言语互动；修辞理论与批评；绩效研究；论证和说服；以技术为媒介的沟通；流行文化; 以及各种情境应用”（www.universities.com/edu/Masters_ Degree_in_Communication_Studies_Speech_Communication_and_Rhetoric_at_Saint_Louis_University_Main_Campus.html）。

17 SLU still offers a master’s program in “Communication Studies + Speech Communication & Rhetoric”: “A program that focuses on the scientific, humanistic, and critical study of human communication in a variety of formats, media, and contexts. Includes instruction in the theory and practice of interpersonal, group, organizational, professional, and intercultural communication; speaking and listening; verbal and nonverbal interaction; rhetorical theory and criticism; performance studies; argumentation and persuasion; technologically mediated communication; popular culture; and various contextual applications” (www.universities.com/edu/ Masters_degree_in_Communication_Studies_Speech_Communica tion_and_Rhetoric_at_Saint_Louis_University_Main_Campus.html).

18最臭名昭著的可能是 1959 年 7 月美国副总统尼克松和苏联总理赫鲁晓夫之间的“厨房辩论”。参见：watergate.info/nixon/1959_nixon-khrushchev-kitchen-debate.shtml。

18 Most notoriously perhaps in the “Kitchen Debate” between US Vice- President Nixon and Soviet Premier Khrushchev, in July 1959. See: watergate.info/nixon/1959_nixon-khrushchev-kitchen-debate.shtml.

19参见：http://xroads.virginia.edu/~hyper/whitman/vistas/vistas.html。

19 See: http://xroads.virginia.edu/~hyper/whitman/vistas/vistas.html.

20麦克卢汉出生于 1911 年，翁出生于 1912 年。

20 McLuhan was born in 1911, Ong in 1912.

21与杰里·鲁宾 (Jerry Rubin)、艾比·霍夫曼 (Abbie Hoffman) 和雅皮士 (青年国际党) 相关的造词：参见例如：www1。american.edu/bgriff/H207web/sixties/rubinchildofAmerika.htm。

22 麦克卢汉的公理“媒介就是信息”被用在《广告狂人》中：请参阅此处的剪辑：www.videohippy.com/video/5901/MAD-MEN–The-medium-is-the-message-106；此处讨论其在该系列中不合时宜的位置：www.nytimes.com/2010/07/25/magazine/25FOB-onlanguage-t.html；这里重演了它的出现和接受——作为“加拿大遗产”的一部分：www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtycdRBAbXk。

22 McLuhan’s axiom “the medium is the message” was used in Mad Men: see here for the clip: www.videohippy.com/video/5901/MAD- MEN–The-medium-is-the-message-106; and here for a discussion of its anachronistic placement in the series: www.nytimes.com/2010/07/25/magazine/25FOB-onlanguage-t.html; and here for a reenactment of its emergence and uptake – as part of “Canadian heritage”: www.youtube.com/watch?v=RtycdRBAbXk.

口语和识字能力

ORALITY AND LITERACY

沃克·J·翁

Walker J. Ong

致谢

ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS

Anthony C. Daly 和 Claude Pavur 非常慷慨地阅读了本书的草稿并提出了评论，作者谨向他们表示感谢。

Anthony C. Daly and Claude Pavur have been very generous in reading and commenting on drafts of this book, and the author wishes to thank them.

作者和出版商衷心感谢大英图书馆允许复制图 1，即托马斯·埃利奥特爵士 (Sir Thomas Elyot) 的《The Boke Named the Gouernour》的扉页。

The author and publisher would like to thank the British Library for permission to reproduce Figure 1, the title page of Sir Thomas Elyot’s The Boke Named the Gouernour .

介绍

INTRODUCTION

近年来，在初级口头文化（完全没有文字知识的文化）和深受文字使用影响的文化中，人们发现了管理知识和言语的方式之间存在某些基本差异。新发现的影响令人震惊。我们在文学、哲学和科学的思想和表达中，甚至在文人之间的口头话语中，认为理所当然的许多特征并不是直接与人类存在本身相关的，而是由于技术所提供的资源而产生的。写作使人类意识可用。我们必须改变对人类身份的理解。

In recent years certain basic differences have been discovered between the ways of managing knowledge and verbalization in primary oral cultures (cultures with no knowledge at all of writing) and in cultures deeply affected by the use of writing. The implications of the new discoveries have been startling. Many of the features we have taken for granted in thought and expression in literature, philosophy and science, and even in oral discourse among literates, are not directly native to human existence as such but have come into being because of the resources which the technology of writing makes available to human consciousness. We have had to revise our understanding of human identity.

本书的主题是口语和读写之间的差异。或者更确切地说，由于本书或任何一本书的读者从本质上来说都熟悉文学文化，因此主题首先是思想及其在口头文化中的口头表达，这对我们来说是陌生的，有时甚至是怪异的，其次是思想及其在口头文化中的口头表达。 ，从口头语言的出现和与口头语言的关系来看，有文字的思想和表达。

The subject of this book is the differences between orality and literacy. Or, rather, since readers of this or any book by deﬁnition are acquainted with literate culture from the inside, the subject is, ﬁrst, thought and its verbal expression in oral culture, which is strange and at times bizarre to us, and, second, literate thought and expression in terms of their emergence from and relation to orality.

本书的主题不是任何解释“流派”。不存在口语和识字的“流派”，也没有什么可以与形式主义、新批评、结构主义或解构主义等价，尽管对口语和识字相互关系的认识可以影响这些流派以及其他各种“流派”的做法。 ”或“运动”贯穿人文和社会科学。了解口语与读写能力的对比和关系确实通常不会产生对理论的热情拥护，而是鼓励人们对人类状况的各个方面进行反思，其数量之多无法完全列举。本书将致力于讨论合理数量的这些方面。彻底的处理需要大量的处理。

The subject of this book is not any ‘school’ of interpretation. There is no ‘school’ of orality and literacy, nothing that would be the equivalent of Formalism or New Criticism or Structuralism or Deconstructionism, although awareness of the interrelationship of orality and literacy can affect what is done in these as well as various other ‘schools’ or ‘movements’ all through the humanities and social sciences. Knowledge of orality-literacy contrasts and relationships does not normally generate impassioned allegiances to theories but rather encourages reﬂection on aspects of the human condition far too numerous ever to be fully enumerated. This book will undertake to treat a reasonable number of those aspects. Exhaustive treatment would demand many volumes.

通过比较在特定时期共存的口头文化和手写（即书写）文化，同步地研究口头和识字是有用的。但绝对有必要通过对连续时期进行比较，从历时性或历史性角度来研究它们。人类社会最初是在口头语言的帮助下形成的，在其历史的很晚的时候才开始识字，而且最初只是在某些群体中。智人已经存在了 30,000 到 50,000 年。最早的文字距今只有 6000 年前。对口头和识字以及从一种到另一种演变的各个阶段的历时研究建立了一个参考框架，在这个框架中，不仅可以更好地理解原始的口头文化和后来的书写文化，而且还可以更好地理解印刷文化。写作达到新的高峰，以及建立在写作和印刷之上的电子文化。在这个历时框架中，过去和现在、荷马和电视可以相互照亮。

It is useful to approach orality and literacy synchronically, by comparing oral cultures and chirographic (i.e., writing) cultures that coexist at a given period of time. But it is absolutely essential to approach them also diachronically or historically, by comparing successive periods with one another. Human society ﬁrst formed itself with the aid of oral speech, becoming literate very late in its history, and at ﬁrst only in certain groups. Homo sapiens has been in existence for between 30,000 and 50,000 years. The earliest script dates from only 6000 years ago. Diachronic study of orality and literacy and of the various stages in the evolution from one to the other sets up a frame of reference in which it is possible to understand better not only pristine oral culture and subsequent writing culture, but also the print culture that brings writing to a new peak and the electronic culture which builds on both writing and print. In this diachronic framework, past and present, Homer and television, can illuminate one another.

但光明的到来并不容易。理解口语和读写能力的关系以及这些关系的含义并不是即时心理史学或即时现象学的问题。它需要广泛的、甚至是广泛的学习、艰苦的思考和仔细的陈述。这些问题不仅深刻而复杂，而且还涉及我们自己的偏见。我们——诸如此类的书籍的读者——有如此多的文化，以至于我们很难想象一个交流或思想的口头世界，除非它是文学世界的一个变体。本书将试图在某种程度上克服我们的偏见，并开辟新的理解方式。

But the illumination does not come easily. Understanding the relations of orality and literacy and the implications of the relations is not a matter of instant psychohistory or instant phenomenology. It calls for wide, even vast, learning, painstaking thought and careful statement. Not only are the issues deep and complex, but they also engage our own biases. We – readers of books such as this – are so literate that it is very difficult for us to conceive of an oral universe of communication or thought except as a variant of a literate universe. This book will attempt to overcome our biases in some degree and to open new ways to understanding.

它侧重于口头和书面之间的关系。识字始于写作，但在后期当然也涉及印刷。因此，本书在某种程度上既注重印刷，又注重写作。它还顺便提到了文字和思想的电子处理，如广播、电视和卫星。我们对口语和读写之间差异的理解只是在电子时代而不是更早的时代发展起来的。电子媒体之间的对比和印刷品使我们对早期的书面和口头之间的对比变得敏感。电子时代也是一个“第二口头语言”的时代，即电话、广播和电视的口头语言，其存在依赖于书写和印刷。

It focuses on the relations between orality and writing. Literacy began with writing but, at a later stage of course, also involves print. This book thus attends somewhat to print as well as to writing. It also makes some passing mention of the electronic processing of the word and of thought, as on radio and television and via satellite. Our understanding of the differences between orality and literacy developed only in the electronic age, not earlier. Contrasts between electronic media and print have sensitized us to the earlier contrast between writing and orality. The electronic age is also an age of ‘secondary orality’, the orality of telephones, radio, and television, which depends on writing and print for its existence.

从口头到读写再到电子处理的转变涉及社会、经济、政治、宗教和其他结构。然而，这些只是本书的间接关注点，本书主要讨论的是口头文化和书面文化之间“心态”的差异。

The shift from orality to literacy and on to electronic processing engages social, economic, political, religious and other structures. These, however, are only indirect concerns of the present book, which treats rather the differences in ‘mentality’ between oral and writing cultures.

迄今为止，几乎所有对比口头文化和手写文化的著作都将口头文化与字母书写进行了对比，而不是与其他书写系统（楔形文字、汉字、日语音节文字、玛雅文字等）进行了对比，并且一直关注的是在文字中使用的字母。西方（字母表在东方也很常见，如印度、东南亚或韩国）。这里的讨论将遵循现有学术的主要路线，尽管在相关点上也会关注字母以外的文字和西方以外的文化。

Almost all the work thus far contrasting oral cultures and chirographic cultures has contrasted orality with alphabetic writing rather than with other writing systems (cuneiform, Chinese characters, the Japanese syllabary, Mayan script and so on) and has been concerned with the alphabet as used in the West (the alphabet is also at home in the East, as in India, Southeast Asia or Korea). Here discussion will follow the major lines of extant scholarship, although some attention will also be given, at relevant points, to scripts other than the alphabet and to cultures other than just those of the West.

世界JO

W. J. O.

圣路易斯大学

Saint Louis University

1

1

语言的口头性

THE ORALITY OF LANGUAGE

有文化的头脑和口述的过去

THE LITERATE MIND AND THE ORAL PAST

在过去的几十年里，学术界重新认识到语言的口头特征以及口头和书面之间的对比的一些更深层次的含义。人类学家、社会学家和心理学家报告了口述社会的田野调查。文化历史学家越来越深入地研究史前史，即在文字使语言记录成为可能之前人类的存在。现代语言学之父费迪南德·德·索绪尔（Ferdinand de Saussure，1857-1913 年）曾提请人们注意口语的首要地位，它是所有口头交流的基础，同时也注意到即使在学者中也存在一种持续的趋势，即认为写作是基本的语言。语言形式。他指出，写作同时具有“有用性、缺点和危险”（1959 年，第 23-4 页）。他仍然认为写作是对口头演讲的一种补充，而不是言语的转化器(1959, pp.23一4）

In the past few decades the scholarly world has newly awakened to the oral character of language and to some of the deeper implications of the contrasts between orality and writing. Anthropologists and sociologists and psychologists have reported on ﬁeldwork in oral societies. Cultural historians have delved more and more into prehistory, that is, human existence before writing made verbalized records possible. Ferdinand de Saussure (1857–1913), the father of modern linguistics, had called attention to the primacy of oral speech, which underpins all verbal communication, as well as to the persistent tendency, even among scholars, to think of writing as the basic form of language. Writing, he noted, has simultaneously ‘usefulness, shortcomings and dangers’ (1959, pp. 23–4). Still he thought of writing as a kind of complement to oral speech, not as a transformer of verbalization (Saussure 1959, pp. 23–4).

自索绪尔以来，语言学对音位学（语言嵌套在声音中的方式）进行了高度复杂的研究。与索绪尔同时代的英国人亨利·斯威特（Henry Sweet，1845-1912）很早就坚持认为单词不是由字母组成，而是由功能性声音单位或音素组成。但是，尽管他们对说话的声音如此关注，直到最近，现代语言学流派也只是偶然地（如果有的话）关注初级口语（未受识字影响的文化的口语）与识字的对比（Sampson 1980）。结构主义者详细分析了口头传统，但大部分没有明确地将其与书面作品进行对比（Maranda and Maranda 1971）。有大量关于书面语言和口语之间差异的文献，其中比较了能够​​读写的人的书面语言和口语（Gumperz、Kaltmann 和 O'Connor 1982 或 1983，参考书目）。这些不是本研究重点关注的差异。这里主要讨论的口语是初级口语，即完全不熟悉书写的人的口语。

Since Saussure, linguistics has developed highly sophisticated studies of phonemics, the way language is nested in sound. Saussure’s contemporary, the Englishman Henry Sweet (1845–1912), had early insisted that words are made up not of letters but of functional sound units or phonemes. But, for all their attention to the sounds of speech, modern schools of linguistics until very recently have attended only incidentally, if at all, to ways in which primary orality, the orality of cultures untouched by literacy, contrasts with literacy (Sampson 1980). Structuralists have analyzed oral tradition in detail, but for the most part without explicitly contrasting it with written compositions (Maranda and Maranda 1971). There is a sizable literature on differences between written and spoken language which compares the written and spoken language of persons who can read and write (Gumperz, Kaltmann and O’Connor 1982 or 1983, bibliography). These are not the differences that the present study is centrally concerned with. The orality centrally treated here is primary orality, that of persons totally unfamiliar with writing.

然而，最近，应用语言学和社会语言学越来越多地比较初级口头言语和书面言语的动态。杰克·古迪（Jack Goody）的著作《野蛮心灵的驯化》（The Domestication of the Savage Mind，1977），以及他自己和其他人的早期作品集《传统社会中的读写能力》（Literacy in Traditional Societies，1968），仍然对伴随着野蛮思想的心理和社会结构的变化提供了宝贵的描述和分析。写作的使用。Chaytor（1945）、Ong（1958b、1967b）、McLuhan（1962）、Haugen（1966）、Chafe（1982）、Tannen（1980a）等人提供了进一步的语言和文化数据和分析。Foley 的专业调查（1980b）包括大量的参考书目。

Recently, however, applied linguistics and sociolinguistics have been comparing more and more the dynamics of primary oral verbalization and those of written verbalization. Jack Goody’s book, The Domestication of the Savage Mind (1977), and his earlier collection of his own and others’ work, Literacy in Traditional Societies (1968), still provide invaluable descriptions and analyses of changes in mental and social structures incident to the use of writing. Chaytor very early (1945), Ong (1958b, 1967b), McLuhan (1962), Haugen (1966), Chafe (1982), Tannen (1980a) and others provide further linguistic and cultural data and analyses. Foley’s expertly focused survey (1980b) includes an extensive bibliography.

对口头思维和表达方式与书面方式之间的对比的最大觉醒不是发生在语言学、描述性或文化学中，而是发生在文学研究中，这显然是从米尔曼·帕里（Milman Parry，1902-35）关于《伊利亚特》文本的著作开始的。帕里英年早逝后，阿尔伯特·B·洛德完成了《奥德赛》 ，并由埃里克·A·哈夫洛克等人后来的作品进行了补充。应用语言学和社会语言学的出版物在理论上或在实践中处理口语读写能力的对比，经常引用这些和相关的著作（Parry 1971；Lord 1960；Havelock 1963；McLuhan 1962；Okpewho 1979；等等）。

The greatest awakening to the contrast between oral modes of thought and expression and written modes took place not in linguistics, descriptive or cultural, but in literary studies, beginning clearly with the work of Milman Parry (1902–35) on the text of the Iliad and the Odyssey, brought to completion after Parry’s untimely death by Albert B. Lord, and supplemented by later work of Eric A. Havelock and others. Publications in applied linguistics and sociolinguistics dealing with orality literacy contrasts, theoretically or in ﬁeldwork, regularly cite these and related works (Parry 1971; Lord 1960; Havelock 1963; McLuhan 1962; Okpewho 1979; etc.).

在详细讨论帕里的发现之前，最好先询问为什么学术界必须重新认识语言的口头特征。语言是一种口头现象，这似乎是不可避免的事实。人类在交往中无数的方式，利用他们所有的感官，触觉，味觉，嗅觉，特别是视觉，以及听觉（Ong 1967b，第1-9页）。一些非口头交流非常丰富——例如手势。然而，从深层意义上讲，语言、清晰的声音是最重要的。不仅是沟通，思想本身也以一种完全特殊的方式与声音相关。我们都听过一句话，一图胜千言。然而，如果这个说法是真的，为什么它一定是一个说法呢？因为只有在特殊条件下，一张图片才值一千个单词——通常包括图片所在的单词上下文。

Before taking up Parry’s discoveries in detail, it will be well to set the stage here by asking why the scholarly world had to reawaken to the oral character of language. It would seem inescapably obvious that language is an oral phenomenon. Human beings communicate in countless ways, making use of all their senses, touch, taste, smell, and especially sight, as well as hearing (Ong 1967b, pp. 1–9). Some non-oral communication is exceedingly rich – gesture, for example. Yet in a deep sense language, articulated sound, is paramount. Not only communication, but thought itself relates in an altogether special way to sound. We have all heard it said that one picture is worth a thousand words. Yet, if this statement is true, why does it have to be a saying? Because a picture is worth a thousand words only under special conditions – which commonly include a context of words in which the picture is set.

无论人类存在于何处，他们都有一种语言，并且在任何情况下，在声音世界中，这种语言基本上都以口头和听到的方式存在（Siertsema 1955）。尽管手势很丰富，但精心设计的手语是言语的替代品，并且依赖于口头言语系统，即使是先天性聋人使用时也是如此（Kroeber 1972；Mallery 1972；Stokoe 1972）。事实上，语言绝大多数是口头的，在人类历史进程中使用的数千种语言（可能是数万种）中，只有大约 106 种语言曾经致力于写作达到足以产生文学的程度，而且大多数从未完全被写了。在当今存在的约 3000 种语言中，只有约 78 种语言有文献（Edmonson 1971，第 323、332 页）。目前还无法计算在文字出现之前有多少种语言已经消失或转变为其他语言。即使现在，数百种正在使用的语言也根本没有被编写过：没有人找到一种有效的方法来编写它们。语言的基本口语是永久的。

Wherever human beings exist they have a language, and in every instance a language that exists basically as spoken and heard, in the world of sound (Siertsema 1955). Despite the richness of gesture, elaborated sign languages are substitutes for speech and dependent on oral speech systems, even when used by the congenitally deaf (Kroeber 1972; Mallery 1972; Stokoe 1972). Indeed, language is so overwhelmingly oral that of all the many thousands of languages – possibly tens of thousands – spoken in the course of human history only around 106 have ever been committed to writing to a degree sufficient to have produced literature, and most have never been written at all. Of the some 3000 languages spoken that exist today only some 78 have a literature (Edmonson 1971, pp. 323, 332). There is as yet no way to calculate how many languages have disappeared or been transmuted into other languages before writing came along. Even now hundreds of languages in active use are never written at all: no one has worked out an effective way to write them. The basic orality of language is permanent.

我们在这里关心的不是所谓的计算机“语言”，它们在某些方面类似于人类语言（英语、梵语、马拉雅拉姆语、汉语普通话、契维语或肖肖尼语等），但永远完全不同于人类语言，因为它们不会发展壮大属于无意识，但直接脱离意识。计算机语言规则（“语法”）首先被陈述，然后被使用。自然人类语言中的语法“规则”首先被使用，并且可以从用法中抽象出来并用文字明确地表述出来，但很困难，而且永远不可能完全。

We are not here concerned with so called computer ‘languages’, which resemble human languages (English, Sanskrit, Malayalam, Mandarin Chinese, Twi or Shoshone etc.) in some ways but are forever totally unlike human languages in that they do not grow out of the unconscious but directly out of consciousness. Computer language rules (‘grammar’) are stated ﬁrst and thereafter used. The ‘rules’ of grammar in natural human languages are used ﬁrst and can be abstracted from usage and stated explicitly in words only with difficulty and never completely.

写作，文字对空间的承诺，扩大了潜力语言的作用几乎无法估量，重构了思想，并在此过程中将某些方言转化为“字语”（Haugen 1966；Hirsh 1977，第 43-8 页）。字语是一种跨方言语言，是通过对写作的深入投入而形成的。书写赋予笔墨的力量远远超过任何纯粹的口头方言。被称为标准英语的图语可以使用至少一百万个半单词的记录词汇，其中不仅现在的含义，而且还有数十万个过去的含义。简单的口头方言通常只有几千个单词的资源，并且其用户几乎不了解这些单词的真实语义历史。

Writing, commitment of the word to space, enlarges the potentiality of language almost beyond measure, restructures thought, and in the process converts a certain few dialects into ‘grapholects’ (Haugen 1966; Hirsh 1977, pp. 43–8). A grapholect is a transdialectal language formed by deep commitment to writing. Writing gives a grapholect a power far exceeding that of any purely oral dialect. The grapholect known as standard English has accessible for use a recorded vocabulary of at least a million and a half words, of which not only the present meanings but also hundreds of thousands of past meanings are known. A simply oral dialect will commonly have resources of only a few thousand words, and its users will have virtually no knowledge of the real semantic history of any of these words.

但是，在写作所打开的所有美妙世界中，口头语言仍然存在并存在。书面文本都必须以某种方式直接或间接地与声音世界（语言的自然栖息地）相关，才能产生其含义。“阅读”文本意味着将其转换为声音，大声或想象，在慢速阅读中逐个音节，在高科技文化中常见的快速阅读中粗略地转换。写作永远离不开口头表达。改编 Jurij Lotman（1977 年，第 21 页，48-61；另请参阅 Champagne 1977-8）用于略有不同目的的术语，我们可以根据先前的主要系统（口语）编写“辅助建模系统”。 。口头表达可以存在，而且大多数情况下根本不需要任何书写就已经存在，而书写从来没有没有口头表达。

But, in all the wonderful worlds that writing opens, the spoken word still resides and lives. Written texts all have to be related somehow, directly or indirectly, to the world of sound, the natural habitat of language, to yield their meanings. ‘Reading’ a text means converting it to sound, aloud or in the imagination, syllable-by-syllable in slow reading or sketchily in the rapid reading common to high technology cultures. Writing can never dispense with orality. Adapting a term used for slightly different purposes by Jurij Lotman (1977, pp. 21, 48–61; see also Champagne 1977–8), we can style writing a ‘secondary modeling system’, dependent on a prior primary system, spoken language. Oral expression can exist and mostly has existed without any writing at all, writing never without orality.

然而，尽管所有言语都有口头根源，但几个世纪以来，直到最近几年，语言和文学的科学和文学研究一直回避口头。文本如此强烈地要求人们关注，以至于口头创作往往被普遍视为书面作品的变体，或者，如果不是这样的话，也被视为受到学术界的认真关注。直到最近，我们才对自己的迟钝变得不耐烦（Finnegan 1977，第 1-7 页）。

Yet, despite the oral roots of all verbalization, the scientiﬁc and literary study of language and literature has for centuries, until quite recent years, shied away from orality. Texts have clamored for attention so peremptorily that oral creations have tended to be regarded generally as variants of written productions or, if not this, as beneath serious scholarly attention. Only relatively recently have we become impatient with our obtuseness here (Finnegan 1977, pp. 1–7).

除了最近几十年外，语言研究都集中在书面文本而不是口头上，原因很简单：研究本身与写作的关系。所有思想，包括原始口头文化中的思想，在某种程度上都是分析性的：它将材料分解成不同的组成部分。但是，如果没有写作和阅读，就不可能对现象或陈述的真理进行抽象的连续的、分类的、解释性的检查。原始口头文化中的人类，他们没有接触任何形式的写作，学到很多东西，拥有并实践伟大的智慧，但他们不“学习”。

Language study in all but recent decades has focused on written texts rather than on orality for a readily assignable reason: the relationship of study itself to writing. All thought, including that in primary oral cultures, is to some degree analytic: it breaks its materials into various components. But abstractly sequential, classiﬁcatory, explanatory examination of phenomena or of stated truths is impossible without writing and reading. Human beings in primary oral cultures, those untouched by writing in any form, learn a great deal and possess and practice great wisdom, but they do not ‘study’.

他们通过学徒学习——例如，与经验丰富的猎人一起打猎——通过门徒训练，这是一种学徒制，通过倾听、通过重复他们所听到的、通过掌握谚语以及组合和重新组合它们的方式、通过吸收其他公式材料、通过参与一种企业回顾——而不是严格意义上的研究。

They learn by apprenticeship – hunting with experienced hunters, for example – by discipleship, which is a kind of apprenticeship, by listening, by repeating what they hear, by mastering proverbs and ways of combining and recombining them, by assimilating other formulary materials, by participation in a kind of corporate retrospection – not by study in the strict sense.

当严格意义上的扩展顺序分析的研究随着写作的内在化而成为可能时，识字者经常研究的第一件事就是语言本身及其用途。言语与我们的意识密不可分，早在文字出现之前，它就让人类着迷，从意识的早期阶段就开始对自身进行认真的反思。来自世界各地的谚语充满了对这种压倒性的人类口头语言现象的观察，关于它的力量、它的美丽和它的危险。在书写开始使用后的几个世纪里，对口头语言的同样的迷恋仍然有增无减。

When study in the strict sense of extended sequential analysis becomes possible with the interiorization of writing, one of the ﬁrst things that literates often study is language itself and its uses. Speech is inseparable from our consciousness and it has fascinated human beings, elicited serious reﬂection about itself, from the very early stages of consciousness, long before writing came into existence. Proverbs from all over the world are rich with observations about this overwhelmingly human phenomenon of speech in its native oral form, about its powers, its beauties, its dangers. The same fascination with oral speech continues unabated for centuries after writing comes into use.

在西方，古希腊人对庞大、精心设计的修辞艺术的阐述表现出了浓厚的兴趣，这是两千多年来西方文化中最全面的学术科目。在其希腊语原文中，techn rh torik，“言语艺术”（通常缩写为rh torik）本质上指的是口头演讲，尽管它是一种反思性的、有组织的“艺术”或科学——例如，在亚里士多德的《修辞艺术》中——修辞学曾经并且必须是写作的产物。托里克_，或修辞学，基本上意味着公开演讲或演讲，几个世纪以来，即使在文学和印刷文化中，它仍然不自觉地几乎成为所有话语的范式，包括写作的范式（Ong 1967b，第 58-63 页；Ong 1971，第 27 页） –8)。因此，写作从一开始就没有减少口语，而是增强了口语，使得将口语的“原则”或组成部分组织成科学的“艺术”成为可能，这是一种按顺序排列的解释体系，显示了口语如何以及为何实现和可以实现以达到其各种特定效果。

In the West among the ancient Greeks the fascination showed in the elaboration of the vast, meticulously worked-out art of rhetoric, the most comprehensive academic subject in all western culture for two thousand years. In its Greek original, techn rhtorik, ‘speech art’ (commonly abridged to just rhtorik ) referred essentially to oral speaking, even though as a reﬂective, organized ‘art’ or science – for example, in Aristotle’s Art of Rhetoric – rhetoric was and had to be a product of writing. Rhtorik, or rhetoric, basically meant public speaking or oratory, which for centuries even in literate and typographic cultures remained unreﬂexively pretty much the paradigm of all discourse, including that of writing (Ong 1967b, pp. 58–63; Ong 1971, pp. 27–8). Thus writing from the beginning did not reduce orality but enhanced it, making it possible to organize the ‘principles’ or constituents of oratory into a scientiﬁc ‘art’, a sequentially ordered body of explanation that showed how and why oratory achieved and could be made to achieve its various speciﬁc effects.

但是，作为修辞学一部分进行研究的演讲——或任何其他口头表演——很难成为演讲，因为这些演讲正在被口头交付。演讲结束后，就没有什么需要讨论的了。你用来“学习”的东西必须是写下来的演讲稿——通常是在演讲之后，而且通常是在演讲很久之后（在古代，除了可耻的无能演讲者之外，从提前准备好的演讲稿中逐字演讲是不常见的做法） – Ong 1967b，第 56-8 页）。这样，即使是口头撰写的演讲也不是作为演讲而是作为书面文本来研究的。

But the speeches – or any other oral performances – that were studied as part of rhetoric could hardly be speeches as these were being orally delivered. After the speech was delivered, nothing of it remained to work over. What you used for ‘study’ had to be the text of speeches that had been written down – commonly after delivery and often long after (in antiquity it was not common practice for any but disgracefully incompetent orators to speak from a text prepared verbatim in advance – Ong 1967b, pp. 56–8). In this way, even orally composed speeches were studied not as speeches but as written texts.

此外，除了演讲等口头表演的转录之外，写作最终产生了严格的书面作品，旨在直接从书面表面吸收。这样的书面作品更加加强了对文本的关注，因为真正的书面作品仅以文本形式出现，尽管其中许多作品通常是被聆听而不是默读，从李维的历史到但丁的喜剧等等（Nelson 1976-7；Bäuml） 1980；戈尔丁 1973；科米尔 1974；埃亨 1982）。

Moreover, besides transcription of oral performances such as orations, writing eventually produced strictly written compositions, designed for assimilation directly from the written surface. Such written compositions enforced attention to texts even more, for truly written compositions came into being as texts only, even though many of them were commonly listened to rather than silently read, from Livy’s histories to Dante’s Comedia and beyond (Nelson 1976–7; Bäuml 1980; Goldin 1973; Cormier 1974; Ahern 1982).

你说的是“口头文学”吗？

DID YOU SAY ‘ORAL LITERATURE’?

学术界对文本的关注产生了意识形态后果。由于他们的注意力集中在文本上，学者们常常不假思索地继续假设，口头语言与他们通常处理的书面语言本质上是相同的，口头艺术形式在所有意图和目的上都只是文本，除了事实上它们没有被写下来。人们越来越认为，除了演讲（受书面修辞规则约束）之外，口头艺术形式本质上是不熟练的，不值得认真研究。

The scholarly focus on texts had ideological consequences. With their attention directed to texts, scholars often went on to assume, often without reﬂection, that oral verbalization was essentially the same as the written verbalization they normally dealt with, and that oral art forms were to all intents and purposes simply texts, except for the fact that they were not written down. The impression grew that, apart from the oration (governed by written rhetorical rules), oral art forms were essentially unskillful and not worth serious study.

然而，并非所有人都遵循这些假设。从十六世纪中叶开始，人们对书写和言语的复杂关系的认识越来越强烈（Cohen 1977）。但文本性在学术思想中的无情统治地位体现在以下事实：迄今为止，尚未形成任何概念来有效地（更不用说优雅地）构思口头艺术本身，而不需要有意识或无意识地参考写作。尽管在书写之前数万年发展起来的口头艺术形式显然与书写毫无关系，但情况也是如此。我们有“文学”这个术语，它本质上意味着“著作”（拉丁文literatura，来自litera，字母表中的字母），涵盖给定的书面文字体。材料——英国文学、儿童文学——但没有相对令人满意的术语或概念来指代纯粹的口头遗产，例如传统的口头故事、谚语、祈祷、公式化表达（Chadwick 1932-40，passim）或其他口头作品，比如北美的拉科塔苏族、西非的曼德族或荷马希腊人。

Not all, however, lived by these assumptions. From the mid sixteenth century on, a sense of the complex relationships of writing and speech grew stronger (Cohen 1977). But the relentless dominance of textuality in the scholarly mind is shown by the fact that to this day no concepts have yet been formed for effectively, let alone gracefully, conceiving of oral art as such without reference, conscious or unconscious, to writing. This is so even though the oral art forms which developed during the tens of thousands of years before writing obviously had no connection with writing at all.
