We have the term ‘literature’, which essentially means ‘writings’ (Latin literatura, from litera, letter of the alphabet), to cover a given body of written materials – English literature, children’s literature – but no comparably satisfactory term or concept to refer to a purely oral heritage, such as the traditional oral stories, proverbs, prayers, formulaic expressions (Chadwick 1932–40, passim ), or other oral productions of, say, the Lakota Sioux in North America or the Mande in West Africa or of the Homeric Greeks.

如上所述，我将一种完全不受任何书写或印刷知识影响的文化的口语风格称为“原始口语”。与当今高科技文化的“次要口头语言”相比，它是“主要的”，在当今高科技文化中，新的口头语言是通过电话、广播、电视和其他电子设备来维持的，而这些设备的存在和功能依赖于书写和印刷。 。今天，严格意义上的初级口头文化几乎不存在，因为每种文化都知道书写并对其影响有一定的经验。尽管如此，许多文化和亚文化在不同程度上保留了原始口头语言的大部分思维模式，即使在高科技环境下也是如此。

As noted above, I style the orality of a culture totally untouched by any knowledge of writing or print, ‘primary orality’. It is ‘primary’ by contrast with the ‘secondary orality’ of present-day high technology culture, in which a new orality is sustained by telephone, radio, television, and other electronic devices that depend for their existence and functioning on writing and print. Today primary oral culture in the strict sense hardly exists, since every culture knows of writing and has some experience of its effects. Still, to varying degrees many cultures and subcultures, even in a high technology ambiance, preserve much of the mind-set of primary orality.

纯粹的口头传统或初级口头说法并不容易被准确地、有意义地理解。书写使“单词”看起来与事物相似，因为我们将单词视为向解码器发出单词信号的可见标记：我们可以在文本和书籍中看到并触摸到这些铭刻的“单词”。写下来的文字都是残渣。口头传统没有这样的残留物或沉积物。当一个经常被讲述的口头故事实际上没有被讲述时，它所存在的只是某些人讲述它的潜力。我们（那些阅读此类文本的人）在大多数情况下都非常坚决地识字，以至于我们很少对口头传统中的语言表达如此微不足道的情况感到舒服。结果——虽然现在出现的频率略有下降——过去的学术界产生了诸如“口头文学”这样的可怕概念。这个完全荒谬的术语今天仍然在流传，甚至在现在越来越敏锐地意识到它揭示了我们如何令人尴尬地揭示了我们无法将口头组织材料的遗产呈现在我们自己的头脑中，除非作为某种书写变体，即使它们与文字无关。根本不写作。哈佛大学伟大的米尔曼·帕里口述文学收藏的标题体现了上一代学者的意识状态，而不是其近代策展人的意识状态。

The purely oral tradition or primary orality is not easy to conceive of accurately and meaningfully. Writing makes ‘words’ appear similar to things because we think of words as the visible marks signaling words to decoders: we can see and touch such inscribed ‘words’ in texts and books. Written words are residue. Oral tradition has no such residue or deposit. When an often-told oral story is not actually being told, all that exists of it is the potential in certain human beings to tell it. We (those who read texts such as this) are for the most part so resolutely literate that we seldom feel comfortable with a situation in which verbalization is so little thing-like as it is in oral tradition. As a result – though at a slightly reduced frequency now – scholarship in the past has generated such monstrous concepts as ‘oral literature’. This strictly preposterous term remains in circulation today even among scholars now more and more acutely aware how embarrassingly it reveals our inability to represent to our own minds a heritage of verbally organized materials except as some variant of writing, even when they have nothing to do with writing at all. The title of the great Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature at Harvard University monumentalizes the state of awareness of an earlier generation of scholars rather than that of its recent curators.

有人可能会争辩说（正如 Finnegan 1977，第 16 页）该术语“文学”虽然主要是为书面作品而设计的，但它已经简单地扩展到包括相关现象，例如未受书面影响的文化中的传统口头叙述。许多原本特定的术语都以这种方式被概括化了。但概念有办法永远保留其词源。最初构建一个术语的元素通常，而且可能总是，以某种方式在随后的含义中徘徊，也许是模糊的，但往往是强大的，甚至是不可简化的。此外，正如稍后将详细介绍的那样，写作是一种特别先发制人的帝国主义活动，即使没有词源学的帮助，它也倾向于将其他事物同化为自身。

One might argue (as does Finnegan 1977, p. 16) that the term ‘literature’, though devised primarily for works in writing, has simply been extended to include related phenomena such as traditional oral narrative in cultures untouched by writing. Many originally speciﬁc terms have been so generalized in this way. But concepts have a way of carrying their etymologies with them forever. The elements out of which a term is originally built usually, and probably always, linger somehow in subsequent meanings, perhaps obscurely but often powerfully and even irreducibly. Writing, moreover, as will be seen later in detail, is a particularly pre-emptive and imperialist activity that tends to assimilate other things to itself even without the aid of etymologies.

尽管文字以口头语言为基础，但写作却专横地将它们永远锁定在视觉领域。一个有文化的人，如果被要求思考“尽管如此”这个词，通常（我强烈怀疑总是）会对拼写出来的单词有一些印象，至少是模糊的，并且完全无法想到“尽管如此”这个词比如说，60 秒，不涉及任何文字，只涉及声音。这就是说，一个有文化的人无法完全恢复对纯粹口头语言的人来说这个词的意义。鉴于这种读写能力的先发制人，似乎不可能使用“文学”一词来涵盖口头传统和表演，而不以某种方式微妙但不可挽回地将它们还原为书面形式的变体。

Though words are grounded in oral speech, writing tyrannically locks them into a visual ﬁeld forever. A literate person, asked to think of the word ‘nevertheless’, will normally (and I strongly suspect always) have some image, at least vague, of the spelled-out word and be quite unable ever to think of the word ‘nevertheless’ for, let us say, 60 seconds without adverting to any lettering but only to the sound. This is to say, a literate person cannot fully recover a sense of what the word is to purely oral people. In view of this preemptiveness of literacy, it appears quite impossible to use the term ‘literature’ to include oral tradition and performance without subtly but irremediably reducing these somehow to variants of writing.

将口头传统或口头表演、流派和风格的遗产视为“口头文学”，就像将马视为没有轮子的汽车一样。当然，您可以承诺这样做。想象一下，写一篇关于马的论文（针对从未见过马的人），它不是从马的概念开始，而是从“汽车”的概念开始，建立在读者对汽车的直接体验之上。它继续讨论马，总是将它们称为“无轮汽车”，向从未见过马的高度汽车动员的读者解释所有的差异点，以努力将“汽车”的所有想法从概念中剔除。无轮汽车”，使该术语具有纯粹的马术含义。代替轮子，无轮汽车有扩大的脚趾甲，称为蹄；眼睛取代了车头灯或后视镜；不是一层漆，而是一种叫做头发的东西；代替汽油作为燃料、干草等。最终，马只是它们所不是的。无论多么准确和通过这种冷漠的描述，那些从未见过马、只听说过“无轮汽车”的汽车读者肯定会对马产生一个奇怪的概念。对于那些从事“口头文学”即“口头写作”的人来说也是如此。你不可能通过从随后的次要现象开始并消除差异来描述主要现象，而不会造成严重的和令人无法理解的扭曲。事实上，以这种方式倒退——先车后马——你永远无法意识到真正的差异。

Thinking of oral tradition or a heritage of oral performance, genres and styles as ‘oral literature’ is rather like thinking of horses as automobiles without wheels. You can, of course, undertake to do this. Imagine writing a treatise on horses (for people who have never seen a horse) which starts with the concept not of horse but of ‘automobile’, built on the readers’ direct experience of automobiles. It proceeds to discourse on horses by always referring to them as ‘wheelless automobiles’, explaining to highly auto mobilized readers who have never seen a horse all the points of difference in an effort to excise all idea of ‘automobile’ out of the concept ‘wheelless automobile’ so as to invest the term with a purely equine meaning. Instead of wheels, the wheelless automobiles have enlarged toenails called hooves; instead of headlights or perhaps rear-vision mirrors, eyes; instead of a coat of lacquer, something called hair; instead of gasoline for fuel, hay, and so on. In the end, horses are only what they are not. No matter how accurate and thorough such apophatic description, automobile-driving readers who have never seen a horse and who hear only of ‘wheelless automobiles’ would be sure to come away with a strange concept of a horse. The same is true of those who deal in terms of ‘oral literature’, that is, ‘oral writing’. You cannot without serious and disabling distortion describe a primary phenomenon by starting with a subsequent secondary phenomenon and paring away the differences. Indeed, starting backwards in this way – putting the car before the horse – you can never become aware of the real differences at all.

虽然“前文字”这个术语本身是有用的，有时也是必要的，但如果不加反思地使用它，它也会带来与“口头文学”这个术语所提出的问题相同的问题，尽管不是那么武断。“前文字”将口语——“初级建模系统”——呈现为与随后的“次级建模系统”不合时宜的偏差。

Although the term ‘preliterate’ itself is useful and at times necessary, if used unreﬂectively it also presents problems which are the same as those presented by the term ‘oral literature’, if not quite so assertive. ‘Preliterate’ presents orality – the ‘primary modeling system’ – as an anachronistic deviant from the ‘secondary modeling system’ that followed it.

与“口头文学”和“前文字”这两个术语相一致，我们还听到了口头话语的“文本”的提及。“文本”的词根意思是“编织”，从绝对意义上来说，它在词源学上比“文学”更符合口头表达，“文学”是指字母表中的词源/（文学）字母。即使在口头环境中，口头话语也通常被认为是编织或缝合——狂想曲“rhapsodize”在希腊语中的基本意思是“将歌曲拼接在一起”。但事实上，当今天的文人使用“文本”一词来指代口头表演时，他们是通过与写作进行类比来思考它的。在识字者的词汇中，来自原始口头文化的人的叙述的“文本”代表了一种反向形态：马再次被视为没有轮子的汽车。

In concert with the terms ‘oral literature’ and ‘preliterate’, we hear mention also of the ‘text’ of an oral utterance. ‘Text’, from a root meaning ‘to weave’, is, in absolute terms, more compatible etymologically with oral utterance than is ‘literature’, which refers to letters etymologically/( literae ) of the alphabet. Oral discourse has commonly been thought of even in oral milieus as weaving or stitching – rhapso¯idein, to ‘rhapsodize’, basically means in Greek ‘to stitch songs together’. But in fact, when literates today use the term ‘text’ to refer to oral performance, they are thinking of it by analogy with writing. In the literate’s vocabulary, the ‘text’ of a narrative by a person from a primary oral culture represents a back-formation: the horse as an automobile without wheels again.

鉴于言语和写作之间的巨大差异，我们可以做些什么来为“口头文学”这个不合时宜且自相矛盾的术语设计一个替代词？改编自诺斯罗普·弗莱（Northrop Frye）在《批评的解剖》（1957，第 248-50、293-303 页）中提出的关于史诗的建议，我们可以将所有纯粹的口头艺术称为“epos”，它具有相同的原始印欧语根源, wekw -，作为拉丁词vox及其英语对应词“声音”，因此牢固地扎根于声乐、口头。因此，口头表演会被视为“声音”，这就是它们的本质。但 epos（口头）史诗这一术语的更常见含义（参见 Bynum 1967）会在一定程度上干扰指所有口头创作的指定通用含义。“声音”似乎有太多相互竞争的联想，但如果有人认为这个词足够活跃，可以推出，我肯定会尽力帮助它保持下去。但我们仍然没有一个更通用的术语来包括纯粹的口头艺术和文学。在这里，我将继续一种知情人士常见的做法，并在必要时诉诸不言自明的迂回说法——“纯口头艺术形式”、“口头艺术形式”（包括口头形式和书面形式，以及一切以书面形式构成的形式）。之间）等。

Given the vast difference between speech and writing, what can be done to devise an alternative for the anachronistic and self contradictory term ‘oral literature’? Adapting a proposal made by Northrop Frye for epic poetry in The Anatomy of Criticism (1957, pp. 248–50, 293–303), we might refer to all purely oral art as ‘epos’, which has the same Proto-IndoEuropean root, wekw -, as the Latin word vox and its English equivalent ‘voice’, and thus is grounded ﬁrmly in the vocal, the oral. Oral performances would thus be felt as ‘voicings’, which is what they are. But the more usual meaning of the term epos, (oral) epic poetry (see Bynum 1967), would somewhat interfere with an assigned generic meaning referring to all oral creations. ‘Voicings’ seems to have too many competing associations, though if anyone thinks the term buoyant enough to launch, I will certainly aid efforts to keep it aﬂoat. But we would still be without a more generic term to include both purely oral art and literature. Here I shall continue a practice common among informed persons and resort, as necessary, to self-explanatory circumlocutions – ‘purely oral art forms’, ‘verbal art forms’ (which would include both oral forms and those composed in writing, and everything in between), and the like.

幸运的是，目前“口头文学”一词正在节节败退，但任何彻底消除它的斗争很可能永远不会完全获胜。对于大多数识字者来说，将单词视为与书写完全无关的任务实在是太艰巨了，即使专门的语言学或人类学工作可能需要这样做。无论你做什么，这些话都会以书面形式出现在你的脑海中。此外，将文字与书写分离在心理上是有威胁的，因为识字者对语言的控制感与语言的视觉转换密切相关：没有词典、书面语法规则、标点符号以及所有其他将文字变成某种东西的工具。你可以向上“查找”，文人如何生活？文字语言（例如标准英语）的识字用户所使用的词汇量比任何口头语言所能容纳的词汇量大数百倍。在这样的语言世界中，词典是必不可少的。提醒自己头脑中没有字典，词典编纂装置是语言作为语言的一个很晚的产物，所有语言都有复杂的语法，并且在完全没有书面帮助的情况下发展了它们的阐述，这是令人沮丧的。在相对高科技的文化中，大多数语言的使用者总是相处得很好，没有任何声音的视觉转换。

At present the term ‘oral literature’ is, fortunately, losing ground, but it may well be that any battle to eliminate it totally will never be completely won. For most literates, to think of words as totally dissociated from writing is simply too arduous a task to undertake, even when specialized linguistic or anthropological work may demand it. The words keep coming to you in writing, no matter what you do. Moreover, to dissociate words from writing is psychologically threatening, for literates’ sense of control over language is closely tied to the visual transformations of language: without dictionaries, written grammar rules, punctuation, and all the rest of the apparatus that makes words into something you can ‘look’ up, how can literates live? Literate users of a grapholect such as standard English have access to vocabularies hundreds of times larger than any oral language can manage. In such a linguistic world dictionaries are essential. It is demoralizing to remind oneself that there is no dictionary in the mind, that lexicographical apparatus is a very late accretion to language as language, that all languages have elaborate grammars and have developed their elaborations with no help from writing at all, and that outside of relatively high technology cultures most users of languages have always got along pretty well without any visual transformations whatsoever of vocal sound.

口头文化确实产生了强大而美丽的口头表演，具有很高的艺术和人类价值，一旦书写占据了心灵，这些表演就不再可能了。然而，如果没有书写，人类意识就无法发挥其更充分的潜力，也无法创造出其他美丽而强大的创造物。从这个意义上说，口头需要产生并且注定会产生写作。正如我们将看到的，识字对于发展是绝对必要的。不仅是科学，而且是历史、哲学、文学和任何艺术的解释性理解，甚至是对语言（包括口头言语）本身的解释。当今世界上几乎没有一种口头文化或占主导地位的口头文化不以某种方式意识到如果没有识字就永远无法获得的巨大复杂的权力。对于植根于初级口语的人来说，这种意识是一种痛苦，他们热切地想要识字，但也非常清楚，进入令人兴奋的识字世界意味着要抛弃早期口语世界中许多令人兴奋和深受喜爱的东西。我们必须死才能继续生活。

Oral cultures indeed produce powerful and beautiful verbal performances of high artistic and human worth, which are no longer even possible once writing has taken possession of the psyche. Nevertheless, without writing, human consciousness cannot achieve its fuller potentials, cannot produce other beautiful and powerful creations. In this sense, orality needs to produce and is destined to produce writing. Literacy, as will be seen, is absolutely necessary for the development not only of science but also of history, philosophy, explicative understanding of literature and of any art, and indeed for the explanation of language (including oral speech) itself. There is hardly an oral culture or a predominantly oral culture left in the world today that is not somehow aware of the vast complex of powers forever inaccessible without literacy. This awareness is agony for persons rooted in primary orality, who want literacy passionately but who also know very well that moving into the exciting world of literacy means leaving behind much that is exciting and deeply loved in the earlier oral world. We have to die to continue living.

幸运的是，识字虽然消耗了自己的口头前因，除非仔细监控，甚至会破坏他们的记忆，但它也是无限适应性的。它也可以恢复他们的记忆。识字可以用来为我们自己重建根本不识字的原始人类意识——至少可以很好地重建这种意识，尽管不是完美的（我们永远无法忘记我们熟悉的现在，无法在我们的脑海中重建任何过去的历史）完整的完整性）。这种重建可以更好地理解识字本身在塑造人类对高科技文化的意识方面的意义。本书在某种程度上试图实现对口语和读写能力的这种理解，这本书必然是一本读写作品，而不是口头表演。

Fortunately, literacy, though it consumes its own oral antecedents and, unless it is carefully monitored, even destroys their memory, is also inﬁnitely adaptable. It can restore their memory, too. Literacy can be used to reconstruct for ourselves the pristine human consciousness which was not literate at all – at least to reconstruct this consciousness pretty well, though not perfectly (we can never forget enough of our familiar present to reconstitute in our minds any past in its full integrity). Such reconstruction can bring a better understanding of what literacy itself has meant in shaping man’s consciousness toward and in high technology cultures. Such understanding of both orality and literacy is what this book, which is of necessity a literate work and not an oral performance, attempts in some degree to achieve.

2

2

原始口头文化的现代发现

THE MODERN DISCOVERY OF PRIMARY ORAL CULTURES

对口头传统的早期认识

EARLY AWARENESS OF ORAL TRADITION

近年来对口头言语的新觉醒并非没有先例。基督诞生前几个世纪，《旧约》一书的作者以希伯来语名字Qoheleth（“集会发言人”）或希腊语对应词《传道书》的笔名作者，明确地提及了他的写作所依据的口头传统：除了智慧之外，科赫勒斯还向人们传授知识，并权衡、审视和整理了许多谚语。科赫勒特试图找到令人愉悦的话语，并准确地写下真实的话语”（传道书 12：9-10）。

The new awakening in recent years to the orality of speech was not without antecedents. Several centuries before Christ, the pseudonymous author of the Old Testament book that goes by his Hebrew nom de plume, Qoheleth (‘assembly speaker’), or its Greek equivalent, Ecclesiastes, clearly adverts to the oral tradition on which his writing draws: ‘Besides being wise, Qoheleth taught the people knowledge, and weighed, scrutinized, and arranged many proverbs. Qoheleth sought to ﬁnd pleasing sayings, and to write down true sayings with precision’ (Ecclesiastes 12:9–10).

“写下……谚语。” 有文化的人，从中世纪的弗洛里吉亚收藏家到伊拉斯谟（1466-1536）或维西莫斯·诺克斯（1752-1821）等，一直在继续将口头传统中的谚语放入文本中，尽管至少从中世纪和伊拉斯谟的历史来看，这一点很重要。至少在西方文化中，大多数收藏家不是直接从口语中而是从其他著作中挑选“谚语”。浪漫主义运动的特点是关注遥远的过去和民间文化。从那时起，数百名收藏家，从苏格兰的詹姆斯·麦克弗森（James McPherson，1736-96 年）、托马斯·珀西（Thomas Percy）开始英国的格林兄弟雅各布（1729-1811）、德国的格林兄弟雅各布（1785-1863）和威廉（1786-1859），或者美国的弗朗西斯·詹姆斯·柴尔德（1825-96），都曾研究过部分口头或准语言的作品。口头或近口头传统或多或少直接，赋予其新的尊重。到了 20 世纪初，苏格兰学者安德鲁·朗（Andrew Lang，1844-1912）和其他人已经彻底否定了这样一种观点，即口头民间传说只是“高级”文学神话的残余碎片——这种观点很自然地产生于前一章讨论的手写和印刷偏差。

‘Write down... sayings.’ Literate persons, from medieval ﬂorilegia collectors to Erasmus (1466–1536) or Vicesimus Knox (1752–1821) and beyond, have continued to put into texts sayings from oral tradition, though it is signiﬁcant that at least from the Middle Ages and Erasmus’ age, in western culture at least, most collectors culled the ‘sayings’ not directly from spoken utterance but from other writings. The Romantic Movement was marked by concern with the distant past and with folk culture. Since then, hundreds of collectors, beginning with James McPherson (1736–96) in Scotland, Thomas Percy (1729–1811) in England, the Grimm brothers Jacob (1785–1863) and Wilhelm (1786–1859) in Germany, or Francis James Child (1825–96) in the United States, have worked over parts of oral or quasi-oral or near-oral tradition more or less directly, giving it new respectability. By the start of the twentieth century, the Scottish scholar Andrew Lang (1844–1912) and others had pretty well discredited the view that oral folklore was simply the left-over debris of a ‘higher’ literary mythology – a view generated quite naturally by the chirographic and typographic bias discussed in the preceding chapter.

早期的语言学家抵制口语和书面语言独特性的观点。尽管索绪尔对口语有了新的见解，或许正因为如此，索绪尔认为写作只是以可见形式代表口语（1959年，第23-4页），爱德华·萨皮尔、C.霍克特和伦纳德·布卢姆菲尔德也是如此。布拉格语言学界，特别是 J. Vachek 和 Ernst Pulgram，注意到书面语言和口头语言之间的一些区别，尽管他们在关注语言共性而不是发展因素时很少利用这种区别（Goody 1977，第 77 页）。

Earlier linguists had resisted the idea of the distinctiveness of spoken and written languages. Despite his new insights into orality, or perhaps because of them, Saussure takes the view that writing simply represents spoken language in visible form (1959, pp. 23–4) as do Edward Sapir, C. Hockett and Leonard Bloomﬁeld. The Prague Linguistic Circle, especially J. Vachek and Ernst Pulgram, noted some distinction between written and spoken language, although in concentrating on linguistic universals rather than developmental factors they made little use of this distinction (Goody 1977, p. 77).

荷马问题

THE HOMERIC QUESTION

鉴于长期以来文人对口头传统的认识，以及朗和其他人的论证，即纯粹的口头文化可以产生复杂的口头艺术形式，那么我们对口头的新理解有什么新内容呢？

Given a long-standing awareness of oral tradition among literates and given Lang’s and others’ demonstration that purely oral cultures could generate sophisticated verbal art forms, what is new in our new understanding of orality?

新的理解是通过各种途径发展起来的，但也许最好的是在“荷马问题”的历史中遵循它。两千年来，有识之士致力于研究荷马，有意识和无意识地混合着不同的见解、错误信息和偏见。在更丰富的背景下，口头语言和文字之间的对比以及不加反思的手写或印刷思维的盲点在任何地方都没有表现出来。

The new understanding developed over various routes, but it can perhaps best be followed in the history of the ‘Homeric question’. For over two millennia literates have devoted themselves to the study of Homer, with varying mixtures of insight, misinformation and prejudice, conscious and unconscious. Nowhere do the contrasts between orality and literacy or the blind spots of the unreﬂective chirographic or typographic mind show in a richer context.

“荷马问题”本身源于十九世纪对荷马的高级批评，它与对圣经的高级批评一起成熟，但它的根源可以追溯到古典时期。（参见 Adam Parry 1971，在接下来的几页中大量引用。）西方古典时期的文人墨客偶尔会意识到《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》与其他希腊诗歌不同，而且它们的起源是模糊的。西塞罗认为两首荷马诗的现存文本是皮西斯特拉图对荷马作品的修订（然而西塞罗认为荷马作品本身就是文本），约瑟夫斯甚至暗示荷马不会写作，但他这样做是为了认为希伯来文化优于非常古的希腊文化，因为它懂得书写，而不是解释荷马作品中的风格或其他特征。

The ‘Homeric question’ as such grew out of the nineteenth-century higher criticism of Homer which had matured together with the higher criticism of the Bible, but it had roots reaching back to classical antiquity. (See Adam Parry 1971, drawn on heavily here in the next few pages.) Men of letters in western classical antiquity had occasionally shown some awareness that the Iliad and the Odyssey differed from other Greek poetry and that their origins were obscure. Cicero suggested that the extant text of the two Homeric poems was a revision by Pisistratus of Homer’s work (which Cicero thought of, however, as itself a text), and Josephus even suggested that Homer could not write, but he did so in order to argue that Hebrew culture was superior to very ancient Greek culture because it knew writing, rather than to account for anything about the style or other features in the Homeric works.

从一开始，深深的压抑就干扰了我们看清荷马史诗的本来面目。《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》从古至今都被普遍认为是西方遗产中最典范、最真实和最有启发性的世俗诗歌。为了解释他们所获得的卓越性，每个时代都倾向于将他们解释为更好地完成了它所设想的诗人正在做的事情或目标。即使浪漫主义运动将“原始”重新解释为文化的一个美好阶段，而不是一个令人遗憾的阶段，学者和读者通常仍然倾向于将原始诗歌的品质归咎于他们自己的时代发现的基本一致的品质。美国古典主义者米尔曼·帕里（Milman Parry，1902-35）比任何早期的学者都更成功地削弱了这种文化沙文主义，从而以诗歌本身的方式进入“原始”荷马诗歌，即使这些诗歌与人们所接受的观点背道而驰。诗歌和诗人就应该如此。

From the beginning, deep inhibitions have interfered with our seeing the Homeric poems for what they in fact are. The Iliad and the Odyssey have been commonly regarded from antiquity to the present as the most exemplary, the truest and the most inspired secular poems in the western heritage. To account for their received excellence, each age has been inclined to interpret them as doing better what it conceived its poets to be doing or aiming at. Even when the Romantic Movement had reinterpreted the ‘primitive’ as a good rather than a regrettable stage of culture, scholars and readers generally still tended to impute to primitive poetry qualities that their own age found fundamentally congenial. More than any earlier scholar, the American classicist Milman Parry (1902–35) succeeded in undercutting this cultural chauvinism so as to get into the ‘primitive’ Homeric poetry on this poetry’s own terms, even when these ran counter to the received view of what poetry and poets ought to be.

早期的作品已经隐约预示了帕里的作品，因为对荷马诗歌的普遍奉承常常伴随着一些不安。人们常常觉得这些诗有些不合时宜。十七世纪的弗朗索瓦·赫德林 (François Hédelin, Abbé d'Aubignac et de Meimac)（1604-76）本着一种更多是修辞辩论而非真正学问的精神，攻击《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》，认为情节糟糕，人物塑造贫乏，而且在伦理和神学上也缺乏说服力。卑鄙，并继续辩称从来没有荷马，归于他的史诗只不过是其他人的狂想曲集。古典学者理查德·本特利（Richard Bentley，1662-1742），因证明所谓的法拉里斯书信而闻名是虚假的，因为间接引发了斯威夫特的反印刷讽刺作品《书籍之战》，认为确实有一个名叫荷马的人，但他所写的各种歌曲直到大约 500 年后，皮西斯特拉图时代，“写”才被整理成史诗。意大利历史哲学家詹巴蒂斯塔·维柯（Giambattista Vico，1668-1744）认为，荷马并不存在，但荷马史诗在某种程度上是全体人民的创造。

Earlier work had vaguely adumbrated Parry’s in that the general adulation of the Homeric poems had often been accompanied by some uneasiness. Often the poems were felt to be somehow out of line. In the seventeenth century François Hédelin, Abbé d’Aubignac et de Meimac (1604–76), in a spirit more of rhetorical polemic than of true learning, attacked the Iliad and the Odyssey as badly plotted, poor in characterization, and ethically and theologically despicable, going on to argue that there never had been a Homer and that the epics attributed to him were no more than collections of rhapsodies by others. The classical scholar Richard Bentley (1662–1742), famous for proving that the so called Epistles of Phalaris were spurious and for indirectly occasioning Swift’s anti typographic satire, The Battle of the Books, thought that there was indeed a man named Homer but that the various songs that he ‘wrote’ were not put together into the epic poems until about 500 years later in the time of Pisistratus. The Italian philosopher of history, Giambattista Vico (1668–1744),believed that there had been no Homer but that the Homeric epics were somehow the creations of a whole people.

罗伯特·伍德（Robert Wood，约1717-71 年），一位英国外交官和考古学家，他仔细辨认了《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》中提到的一些地点，显然是第一个猜想接近帕里最终证明的猜想的人。伍德相信荷马不识字，正是记忆的力量使他能够创作出这首诗。伍德引人注目地表明，记忆在口头文化中所扮演的角色与在文字文化中所扮演的角色截然不同。尽管伍德无法解释荷马的助记符是如何运作的，但他确实表明荷马诗歌的精神是流行的，而不是学习的。让·雅克·卢梭（Jean Jacques Rousseau，1821 年，第 163-4 页）引用哈杜安神父（亚当·帕里均未提及）的话，认为荷马和他同时代的希腊人很可能没有文字。然而，卢梭确实认为平板电脑上的信息存在问题，在《伊利亚特》第六卷中，贝勒列丰被带到利西亚国王那里。但没有证据表明平板电脑上要求处决贝尔勒丰的“标志”是真实的文字（见下文，第 83-5 页）。事实上，在荷马史诗中，它们听起来像是某种粗糙的表意文字。

Robert Wood ( c. 1717–71), an English diplomat and archaeologist, who carefully identiﬁed some of the places referred to in the Iliad and the Odyssey, was apparently the ﬁrst whose conjectures came close to what Parry ﬁnally demonstrated. Wood believed that Homer was not literate and that it was the power of memory that enabled him to produce this poetry. Wood strikingly suggests that memory played a quite different role in oral culture from that which it played in literate culture. Although Wood could not explain just how Homer’s mnemonics worked, he does suggest that the ethos of Homeric verse was popular rather than learned. Jean Jacques Rousseau (1821, pp. 163–4), citing Père Hardouin (neither mentioned by Adam Parry) thought it most likely that Homer and his contemporaries among the Greeks had no writing. Rousseau does, however, see as a problem the message on a tablet which, in Book VI of the Iliad, Belerephon carried to the King of Lycia. But there is no evidence that the ‘signs’ on the tablet calling for Belerephon’s own execution were in a true script (see below, pp. 83–5). In fact, in the Homeric account they sound like some sort of crude ideographs.

十九世纪见证了所谓分析家的荷马理论的发展，该理论由弗里德里希·奥古斯特·沃尔夫（Friedrich August Wolf，1759-1824 年）在他 1795 年的序言中发起。分析家将《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》的文本视为早期诗歌或片段的组合，并开始通过分析来确定这些片段是什么以及它们是如何分层在一起的。但是，正如亚当·帕里 (Adam Parry) 指出的那样（1971 年，第 xiv-xvii 页），分析师们认为组合在一起的这些内容只是文本，他们的头脑中没有想到其他选择。不可避免的是，分析家们在二十世纪初被一神论者所取代，他们通常是文学虔诚主义者、抓住救命稻草的没有安全感的邪教分子，他们坚持认为《伊利亚特》和《《奥德赛》的结构如此精良，人物塑造如此一致，总体艺术水平如此之高，以至于它们不可能是一群无组织的编辑者的作品，而必须是一个人的创作。这或多或少是当帕里还是一名学生并开始形成自己的观点时，他就成为主流观点。

The nineteenth century saw the development of the Homeric theories of the so called Analysts, initiated by Friedrich August Wolf (1759–1824), in his 1795 Prolegomena. The Analysts saw the texts of the Iliad and the Odyssey as combinations of earlier poems or fragments, and set out to determine by analysis what the bits were and how they had been layered together. But, as Adam Parry notes (1971, pp. xiv–xvii), the Analysts assumed that the bits being put together were simply texts, no alternative having suggested itself to their minds. Inevitably, the Analysts were succeeded in the early twentieth century by the Unitarians, often literary pietists, insecure cultists grasping at straws, who maintained that the Iliad and the Odyssey were so well structured, so consistent in characterization, and in general such high art that they could not be the work of an unorganized succession of redactors but must be the creation of one man. This was more or less the predominant opinion when Parry was a student and beginning to form his own opinions.

米尔曼·帕里的发现

MILMAN PARRY’S DISCOVERY

与许多开创性的智力著作一样，米尔曼·帕里的见解既深刻又确定，但难以明确表达。帕里的儿子，已故的亚当·帕里（Adam Parry，1971 年，第 ix-lxii 页）完美地追溯了他父亲思想的迷人发展，从 1920 年代初在加州大学伯克利分校的硕士学位论文到他 1935 年英年早逝。

Like much trail-blazing intellectual work, Milman Parry’s grew out of insights as deep and sure as they were difficult to make explicit. Parry’s son, the late Adam Parry (1971, pp. ix-lxii), has beautifully traced the fascinating development of his father’s thought, from his MA thesis at the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1920s till his untimely death in 1935.

帕里的总体愿景中并非所有元素都是全新的。从 20 年代初开始，支配他思想的基本公理是，荷马诗歌中“词语和词形的选择取决于[口头创作的]六步诗行的形状”（Adam Parry 1971，第 xix 页）， JE Ellendt 和 H. Düntzer 的工作已经预料到了这一点。帕里的萌芽洞察力中的其他因素也在预料之中。阿诺德·范·根内普（Arnold van Gennep）注意到当代口头文化诗歌中的公式化结构，穆尔科先生（M. Murko）也认识到此类文化的口头诗歌中缺乏精确的逐字记忆。更重要的是，耶稣会神父兼学者马塞尔·茹斯（Marcel Jousse）在法国残余的口头农民环境中长大，成年后的大部分时间都在中东度过，吸收其口头文化，这些文化中的口头作文与所有书面作文有着明显的区别。Jousse（1925）对口头文化及其产生的人格结构进行了风格化verbomoteur（“verbomotor”——遗憾的是，Jousse 的作品尚未被翻译成英文；参见 Ong 1967b，第 30 页、147-8、335-6）。米尔曼·帕里的愿景包括并融合了所有这些见解和其他见解，为荷马诗歌是什么以及荷马诗歌的产生条件如何使其成为现在的样子提供了可证明的说明。

Not every element in Parry’s plenary vision was entirely new. The fundamental axiom governing his thought from the early 1920s on, ‘the dependence of the choice of words and word-forms on the shape of the [orally composed] hexameter line’ in the Homeric poems (Adam Parry 1971, p. xix), had been anticipated in the work of J. E. Ellendt and H. Düntzer. Other elements in Parry’s germinal insight had also been anticipated. Arnold van Gennep had noted formulary structuring in poetry of oral cultures of the present age, and M. Murko had recognized the absence of exact verbatim memory in oral poetry of such cultures. More importantly, Marcel Jousse, the Jesuit priest and scholar, who had been reared in a residually oral peasant milieu in France and who spent most of his adult life in the Middle East soaking up its oral culture, had sharply differentiated the oral composition in such cultures from all written composition. Jousse (1925) had styled oral cultures and the personality structures they produced verbomoteur (‘verbomotor’ – regrettably, Jousse’s work has not been translated into English; see Ong 1967b, pp. 30, 147–8, 335–6). Milman Parry’s vision included and fused all these insights and others to provide a provable account of what Homeric poetry was and of how the conditions under which it was produced made it what it was.

然而，即使这些早期学者部分预见到了帕里的愿景，也是他自己的，因为当它在 1920 年代初首次呈现在他面前时，他显然甚至不知道刚才提到的这些学者中的任何一个的存在（亚当·帕里1971 年，第 xxii 页）。当然，毫无疑问，当时影响早期学者的微妙影响也同样影响着他。

Parry’s vision, however, even where partly anticipated by these earlier scholars, was his own, for when it initially presented itself to him in the early 1920s, he apparently did not even know of the existence of any of these scholars just mentioned (Adam Parry 1971, p. xxii). Doubtless, of course, subtle inﬂuences in the air at the time that had inﬂuenced earlier scholars were also inﬂuencing him.

正如他在巴黎的博士论文（Milman Parry 1928）中成熟和论证的那样，帕里的发现可以这样表述：事实上，荷马诗歌的每一个显着特征都是由于口头写作方法所强加的经济性。一旦人们抛开几代文学文化根深蒂固在心灵中的表达和思维过程的假设，就可以通过仔细研究诗歌本身来重建这些内容。这一发现在文学界是革命性的，并将在文化和心灵史上的其他地方产生巨大的影响。

As matured and demonstrated in his Paris doctoral dissertation (Milman Parry 1928), Parry’s discovery might be put this way: virtually every distinctive feature of Homeric poetry is due to the economy enforced on it by oral methods of composition. These can be reconstructed by careful study of the verse itself, once one puts aside the assumptions about expression and thought processes engrained in the psyche by generations of literate culture. This discovery was revolutionary in literary circles and would have tremendous repercussions elsewhere in cultural and psychic history.

这一发现，特别是帕里对前面提到的公理的使用，“单词和单词形式的选择取决于六音步线的形状”，有哪些更深层的含义？Düntzer 指出，用于葡萄酒的荷马形容词在韵律上都是不同的，并且给定形容词的使用不是由其精确含义决定，而是由它出现的段落的韵律需求决定（Adam Parry 1971，p） .xx）。荷马史诗的恰当性被虔诚地、严重地夸大了。口述诗人拥有丰富的、多样化的绰号，足以为他将故事缝合在一起时可能出现的任何格律上的紧急情况提供一个绰号——每次讲述的方式都不同，因为，正如我们将看到的，口述诗人通常不会逐字记忆。他们的诗句。

What are some of the deeper implications of this discovery, and particularly of Parry’s use of the axiom earlier noted, ‘the dependence of the choice of words and word-forms on the shape of the hexameter line’? Düntzer had noted that the Homeric epithets used for wine are all metrically different and that the use of a given epithet was determined not by its precise meaning so much as by the metrical needs of the passage in which it turned up (Adam Parry 1971, p. xx). The appositeness of the Homeric epithet had been piously and grossly exaggerated. The oral poet had an abundant repertoire of epithets diversiﬁed enough to provide an epithet for any metrical exigency that might arise as he stitched his story together – differently at each telling, for, as will be seen, oral poets do not normally work from verbatim memorization of their verse.

现在，很明显，韵律的需要以某种方式决定了任何用韵律作曲的诗人对词语的选择。但普遍的假设是，正确的韵律术语以某种流动且很大程度上不可预测的方式向诗歌想象暗示自己，只与“天才”（即与本质上无法解释的能力）相关。诗人被书法文化甚至印刷文化所理想化，因此不希望使用预制材料。如果一位诗人确实呼应了早期诗歌的一些片段，那么他就应该将这些内容改编成他自己的“同类事物”。确实，某些做法违背了这一假设，特别是使用短语书为后古典拉丁诗歌的写作者提供了标准的表达方式。拉丁短语书籍蓬勃发展，Gradus ad Parnassum被小学生广泛使用（Ong 1967b，第 174 页）。85–6；1971 年，第 77 页，261–3；1977 年，第 166、178 页）。Gradus提供了来自古典拉丁诗人的修饰词和其他短语，长音节和短音节都方便地标记为韵律配合，以便有抱负的诗人可以从 Gradus 中组装一首诗，就像男孩们可以从旧的 Erector Set 或 Meccano 中组装一个结构一样一套或来自一套修补匠玩具。整体结构可能是他自己设计的，但在他出现之前，各个部分就已经存在了。

Now, it is obvious that metrical needs in one way or another determine the selection of words by any poet composing in meter. But the general presumption had been that proper metrical terms somehow suggested themselves to the poetic imagination in a ﬂuid and largely unpredictable way, correlated only with ‘genius’ (that is, with an ability essentially inexplicable). Poets, as idealized by chirographic cultures and even more by typographic cultures, were not expected to use prefabricated materials. If a poet did echo bits of earlier poems, he was expected to modulate these into his own ‘kind of thing’. Certain practices, it is true, went against this presumption, notably the use of phrase books providing standard ways of saying things for those writing postclassical Latin poetry. Latin phrase books ﬂourished, particularly after the invention of printing made compilations easily multipliable, and they continued to ﬂourish far through the nineteenth century, when the Gradus ad Parnassum was much in use by schoolboys (Ong 1967b, pp. 85–6; 1971, pp. 77, 261–3; 1977, pp. 166, 178). The Gradus provided epithetic and other phrases from classical Latin poets, with the long and short syllables all conveniently marked for metrical ﬁt, so that the aspirant poet could assemble a poem from the Gradus as boys might assemble a structure from an old Erector set or Meccano set or from a set of Tinker Toys. The over-all structure could be of his own making but the pieces were all there before he came along.

然而，这种手术仅对初学者来说是可以忍受的。有能力的诗人应该创造出他自己的韵律合适的短语。平凡的思想可以被容忍，但平凡的语言却不能被容忍。在《批评论文》（1711）中，亚历山大·波普期望诗人的“机智”能够保证，当他处理“人们经常想到的事情”时，他会以一种让读者发现“从未如此出色地表达”的方式来做到这一点。表达公认真理的方式必须是原创的。波普之后不久，浪漫主义时代需要更多的原创性。对于极端浪漫主义者来说，完美的诗人理想地应该像上帝一样，从无到有地创造：他或她越好，诗中的一切就越不可预测。只有初学者或永远贫穷的诗人才会使用预制的东西。

This kind of procedure, however, was viewed as tolerable only in beginners. The competent poet was supposed to generate his own metrically ﬁtted phrases. Commonplace thought might be tolerated, but not commonplace language. In An Essay on Criticism (1711) Alexander Pope expected the poet’s ‘wit’ to guarantee that when he treated ‘what oft was thought’ he did it in such a way that readers found it ‘ne’er so well expressed’. The way of putting the accepted truth had to be original. Shortly after Pope, the Romantic Age demanded still more originality. For the extreme Romantic, the perfect poet should ideally be like God Himself, creating ex nihilo: the better he or she was, the less predictable was anything and everything in the poem. Only beginners or permanently poor poets used prefabricated stuff.

几个世纪以来的共识是，荷马不是一位初学诗人，也不是一位蹩脚诗人。也许他甚至是一个先天的“天才”，从未经历过雏鸟阶段，但从孵化的那一刻起就能飞翔——就像早熟的姆温多、尼扬加史诗英雄、“刚出生的小孩子”一样。 -走了'。无论如何，在《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》中，荷马通常被认为是完全有成就的、技艺高超的。但现在他的脑子里似乎已经有了某种短语手册。对米尔曼·帕里所做的事情的仔细研究表明，他重复了一个又一个公式。希腊语术语“rhapsodize”、rhapsoidein的含义，“将歌曲缝合在一起”（rhaptein , 缝合; o´ide，歌曲），变得不祥：荷马将预制部件缝合在一起。你没有创造者，而是装配线工人。

Homer, by the consensus of centuries, was no beginner poet, nor was he a poor poet. Perhaps he was even a congenital ‘genius’, who had never been through a ﬂedgling stage at all but could ﬂy the moment he was hatched – like the precocious Mwindo, the Nyanga epic hero, the ‘Little-One-just-Born-He-Walked’. In any case, in the Iliad and the Odyssey Homer was normally taken to be fully accomplished, consummately skilled. Yet it now began to appear that he had had some kind of phrase book in his head. Careful study of the sort Milman Parry was doing showed that he repeated formula after formula. The meaning of the Greek term ‘rhapsodize’, rhapsoidein, ‘to stitch song together’ ( rhaptein, to stitch; o¯ide, song), became ominous: Homer stitched together prefabricated parts. Instead of a creator, you had an assembly-line worker.

这个想法对遥远的文人尤其具有威胁。因为有文化的人接受的教育原则上永远不要使用陈词滥调。如何接受这样一个事实：荷马史诗似乎越来越多地由陈词滥调或非常像陈词滥调的元素组成？总的来说，随着帕里的工作的进展并被后来的学者发扬光大，它变成了显然，《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》中的文字中只有一小部分不是公式的一部分，而且在某种程度上是毁灭性的可预测公式。

This idea was particularly threatening to far-gone literates. For literates are educated never to use clichés, in principle. How to live with the fact that the Homeric poems, more and more, appeared to be made up of clichés, or elements very like clichés? By and large, as Parry’s work had proceeded and was carried forward by later scholars, it became evident that only a tiny fraction of the words in the Iliad and the Odyssey were not parts of formulas, and to a degree devastatingly predictable formulas.

此外，标准化公式围绕同样标准化的主题进行分组，例如议会、军队的集结、挑战、战败者的掠夺、英雄的盾牌等等（Lord 1960，第 68-98 页） ）。在世界各地的口头叙述和其他口头话语中都可以找到类似主题的曲目。（书面叙述和其他书面话语也必然使用主题，但主题更加多样化且不那么突兀。）

Moreover, the standardized formulas were grouped around equally standardized themes, such as the council, the gathering of the army, the challenge, the despoiling of the vanquished, the hero’s shield, and so on and on (Lord 1960, pp. 68–98). A repertoire of similar themes is found in oral narrative and other oral discourse around the world. (Written narrative and other written discourses use themes, too, of necessity, but the themes are inﬁnitely more varied and less obtrusive.)

荷马史诗的整个语言，具有早期和晚期风神和爱奥尼亚特征的奇特混合，最好的解释不是几个文本的叠加，而是史诗诗人多年来使用他们保留和使用的古老表达方式产生的语言。 /或主要出于度量目的而重新设计。经过几个世纪前的塑造和重塑后，这两部史诗于公元前 700-650 年左右以新希腊字母表记录下来，这是第一部被纳入该字母表的长篇作品（Havelock 1963，第 115 页）。他们的语言不是任何人在日常生活中说过的希腊语，而是通过一代又一代的诗人学习而特别塑造的希腊语。（即使在今天，类似的特殊语言的痕迹仍然很常见，例如，

The entire language of the Homeric poems, with its curious mix of early and late Aeolic and Ionic peculiarities, was best explained not as an overlaying of several texts but as a language generated over the years by epic poets using old set expressions which they preserved and/or reworked largely for metrical purposes. After being shaped and reshaped centuries earlier, the two epics were set down in the new Greek alphabet around 700–650 BC, the ﬁrst lengthy compositions to be put into this alphabet (Havelock 1963, p. 115). Their language was not a Greek that anyone had ever spoken in day-to-day life, but a Greek specially contoured through use of poets learning from one another generation after generation. (Traces of a comparable special language are familiar even today, for example, in the peculiar formulas still found in the English used for fairy tales.)

如此毫不掩饰公式化、由预制部分构成的诗歌怎么可能仍然如此好呢？米尔曼·帕里正视这个问题。否认现在已知的事实是没有用的，即荷马史诗重视并以某种方式利用了后来读者原则上被训练贬低的东西，即固定短语、公式、预期的限定词——更直白地说，陈词滥调。

How could any poetry that was so unabashedly formulary, so constituted of prefabricated parts, still be so good? Milman Parry faced up squarely to this question. There was no use denying the now known fact that the Homeric poems valued and somehow made capital of what later readers had been trained in principle to disvalue, namely, the set phrase, the formula, the expected qualiﬁer – to put it more bluntly, the cliché.

其中某些更广泛的影响仍有待埃里克·A·哈夫洛克（Eric A. Havelock，1963）稍后详细阐述。荷马希腊人重视陈词滥调，因为不仅诗人，而且整个口头思维世界或思想世界都依赖于思想的公式化构成。在口头文化中，知识一旦获得，就必须不断重复，否则就会丢失：固定的、公式化的思维模式对于智慧和有效的管理至关重要。但是，到了柏拉图时代（427？–347公元前）发生了变化：希腊人终于有效地内化了书写——这在公元前 720-700 年希腊字母发展之后花了几个世纪（Havelock 1963，第 49 页，引用 Rhys Carpenter）。存储知识的新方式不是通过助记公式，而是通过书面文本。这使头脑得以解放，可以进行更原创、更抽象的思考。哈夫洛克表明，柏拉图本质上（如果不是很有意识的话）将诗人排除在他的理想共和国之外，因为他发现自己处于一个新的手写风格的思维世界中，在这个世界中，所有传统诗人所钟爱的公式或陈词滥调已经过时且适得其反。

Certain of these wider implications remained to be worked out later in great detail by Eric A. Havelock (1963). Homeric Greeks valued clichés because not only the poets but the entire oral noetic world or thought world relied upon the formulaic constitution of thought. In an oral culture, knowledge, once acquired, had to be constantly repeated or it would be lost: ﬁxed, formulaic thought patterns were essential for wisdom and effective administration. But, by Plato’s day (427?–347 BC ) a change had set in: the Greeks had at long last effectively interiorized writing – something which took several centuries after the development of the Greek alphabet around 720–700 BC(Havelock 1963, p. 49, citing Rhys Carpenter). The new way to store knowledge was not in mnemonic formulas but in the written text. This freed the mind for more original, more abstract thought. Havelock shows that Plato excluded poets from his ideal republic essentially (if not quite consciously) because he found himself in a new chirographically styled noetic world in which the formula or cliché, beloved of all traditional poets, was outmoded and counterproductive.

对于西方文化来说，所有这些都是令人不安的结论，因为西方文化与荷马密切相关，属于理想化的希腊古代的一部分。它们表明，荷马希腊将我们视为罪恶的东西培养成一种诗意和理性的美德，它们表明，荷马希腊与柏拉图之后的哲学所代表的一切之间的关系，无论表面上是亲切和连续的，但实际上却是深深的对立的，如果通常是在无意识层面而不是意识层面。这场冲突破坏了柏拉图自己的无意识。因为柏拉图在《斐德罗篇》和他的第七封信中表达了严重的保留写作是一种机械的、不人道的处理知识的方式，对问题反应迟钝，并且会破坏记忆，尽管我们现在知道，柏拉图所奋斗的哲学思想完全依赖于写作。难怪这里的含义长期以来一直无法浮出水面。古希腊文明对全世界的重要性开始以全新的方式展现出来：它标志着人类历史上的一个转折点，即根深蒂固的字母读写能力首次与口头语言发生正面冲突。而且，尽管柏拉图感到不安，但当时柏拉图和其他任何人都没有或不可能明确意识到这就是正在发生的事情。

All these are disturbing conclusions for a western culture that has identiﬁed closely with Homer as part of an idealized Greek antiquity. They show Homeric Greece cultivating as a poetic and noetic virtue what we have regarded as a vice, and they show that the relationship between Homeric Greece and everything that philosophy after Plato stood for was, however superﬁcially cordial and continuous, in fact deeply antagonistic, if often at the unconscious rather than the conscious level. The conﬂict wracked Plato’s own unconscious. For Plato expresses serious reservations in the Phaedrus and his Seventh Letter about writing, as a mechanical, inhuman way of processing knowledge, unresponsive to questions and destructive of memory, although, as we now know, the philosophical thinking Plato fought for depended entirely on writing. No wonder the implications here resisted surfacing for so long. The importance of ancient Greek civilization to all the world was beginning to show in an entirely new light: it marked the point in human history when deeply interiorized alphabetic literacy ﬁrst clashed head-on with orality. And, despite Plato’s uneasiness, at the time neither Plato nor anyone else was or could be explicitly aware that this was what was going on.

帕里的公式概念是在对希腊六音步诗句的研究中得出的。当其他人处理这个概念并对其进行发展时，关于如何包含、扩展或调整这个定义的各种争议不可避免地出现（见 Adam Parry 1971，p.xxviii，n.1）。造成这种情况的一个原因是，在帕里的概念中，有一个更深层次的含义，从他对公式的定义中并不能立即明显看出，“在相同的韵律条件下经常使用的一组单词来表达给定的基本思想”（亚当·帕里1971，p。272）。David E. Bynum 在《The Daemon in the Wood》（1978 年，第 11-18 页和passim）中对这一层进行了最深入的探索。拜纳姆指出，“帕里的“基本思想”很少像帕里的定义的简短或公式本身通常的简洁、史诗风格的传统性或大多数公式的词汇参考的平庸性所暗示的那样简单”（1978，第 13 页）。拜纳姆区分了“公式化”元素和“严格公式化（完全重复）的短语”（参见 Adam Parry 1971，p.xxxiii，n.1）。尽管后者标志着口头诗歌（Lord 1960，第 33-65 页），但在此类诗歌中，它们成群出现和重复出现（例如，在拜纳姆的一个例子中，高树参加了一位伟大的战士接近时的骚动– 1978 年，第 11 页。18）。这些簇构成了公式的组织原则，因此“基本思想”并不需要清晰、直接的表述，而是一种主要在无意识中结合在一起的虚构复合体。

Parry’s concept of the formula was worked out in the study of Greek hexameter verse. As others have dealt with the concept and developed it, various disputes have inevitably arisen as to how to contain or extend or adapt the deﬁnition (see Adam Parry 1971, p. xxviii, n. 1). One reason for this is that in Parry’s concept there is a deeper stratum of meaning not immediately apparent from his deﬁnition of the formula, ‘a group of words which is regularly employed under the same metrical conditions to express a given essential idea’ (Adam Parry 1971, p. 272). This stratum has been explored most intensively by David E. Bynum in The Daemon in the Wood (1978, pp. 11–18, and passim ). Bynum notes that ‘Parry’s “essential ideas” are seldom altogether so simple as the shortness of Parry’s deﬁnition or the usual brevity of formulas themselves, the conventionality of the epic style, or the banality of most formulas’ lexical reference may suggest’ (1978, p. 13). Bynum distinguishes between ‘formulaic’ elements and ‘strictly formulary (exactly repeated) phrases’ (cf. Adam Parry 1971, p. xxxiii, n. 1). Although these latter mark oral poetry (Lord 1960, pp. 33–65), in such poetry they occur and recur in clusters (in one of Bynum’s instances, for example, high trees attend the commotion of a terriﬁc warrior’s approach – 1978, p. 18). The clusters constitute the organizing principles of the formulas, so that the ‘essential idea’ is not subject to clear, straightforward formulation but is rather a kind of ﬁctional complex held together largely in the unconscious.

拜纳姆这本令人印象深刻的书在很大程度上集中于基本小说，他将其设计为“两棵树”模式，并在从美索不达米亚和地中海古代到现代南斯拉夫、中非和其他地方的口头叙事和世界各地的相关图像中识别出这种元素。自始至终，“分离、馈赠和不可预测的危险的概念”集中在一棵树（绿树）周围，“统一、补偿、互惠的概念”集中在另一棵树（干树、砍伐的木头）周围——1978年， p。145. 拜纳姆对这个和其他独特的口头“基本小说”的关注有助于我们在口头叙事组织和手写印刷叙事组织之间做出比以前可能的更清晰的区分。

Bynum’s impressive book focuses in great part around the elemental ﬁction which he styles the Two Tree pattern and which he identiﬁes in oral narrative and associated iconography around the world from Mesopotamian and Mediterranean antiquity through oral narrative in modern Yugoslavia, Central Africa, and elsewhere. Throughout, ‘the notions of separation, gratuity, and an unpredictable danger’ cluster around one tree (the green tree) and ‘the ideas of uniﬁcation, recompense, reciprocity’ cluster about the other (the dry tree, hewn wood) – 1978, p. 145. Bynum’s attention to this and other distinctively oral ‘elemental ﬁction’ helps us to make some clearer distinctions between oral narrative organization and chirographic typographic narrative organization than have previously been possible.

本书将根据与拜纳姆不同但又相似的理由来关注这些区别。Foley (1980a) 已经表明，口头公式到底是什么以及它如何发挥作用取决于它所使用的传统，但所有传统中都有足够的共同点来使这个概念有效。除非另有明确说明，否则我将在这里将公式和公式以及公式理解为非常笼统地指的是诗歌或散文中或多或少精确重复的固定短语或固定表达方式（例如谚语），正如我们将看到的那样，它们确实具有在口头文化中的作用更为重要和比任何书面、印刷或电子文化更普遍。（参见 Adam Parry 1971，第 xxxiii 页，n.1。）

Such distinctions will be attended to in this book on grounds different from but neighboring on Bynum’s. Foley (1980a) has shown that exactly what an oral formula is and how it works depends on the tradition in which it is used, but that there is ample common ground in all traditions to make the concept valid. Unless it is clearly indicated otherwise, I shall understand formula and formulary and formulaic here as referring quite generically to more or less exactly repeated set phrases or set expressions (such as proverbs) in verse or prose, which, as will be seen, do have a function in oral culture more crucial and pervasive than any they may have in a writing or print or electronic culture. (Cf. Adam Parry 1971, p. xxxiii, n. 1.)

口头公式化的思想和表达深深地存在于意识和无意识中，一旦习惯了它们，它们就不会消失。Finnegan (1977, p. 70) 显然有些惊讶地报道了奥普兰的观察，即当科萨诗人学习写作时，他们写的诗歌也具有公式化的风格。事实上，如果他们能够管理任何其他风格，那将是完全令人惊讶的，特别是因为公式化风格不仅仅标志着诗歌，而且或多或少地标志着原始口头文化中的所有思想和表达。各地的早期书面诗歌似乎首先必然是对口头表演剧本的模仿。头脑最初没有适当的手写资源。你在表面上写下了你想象自己在某种可实现的口头环境中大声说出的单词。写作只是慢慢地变成了写作中的写作，一种话语——无论是诗意的还是其他的——被组合在一起，却没有感觉到写作实际上是在大声说话（就像早期作家在写作中所做的那样）。正如稍后所指出的，克兰奇报告说，即使是十一世纪的坎特伯雷埃德默似乎也认为写作是“对自己进行口述”（1979，第218页）。口头思想和表达习惯，包括大量使用公式化元素，主要通过古老的古典修辞学的教学而得以维持，在柏拉图反对口头诗人的大约两千多年后，仍然是英国都铎王朝几乎所有类型散文风格的标志。 1971 年，第 23-47 页）。直到两个世纪后的浪漫主义运动，它们的大部分内容在英语中实际上被消灭了。许多现代文化已经认识了书写几个世纪，但从未将其完全内在化，例如阿拉伯文化和某些其他地中海文化（例如希腊-Tannen 1980a），仍然严重依赖公式化的思想和表达。卡里尔·纪伯伦的职业生涯是为有文化的美国人提供印刷版的口服处方产品，这些美国人对类似谚语的话语感到新奇，据我的一位黎巴嫩朋友说，贝鲁特公民认为这些谚语是司空见惯的。

Oral formulaic thought and expression ride deep in consciousness and the unconscious, and they do not vanish as soon as one used to them takes pen in hand. Finnegan (1977, p. 70) reports, with apparently some surprise, Opland’s observation that when Xhosa poets learn to write, their written poetry is also characterized by a formulaic style. It would in fact be utterly surprising if they could manage any other style, especially since formulaic style marks not poetry alone but, more or less, all thought and expression in primary oral culture. Early written poetry everywhere, it seems, is at ﬁrst necessarily a mimicking in script of oral performance. The mind has initially no properly chirographic resources. You scratch out on a surface words you imagine yourself saying aloud in some realizable oral setting. Only very gradually does writing become composition in writing, a kind of discourse – poetic or otherwise – that is put together without a feeling that the one writing is actually speaking aloud (as early writers may well have done in composing). As noted later here, Clanchy reports how even the eleventh-century Eadmer of Canterbury seems to think of composing in writing as ‘dictating to himself’ (1979, p. 218). Oral habits of thought and expression, including massive use of formulaic elements, sustained in use largely by the teaching of the old classical rhetoric, still marked prose style of almost every sort in Tudor England some two thousand years after Plato’s campaign against oral poets (Ong 1971, pp. 23–47). They were effectively obliterated in English, for the most part, only with the Romantic Movement two centuries later. Many modern cultures that have known writing for centuries but have never fully interiorized it, such as Arabic culture and certain other Mediterranean cultures (e.g. Greek – Tannen 1980a), rely heavily on formulaic thought and expression still. Kahlil Gibran has made a career of providing oral formulary products in print to literate Americans who ﬁnd novel the proverb-like utterances that, according to a Lebanese friend of mine, citizens of Beirut regard as commonplace.

后续及相关工作

CONSEQUENT AND RELATED WORK

米尔曼·帕里的许多结论和重点当然在后来的学术研究中有所修改（例如，参见 Stoltz 和 Shannon 1976），但他关于口语及其对诗歌结构和美学的影响的中心思想已经彻底改变了荷马研究和美学的观点。还有其他研究，从人类学到文学史。Adam Parry（1971，第 xliv-lxxx）描述了他父亲发起的革命的一些直接影响。Holoka (1973) 和 Haymes (1973) 在他们宝贵的书目调查中记录了许多其他内容。尽管帕里的作品在一些细节上受到了攻击和修改，

Many of Milman Parry’s conclusions and emphases have of course been somewhat modiﬁed by subsequent scholarship (see, for example, Stoltz and Shannon 1976), but his central message about orality and its implications for poetic structures and for aesthetics has revolutionized for good Homeric studies and other studies as well, from anthropology to literary history. Adam Parry (1971, pp. xliv-lxxx) has described some of the immediate effects of the revolution which his father wrought. Holoka (1973) and Haymes (1973) have recorded many others in their invaluable bibliographical surveys. Although Parry’s work has been attacked and revised in some of its details, the few totally unreceptive reactions to his work have mostly by now simply been put aside as products of the unreﬂective chirographic-typographic mentality which at ﬁrst blocked any real comprehension of what Parry was saying and which his work itself has now rendered obsolete.

学者们仍在阐述和验证帕里的发现和见解的更全面的含义。惠特曼（Whitman，1958）很早就用他对《伊利亚特》的雄心勃勃的大纲进行了补充，该大纲的结构是在情节结束时重复情节开头的元素的公式化倾向；根据惠特曼的分析，这部史诗就像中国的拼图一样，盒子套在盒子里。然而，为了理解口语与读写能力的对比，继帕里之后最重要的发展是由阿尔伯特·B·洛德（Albert B. Lord）和埃里克·A·哈夫洛克（Eric A. Havelock）提出的。在《故事歌手》中（1960），洛德以令人信服的技巧延续并扩展了帕里的工作，报道了漫长的实地考察和塞尔维亚-克罗地亚史诗歌手口头表演的大量录音以及对这些歌手的长时间采访。早些时候，弗朗西斯·马古恩以及那些在哈佛大学与他和洛德一起学习的人，特别是罗伯特·克里德和杰西·贝辛格，已经将帕里的思想应用于古英语诗歌的研究（Foley 1980b，第 490 页）。

Scholars are still elaborating and qualifying the fuller implications of Parry’s discoveries and insights. Whitman (1958) early supplemented it with his ambitious outline of the Iliad as structured by the formulaic tendency to repeat at the end of an episode elements from the episode’s beginning; the epic is built like a Chinese puzzle, boxes within boxes, according to Whitman’s analysis. For understanding orality as contrasted with literacy, however, the most signiﬁcant developments following upon Parry have been worked out by Albert B. Lord and Eric A. Havelock. In The Singer of Tales (1960), Lord carried through and extended Parry’s work with convincing ﬁnesse, reporting on lengthy ﬁeld trips and massive taping of oral performances by Serbo-Croatian epic singers and of lengthy interviews with these singers. Earlier, Francis Magoun and those who studied with him and Lord at Harvard, notably Robert Creed and Jess Bessinger, were already applying Parry’s ideas to the study of Old English poetry (Foley 1980b, p. 490).

哈夫洛克的《柏拉图序言》（1963）将帕里和洛德关于口头史诗叙事中口头性的发现扩展到整个古希腊口头文化，并令人信服地展示了希腊哲学的开端如何与写作带来的思想重组联系在一起。 。柏拉图将诗人排除在他的思想之外《理想国》实际上是柏拉图对荷马所延续的原始聚合、并列、口述式思维的拒绝，转而支持对世界和思想本身的敏锐分析或剖析，而这种分析或剖析是通过字母表在希腊心灵中的内化而成为可能的。在随后的著作《西方读写能力的起源》（1976）中，哈夫洛克将希腊分析思想的优势归因于希腊人将元音引入字母表。最初的字母表是由闪米特人发明的，仅由辅音和一些半元音组成。通过引入元音，希腊人达到了对难以捉摸的声音世界进行抽象、分析和视觉编码的新水平。这一成就预示并实现了他们后来的抽象智力成就。

Havelock’s Preface to Plato (1963) has extended Parry’s and Lord’s ﬁndings about orality in oral epic narrative out into the whole of ancient oral Greek culture and has shown convincingly how the beginnings of Greek philosophy were tied in with the restructuring of thought brought about by writing. Plato’s exclusion of poets from his Republic was in fact Plato’s rejection of the pristine aggregative, paratactic, oral-style thinking perpetuated in Homer in favor of the keen analysis or dissection of the world and of thought itself made possible by the interiorization of the alphabet in the Greek psyche. In a subsequent work, Origins of Western Literacy (1976), Havelock attributes the ascendency of Greek analytic thought to the Greeks’ introduction of vowels into the alphabet. The original alphabet, invented by Semitic peoples, had consisted only of consonants and some semivowels. In introducing vowels, the Greeks reached a new level of abstract, analytic, visual coding of the elusive world of sound. This achievement presaged and implemented their later abstract intellectual achievements.

帕里发起的工作线尚未与它可以轻易联系的许多领域的工作结合起来。但一些重要的联系已经建立。例如，他在非洲史诗中的权威和明智的工作（1979），伊西多尔·奥克佩（Isidore Okpewho）将帕里的见解和分析（在洛德的作品中详细阐述）带入了与欧洲截然不同的文化的口头艺术形式，从而使非洲史诗和古希腊史诗相互辉映另一个。Joseph C. Miller (1980) 论述非洲口头传统和历史。尤金·欧阳（Eugene Eoyang，1977）展示了对口语心理动力学的忽视如何导致对早期中国叙事的误解，普拉克斯（Plaks，1977）收集的其他作者也研究了中国文学叙事的公式化前因。兹韦特勒研究过古典阿拉伯诗歌（1977）。布鲁斯·罗森伯格（Bruce Rosenberg，1970）研究了美国民间传教士中古老口语的生存情况。在纪念主的节日文中，约翰·迈尔斯·弗利（John Miles Foley，1981）收集了从巴尔干半岛到尼日利亚和新墨西哥州、从古代到现代的口语新研究。其他专门的工作现在也正在出现。

The line of work initiated by Parry has yet to be joined to work in the many ﬁelds with which it can readily connect. But a few important connections have already been made. For example, in his magisterial and judicious work on The Epic in Africa (1979), Isidore Okpewho brings Parry’s insights and analyses (in this case as elaborated in Lord’s work) to bear on the oral art forms of cultures quite different from the European, so that the African epic and the ancient Greek epic throw reciprocal light on one another. Joseph C. Miller (1980) treats African oral tradition and history. Eugene Eoyang (1977) has shown how neglect of the psychodynamics of orality has led to misconceptions about early Chinese narrative, and other authors collected by Plaks (1977) have examined formulary antecedents to literary Chinese narrative. Zwettler has dealt with Classical Arabic poetry (1977). Bruce Rosenberg (1970) has studied the survival of the old orality in American folk preachers. In a festschrift in honor of Lord, John Miles Foley (1981) has collected new studies on orality from the Balkans to Nigeria and New Mexico and from antiquity to the present. And other specialized work is now appearing.

人类学家更直接地研究口头问题。不仅借鉴了 Parry、Lord 和 Havelock，还借鉴了其他人的工作，包括我自己关于印刷品对 16 世纪思维过程的影响的早期工作（Ong 1958b – Goody 在 1974 年重印中引用），Jack Goody (1977) ）令人信服地展示了迄今为止被称为从魔法到科学的转变，或者从所谓的“前逻辑”到越来越“理性”的意识状态，或者从列维-斯特劳斯的“野蛮”思想到驯化的思想的转变。思想，可以更经济、更有说服力地解释为从口头到识字的各个阶段的转变。我早些时候曾提出（1967b，第 189 页），“西方”和其他观点之间经常进行的许多对比似乎可以简化为深刻内化的读写能力与或多或少残留的口头意识状态之间的对比。已故马歇尔·麦克卢汉的著名作品（1962、1964）也大量强调了耳眼、口语文本的对比，引起人们对詹姆斯·乔伊斯早熟敏锐的耳眼极性意识的关注，并将这种极性与大量其他方面联系起来。麦克卢汉博大精深的博学多才和惊人的洞察力汇集了截然不同的学术著作。麦克卢汉不仅吸引了学者的注意（Eisenstein 1979，第x-xi，xvii页），而且还吸引了大众媒体工作人员的注意，商界领袖和消息灵通的公众普遍喜欢他，主要是因为他对他的许多格言或神谕的言论着迷，这些言论对一些读者来说过于油嘴滑舌，但往往具有深刻的洞察力。他将这些称为“探针”。他通常会快速地从一种“探索”转向另一种“探索”，很少对“线性”（即分析）类型进行彻底的解释。他的名言“媒介就是信息”表明了他对从口头、读写和印刷到电子媒体转变的重要性的敏锐认识。很少有人能像马歇尔·麦克卢汉那样对这么多不同的思想产生如此激动人心的影响，包括那些不同意他或相信自己不同意他的人。对某些读者来说过于圆滑，但往往具有深刻的洞察力。他将这些称为“探针”。他通常会快速地从一种“探索”转向另一种“探索”，很少对“线性”（即分析）类型进行彻底的解释。他的名言“媒介就是信息”表明了他对从口头、读写和印刷到电子媒体转变的重要性的敏锐认识。很少有人能像马歇尔·麦克卢汉那样对这么多不同的思想产生如此激动人心的影响，包括那些不同意他或相信自己不同意他的人。对某些读者来说过于圆滑，但往往具有深刻的洞察力。他将这些称为“探针”。他通常会快速地从一种“探索”转向另一种“探索”，很少对“线性”（即分析）类型进行彻底的解释。他的名言“媒介就是信息”表明了他对从口头、读写和印刷到电子媒体转变的重要性的敏锐认识。很少有人能像马歇尔·麦克卢汉那样对这么多不同的思想产生如此激动人心的影响，包括那些不同意他或相信自己不同意他的人。他敏锐地意识到从口头到识字和印刷再到电子媒体转变的重要性。很少有人能像马歇尔·麦克卢汉那样对这么多不同的思想产生如此激动人心的影响，包括那些不同意他或相信自己不同意他的人。他敏锐地意识到从口头到识字和印刷再到电子媒体转变的重要性。很少有人能像马歇尔·麦克卢汉那样对这么多不同的思想产生如此激动人心的影响，包括那些不同意他或相信自己不同意他的人。

Anthropologists have gone more directly into the matter of orality. Drawing not only on Parry and Lord and Havelock but also on others’ work, including early work of my own on the effect of print on sixteenth-century thought processes (Ong 1958b – cited by Goody from a 1974 reprinting), Jack Goody (1977) has convincingly shown how shifts hitherto labeled as shifts from magic to science, or from the so called ‘prelogical’ to the more and more ‘rational’ state of consciousness, or from Lévi-Strauss’s ‘savage’ mind to domesticated thought, can be more economically and cogently explained as shifts from orality to various stages of literacy. I had earlier suggested (1967b, p. 189) that many of the contrasts often made between ‘western’ and other views seem reducible to contrasts between deeply interiorized literacy and more or less residually oral states of consciousness. The late Marshall McLuhan’s well-known work (1962, 1964) has also made much of ear-eye, oral-textual contrasts, calling attention to James Joyce’s precociously acute awareness of ear-eye polarities and relating to such polarities a great amount of otherwise quite disparate scholarly work brought together by McLuhan’s vast eclectic learning and his startling insights. McLuhan attracted the attention not only of scholars (Eisenstein 1979, pp. x–xi, xvii) but also of people working in the mass media, of business leaders, and of the generally informed public, largely because of fascination with his many gnomic or oracular pronouncements, too glib for some readers but often deeply perceptive. These he called ‘probes’. He generally moved rapidly from one ‘probe’ to another, seldom if ever undertaking any thorough explanation of a ‘linear’ (that is, analytic) sort. His cardinal gnomic saying, ‘The medium is the message’, registered his acute awareness of the importance of the shift from orality through literacy and print to electronic media. Few people have had so stimulating an effect as Marshall McLuhan on so many diverse minds, including those who disagreed with him or believed they did.

然而，尽管在某些圈子里，对复杂的口语与读写能力对比的关注正在增长，但在许多可能有所帮助的领域，这种关注仍然相对较少。例如，朱利安·杰恩斯（Julian Jaynes，1977）所描述的意识的早期和晚期阶段以及与两院思维中的神经生理学变化相关联的意识的早期和晚期阶段似乎也很大程度上适用于从口头到读写的转变的更简单和更可验证的描述。杰恩斯发现了意识的原始阶段，其中大脑是强烈的“两院制”，右半球产生不受控制的“声音”，这些声音归因于神的声音，而左半球将其处理成语言。公元前 2000 至 1000 年间，“声音”开始失去效力。值得注意的是，这个时期被公元前 1500 年左右字母表的发明巧妙地一分为二，杰恩斯确实相信写作有助于瓦解原来的两院制。这《伊利亚特》为他提供了两院制在不自觉的人物中的例子。杰恩斯写《奥德赛》的日期比《伊利亚特》晚一百年并相信狡猾的奥德修斯标志着现代自我意识的突破，不再受“声音”的统治。无论人们如何看待杰恩斯的理论，人们都会被杰恩斯所描述的早期或“两院制”心理特征之间的相似性所震惊——缺乏内省、缺乏分析能力、对意志本身的关注、缺乏某种感觉。过去和未来之间的差异——以及不仅在过去而且在今天口头文化中的心理特征。对于有文化的人来说，口头意识状态的影响是奇怪的，它们可能会引起复杂的解释，但结果可能是不必要的。两院制可能仅仅意味着口头制。口头和两院制问题也许需要进一步调查。

However, if attention to sophisticated orality-literacy contrasts is growing in some circles, it is still relatively rare in many ﬁelds where it could be helpful. For example, the early and late stages of consciousness which Julian Jaynes (1977) describes and relates to neurophysiological changes in the bicameral mind would also appear to lend themselves largely to much simpler and more veriﬁable description in terms of a shift from orality to literacy. Jaynes discerns a primitive stage of consciousness in which the brain was strongly ‘bicameral’, with the right hemisphere producing uncontrollable ‘voices’ attributed to the gods which the left hemisphere processed into speech. The ‘voices’ began to lose their effectiveness between 2000 and 1000 BC. This period, it will be noted, is neatly bisected by the invention of the alphabet around 1500 BC, and Jaynes indeed believes that writing helped bring about the breakdown of the original bicamerality. The Iliad provides him with examples of bicamerality in its unselfconscious characters. Jaynes dates the Odyssey a hundred years later than the Iliad and believes that wily Odysseus marks a breakthrough into the modern self-conscious mind, no longer under the rule of the ‘voices’. Whatever one makes of Jaynes’s theories, one cannot but be struck by the resemblance between the characteristics of the early or ‘bicameral’ psyche as Jaynes describes it – lack of introspectivity, of analytic prowess, of concern with the will as such, of a sense of difference between past and future – and the characteristics of the psyche in oral cultures not only in the past but even today. The effects of oral states of consciousness are bizarre to the literate mind, and they can invite elaborate explanations which may turn out to be needless. Bicamerality may mean simply orality. The question of orality and bicamerality perhaps needs further investigation.

3

3

口语的一些心理动力学

SOME PSYCHODYNAMICS OF ORALITY

有声音的话语就是力量和行动

SOUNDED WORD AS POWER AND ACTION

根据刚刚回顾的工作以及将要引用的其他工作，可以对原始口头文化（即未受书写影响的口头文化）的心理动力学进行一些概括。为了简洁起见，当上下文含义清楚时，我将把初级口头文化简称为口头文化。

As a result of the work just reviewed, and of other work which will be cited, it is possible to generalize somewhat about the psychodynamics of primary oral cultures, that is, of oral cultures untouched by writing. For brevity, when the context keeps the meaning clear, I shall refer to primary oral cultures simply as oral cultures.

完全识字的人很难想象原始口头文化是什么样子，即一种完全不了解书写甚至不知道书写可能性的文化。尝试想象一种没有人“查过”任何东西的文化。在原始的口头文化中，“查找某物”这个表达是一个空洞的短语：它没有任何可以想象的意义。如果没有书写，文字本身就没有视觉存在，即使它们所代表的对象是视觉的。它们是声音。你可能会“召回”他们——“召回”他们。但无处可“寻找”它们。它们没有焦点，没有痕迹（视觉隐喻，显示对书写的依赖），甚至没有轨迹。它们是事件、事件。

Fully literate persons can only with great difficulty imagine what a primary oral culture is like, that is, a culture with no knowledge whatsoever of writing or even of the possibility of writing. Try to imagine a culture where no one has ever ‘looked up’ anything. In a primary oral culture, the expression ‘to look up something’ is an empty phrase: it would have no conceivable meaning. Without writing, words as such have no visual presence, even when the objects they represent are visual. They are sounds. You might ‘call’ them back – ‘recall’ them. But there is nowhere to ‘look’ for them. They have no focus and no trace (a visual metaphor, showing dependency on writing), not even a trajectory. They are occurrences, events.

要了解什么是主要口头文化以及我们关于这种文化的问题的本质是什么，首先需要反思一下声音本身作为声音的本质（Ong 1967b，第 111-38 页）。所有感觉都发生在时间中，但与人类感觉中记录的其他领域不同，声音与时间有着特殊的关系。声音只有在消失时才存在。它不仅是易腐烂的，而且本质上是转瞬即逝的，而且它被感觉为转瞬即逝的。当我念出“permanence”这个词时，当我念到“-pence”时，“perma-”已经消失了，而且必须消失。

To learn what a primary oral culture is and what the nature of our problem is regarding such a culture, it helps ﬁrst to reﬂect on the nature of sound itself as sound (Ong 1967b, pp. 111–38). All sensation takes place in time, but sound has a special relationship to time unlike that of the other ﬁelds that register in human sensation. Sound exists only when it is going out of existence. It is not simply perishable but essentially evanescent, and it is sensed as evanescent. When I pronounce the word ‘permanence’, by the time I get to the ‘-pence’, the ‘perma-’ is gone, and has to be gone.

没有办法阻止声音并拥有声音。我可以停止摄像机并将一帧固定在屏幕上。如果我停止声音的运动，我就什么都没有了——只有寂静，根本没有声音。所有的感觉都及时发生，但没有其他感觉场能够以这种方式完全抵抗保持动作，即稳定。视觉可以记录运动，但也可以记录静止。事实上，它有利于静止，因为通过视觉仔细观察某物，我们更喜欢让它保持安静。我们经常将运动简化为一系列静态镜头，以便更好地了解运动是什么。没有与声音静止镜头相当的东西。示波器没有声音。它位于声音世界之外。

There is no way to stop sound and have sound. I can stop a moving picture camera and hold one frame ﬁxed on the screen. If I stop the movement of sound, I have nothing – only silence, no sound at all. All sensation takes place in time, but no other sensory ﬁeld totally resists a holding action, stabilization, in quite this way. Vision can register motion, but it can also register immobility. Indeed, it favors immobility, for to examine something closely by vision, we prefer to have it quiet. We often reduce motion to a series of still shots the better to see what motion is. There is no equivalent of a still shot for sound. An oscillogram is silent. It lies outside the sound world.

对于任何了解原始口头文化或与原始口头文化相距不远的文化中的单词的人来说，希伯来语术语dabar并不奇怪意思是“词”和“事件”。马林诺夫斯基 (Malinowski, 1923, pp. 45 1, 470-81) 指出，在“原始”（口头）民族中，语言通常是一种行动方式，而不仅仅是思想的象征，尽管他很难解释他所得到的内容（Sampson 1980，第 223-6 页），因为在 1923 年，对口语心理动力学的理解几乎不存在。口语民族普遍地、可能是普遍地认为词语具有巨大的力量，这并不奇怪。不使用电源就无法发出声音。当水牛完全没有生命，甚至死了时，猎人可以看到水牛，闻到水牛的味道，尝到水牛的味道，并触摸水牛，但如果他听到水牛的声音，他最好小心：有事情发生了。从这个意义上说，所有声音，尤其是来自生物体内部的口头言语，都是“动态的”。

For anyone who has a sense of what words are in a primary oral culture, or a culture not far removed from primary orality, it is not surprising that the Hebrew term dabar means ‘word’ and ‘event’. Malinowski (1923, pp. 45 1, 470-81) has made the point that among ‘primitive’ (oral) peoples generally language is a mode of action and not simply a countersign of thought, though he had trouble explaining what he was getting at (Sampson 1980, pp. 223–6), since understanding of the psychodynamics of orality was virtually nonexistent in 1923. Neither is it surprising that oral peoples commonly, and probably universally, consider words to have great power. Sound cannot be sounding without the use of power. A hunter can see a buffalo, smell, taste, and touch a buffalo when the buffalo is completely inert, even dead, but if he hears a buffalo, he had better watch out: something is going on. In this sense, all sound, and especially oral utterance, which comes from inside living organisms, is ‘dynamic’.

事实上，口语民族通常并且很可能普遍认为词语具有神奇的力量，这显然与他们对词语的理解（至少是无意识的）有关，因为他们认为词语必然是说出来的、听起来的，因此是权力驱动的。精通印刷术的人忘记了将单词视为主要是口头的、事件的，因此也是必然是有动力的：对他们来说，词语更倾向于被同化为“在那儿”平坦表面上的事物。这样的“事物”并不那么容易与魔法联系在一起，因为它们不是行动，而是在根本意义上死了，尽管会动态复活（Ong 1977，第230-71页）。

The fact that oral peoples commonly and in all likelihood universally consider words to have magical potency is clearly tied in, at least unconsciously, with their sense of the word as necessarily spoken, sounded, and hence power-driven. Deeply typographic folk forget to think of words as primarily oral, as events, and hence as necessarily powered: for them, words tend rather to be assimilated to things, ‘out there’ on a ﬂat surface. Such ‘things’ are not so readily associated with magic, for they are not actions, but are in a radical sense dead, though subject to dynamic resurrection (Ong 1977, pp. 230–71).

口头民族通常认为名称（一种单词）传达着对事物的权力。对创世记 2 章 20 节中亚当给动物命名的解释通常会引起人们对这种看似古怪的古老信仰的居高临下的关注。事实上，这种信念远没有那些不加思考的手写体和印刷术的人们所认为的那样古怪。首先，名称确实赋予人类对其名称的权力：如果不学习大量的名称，人们根本无法理解化学等知识，也无法实践化学工程。所有其他智力知识也是如此。其次，手写体和印刷术的人们倾向于将名称视为标签，即想象性地贴在指定物体上的书面或印刷标签。口头上的人们并不认为名字是一个标签，因为他们不知道名字是看得见的东西。文字的书面或印刷形式可以作为标签；真实的、口头的言语不可能是这样。

Oral peoples commonly think of names (one kind of words) as conveying power over things. Explanations of Adam’s naming of the animals in Genesis 2:20 usually call condescending attention to this presumably quaint archaic belief. Such a belief is in fact far less quaint than it seems to unreﬂective chirographic and typographic folk. First of all, names do give human beings power over what they name: without learning a vast store of names, one is simply powerless to understand, for example, chemistry and to practice chemical engineering. And so with all other intellectual knowledge. Secondly, chirographic and typographic folk tend to think of names as labels, written or printed tags imaginatively affixed to an object named. Oral folk have no sense of a name as a tag, for they have no idea of a name as something that can be seen. Written or printed representations of words can be labels; real, spoken words cannot be.

你知道你能记住什么：助记符和公式

YOU KNOW WHAT YOU CAN RECALL: MNEMONICS AND FORMULAS

在口头文化中，言语对声音的限制不仅决定了表达方式，还决定了思维过程。

In an oral culture, restriction of words to sound determines not only modes of expression but also thought processes.

你知道你能回忆起什么。当我们说我们了解欧几里得几何时，我们的意思并不是说我们此刻已经记住了它的每一个命题和证明，而是我们可以很容易地把它们想起。我们可以回忆起他们。“你知道你能回忆起什么”这一定理也适用于口头文化。但是生活在口述文化中的人们如何回忆呢？今天的识字者学习的有组织的知识，以便他们“知道”它，也就是说，能够回忆起它，除了极少数（如果有的话），已经被组装起来并以书面形式提供给他们。不仅欧几里得几何学如此，美国革命历史、甚至棒球击球率或交通规则也是如此。

You know what you can recall. When we say we know Euclidean geometry, we mean not that we have in mind at the moment every one of its propositions and proofs but rather that we can bring them to mind readily. We can recall them. The theorem ‘You know what you can recall’ applies also to an oral culture. But how do persons in an oral culture recall? The organized knowledge that literates today study so that they ‘know’ it, that is, can recall it, has, with very few if any exceptions, been assembled and made available to them in writing. This is the case not only with Euclidean geometry but also with American Revolutionary history, or even baseball batting averages or traffic regulations.

口头文化没有文本。它是如何组织在一起的召回材料？这相当于问“它以有组织的方式知道或能够知道什么？”

An oral culture has no texts. How does it get together organized material for recall? This is the same as asking, ‘What does it or can it know in an organized fashion?’

假设一个处于口头文化中的人会思考一个特定的复杂问题，并最终设法阐明一个本身相对复杂的解决方案，可以说，由几百个单词组成。他或她如何保留如此精心阐述的言语以供日后回忆？在完全没有任何文字的情况下，思想者之外没有任何东西，没有文本，可以使他或她再次产生相同的思想，甚至可以验证他或她是否这样做过。备忘录例如有凹口的棍子或一系列精心排列的物体本身并不能检索出一系列复杂的断言。事实上，如何才能组装出一个冗长的分析解决方案呢？对话者实际上是必不可少的：连续几个小时自言自语是很困难的。口头文化中持续的思想与交流息息相关。

Suppose a person in an oral culture would undertake to think through a particular complex problem and would ﬁnally manage to articulate a solution which itself is relatively complex, consisting, let us say, of a few hundred words. How does he or she retain for later recall the verbalization so painstakingly elaborated? In the total absence of any writing, there is nothing outside the thinker, no text, to enable him or her to produce the same line of thought again or even to verify whether he or she has done so or not. Aides-mémoire such as notched sticks or a series of carefully arranged objects will not of themselves retrieve a complicated series of assertions. How, in fact, could a lengthy, analytic solution ever be assembled in the ﬁrst place? An interlocutor is virtually essential: it is hard to talk to yourself for hours on end. Sustained thought in an oral culture is tied to communication.

但即使有一个倾听者来激发和奠定你的思想，你的思想的点点滴滴也无法保存在笔记中。你怎么能回想起你费尽心力搞定的事情呢？唯一的答案是：想想难忘的想法。在初级口头文化中，为了有效地解决保留和检索仔细表达的思想的问题，你必须以助记模式进行思考，并为准备好口头重现而设计。你的思想必须以一种有节奏的、平衡的模式、重复或对偶、头韵和谐音、修饰语和其他公式化的表达方式、标准的主题背景（集会、进餐、决斗、英雄的“帮手”、等等），每个人都经常听到的谚语，因此它们很容易浮现在脑海中，并且它们本身被设计成便于记忆和容易回忆的模式，或者以其他助记形式。严肃的思想与记忆系统交织在一起。助记符的需要决定偶数语法（Havelock 1963，第 87-96 页、131-2、294-6）。

But even with a listener to stimulate and ground your thought, the bits and pieces of your thought cannot be preserved in jotted notes. How could you ever call back to mind what you had so laboriously worked out? The only answer is: Think memorable thoughts. In a primary oral culture, to solve effectively the problem of retaining and retrieving carefully articulated thought, you have to do your thinking in mnemonic patterns, shaped for ready oral recurrence. Your thought must come into being in heavily rhythmic, balanced patterns, in repetitions or antitheses, in alliterations and assonances, in epithetic and other formulary expressions, in standard thematic settings (the assembly, the meal, the duel, the hero’s ‘helper’, and so on), in proverbs which are constantly heard by everyone so that they come to mind readily and which themselves are patterned for retention and ready recall, or in other mnemonic form. Serious thought is intertwined with memory systems. Mnemonic needs determine even syntax (Havelock 1963, pp. 87–96, 131–2, 294–6).

持久的口头思考，即使不是在正式的诗句中，也往往具有高度的节奏感，因为节奏有助于回忆，甚至在生理上也是如此。Jousse（1978）在古阿拉姆语和希腊塔尔古姆中展示了有节奏的口头模式、呼吸过程、手势和人体两侧对称之间的密切联系，因此在古希伯来语中也是如此。在古希腊人中，赫西奥德，他处于荷马式希腊口头文学和完全发展的希腊文学之间的中间状态，以公式化的诗歌形式传递了准哲学材料，并将其构造成他所从中出现的口头文化（Havelock 1963，第97-8页，294-301）。

Protracted orally based thought, even when not in formal verse, tends to be highly rhythmic, for rhythm aids recall, even physiologically. Jousse (1978) has shown the intimate linkage between rhythmic oral patterns, the breathing process, gesture, and the bilateral symmetry of the human body in ancient Aramaic and Hellenic targums, and thus also in ancient Hebrew. Among the ancient Greeks, Hesiod, who was intermediate between oral Homeric Greece and fully developed Greek literacy, delivered quasi-philosophic material in the formulaic verse forms that structured it into the oral culture from which he had emerged (Havelock 1963, pp. 97–8, 294–301).

公式有助于实现有节奏的话语，并且本身也可以作为助记剂，作为在所有人的嘴和耳朵中流传的固定表达方式。“早晨的红色，是水手的警告；夜晚的红色，水手的喜悦。“分而治之。” “犯错是人之常情，宽恕是神圣的。” “忧愁胜过欢笑，因为面容忧伤，心就更加聪明”（传道书 7:3）。“攀附的藤蔓。” “坚固的橡树。” “追逐自然，她疾驰而归。” 这种或其他类型的固定的、通常是节奏平衡的表达方式偶尔可以在印刷品中找到，确实可以在谚语书中“查找”，但在口头文化中它们并不偶尔出现。他们是不间断的。它们构成了思想本身的实质。没有它们，任何扩展形式的思想都是不可能的，因为思想就存在于它们之中。

Formulas help implement rhythmic discourse and also act as mnemonic aids in their own right, as set expressions circulating through the mouths and ears of all. ‘Red in the morning, the sailor’s warning; red in the night, the sailor’s delight.’ ‘Divide and conquer.’ ‘To err is human, to forgive is divine.’ ‘Sorrow is better than laughter, because when the face is sad the heart grows wiser’ (Ecclesiastes 7:3). ‘The clinging vine.’ ‘The sturdy oak.’ ‘Chase off nature and she returns at a gallop.’ Fixed, often rhythmically balanced, expressions of this sort and of other sorts can be found occasionally in print, indeed can be ‘looked up’ in books of sayings, but in oral cultures they are not occasional. They are incessant. They form the substance of thought itself. Thought in any extended form is impossible without them, for it consists in them.

口头模式思想越复杂，它就越有可能被巧妙地使用固定表达方式所标记。从荷马时代的希腊到当今全球的口头文化，都是如此。哈夫洛克的《柏拉图序言》(1963) 和奇努阿·阿切贝的小说《不再安逸》等虚构作品（1961）直接借鉴了西非的伊博语口头传统，同样提供了受过口头教育的人物的思维模式的丰富实例，当说话者以高智商和复杂性对情境进行反思时，他们在这些口头的、助记工具的凹槽中移动他们发现自己卷入其中。口头文化中的法律本身被铭刻在公式化的俗语、谚语中，它们不仅仅是法理装饰，它们本身就构成了法律。口头文化中的法官经常被要求阐明一组相关的谚语，他可以根据这些谚语对他面前的正式诉讼案件做出公平的判决（Ong 1978，第 5 页）

The more sophisticated orally patterned thought is, the more it is likely to be marked by set expressions skillfully used. This is true of oral cultures generally from those of Homeric Greece to those of the present day across the globe. Havelock’s Preface to Plato (1963) and ﬁctional works such as Chinua Achebe’s novel No Longer at Ease (1961), which draws directly on Ibo oral tradition in West Africa, alike provide abundant instances of thought patterns of orally educated characters who move in these oral, mnemonically tooled grooves, as the speakers reﬂect, with high intelligence and sophistication, on the situations in which they ﬁnd themselves involved. The law itself in oral cultures is enshrined in formulaic sayings, proverbs, which are not mere jurisprudential decorations, but themselves constitute the law. A judge in an oral culture is often called on to articulate sets of relevant proverbs out of which he can produce equitable decisions in the cases under formal litigation before him (Ong 1978, p. 5)

在口头文化中，用非公式化、非模式化、非助记符的术语来思考某件事，即使有可能，也是浪费时间，因为这种思考一旦完成，就永远无法有效地恢复。就像借助写作一样。它不会是持久的知识，而只是一种短暂的知识思想，无论多么复杂。口头文化中的繁重模式和共同的固定公式服务于手写文化中书写的某些目的，但在这样做的过程中，它们当然决定了可以进行的思维类型，以及智力上组织经验的方式。在口头文化中，经验是通过记忆而被智力化的。这就是为什么对于河马的圣奥古斯丁（公元前 354-430 年）以及生活在一种文化中的其他学者来说，他们具有一定的识字能力，但仍然带有压倒性的大量口头残留，当他谈到力量时，记忆量如此之大的原因之一的心灵。

In an oral culture, to think through something in nonformulaic, non-patterned, non-mnemonic terms, even if it were possible, would be a waste of time, for such thought, once worked through, could never be recovered with any effectiveness, as it could be with the aid of writing. It would not be abiding knowledge but simply a passing thought, however complex. Heavy patterning and communal ﬁxed formulas in oral cultures serve some of the purposes of writing in chirographic cultures, but in doing so they of course determine the kind of thinking that can be done, the way experience is intellectually organized. In an oral culture, experience is intellectualized mnemonically. This is one reason why, for a St Augustine of Hippo (BC 354– 430), as for other savants living in a culture that knew some literacy but still carried an overwhelmingly massive oral residue, memory bulks so large when he treats of the powers of the mind.

当然，所有的表达和所有的思想在某种程度上都是公式化的，因为每个词和词中传达的每个概念都是一种公式，一种处理经验数据的固定方式，决定了经验和反思在智力上的方式。组织起来，并充当某种助记工具。将经验放入任何文字中（这意味着至少对其进行一点改造——与伪造它不同）可以实现对它的回忆。然而，表征口语的公式比单个单词更为复杂，尽管有些可能相对简单：贝奥武夫诗人的“鲸鱼之路”是海洋的公式（隐喻），在某种意义上，术语“海”不是。

Of course, all expression and all thought is to a degree formulaic in the sense that every word and every concept conveyed in a word is a kind of formula, a ﬁxed way of processing the data of experience, determining the way experience and reﬂection are intellectually organized, and acting as a mnemonic device of sorts. Putting experience into any words (which means transforming it at least a little bit – not the same as falsifying it) can implement its recall. The formulas characterizing orality are more elaborate, however, than are individual words, though some may be relatively simple: the Beowulf -poet’s ‘whale-road’ is a formula (metaphorical) for the sea in a sense in which the term ‘sea’ is not.

口头思维和表达的进一步特征

FURTHER CHARACTERISTICS OF ORALLY BASED THOUGHT AND EXPRESSION

了解原始口头文化中思想和表达的助记基础，可以为理解口头思想和表达的公式化风格之外的一些进一步特征开辟道路。这里讨论的特征是那些将基于口头的思想和表达与基于手写和印刷的思想和表达区别开来的特征，也就是说，这些特征最有可能让那些在书写和印刷文化中长大的人感到惊讶。这些特征并不是排他性的或决定性的，而是具有启发性的，因为需要做更多的工作和反思来加深对基于口头的思想的理解（从而理解基于手写、基于印刷和基于电子的思想）。

Awareness of the mnemonic base of the thought and expression in primary oral cultures opens the way to understanding some further characteristics of orally based thought and expression in addition to their formulaic styling. The characteristics treated here are some of those which set off orally based thought and expression from chirographically and typographically based thought and expression, the characteristics, that is, which are most likely to strike those reared in writing and print cultures as surprising. This inventory of characteristics is not presented as exclusive or conclusive but as suggestive, for much more work and reﬂection are needed to deepen understanding of orally based thought (and thereby understanding of chirographically based, typographically based, and electronically based thought).

在初级口头文化中，思想和表达往往有以下几种。

In a primary oral culture, thought and expression tend to be of the following sorts.

(i) 附加而非从属

(i) Additive rather than subordinative

附加口头风格的一个熟悉的例子是创世记 1:1-5 中的创世叙述，它确实是一篇文本，但保留了可识别的口头模式。杜埃版本（1610）是在仍然存在大量口头残留的文化中产生的，在许多方面与附加的希伯来语原版（通过制作杜埃版本的拉丁语介导）非常接近：

A familiar instance of additive oral style is the creation narrative in Genesis 1:1–5, which is indeed a text but one preserving recognizable oral patterning. The Douay version (1610), produced in a culture with a still massive oral residue, keeps close in many ways to the additive Hebrew original (as mediated through the Latin from which the Douay version was made):

起初，上帝创造了天地。大地空空如也，深渊的表面一片黑暗。神的灵运行在水面上。上帝说：成为光。光就被创造出来了。神看光是好的；他将光明与黑暗分开。他称光为昼，称黑暗为夜；有一天有晚上，有早晨。

In the beginning God created heaven and earth. And the earth was void and empty, and darkness was upon the face of the deep; and the spirit of God moved over the waters. And God said: Be light made. And light was made. And God saw the light that it was good; and he divided the light from the darkness. And he called the light Day, and the darkness Night; and there was evening and morning one day.

九个介绍性“和”。《新美国圣经》（1970 年）根据书写和印刷所塑造的情感进行了调整，翻译如下：

Nine introductory ‘ands’. Adjusted to sensibilities shaped more by writing and print, the New American Bible (1970) translates:

起初，神创造天地时，大地还是一片无形的荒原，黑暗笼罩着深渊，狂风席卷水面。然后上帝说：“要有光”，就有了光。上帝看到了光是多么的好。然后神将光与黑暗分开。上帝称光为“昼”，称黑暗为“夜”。就这样，晚上过去了，早晨也过去了——这是第一天。

In the beginning, when God created the heavens and the earth, the earth was a formless wasteland, and darkness covered the abyss, while a mighty wind swept over the waters. Then God said, ‘Let there be light’, and there was light. God saw how good the light was. God then separated the light from the darkness. God called the light ‘day’ and the darkness he called ‘night’. Thus evening came, and morning followed – the ﬁrst day.

两个介绍性的“和”，每个都包含在一个复合句中。Douay 将希伯来语we或wa（“和”）简单地翻译为“和”。新美国人将其译为“并且”、“当”、“那么”、“因此”或“同时”，以提供具有分析性、推理性的从属关系的叙述流，这是写作的特征（Chafe 1982）并且看起来更自然在二十世纪的文本中。口头结构通常注重语用（说话者的便利性 – Sherzer，1974 年，长篇公众报告库纳人的口头表演，听者无法理解）。正如 Givón 所建议的（1979 年），手写结构更多地关注句法（话语本身的组织）。书面话语比口头话语发展出更复杂和更固定的语法，因为为了提供意义，它更简单地依赖于语言结构，因为它缺乏围绕口头话语的正常的完整存在语境，并有助于在某种程度上独立于语法确定口头话语中的意义。
