Two introductory ‘ands’, each submerged in a compound sentence. The Douay renders the Hebrew we or wa (‘and’) simply as ‘and’. The New American renders it ‘and’, ‘when’, ‘then’, ‘thus’, or ‘while’, to provide a ﬂow of narration with the analytic, reasoned subordination that characterizes writing (Chafe 1982) and that appears more natural in twentieth-century texts. Oral structures often look to pragmatics (the convenience of the speaker – Sherzer, 1974, reports lengthy public oral performances among the Cuna incomprehensible to their hearers). Chirographic structures look more to syntactics (organization of the discourse itself), as Givón has suggested (1979). Written discourse develops more elaborate and ﬁxed grammar than oral discourse does because to provide meaning it is more dependent simply upon linguistic structure, since it lacks the normal full existential contexts which surround oral discourse and help determine meaning in oral discourse somewhat independently of grammar.

如果认为杜埃只是比新美国“更接近”今天的原版，那就错了。它更接近，因为它总是用同一个词来表示“我们”或“wa”，但它给当今的感觉带来了遥远、古老甚至古怪的感觉。生活在口头文化或具有高度口头残留的文化中的人们，包括产生《圣经》的文化，并不喜欢这种古老或古怪的表达方式。这对他们来说感觉自然和正常，就像新美国版本对我们来说感觉自然和正常一样。

It would be a mistake to think that the Douay is simply ‘closer’ to the original today than the New American is. It is closer in that it renders we or wa always by the same word, but it strikes the present-day sensibility as remote, archaic, and even quaint. Peoples in oral cultures or cultures with high oral residue, including the culture that produced the Bible, do not savor this sort of expression as so archaic or quaint. It feels natural and normal to them somewhat as the New American version feels natural and normal to us.

世界各地的初级口头叙述中都可以找到附加结构的其他实例，我们现在有大量的磁带供应（参见 Foley，1980b，列出了一些磁带）。

Other instances of additive structure can be found across the world in primary oral narrative, of which we now have a massive supply on tape (see Foley, 1980b, for listing of some tapes).

(ii) 综合而非分析

(ii) Aggregative rather than analytic

这一特征与依赖公式来实现记忆密切相关。基于口头的思想和表达的元素往往不是简单的整数，而是整数簇，例如平行术语或短语或从句、对立术语或短语或从句、加词。口头上，尤其是在正式谈话中，人们更喜欢的不是士兵，而是勇敢的士兵。不是公主，而是美丽的公主；不是橡树，而是坚固的橡树。因此，口头表达带有大量的绰号和其他公式化的包袱，而高识字率的人则认为它们是累赘和令人厌烦的多余，因为它们的总重量（Ong 1977，第188-212页）。

This characteristic is closely tied to reliance on formulas to implement memory. The elements of orally based thought and expression tend to be not so much simple integers as clusters of integers, such as parallel terms or phrases or clauses, antithetical terms or phrases or clauses, epithets. Oral folk prefer, especially in formal discourse, not the soldier, but the brave soldier; not the princess, but the beautiful princess; not the oak, but the sturdy oak. Oral expression thus carries a load of epithets and other formulary baggage which high literacy rejects as cumbersome and tiresomely redundant because of its aggregative weight (Ong 1977, pp. 188–212).

在许多低技术、发展中的文化中，政治谴责中的陈词滥调——人民的敌人、资本主义战争贩子——让高文化水平的人认为他们是无意识的，这是口头思维过程中残留的公式化要素。苏联文化中口腔残留物含量较高（如果有所下降）的众多迹象之一是（或者是一些几年前，当我遇到它时）总是坚持说“10月26日的光荣革命”——这里的修饰语是强制性的稳定，就像荷马的修饰语“聪明的内斯特”或“聪明的奥德修斯”，或者“即使在二十世纪初的美国，“光荣的七月四日”也曾经存在于口腔残渣的口袋里。前苏联每年仍然公布苏联历史上各个经典地点的官方称号。

The clichés in political denunciations in many low-technology, developing cultures – enemy of the people, capitalist war-mongers – that strike high literates as mindless are residual formulary essentials of oral thought processes. One of the many indications of a high, if subsiding, oral residue in the culture of the Soviet Union is (or was a few years ago, when I encountered it) the insistence on speaking there always of ‘the Glorious Revolution of October 26’ – the epithetic formula here is obligatory stabilization, as were Homeric epithetic formulas ‘wise Nestor’ or ‘clever Odysseus’, or as ‘the glorious Fourth of July’ used to be in the pockets of oral residue common even in the early twentieth-century United States. The former Soviet Union still announced each year the official epithets for various loci classici in Soviet history.

口头文化很可能会问橡树为什么坚固，但它这样做是为了向你保证它们是坚固的，以保持总体完整，而不是真正质疑或怀疑其归属。（有关直接来自扎伊尔卢巴人口头文化的例子，请参阅 Faik-Nzuji 1970。）口头文化中的传统表达方式绝不能被拆除：几代人的努力让它们聚集在一起，而且除了心灵之外别无他处。来存储它们。所以士兵是勇敢的，公主是美丽的，橡树是永远坚固的。这并不是说士兵、公主或橡树可能没有其他绰号，甚至相反的绰号，但这些也是标准的：吹牛的士兵、不幸的公主也可以成为装备的一部分。对于加词得到的结果对于其他公式也得到。一旦公式表达具体化，最好保持完整。如果没有书写系统，分解思想——即分析——是一个高风险的过程。正如列维-斯特劳斯在总结性陈述中所说的那样，“野蛮的[即口头]头脑总体化”（1966年，第245页）。

An oral culture may well ask in a riddle why oaks are sturdy, but it does so to assure you that they are, to keep the aggregate intact, not really to question or cast doubt on the attribution. (For examples directly from the oral culture of the Luba in Zaire, see Faik-Nzuji 1970.) Traditional expressions in oral cultures must not be dismantled: it has been hard work getting them together over the generations, and there is nowhere outside the mind to store them. So soldiers are brave and princesses beautiful and oaks sturdy forever. This is not to say that there may not be other epithets for soldiers or princesses or oaks, even contrary epithets, but these are standard, too: the braggart soldier, the unhappy princess, can also be part of the equipment. What obtains for epithets obtains for other formulas. Once a formulary expression has crystallized, it had best be kept intact. Without a writing system, breaking up thought – that is, analysis – is a high-risk procedure. As Lévi- Strauss has well put it in a summary statement ‘the savage [i.e. oral] mind totalizes’ (1966, p. 245).

(iii) 冗余或“大量”

(iii) Redundant or ‘copious’

思想需要某种连续性。写作在文本中建立了一条心灵之外的连续性“线”。如果分心使我头脑中出现我正在阅读的材料的上下文混乱或消失，则可以通过有选择地回顾文本来检索上下文。回环可以是完全偶然的、纯粹临时的。头脑将自己的能量集中在前进上，因为它回环到的东西在其自身之外是静止的，总是可以在铭文上零碎地获得。在口语中，情况有所不同。心外没有什么可以倒回的，因为口语一说出来就消失了。因此心灵必须放慢脚步，密切关注已经处理过的大部分事情。冗余，重复刚才所说的内容，可以使说话者和听者都确定在正轨上。

Thought requires some sort of continuity. Writing establishes in the text a ‘line’ of continuity outside the mind. If distraction confuses or obliterates from the mind the context out of which emerges the material I am now reading, the context can be retrieved by glancing back over the text selectively. Backlooping can be entirely occasional, purely ad hoc. The mind concentrates its own energies on moving ahead because what it backloops into lies quiescent outside itself, always available piecemeal on the inscribed page. In oral discourse, the situation is different. There is nothing to backloop into outside the mind, for the oral utterance has vanished as soon as it is uttered. Hence the mind must move ahead more slowly, keeping close to the focus of attention much of what it has already dealt with. Redundancy, repetition of the just-said, keeps both speaker and hearer surely on the track.

由于冗余是口头思维和言语的特征，因此从深刻的意义上来说，它比稀疏线性对于思维和言语来说更自然。稀疏的线性或分析性思维和言语是人工创造，由写作技术构建。大规模地消除冗余需要一种省时的技术，即写作，它对心理施加某种压力，以防止表达陷入更自然的模式。心理可以控制压力，部分原因是手写在物理上是一个非常缓慢的过程——通常约为口头语言速度的十分之一（Chafe 1982）。通过写作，大脑被迫进入一种放慢速度的模式，这使其有机会干扰和重组其更正常、多余的过程。

Since redundancy characterizes oral thought and speech, it is in a profound sense more natural to thought and speech than is sparse linearity. Sparsely linear or analytic thought and speech are artiﬁcial creations, structured by the technology of writing. Eliminating redundancy on a signiﬁcant scale demands a time-obviating technology, writing, which imposes some kind of strain on the psyche in preventing expression from falling into its more natural patterns. The psyche can manage the strain in part because handwriting is physically such a slow process – typically about one-tenth of the speed of oral speech (Chafe 1982). With writing, the mind is forced into a slowed-down pattern that affords it the opportunity to interfere with and reorganize its more normal, redundant processes.

在大量听众面前进行口头表达的物理条件也有利于冗余，事实上，冗余比大多数面对面的谈话更为明显。即使只是因为声学问题，并不是所有听众都能听懂演讲者所说的每一个字。对于说话者来说，将同一件事或同等的同一件事说两到三次是有利的。如果你漏掉了“不仅……”，你可以通过“而且……”的推断来补充。直到电子扩音器将声学问题减少到最低限度，直到威廉·詹宁斯·布莱恩（William Jennings Bryan，1860-1925）等公共演讲者在他们的公共演讲中仍然延续着旧有的冗余，并出于习惯的力量让它们渗透到他们的写作中。在某些用于口头语言交流的声学替代物中，冗余达到了惊人的程度，就像非洲鼓的谈话一样。平均而言，用鼓来表达的单词量是用口语表达的单词量的八倍左右（Ong 1977，第 101 页）。

Redundancy is also favored by the physical conditions of oral expression before a large audience, where redundancy is in fact more marked than in most face-to-face conversation. Not everyone in a large audience understands every word a speaker utters, if only because of acoustical problems. It is advantageous for the speaker to say the same thing, or equivalently the same thing, two or three times. If you miss the ‘not only... ’you can supply it by inference from the ‘but also...’. Until electronic ampliﬁcation reduced acoustical problems to a minimum, public speakers as late as, for example, William Jennings Bryan (1860–1925) continued the old redundancy in their public addresses and by force of habit let them spill over into their writing. In some kinds of acoustic surrogates for oral verbal communication, redundancy reaches fantastic dimensions, as in African drum talk. It takes on the average around eight times as many words to say something on the drums as in the spoken language (Ong 1977, p. 101).

公众演讲者在思考接下来要说什么时需要继续讲下去，这也鼓励了冗余。在口头表达中，虽然停顿可能有效，但犹豫总是会造成阻碍。因此，最好是巧妙地重复某件事，而不是简单地停止说话而寻找下一个想法。口语文化鼓励流利、丰富、健谈。修辞学家称之为“copia”。他们通过某种监督继续鼓励这种行为，当他们将修辞从公开演讲的艺术转变为写作的艺术。从中世纪到文艺复兴时期的早期书面文本往往都充满了“夸张”，以现代标准来看，这是令人恼火的冗余。只要西方文化中存在着大量的口头残留，对复制品的关注就在西方文化中依然强烈——这大约持续到浪漫主义时代甚至更久远。托马斯·巴宾顿·麦考利（Thomas Babington Macaulay，1800-59 年）是早期维多利亚时代众多令人着迷的人之一，他的冗长的书面作品读起来仍然像热情洋溢的口头演讲一样，温斯顿·丘吉尔（Winston Churchill，1874-1965）的著作也常常如此。 。

The public speaker’s need to keep going while he is running through his mind what to say next also encourages redundancy. In oral delivery, though a pause may be effective, hesitation is always disabling. Hence it is better to repeat something, artfully if possible, rather than simply to stop speaking while ﬁshing for the next idea. Oral cultures encourage ﬂuency, fulsomeness, volubility. Rhetoricians were to call this copia. They continued to encourage it, by a kind of oversight, when they had modulated rhetoric from an art of public speaking to an art of writing. Early written texts, through the Middle Ages and the Renaissance, are often bloated with ‘ampliﬁcation’, annoyingly redundant by modern standards. Concern with copia remains intense in western culture so long as the culture sustains massive oral residue – which is roughly until the age of Romanticism or even beyond. Thomas Babington Macaulay (1800–59) is one of the many fulsome early Victorians whose pleonastic written compositions still read much as an exuberant, orally composed oration would sound, as do also, very often, the writings of Winston Churchill (1874–1965).

(iv) 保守或传统主义

(iv) Conservative or traditionalist

由于在初级口头文化中，不大声重复的概念化知识很快就会消失，因此口头社会必须投入巨大的精力一遍又一遍地讲述多年来艰苦学习的内容。这种需要建立了一种高度传统主义或保守的心态，这种心态有充分的理由抑制智力实验。知识来之不易，又弥足珍贵，社会对那些专门从事知识保护、了解并能讲述古代故事的睿智老人给予高度评价。通过将知识储存在头脑之外，写作，甚至是印刷品，降低了聪明老人和聪明老妇的形象，即过去的重复者，而有利于新事物的年轻发现者。

Since in a primary oral culture conceptualized knowledge that is not repeated aloud soon vanishes, oral societies must invest great energy in saying over and over again what has been learned arduously over the ages. This need establishes a highly traditionalist or conservative set of mind that with good reason inhibits intellectual experimentation. Knowledge is hard to come by and precious, and society regards highly those wise old men and women who specialize in conserving it, who know and can tell the stories of the days of old. By storing knowledge outside the mind, writing and, even more, print downgrade the ﬁgures of the wise old man and the wise old woman, repeaters of the past, in favor of younger discoverers of something new.

写作当然有其自身的保守性。它首次出现后不久，就冻结了早期苏美尔的法律法规（Oppenheim 1964，第 232 页）。但是，通过将保守的功能置于自身之上，文本将思想从保守的任务中解放出来，即从记忆工作中解放出来，从而使思想能够转向新的推测（Havelock 1963，第254-305页）。特定手写文化的残余口头性可以在一定程度上根据其留在头脑中的记忆负荷来计算，即根据文化的教育程序所需的记忆量来计算（Goody 1968a，第13-14页）。

Writing is of course conservative in its own ways. Shortly after it ﬁrst appeared, it served to freeze legal codes in early Sumeria (Oppenheim 1964, p. 232). But by taking conservative functions on itself, the text frees the mind of conservative tasks, that is, of its memory work, and thus enables the mind to turn itself to new speculation (Havelock 1963, pp. 254–305).Indeed, the residual orality of a given chirographic culture can be calculated to a degree from the mnemonic load it leaves on the mind, that is, from the amount of memorization the culture’s educational procedures require (Goody 1968a, pp. 13–14).

当然，口头文化并不缺乏自己的独创性。叙事的原创性不在于编造新的故事，而在于管理此时与观众的特定互动——每次讲述故事时都必须以独特的方式引入独特的情境，因为在口头文化中，必须让观众做出反应，而且往往是激烈的反应。但叙述者也会在旧故事中引入新元素（Goody 1977，第 29-30 页）。在口头传统中，一个神话有多少次重复，就会有多少次神话的小变种，而且重复的次数可以无限增加。酋长的赞美诗邀请企业家创业，因为旧的公式和主题必须与新的、往往复杂的政治局势相互作用。但公式和主题被重新洗牌，而不是被新材料取代。

Of course oral cultures do not lack originality of their own kind. Narrative originality lodges not in making up new stories but in managing a particular interaction with this audience at this time – at every telling the story has to be introduced uniquely into a unique situation, for in oral cultures an audience must be brought to respond, often vigorously. But narrators also introduce new elements into old stories (Goody 1977, pp.29–30). In oral tradition, there will be as many minor variants of a myth as there are repetitions of it, and the number of repetitions can be increased indeﬁnitely. Praise poems of chiefs invite entrepreneurship, as the old formulas and themes have to be made to interact with new and often complicated political situations. But the formulas and themes are reshuffled rather than supplanted with new materials.

宗教实践以及随之而来的宇宙观和根深蒂固的信仰也在口头文化中发生变化。当治疗时，对特定神殿的崇拜的实际结果感到失望，当治愈时，有一些罕见的、精力充沛的领导者——古迪将他们称为口头社会中的“知识分子”（1977，第30页）——发明了新的神殿和这些新的概念宇宙。然而，这些新宇宙和其他显示出一定原创性的变化是在本质上公式化和主题性的思维经济中产生的。它们很少因为新颖而被明确吹捧，而是被认为符合祖先的传统。

Religious practices, and with them cosmologies and deepseated beliefs, also change in oral cultures. Disappointed with the practical results of the cult at a given shrine when cures there are infrequent, vigorous leaders – the ‘intellectuals’ in oral society, Goody styles them (1977, p. 30) – invent new shrines and with these new conceptual universes. Yet these new universes and the other changes that show a certain originality come into being in an essentially formulaic and thematic noetic economy. They are seldom if ever explicitly touted for their novelty but are presented as ﬁtting the traditions of the ancestors.

（五）贴近人类生活世界

(v) Close to the human lifeworld

在缺乏依赖于远离生活经验的书写来构建知识的精细分析范畴的情况下，口头文化必须或多或少地密切参考人类生活世界来概念化和语言化所有知识，将外来的客观世界同化为更丰富的知识。人类之间直接、熟悉的互动。手写（书写）文化，甚至印刷（印刷）文化可以使人类产生距离，甚至在某种程度上使人类变性，在完全缺乏人类行为背景的抽象、中立的列表中逐项列出领导人姓名和政治分歧等内容。口头文化中没有比列表更中立的工具了。在第二本书的后半部分，《伊利亚特》提出了著名的船只目录——超过四百行——其中汇编了希腊领导人的名字和他们统治的地区，但在人类行动的整体背景下：人名和地名随着所做的事情而出现（Havelock 1963，第 176–80 页）。这是荷马希腊的正常且很可能是唯一可以提供此类政治信息的地方以语言形式出现的内容是叙述或家谱，这不是一个中立的列表，而是描述个人关系的记录（参见 Goody 和 Watt 1968，第 32 页）。口头文化对脱离人类或准人类活动的统计数据或事实知之甚少。

In the absence of elaborate analytic categories that depend on writing to structure knowledge at a distance from lived experience, oral cultures must conceptualize and verbalize all their knowledge with more or less close reference to the human lifeworld, assimilating the alien, objective world to the more immediate, familiar interaction of human beings. A chirographic (writing) culture and even more a typographic (print) culture can distance and in a way denature even the human, itemizing such things as the names of leaders and political divisions in an abstract, neutral list entirely devoid of a human action context. An oral culture has no vehicle so neutral as a list. In the latter half of the second book, the Iliad presents the famous catalogue of the ships – over four hundred lines – which compiles the names of Grecian leaders and the regions they ruled, but in a total context of human action: the names of persons and places occur as involved in doings (Havelock 1963, pp. 176–80). The normal and very likely the only place in Homeric Greece where this sort of political information could be found in verbalized form was in a narrative or a genealogy, which is not a neutral list but an account describing personal relations (cf. Goody and Watt 1968, p. 32). Oral cultures know few statistics or facts divorced from human or quasi-human activity.

口头文化同样没有与行业操作手册相对应的东西（事实上，即使在手写文化中，此类手册也极其罕见且总是粗糙的，只有在印刷品相当内化之后才有效存在 – Ong 1967b，第 28–9、234、258 页）。技能是通过学徒学习的（即使在高科技文化中，这种情况在很大程度上仍然如此），这意味着通过观察和实践，只需要很少的口头解释。对荷马文化至关重要的导航程序等事物的最大程度的口头表达根本不会出现在任何抽象的手册式描述中，而是出现在《伊利亚特》中的以下段落中。我。141-4，其中抽象描述嵌入在呈现人类行动的具体命令或具体行为的描述的叙述中：

An oral culture likewise has nothing corresponding to how-to-do-it manuals for the trades (such manuals in fact are extremely rare and always crude even in chirographic cultures, coming into effective existence only after print has been considerably interiorized – Ong 1967b, pp. 28–9, 234, 258). Trades were learned by apprenticeship (as they still largely are even in high technology cultures), which means from observation and practice with only minimal verbalized explanation. The maximum verbal articulation of such things as navigation procedures, which were crucial to Homeric culture, would have been encountered not in any abstract manual-style description at all but in such things as the following passage from the Iliad i. 141–4, where the abstract description is embedded in a narrative presenting speciﬁc commands for human action or accounts of speciﬁc acts:

至于现在，一艘黑色的船让我们驶向伟大的盐海

，让我们在其中谨慎地聚集桨手，然后

让我们在甲板上

让我们上船。必须有一个人作为队长，一个谋士。

As for now a black ship let us draw to the great salt sea

And therein oarsmen let us advisedly gather and thereupon a hecatomb

Let us set and upon the deck Chryseis of fair cheeks

Let us embark. And one man as captain, a man of counsel, there must be.

（引自 Havelock 1963，第 81 页；另见同上，第 174-5 页）。初级口头文化并不关心将技能知识保存为抽象的、自存的语料库。

(quoted in Havelock 1963, p. 81; see also ibid., pp. 174–5). Primary oral culture is little concerned with preserving knowledge of skills as an abstract, self-subsistent corpus.

(vi) 对抗性基调

(vi) Agonistically toned

许多（如果不是全部）口头或残余口头文化给识字者留下的印象是，他们的言语表现乃至生活方式都异常激烈。写作促进了抽象，使知识脱离了人类相互斗争的舞台。它将认识者与已知者分开。通过将知识嵌入人类生活世界，口语将知识置于斗争。谚语和谜语不仅仅用于存储知识，还用于与他人进行言语和智力战斗：说出一个谚语或谜语会挑战听众用更恰当或矛盾的谚语或谜语来代替它（Abrahams 1968；1972）。吹嘘自己的能力和/或对对手进行口头攻击经常出现在叙事人物之间的相遇中：在《伊利亚特》、《贝奥武甫》、整个中世纪欧洲浪漫史、 《姆温多史诗》中以及圣经中无数其他非洲故事（Okpewho 1979；Obiechina 1975），例如大卫与歌利亚之间的故事（撒母耳记上 17：43-7）。作为世界各地口头社会的标准，相互谩骂已经在语言学中被赋予了一个特定的名称：飞翔（或飞翔）。在美国、加勒比地区和其他地方的某些年轻黑人男性在口头文化仍然占主导地位的环境中长大，他们从事各种被称为“打”、“琼斯”、“发声”或其他名称的活动，其中一位对手试图超越另一位，诽谤另一位的母亲。打斗并不是真正的打斗，而是一种艺术形式，就像其他文化中其他风格化的言语谩骂一样。

Many, if not all, oral or residually oral cultures strike literates as extraordinarily agonistic in their verbal performance and indeed in their lifestyle. Writing fosters abstractions that disengage knowledge from the arena where human beings struggle with one another. It separates the knower from the known. By keeping knowledge embedded in the human lifeworld, orality situates knowledge within a context of struggle. Proverbs and riddles are not used simply to store knowledge but to engage others in verbal and intellectual combat: utterance of one proverb or riddle challenges hearers to top it with a more apposite or a contradictory one (Abrahams 1968; 1972). Bragging about one’s own prowess and/or verbal tongue-lashings of an opponent ﬁgure regularly in encounters between characters in narrative: in the Iliad, in Beowulf, throughout medieval European romance, in The Mwindo Epic and countless other African stories (Okpewho 1979; Obiechina 1975), in the Bible, as between David and Goliath (1 Samuel 17:43–7). Standard in oral societies across the world, reciprocal name-calling has been ﬁtted with a speciﬁc name in linguistics: ﬂyting (or ﬂiting). Growing up in a still dominantly oral culture, certain young black males in the United States, the Caribbean, and elsewhere, engage in what is known variously as the ‘dozens’ or ‘joning’ or ‘sounding’ or by other names, in which one opponent tries to outdo the other in vilifying the other’s mother. The dozens is not a real ﬁght but an art form, as are the other stylized verbal tongue lashings in other cultures.

不仅在知识的使用方面，而且在对身体行为的庆祝方面，口头文化都显示出自己是竞争性的。对身体暴力的热情描述往往标志着口头叙述。例如，在《伊利亚特》中，第八卷和第十卷至少在彻底的暴力方面可以与当今最耸人听闻的电视和电影节目相媲美，并且在精致的血腥细节方面远远超过它们，这些细节在口头描述时比在视觉呈现时更容易令人厌恶。对粗暴身体暴力的描绘是许多口头史诗和其他口头体裁的核心，并在早期识字中残留下来，但在后来的文学叙事中逐渐减弱或成为边缘。它在中世纪民谣中幸存下来，但已经被托马斯·纳什（Thomas Nashe）在《不幸的旅行者》中恶搞了（1594）。随着文学叙事走向严肃小说，它最终将行动的焦点越来越多地吸引到内部危机，而远离纯粹的外部危机。

Not only in the use to which knowledge is put, but also in the celebration of physical behavior, oral cultures reveal themselves as agonistically programmed. Enthusiastic description of physical violence often marks oral narrative. In the Iliad, for example, Books viii and x would at least rival the most sensational television and cinema shows today in outright violence and far surpass them in exquisitely gory detail, which can be less repulsive when described verbally than when presented visually. Portrayal of gross physical violence, central to much oral epic and other oral genres and residual through much early literacy, gradually wanes or becomes peripheral in later literary narrative. It survives in medieval ballads but is already being spoofed by Thomas Nashe in The Unfortunate Traveller (1594). As literary narrative moves toward the serious novel, it eventually pulls the focus of action more and more to interior crises and away from purely exterior crises.

当然，在许多早期社会中，生活中常见且持续的身体困难在一定程度上解释了早期言语艺术形式中暴力的明显证据。对疾病和灾难的身体原因的无知也会加剧个人紧张。由于疾病或灾难是由某种原因引起的，因此可以假设另一个人（魔术师、女巫）的个人恶意来代替物理原因，并且个人敌意因此增加。但口头艺术形式中的暴力也与口头本身的结构有关。当所有言语交流都必须通过直接的口口相传，涉及声音的交换动态时，人际关系就会保持高度——既有吸引力，更有什者，还有对抗性。

The common and persistent physical hardships of life in many early societies of course explain in part the high evidence of violence in early verbal art forms. Ignorance of physical causes of disease and disaster can also foster personal tensions. Since the disease or disaster is caused by something, in lieu of physical causes the personal malevolence of another human being – a magician, a witch – can be assumed and personal hostilities thereby increased. But violence in oral art forms is also connected with the structure of orality itself. When all verbal communication must be by direct word of mouth, involved in the give-and-take dynamics of sound, interpersonal relations are kept high–both attractions and, even more, antagonisms.

口头或残留口头文化中的激烈谩骂或谩骂的另一面是与口头有关的赞美的丰富表达，这种表达随处可见。它在当今被广泛研究的非洲口头赞美诗中（Finnegan 1970；Opland 1975）以及从古典时期一直延伸到十八世纪的西方口头修辞传统中都广为人知。“我是来埋葬凯撒的，不是来赞美他的”，马库斯·安东尼在莎士比亚的《尤利乌斯·凯撒》中的葬礼演说中喊道（第 ii.79 节），然后继续以颂扬的修辞模式来赞扬凯撒，这些赞美的修辞模式已深入人心所有文艺复兴时期的学生，伊拉斯谟在他的《愚人赞》中如此机智地使用了这些。古老的、残留的口头修辞传统中的过分赞美，让来自高文化文化的人觉得不真诚、浮夸和滑稽的自命不凡。但赞美却伴随着善与恶、美德与罪恶、恶棍与英雄的高度两极分化、竞争性的口头世界。

The other side of agonistic name-calling or vituperation in oral or residually oral cultures is the fulsome expression of praise which is found everywhere in connection with orality. It is well known in the much-studied present-day African oral praise poems (Finnegan 1970; Opland 1975) as all through the residually oral western rhetorical tradition stretching from classical antiquity through the eighteenth century. ‘I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him’, Marcus Antonius cries in his funeral oration in Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar (v. ii. 79), and then proceeds to praise Caesar in rhetorical patterns of encomium which were drilled into the heads of all Renaissance schoolboys and which Erasmus used so wittily in his Praise of Folly. The fulsome praise in the old, residually oral, rhetoric tradition strikes persons from a high-literacy culture as insincere, ﬂatulent, and comically pretentious. But praise goes with the highly polarized, agonistic, oral world of good and evil, virtue and vice, villains and heroes.

口头思维过程和表达的竞争动态一直是西方文化发展的核心，它们通过修辞“艺术”以及苏格拉底和柏拉图的相关辩证法制度化，为竞争性口头言语表达提供了科学基础。在写作的帮助下完成了。稍后将对此进行更多讨论。

The agonistic dynamics of oral thought processes and expression have been central to the development of western culture, where they were institutionalized by the ‘art’ of rhetoric, and by the related dialectic of Socrates and Plato, which furnished agonistic oral verbalization with a scientiﬁc base worked out with the help of writing. More will be said about this later.

(vii) 具有同理心和参与性，而不是客观地保持距离

(vii) Empathetic and participatory rather than objectively distanced

对于口头文化来说，学习或了解意味着与已知事物达成密切的、同理心的、共同的认同（Havelock 1963，第 145-6 页），“接受它”。写作将认识者与已知者分开，从而为“客观性”（即个人脱离或疏远的意义上的）创造了条件。荷马和其他口头表演者确实拥有的“客观性”是通过公式化的表达来强化的：个人的反应不是简单地表达为个人或“主观”，而是包含在集体反应中，即共同的“灵魂”。尽管柏拉图反对写作，但在写作的影响下，柏拉图将诗人排除在他的《理想国》之外，因为研究他们本质上是学习与“灵魂”做出反应，感觉自己与阿喀琉斯或奥德修斯认同（Havelock 1963，第197页） 233）。《姆温多史诗》的编辑们在处理两千多年后的另一个主要口头环境时(1971, p. 37) 提请注意史诗表演者坎迪·鲁雷克 (Candi Rureke) 的类似强烈认同，并通过他让听众与英雄姆温多 (Mwindo) 产生同样的强烈认同，这种认同实际上影响了叙述的语法，因此有时，叙述者在描述英雄的行为时会用第一人称。叙述者、观众和角色如此紧密地联系在一起，以至于鲁雷克让史诗人物姆温多亲自向记录鲁雷克表演的抄写员讲话：“抄写员，行军！” 或者“哦，抄写员，你看我已经走了。” 在叙述者和观众的感知中，口头表演的英雄甚至融入了口头世界，甚至是那些将口头表演转化为文本的抄写者。

For an oral culture learning or knowing means achieving close, empathetic, communal identiﬁcation with the known (Havelock 1963, pp. 145–6), ‘getting with it’. Writing separates the knower from the known and thus sets up conditions for ‘objectivity’, in the sense of personal disengagement or distancing. The ‘objectivity’ which Homer and other oral performers do have is that enforced by formulaic expression: the individual’s reaction is not expressed as simply individual or ‘subjective’ but rather as encased in the communal reaction, the communal ‘soul’. Under the inﬂuence of writing, despite his protest against it, Plato had excluded the poets from his Republic, for studying them was essentially learning to react with ‘soul’, to feel oneself identiﬁed with Achilles or Odysseus (Havelock 1963, pp. 197–233). Treating another primary oral setting over two thousand years later, the editors of The Mwindo Epic (1971, p. 37) call attention to a similar strong identiﬁcation of Candi Rureke, the performer of the epic, and through him of his listeners, with the hero Mwindo, an identiﬁcation which actually affects the grammar of the narration, so that on occasion the narrator slips into the ﬁrst person when describing the actions of the hero. So bound together are narrator, audience, and character that Rureke has the epic character Mwindo himself address the scribes taking down Rureke’s performance: ‘Scribe, march!’ or ‘O scribe you, you see that I am already going.’ In the sensibility of the narrator and his audience the hero of the oral performance assimilates into the oral world even the transcribers who are de-oralizing it into text.

(viii) 稳态

(viii) Homeostatic

与有文字的社会相比，口头社会的特点是处于稳态（Goody and Watt 1968，第 31-4 页）。也就是说，口语社会很大程度上生活在当下，通过抛弃不再与当下相关的记忆来保持自身的平衡或动态平衡。

By contrast with literate societies, oral societies can be characterized as homeostatic (Goody and Watt 1968, pp. 31–4). That is to say, oral societies live very much in a present which keeps itself in equilibrium or homeostasis by sloughing off memories which no longer have present relevance.

控制体内平衡的力量可以通过反映主要口头环境中的词语状况来感知。印刷文化发明了字典，其中可以用正式定义记录单词在可数据文本中出现的各种含义。因此，众所周知，单词具有多层含义，其中许多与普通现在的含义完全无关。词典宣传语义差异。

The forces governing homeostasis can be sensed by reﬂection on the condition of words in a primary oral setting. Print cultures have invented dictionaries in which the various meanings of a word as it occurs in datable texts can be recorded in formal deﬁnitions. Words thus are known to have layers of meaning, many of them quite irrelevant to ordinary present meanings. Dictionaries advertise semantic discrepancies.

口头文化当然没有词典，也很少有语义差异。每个词的含义都受到古迪和瓦特（Goody and Watt，1968，p.29）所说的“直接语义批准”的控制，也就是说，受到此时此地使用该词的现实生活情境的控制。口头思维对定义不感兴趣（Laura 1976，第 48-99 页）。词语只有从它们始终坚持的实际栖息地中才能获得意义，它不像字典中那样只是其他单词，还包括手势、声音变化、面部表情，以及真实的、口头的单词总是出现在其中的整个人类存在环境。单词的含义不断地从现在而来，尽管过去的含义当然以多种不同的方式塑造了现在的含义，但不再被认可。

Oral cultures of course have no dictionaries and few semantic discrepancies. The meaning of each word is controlled by what Goody and Watt (1968, p. 29) call ‘direct semantic ratiﬁcation’, that is, by the real-life situations in which the word is used here and now. The oral mind is uninterested in deﬁnitions (Laura 1976, pp. 48–99). Words acquire their meanings only from their always insistent actual habitat, which is not, as in a dictionary, simply other words, but includes also gestures, vocal inﬂections, facial expression, and the entire human, existential setting in which the real, spoken word always occurs. Word meanings come continuously out of the present, though past meanings of course have shaped the present meaning in many and varied ways, no longer recognized.

确实，口头艺术形式，例如史诗，保留了一些古老形式和意义的词语。但他们也通过当前的使用保留了这些词——不是普通乡村话语的当前使用，而是普通史诗诗人的当前使用，他们在特殊词汇中保留了古老的形式。这些表演是普通社会生活的一部分，因此古老的形式仍然流行，尽管仅限于诗歌活动。因此，对旧术语的旧含义的记忆具有一定的持久性，但不是无限的持久性。

It is true that oral art forms, such as epic, retain some words in archaic forms and senses. But they retain such words, too, through current use – not the current use of ordinary village discourse but the current use of ordinary epic poets, who preserve archaic forms in their special vocabulary. These performances are part of ordinary social life and so the archaic forms are current, though limited to poetic activity. Memory of the old meaning of old terms thus has some durability, but not unlimited durability.

当几代人过去，这个古老词所指的对象或机构不再是现在生活经验的一部分时，尽管这个词被保留下来，但它的含义通常会改变或干脆消失。非洲会说话的鼓，例如在扎伊尔东部的洛克勒人中使用的，以复杂的公式说话，这些公式保留了洛克勒鼓手可以发声但他们不再知道其含义的某些古老单词（Carrington 1974，第 41-2 页；Ong 1977，第94-5页）无论这些词所指的是什么，都已经从洛克勒的日常经验中消失了，剩下的词已经变得空洞了。即使在高科技文化中，从一代小孩子口口相传到下一代的韵律和游戏也有类似的单词，这些单词已经失去了原来的指称意义，实际上是无意义的音节。

When generations pass and the object or institution referred to by the archaic word is no longer part of present, lived experience, though the word has been retained, its meaning is commonly altered or simply vanishes. African talking drums, as used for example among the Lokele in eastern Zaire, speak in elaborate formulas that preserve certain archaic words which the Lokele drummers can vocalize but whose meaning they no longer know (Carrington 1974, pp. 41–2; Ong 1977, pp. 94–5) Whatever these words referred to has dropped out of Lokele daily experience, and the term that remains has become empty. Rhymes and games transmitted orally from one generation of small children to the next even in high technology culture have similar words which have lost their original referential meanings and are in effect nonsense syllables. Many instances of such survival of empty terms can be found in Opie and Opie (1952), who, as literates, of course manage to recover and report the original meanings of the terms lost to their present oral users.

Goody 和 Watt（1968，第 31-3 页）引用了 Laura Bohannan、Emrys Peters、Godfrey 和 Monica Wilson 来讲述家谱传承过程中口头文化动态平衡的惊人例子。几十年前，在尼日利亚的蒂夫人中，人们发现，在解决法庭纠纷时实际口头使用的家谱与四十年前英国人仔细记录的家谱有很大不同（因为它们在当时也很重要）。法庭纠纷）。后来的蒂夫坚持认为，他们使用的家谱与四十年前相同，并且早期的书面记录是错误的。所发生的事情是，后来的家谱已经适应了蒂夫人之间变化的社会关系：它们的相同之处在于它们以相同的方式发挥着调节现实世界的作用。过去的完整性服从于现在的完整性。

Goody and Watt (1968, pp. 31–3) cite Laura Bohannan, Emrys Peters, and Godfrey and Monica Wilson for striking instances of the homeostasis of oral cultures in the handing on of genealogies. Some decades ago among the Tiv people of Nigeria the genealogies actually used orally in settling court disputes have been found to diverge considerably from the genealogies carefully recorded in writing by the British forty years earlier (because of their importance then, too, in court disputes). The later Tiv have maintained that they were using the same genealogies as forty years earlier and that the earlier written record was wrong. What had happened was that the later genealogies had been adjusted to the changed social relations among the Tiv: they were the same in that they functioned in the same way to regulate the real world. The integrity of the past was subordinate to the integrity of the present.

Goody 和 Watt (1968, p. 33) 报告了加纳贡贾人中一个更为惊人的详细“结构性失忆症”案例。英国人在 20 世纪之交的书面记录显示，贡贾口头传说当时描述贡贾国的创始人恩德乌拉·贾克帕 (Ndewura Jakpa) 有七个儿子，每个儿子都是贡贾七个领土分区之一的统治者。国家。六十年后，当国家神话再次被记录时，七个部门中的两个已经消失，一个是由于同化为另一个部门，另一个是由于边界转移。在这些后来的神话中，恩德乌拉·贾克帕有五个儿子，但没有提及这两个已灭绝的分支。贡贾人仍然与他们的过去保持联系，在他们的神话中顽强地坚持这种联系，但过去与现在没有明显关联的部分已经消失了。当下将其自身的经济强加于过去的记忆之上。Packard (1980, p. 157) 指出，Claude Lévi-Strauss、TO Beidelman、Edmund Leach 和其他人认为口头传统反映了一个社会当前的文化价值观，而不是对过去的无聊好奇。他发现巴蜀人是如此，正如哈姆斯（Harms，1980，第 178 页）发现博班吉人也是如此。

Goody and Watt (1968, p. 33) report an even more strikingly detailed case of ‘structural amnesia’ among the Gonja in Ghana. Written records made by the British at the turn of the twentieth century show that Gonja oral tradition then presented Ndewura Jakpa, the founder of the state of Gonja, as having had seven sons, each of whom was ruler of one of the seven territorial divisions of the state. By the time sixty years later when the myths of state were again recorded, two of the seven divisions had disappeared, one by assimilation to another division and the other by reason of a boundary shift. In these later myths, Ndewura Jakpa had ﬁve sons, and no mention was made of the two extinct divisions. The Gonja were still in contact with their past, tenacious about this contact in their myths, but the part of the past with no immediately discernible relevance to the present had simply fallen away. The present imposed its own economy on past remembrances. Packard (1980, p. 157) has noted that Claude Lévi-Strauss, T. O. Beidelman, Edmund Leach and others have suggested that oral traditions reﬂect a society’s present cultural values rather than idle curiosity about the past. He ﬁnds this is true of the Bashu, as Harms (1980, p. 178) ﬁnds it also true of the Bobangi.

需要注意这里对口述家谱的影响。西非的吟游诗人或其他口述家谱学家会背诵他的听众听到的那些家谱。如果他知道不再需要的家谱，它们就会从他的曲目中删除并最终消失。政治胜利者的家谱当然比失败者的家谱更有可能保存下来。Henige (1980, p. 255) 在报道甘达和妙罗国王名单时指出，“口头模式……允许忘记过去不方便的部分”，因为“持续存在的紧迫性”。此外，熟练的口头叙述者会故意改变他们的传统叙述，因为他们的部分技能是他们适应新观众和新情况的能力，或者只是为了卖弄风情。受雇于王室家族的西非格鲁特（Okpewho 1979，第25-6页，第247页，第33页；第248页，第36页）将调整他的背诵以赞美他的雇主。口头文化鼓励必胜主义，但在现代，随着曾经的口头社会变得越来越有文化，这种必胜主义往往会有所消失。

The implications here for oral genealogies need to be noted. A West African griot or other oral genealogist will recite those genealogies which his hearers listen to. If he knows genealogies which are no longer called for, they drop from his repertoire and eventually disappear. The genealogies of political winners are of course more likely to survive than those of losers. Henige (1980, p. 255), reporting on Ganda and Myoro kinglists, notes that the ‘oral mode... allows for inconvenient parts of the past to be forgotten’ because of ‘the exigencies of the continuing present’. Moreover, skilled oral narrators deliberately vary their traditional narratives because part of their skill is their ability to adjust to new audiences and new situations or simply to be coquettish. A West African griot employed by a princely family (Okpewho 1979, pp. 25–6, 247, n. 33; p. 248, n. 36) will adjust his recitation to compliment his employers. Oral cultures encourage triumphalism, which in modern times has regularly tended somewhat to disappear as once-oral societies become more and more literate.

(ix) 情景而非抽象

(ix) Situational rather than abstract

所有概念性思维在某种程度上都是抽象的。因此，“具体”一词“树”并不仅仅指单一的“具体”树，而是一种抽象概念，是从个体的、可感知的现实中提取出来的；它指的是一个既不是这棵树也不是那棵树但可以适用于任何树的概念。我们为树设计的每个单独对象都是真正的“具体”，本身就是“具体”，根本不是“抽象”，但我们应用于单个对象的术语本身就是抽象的。然而，如果所有概念思维在某种程度上都是抽象的，那么概念的某些用途就比其他用途更抽象。

All conceptual thinking is to a degree abstract. So ‘concrete’ a term as ‘tree’ does not refer simply to a singular ‘concrete’ tree but is an abstraction, drawn out of, away from, individual, sensible actuality; it refers to a concept which is neither this tree nor that tree but can apply to any tree. Each individual object that we style a tree is truly ‘concrete’, simply itself, not ‘abstract’ at all, but the term we apply to the individual object is in itself abstract. Nevertheless, if all conceptual thinking is thus to some degree abstract, some uses of concepts are more abstract than other uses.

口头文化倾向于在情境、操作参考框架中使用概念，这些概念在某种程度上是抽象的，因为它们仍然接近人类的生活世界。有大量文献与这一现象有关。哈夫洛克（Havelock，1978a）表明，前苏格拉底时代的希腊人以操作性而非形式概念化的方式思考正义，已故的安妮·阿莫里·帕里（Anne Amory Parry，1973）对荷马对埃吉斯托斯使用的绰号“amymon”也提出了大致相同的观点：该绰号的意思是“不”。 “无可指责”，这是一个简洁的抽象概念，有文化的人用它来翻译这个词，但“美丽的战士准备好战斗就是美丽的”。

Oral cultures tend to use concepts in situational, operational frames of reference that are minimally abstract in the sense that they remain close to the living human lifeworld. There is a considerable literature bearing on this phenomenon. Havelock (1978a) has shown that pre- Socratic Greeks thought of justice in operational rather than formally conceptualized ways and the late Anne Amory Parry (1973) made much the same point about the epithet amymon applied by Homer to Aegisthus: the epithet means not ‘blameless’, a tidy abstraction with which literates have translated the term, but ‘beautiful-in-the-way-awarrior-ready-to-ﬁght-is-beautiful’.

对于目前的目的而言，关于操作思维的著作没有比 AR Luria 的《认知发展：其文化和社会基础》（1976 年）更丰富的了。在杰出的苏联心理学家列夫·维果茨基（Lev Vygotsky）的建议下，卢里亚于 1931 年对苏联乌兹别克斯坦（阿维森纳的故乡）和吉尔吉斯斯坦等偏远地区的文盲（即口语）和稍微识字的人进行了广泛的田野调查。 –2. 卢里亚的书直到 1974 年（即他的研究完成 42 年后）才出版了俄文原版，并于两年后出版了英文译本。

No work on operational thinking is richer for the present purpose than A. R. Luria’s Cognitive Development: Its Cultural and Social Foundations (1976). At the suggestion of the distinguished Soviet psychologist Lev Vygotsky, Luria did extensive ﬁeldwork with illiterate (that is, oral) persons and somewhat literate persons in the remoter areas of Uzbekistan (the homeland of Avicenna) and Kirghizia in the Soviet Union during the years 1931–2. Luria’s book was published in its original Russian edition only in 1974, forty-two years after his research was completed, and appeared in English translation two years later.

Luria 的工作为我们的运作提供了更充分的见解基于口头的思想比吕西安·莱维-布留尔 (Lucien Lévy-Bruhl, 1923) 的理论更重要，后者得出的结论是，“原始”（事实上，基于口头的）思想是“前逻辑的”和神奇的，因为它基于信仰体系而不是实践。现实，或者比列维-布留尔的反对者如弗朗兹·博阿斯（不是乔治·博阿斯，在《卢里亚 1976 年，第 8 页》中错误地提出）的建议更重要，后者坚持认为原始人的思想与我们相同，但使用了一组不同的类别。

Luria’s work provides more adequate insights into the operation of orally based thought than had the theories of Lucien Lévy-Bruhl (1923), who concluded that ‘primitive’ (in fact, orally based) thought was ‘prelogical’ and magical in the sense that it was based on belief systems rather than on practical actuality, or than had the proposals of Lévy-Bruhl’s opponents such as Franz Boas (not George Boas, as erroneously in Luria 1976, p. 8), who maintained that primitive peoples thought as we do but used a different set of categories.

在马克思主义理论的详尽框架中，卢里亚在某种程度上关注了除识字直接后果之外的其他问题，例如“以农业为中心的不受监管的个人主义经济”和“集体化的开端”（1976，第14页），以及他没有系统地根据口语读写能力的差异明确地编码他的发现。但尽管有精心设计的马克思主义框架，卢里亚的报告实际上显然转向了口头表达和识字之间的差异。他以从文盲到中等识字程度的各种程度来识别他采访的人，他的数据显然属于基于口头的意念过程与基于手写的意念过程的类别。

In an elaborate framework of Marxist theory, Luria attends to some degree to matters other than the immediate consequences of literacy, such as ‘the unregulated individualistic economy centered on agriculture’ and ‘the beginnings of collectivization’ (1976, p. 14), and he does not systematically encode his ﬁndings expressly in terms of oralliteracy differences. But despite the elaborate Marxist scaffolding, Luria’s report clearly turns in fact on the differences between orality and literacy. He identiﬁes the persons he interviews on a scale ranging from illiteracy to various levels of moderate literacy and his data fall clearly into the classes of orally based versus chirographically based noetic processes. The contrasts that show between illiterates (by far the larger number of his subjects) and literates as such are marked and certainly signiﬁcant (often Luria notes this fact explicitly) and they show what work reported on and cited by Carothers (1959) also shows: it takes only a moderate degree of literacy to make a tremendous difference in thought processes.

卢里亚和他的同事在茶馆轻松的氛围中与受试者进行长时间交谈，收集数据，非正式地介绍调查本身的问题，就像受试者熟悉的谜语一样。因此，我们尽一切努力使问题适应受试者自己的环境。这些受试者并不是所在社会的领导者，但有充分的理由认为他们具有正常的智力范围，并且相当能代表该文化。在卢里亚的研究结果中，以下内容可能值得特别关注。

Luria and his associates gathered data in the course of long conversations with subjects in the relaxed atmosphere of a tea house, introducing the questions for the survey itself informally, as something like riddles, with which the subjects were familiar. Thus every effort was made to adapt the questions to the subjects in their own milieu. The subjects were not leaders in their societies, but there is every reason to suppose that they had a normal range of intelligence and were quite representative of the culture. Among Luria’s ﬁndings the following may be noted as of special interest here.

(1) 文盲（口头）受试者通过指定物体名称来识别几何图形，而不是抽象地称为圆形、方形等。圆形可以被称为盘子、筛子、桶、手表或月亮；一个正方形可以被称为镜子、门、房子、杏晒板。卢里亚的研究对象认为这些设计是他们所研究的真实事物的代表。知道。他们从不处理抽象的圆形或正方形，而是处理具体的物体。另一方面，师范学校的学生，文化程度中等，通过分类几何名称来识别几何图形：圆形、正方形、三角形等（1976，第32-9页）。他们接受的训练是在课堂上给出答案，而不是现实生活中的答案。

(1) Illiterate (oral) subjects identiﬁed geometrical ﬁgures by assigning them the names of objects, never abstractly as circles, squares, etc. A circle would be called a plate, sieve, bucket, watch, or moon; a square would be called a mirror, door, house, apricot drying-board. Luria’s subjects identiﬁed the designs as representations of real things they knew. They never dealt with abstract circles or squares but rather with concrete objects. Teachers’ school students on the other hand, moderately literate, identiﬁed geometrical ﬁgures by categorical geometric names: circles, squares, triangles, and so on (1976, pp. 32–9). They had been trained to give school-room answers, not real-life responses.

(2) 向受试者展示四个物体的图画，其中三个属于一个类别，第四个属于另一类别，并要求受试者将相似的或可以放入一组或用一个词指定的物体组合在一起。一系列包括锤子、锯子、原木、斧头等物品的图画。不识字的受试者始终不以分类术语（三种工具，日志不是工具）来思考该群体，而是根据实际情况——“情境思维”——完全不考虑“工具”分类适用于除日志之外的所有工具。 。如果你是一个拿着工具的工人，看到日志，你会想到将工具应用到它上面，而不是让工具远离它的用途——在一些奇怪的智力游戏中。一个25岁的文盲农民：“他们都一样。” 锯子会把原木锯开，斧头会把它砍成小块。如果其中一个必须离开，我会扔掉斧子。它的工作效果不如锯”（1976，第 56 页）。当他得知锤子、锯子和斧头都是工具时，他对范畴类别不屑一顾，坚持情境思考：“是的，但即使我们有工具，我们仍然需要木材——否则我们无法建造任何东西”（同上）。当被问及为什么另一个人拒绝了另一系列中他认为所有四个项目中的一个项目时，他回答说，“可能这种想法已经流淌在他的血液中”。

(2) Subjects were presented with drawings of four objects, three belonging to one category and the fourth to another, and were asked to group together those that were similar or could be placed in one group or designated by one word. One series consisted of drawings of the objects hammer, saw, log, hatchet. Illiterate subjects consistently thought of the group not in categorical terms (three tools, the log not a tool) but in terms of practical situations – ‘situational thinking’ – without adverting at all to the classiﬁcation ‘tool’ as applying to all but the log. If you are a workman with tools and see a log, you think of applying the tool to it, not of keeping the tool away from what it was made for – in some weird intellectual game. A 25-year-old illiterate peasant: ‘They’re all alike. The saw will saw the log and the hatchet will chop it into small pieces. If one of these has to go, I’d throw out the hatchet. It doesn’t do as good a job as a saw’ (1976, p. 56). Told that the hammer, saw, and hatchet are all tools, he discounts the categorical class and persists in situational thinking: ‘Yes, but even if we have tools, we still need wood – otherwise we can’t build anything’ (ibid.). Asked why another person had rejected one item in another series of four that he felt all belonged together, he replied, ‘Probably that kind of thinking runs in his blood’.

相比之下，一个在乡村学校只学习了两年的 18 岁学生，不仅用明确的术语对类似的序列进行了分类，而且还受到攻击，坚持分类的正确性（1976，第 74 页）。一名 56 岁的几乎没有文化的工人混合了情境分组和类别分组，尽管后者占主导地位。考虑到斧头、斧头、镰刀系列要从锯子、麦穗、原木系列完成，他用锯子完成了这个系列——“它们都是农具”——但后来重新考虑并添加了关于谷物的内容，“你可以收割谷物”它用镰刀”（1976年，第72页）。抽象分类并不完全令人满意。

By contrast an 18-year-old who had studied at a village school for only two years, not only classiﬁed a similar series in categorical terms but insisted on the correctness of the classiﬁcation under attack (1976, p. 74). A barely literate worker, aged 56, mingled situational grouping and categorical grouping, though the latter predominated. Given the series axe, hatchet, sickle to complete from the series saw, ear of grain, log, he completed the series with the saw – ‘They are all farming tools’ – but then reconsidered and added about the grain, ‘You could reap it with the sickle’ (1976, p. 72). Abstract classiﬁcation was not entirely satisfying.

在讨论中，卢里亚有时会向文盲受试者传授一些抽象分类的原则。但他们的把握从来都不是当他们真正回到为自己解决问题时，他们会回归情境思维而不是分类思维（1976，第 67 页）。他们相信，除了操作性思维之外的思维，即分类思维，并不重要、无趣、琐碎（1976，第54-5页）。人们回想起马林诺夫斯基的描述（1923，第 502 页），其中描述了“原始人”（口头民族）如何为生活中有用的动植物命名，但将森林中的其他事物视为不重要的普遍背景：“这只是”衬套”。' “只是一只会飞的动物。”

At points in his discussions Luria undertook to teach illiterate subjects some principles of abstract classiﬁcation. But their grasp was never ﬁrm, and when they actually returned to working out a problem for themselves, they would revert to situational rather than categorical thinking (1976, p. 67). They were convinced that thinking other than operational thinking, that is, categorical thinking, was not important, uninteresting, trivializing (1976, pp. 54–5). One recalls Malinowski’s account (1923, p. 502) of how ‘primitives’ (oral peoples) have names for the fauna and ﬂora that are useful in their lives but treat other things in the forest as unimportant generalized background: ‘That is just “bush”.’ ‘Merely a ﬂying animal.’

（3）我们知道，形式逻辑是希腊文化在将字母书写技术内化之后的发明，从而使字母书写所带来的思维成为其思维资源的永久组成部分。根据这些知识，卢里亚对文盲对形式三段论和推理推理的反应进行的实验特别具有启发性。简而言之，他的文盲受试者似乎根本不按照正式的演绎程序进行操作——这并不等于说他们无法思考或他们的思维不受逻辑支配，而只是说他们不会将自己的思维融入逻辑中。纯粹的逻辑形式，他们似乎觉得无趣。为什么它们应该有趣？三段论与思想有关，但在实际问题中，没有人按照正式表述的三段论来运作。

(3) We know that formal logic is the invention of Greek culture after it had interiorized the technology of alphabetic writing, and so made a permanent part of its noetic resources the kind of thinking that alphabetic writing made possible. In the light of this knowledge, Luria’s experiments with illiterates’ reactions to formally syllogistic and inferential reasoning are particularly revealing. In brief, his illiterate subjects seemed not to operate with formal deductive procedures at all – which is not the same as to say that they could not think or that their thinking was not governed by logic, but only that they would not ﬁt their thinking into pure logical forms, which they seem to have found uninteresting. Why should they be interesting? Syllogisms relate to thought, but in practical matters no one operates in formally stated syllogisms.

贵金属不会生锈。黄金是一种贵金属。生不生锈？对此问题的典型回答包括：“贵金属会生锈吗？” 金子会生锈吗？（农民，18岁以上）；“贵金属会生锈。珍贵的金锈”（34岁的文盲农民）（1976年，第104页）。在有雪的极北地区，所有的熊都是白色的。新地岛位于极北地区，那里常年积雪。熊是什么颜色的？这是一个典型的回应，

Precious metals do not rust. Gold is a precious metal. Does it rust or not? Typical responses to this query included: ‘Do precious metals rust or not? Does gold rust or not?’ (peasant, 18 years of age); ‘Precious metal rusts. Precious gold rusts’ (34-year-old illiterate peasant) (1976, p. 104). In the Far North, where there is snow, all bears are white. Novaya Zembla is in the Far North and there is always snow there. What color are the bears? Here is a typical response,

'我不知道。我见过黑熊。我从来没有见过其他的……每个地方都有自己的动物”（1976，第108-9页）。你可以通过观察来了解熊的颜色。谁听说过在现实生活中推理出北极熊的颜色？另外，我怎么确定你肯定知道雪国里所有的熊都是白色的？当这个三段论第二次出现时，一位几乎不识字的 45 岁集体农场主席设法“按照你的话来说，他们都应该是白人”（1976 年，第 114 页）。“言出必行”似乎表明了对正式知识结构的认识。有点识字有很长的路要走。另一方面，主席有限的识字能力使他在人与人之间的人类生活世界中比在纯粹抽象的世界中更自在：“按你的话去做......”这是你的责任，而不是我的，如果答案就这样出来了。

‘I don’t know. I’ve seen a black bear. I’ve never seen any others.... Each locality has its own animals’ (1976, pp. 108–9). You ﬁnd what color bears are by looking at them. Who ever heard of reasoning out in practical life the color of a polar bear? Besides, how am I sure that you know for sure that all bears are white in a snowy country? When the syllogism is given to him a second time, a barely literate 45-year-old chairman of a collective farm manages ‘To go by your words, they should all be white’ (1976, p. 114). ‘To go by your words’ appears to indicate awareness of the formal intellectual structures. A little literacy goes a long way. On the other hand, the chairman’s limited literacy leaves him more comfortable in the person-to-person human lifeworld than in a world of pure abstractions: ‘To go by your words....’ It is your responsibility, not mine, if the answer comes out in such a fashion.

詹姆斯·费尔南德斯 (James Fernandez, 1980) 在提及迈克尔·科尔 (Michael Cole) 和西尔维娅·斯克里布纳 (Sylvia Scribner) 在利比里亚 (1973) 的工作时指出，三段论是自足的：它的结论仅源自其前提。他指出，没有受过学术教育的人并不熟悉这一特殊的基本规则，而是倾向于在对给定陈述的解释中，在三段论中，就像在其他地方一样，超越陈述本身，就像人们在现实生活中或在谜语中通常所做的那样（在所有口头文化中都很常见）。我想补充一点，即三段论因此就像一个文本，是固定的、封闭的、孤立的。这一事实戏剧性地体现了逻辑的手写基础。这个谜语属于口头世界。为了解开谜语，需要精明：人们利用的知识，往往是深深的潜意识，超越了谜语中的文字本身。

Referring to work by Michael Cole and Sylvia Scribner in Liberia (1973), James Fernandez (1980) pointed out that a syllogism is self-contained: its conclusions are derived from its premises only. He notes that persons not academically educated are not acquainted with this special ground rule but tend rather in their interpretation of given statements, in a syllogism as elsewhere, to go beyond the statements themselves, as one does normally in real-life situations or in riddles (common in all oral cultures). I would add the observation that the syllogism is thus like a text, ﬁxed, boxed-off, isolated. This fact dramatizes the chirographic base of logic. The riddle belongs in the oral world. To solve a riddle, canniness is needed: one draws on knowledge, often deeply subconscious, beyond the words themselves in the riddle.

(4) 在卢里亚的实地工作中，即使是对最具体的物体进行定义的要求也会遇到阻力。“试着向我解释一下什么是树。” '我为什么要？每个人都知道什么是树，他们不需要我告诉他们”，一位 22 岁的文盲农民回答道（1976 年，第 86 页）。当现实生活中的环境比定义更令人满意时，为什么还要定义呢？基本上，农民是对的。没有办法反驳初级口头世界。你所能做的就是远离它，投入读写之中。

(4) In Luria’s ﬁeld work, requests for deﬁnitions of even the most concrete objects met with resistance. ‘Try to explain to me what a tree is.’ ‘Why should I? Everyone knows what a tree is, they don’t need me telling them’, replied one illiterate peasant, aged 22 (1976, p. 86). Why deﬁne, when a real-life setting is inﬁnitely more satisfactory than a deﬁnition? Basically, the peasant was right. There is no way to refute the world of primary orality. All you can do is walk away from it into literacy.

“你会如何用两个词来定义一棵树？” '用两个字来说？苹果树、榆树、杨树。'假设你去一个没有汽车的地方。你会告诉人们什么[汽车是什么]？“如果我去，我会告诉他们公共汽车有四条腿，前面有供人们坐的椅子，有遮荫的屋顶和发动机。但当你认真思考这个问题时，我会说：“如果你坐上汽车去兜风，你就会发现答案。”受访者列举了一些特征，但最终还是回到了个人的情境体验（ 1976 年，第 87 页）。

‘How would you deﬁne a tree in two words?’ ‘In two words? Apple tree, elm, poplar.’ ‘Say you go to a place where there are no cars. What will you tell people [a car is]?’ ‘If I go, I’ll tell them that buses have four legs, chairs in front for people to sit on, a roof for shade and an engine. But when you get right down to it, I’d say: “If you get in a car and go for a drive, you’ll ﬁnd out.”’ The respondent enumerates some features but turns back ultimately to personal, situational experience (1976, p. 87).

相比之下，一位 30 岁、有文化的集体农庄工人：“它是工厂生产的。” 它一次旅行可以走完一匹马需要十天才能走完的距离——它移动得如此之快。它使用火和蒸汽。我们首先必须生火，使水变得热气腾腾——蒸汽提供机器它的力量......我不知道车里是否有水，一定是。但水还不够，还需要火”（1976，第90页）。尽管他消息不多，但他确实尝试过定义汽车。然而，他的定义并不是对视觉外观的尖锐描述——这种描述超出了口头思维的能力——而是根据其操作进行定义。

By contrast, a literate collective-farm worker, aged 30: ‘It’s made in a factory. In one trip it can cover the distance it would take a horse ten days to make – it moves that fast. It uses ﬁre and steam. We ﬁrst have to set the ﬁre going so the water gets steaming hot – the steam gives the machine its power.... I don’t know whether there is water in a car, must be. But water isn’t enough, it also needs ﬁre’ (1976, p. 90). Although he was not well informed, he did make an attempt to deﬁne a car. His deﬁnition, however, is not a sharp-focused description of visual appearance – this kind of description is beyond the capacity of the oral mind – but a deﬁnition in terms of its operations.

(5) 卢里亚的文盲很难清晰地进行自我分析。自我分析需要对情境思维进行一定程度的破坏。它要求孤立自我，每个人的整个生活世界都围绕着自我而旋转，将每种情况的中心从该情况中移开，足以让中心，即自我，得到检查和描述。卢里亚只是在与人的特征及其个体差异进行了长时间的交谈之后才提出了他的问题（1976，第148页）。一位来自山地牧场的38岁文盲男子被问到（1976年，第150页），“你是一个什么样的人，你的性格是什么样的，你的优点和缺点是什么？” 你会如何形容自己？' “我从乌奇库尔干来到这里，我很穷，现在我结婚了，有了孩子。” “你对自己满意还是想与众不同？“如果我能多一点土地，能种点小麦就好了。” 外部因素引起注意。“那你的缺点是什么？” “今年我种了一普特小麦，我们正在逐步解决缺点。” 更多外部情况。“嗯，人是不同的——冷静，脾气暴躁，或者有时他们的记忆力很差。你觉得你自己怎么样？“我们表现得很好——如果我们是坏人，没有人会尊重我们”（1976，第15页）。将自我评价调整为群体评价（“我们”），然后根据他人的预期反应进行处理。另一位36岁的农民问他是一个什么样的人，他的回答令人感动且富有人性：“关于我自己的内心，我能说什么呢？” 我该如何谈论我的性格？询问别人；他们可以告诉你关于我的事。我自己也无话可说。判断力来自外部，而不是内部。

(5) Luria’s illiterates had difficulty in articulate self-analysis. Selfanalysis requires a certain demolition of situational thinking. It calls for isolation of the self, around which the entire lived world swirls for each individual person, removal of the center of every situation from that situation enough to allow the center, the self, to be examined and described. Luria put his questions only after protracted conversation about people’s characteristics and their individual differences (1976, p. 148). A 38-year-old man, illiterate, from a mountain pasture camp was asked (1976, p. 150), ‘What sort of person are you, what’s your character like, what are your good qualities and shortcomings? How would you describe yourself?’ ‘I came here from Uch-Kurgan, I was very poor, and now I’m married and have children.’ ‘Are you satisﬁed with yourself or would you like to be different?’ ‘It would be good if I had a little more land and could sow some wheat.’ Externals command attention. ‘And what are your shortcomings?’ ‘This year I sowed one pood of wheat, and we’re gradually ﬁxing the shortcomings.’ More external situations. ‘Well, people are different – calm, hot-tempered, or sometimes their memory is poor. What do you think of yourself?’ ‘We behave well – if we were bad people, no one would respect us’ (1976, p. 15). Self-evaluation modulated into group evaluation (‘we’) and then handled in terms of expected reactions from others. Another man, a peasant aged 36, asked what sort of person he was, responded with touching and humane directness: ‘What can I say about my own heart? How can I talk about my character? Ask others; they can tell you about me. I myself can’t say anything.’ Judgement bears in on the individual from outside, not from within.

这些是 Luria 众多样本中的几个样本，但它们很典型。有人可能会说，这种回答并不是最佳的，因为受访者不习惯被问到这类问题，无论卢里亚如何巧妙地将这些问题融入谜语般的环境中。但缺乏熟悉恰恰是关键：口头文化根本不涉及诸如几何图形、抽象分类、形式逻辑推理过程、定义，甚至全面的描述，或清晰的自我分析等项目，所有这些都不仅源自思想本身，而且源自文本形式的思想。卢里亚的问题是与文本使用相关的课堂问题，实际上与识字者提出的标准智力测试问题非常相似或相同。它们是合法的，但它们来自口头受访者不共享的世界。

These are a few samples from Luria’s many, but they are typical. One could argue that responses were not optimal because the respondents were not used to being asked these kinds of questions, no matter how cleverly Luria could work them into riddle-like settings. But lack of familiarity is precisely the point: an oral culture simply does not deal in such items as geometrical ﬁgures, abstract categorization, formally logical reasoning processes, deﬁnitions, or even comprehensive descriptions, or articulated self-analysis, all of which derive not simply from thought itself but from text-formed thought. Luria’s questions are schoolroom questions associated with the use of texts, and indeed closely resemble or are identical with standard intelligence test questions got up by literates. They are legitimate, but they come from a world the oral respondent does not share.

受试者的反应表明，也许不可能设计出一种书面测试，甚至是一种在识字环境中形成的口头测试，来准确评估来自高度口语文化的人的本土智力能力。Gladwin (1970, p. 219) 指出，南太平洋的普拉瓦特岛民尊重他们的航海家，他们必须非常聪明，因为他们拥有复杂而高要求的技能，不是因为他们认为他们“聪明”，而是因为他们是优秀的航海家。当被问及对新任乡村学校校长的看法时，一位中非人回答卡林顿（1974 年，第 61 页），“让我们看一下他是如何跳舞的”。口语人士评估智力不是从人为的教科书测验中推断出来的，而是根据操作环境来评估的。

The subject’s reactions suggest that it is perhaps impossible to devise a test in writing or even an oral test shaped in a literate setting that would assess accurately the native intellectual abilities of persons from a highly oral culture. Gladwin (1970, p. 219) notes that the Pulawat Islanders in the South Paciﬁc respect their navigators, who have to be highly intelligent for their complex and demanding skill, not because they consider them ‘intelligent’ but quite simply because they are good navigators. Asked what he thought of a new village school principal, a Central African responded to Carrington (1974, p. 61), ‘Let’s watch a little how he dances’. Oral folk assess intelligence not as extrapolated from contrived textbook quizzes but as situated in operational contexts.

学生或任何其他人提出此类分析问题出现在文本性的最后阶段。事实上，这些问题不仅在口头文化中缺失，而且在书写文化中也缺失。书面考试问题在印刷术对意识产生影响后很久（在书写发明数千年后）才开始普遍使用（在西方）。古典拉丁语中没有“考试”一词，例如我们今天“参加”并试图在学校“通过”。直到西方的过去几代人，也许仍然是当今世界的大部分地区，学术实践都要求学生在课堂上“背诵”，即口头反馈给老师的陈述（公式——口头遗产）：他们是从课堂教学或教科书中记住的（Ong 1967b，第 53-76 页）。

Plying students or anyone else with analytic questions of this sort appears at a very late stage of textuality. Such questions are in fact missing not only from oral cultures, but also from writing cultures. Written examination questions came into general use (in the West) only well after print had worked its effects on consciousness, thousands of years after the invention of writing. Classical Latin has no word for an ‘examination’ such as we ‘take’ today and try to ‘pass’ in school. Until the past few generations in the West, and still in perhaps most of the world today, academic practice has demanded that students in class, ‘recite’, that is, feed back orally to the teacher statements (formulas – the oral heritage) that they had memorized from classroom instruction or from textbooks (Ong 1967b, pp. 53–76).

智力测试的支持者需要认识到，我们普通的智力测试问题是为一种特殊的意识量身定制的，这种意识深受识字和印刷的影响，即“现代意识”（Berger 1978）。来自口头或残余口头文化的高智商者可能会正常地对卢里亚做出反应正如他的许多受访者显然所做的那样，不是通过回答看似无意识的问题本身，而是通过尝试评估整个令人困惑的背景（口头思维汇总）：他问我这个愚蠢的问题是为了什么？他想做什么？（另见 Ong 1978，第 4 页）。“什么是树？” 当他和其他人都看到了数千棵树时，他真的希望我对此做出回应吗？我可以使用的谜语。但这并不是谜语。这是一个游戏吗？当然是游戏，只是口语者不熟悉规则。提出此类问题的人从小就生活在一系列此类问题中，并且没有意识到他们正在使用特殊的规则。

Proponents of intelligence tests need to recognize that our ordinary intelligence test questions are tailored to a special kind of consciousness, one deeply conditioned by literacy and print, ‘modern consciousness’ (Berger 1978). A highly intelligent person from an oral or residually oral culture might be expected normally to react to Luria’s type of question, as many of his respondents clearly did, not by answering the seemingly mindless question itself but by trying to assess the total puzzling context (the oral mind totalizes): What is he asking me this stupid question for? What is he trying to do? (See also Ong 1978, p. 4). ‘What is a tree?’ Does he really expect me to respond to that when he and everyone else has seen thousands of trees? Riddles I can work with. But this is no riddle. Is it a game? Of course it is a game, but the oral person is unfamiliar with the rules. The people who ask such questions have been living in a barrage of such questions from infancy and are not aware that they are using special rules.

在一个具有一定识字能力的社会中，例如卢里亚的臣民，文盲当然可以而且经常确实拥有其他人进行有识字的组织思维的经验。例如，他们会听到有人读过书面文章或听过只有识字者才能参与的对话。卢里亚作品的价值之一在于，它表明，至少就他而言，这种对知识组织的短暂了解已经案例表明，对文盲没有明显的影响。写作必须被个人内化才能影响思维过程。

In a society with some literacy, such as that of Luria’s subjects, illiterates can and often do of course have experience of literately organized thinking on the part of others. They will, for example, have heard someone read written compositions or have heard conversations such as only literates can engage in. One value of Luria’s work is that it shows that such passing acquaintanceship with literate organization of knowledge has, at least so far as his cases show, no discernible effect on illiterates. Writing has to be personally interiorized to affect thinking processes.

具有内化写作能力的人不仅会写，而且还会说文，也就是说，他们在不同程度上甚至以思维模式和言语模式来组织他们的口头表达，除非他们会写，否则他们不会知道这些。因为它不遵循这些模式，有文化的人认为口头思想组织是幼稚的。然而，口头思维可能相当复杂，并且有其自身的反思性。纳瓦霍民俗动物故事的纳瓦霍叙述者可以对故事的各种含义进行详尽的解释，以帮助理解人类生活中从生理到心理和道德的复杂问题，并且完全意识到诸如身体不一致之类的事情（例如，眼睛是琥珀色的土狼）以及需要象征性地解释故事中的元素（Toelken 1976，第 156 页）。假设口头民族本质上是不聪明的，他们的心理过程是“粗糙的”，这种想法几个世纪以来一直让学者们错误地认为，因为荷马史诗是如此熟练，所以它们基本上一定是书面作品。

Persons who have interiorized writing not only write but also speak literately, which is to say that they organize, to varying degrees, even their oral expression in thought patterns and verbal patterns that they would not know of unless they could write. Because it does not follow these patterns, literates have considered oral organization of thought naive. Oral thinking, however, can be quite sophisticated and in its own way reﬂective. Navaho narrators of Navaho folkloric animal stories can provide elaborate explanations of the various implications of the stories for an understanding of complex matters in human life from the physiological to the psychological and moral, and are perfectly aware of such things as physical inconsistencies (for example, coyotes with amber balls for eyes) and the need to interpret elements in the stories symbolically (Toelken 1976, p. 156). To assume that oral peoples are essentially unintelligent, that their mental processes are ‘crude’, is the kind of thinking that for centuries brought scholars to assume falsely that because the Homeric poems are so skillful, they must be basically written compositions.

我们也不能想象基于口头的思想是“前逻辑的”或在任何简单化的意义上都是“不合逻辑的”——例如，口头民间不理解因果关系。他们非常清楚，如果你用力推一个移动物体，推力就会导致它移动。事实是，他们无法以分析类型的线性序列来组织复杂的原因串联，而这种线性序列只能在文本的帮助下建立起来。它们产生的冗长序列，例如家谱，不是分析性的，而是聚合性的。但口头文化可以产生令人惊讶的复杂、智能和美丽的思想和经验组织。为了理解它们是如何做到这一点的，有必要讨论一些口头记忆的操作。

Nor must we imagine that orally based thought is ‘prelogical’ or ‘illogical’ in any simplistic sense – such as, for example, in the sense that oral folk do not understand causal relationships. They know very well that if you push hard on a mobile object, the push causes it to move. What is true is that they cannot organize elaborate concatenations of causes in the analytic kind of linear sequences which can only be set up with the help of texts. The lengthy sequences they produce, such as genealogies, are not analytic but aggregative. But oral cultures can produce amazingly complex and intelligent and beautiful organizations of thought and experience. To understand how they do so, it will be necessary to discuss some of the operations of oral memory.

口语记忆

ORAL MEMORIZATION

言语记忆技能无疑是口语文化中的宝贵资产。但言语记忆在口头艺术形式中的运作方式与过去识字者的普遍想象有很大不同。在有文化的文化中，逐字记忆通常是从文本中完成的，记忆者根据需要经常返回文本以完善和测试逐字掌握。过去，识字者普遍认为口语文化中的口语记忆通常可以达到绝对逐字重复的相同目标。在录音被知晓之前，如何验证这种重复尚不清楚，因为在没有书写的情况下，测试长段落逐字重复的唯一方法是由两个或更多人一起同时背诵这些段落。连续的念诵不能相互核对。但在口头文化中同时背诵的例子却很少见。文人很高兴简单地假设惊人的口头记忆在某种程度上根据他们自己的逐字文本模型发挥作用。

Verbal memory skill is understandably a valued asset in oral cultures. But the way verbal memory works in oral art forms is quite different from what literates in the past commonly imagined. In a literate culture verbatim memorization is commonly done from a text, to which the memorizer returns as often as necessary to perfect and test verbatim mastery. In the past, literates have commonly assumed that oral memorization in an oral culture, normally achieved the same goal of absolutely verbatim repetition. How such repetition could be veriﬁed before sound recordings were known was unclear, since in the absence of writing the only way to test for verbatim repetition of lengthy passages would be the simultaneous recitation of the passages by two or more persons together. Successive recitations could not be checked against each other. But instances of simultaneous recitation in oral cultures were hardly sought for. Literates were happy simply to assume that the prodigious oral memory functioned somehow according to their own verbatim textual model.

在更现实地评估原始口头文化中言语记忆的本质时，米尔曼·帕里和阿尔伯特·洛德的工作再次证明是革命性的。帕里对荷马史诗的研究集中了这个问题。帕里证明，《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》基本上都是口头创作，无论环境如何决定他们对写作的承诺。乍一看，这一发现似乎证实了逐字记忆的假设。《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》都是严格的格律诗。歌手如何按需创作叙事除非他逐字逐句地背下来，否则由数千个短节六音步行组成？能够按需背诵冗长格律作品的文人，已经从文本中逐字背诵它们。然而，Parry（1928，in Parry 1971）为一种新方法奠定了基础，这种方法可以很好地解释这种产生，而无需逐字记忆。正如在第二章中所见，他表明六音步不仅由单词单元组成，而且由公式、用于处理传统材料的单词组组成，每个公式的形状适合一条六音步线。这位诗人拥有大量的六音步短语词汇。凭借他的六音步词汇，只要他处理的是传统材料，他就可以无休无止地编造出正确的格律线。

In assessing more realistically the nature of verbal memory in primary oral cultures, the work of Milman Parry and Albert Lord again proved revolutionary. Parry’s work with the Homeric poems focused the issue. Parry demonstrated that the Iliad and the Odyssey were basically oral creations, whatever circumstances governed their commitment to writing. At ﬁrst blush, this discovery would seem to have conﬁrmed the assumption of verbatim memorization. The Iliad and the Odyssey were strictly metrical. How could a singer produce on demand a narrative consisting of thousands of dactylic hexameter lines unless he had them memorized word for word? Literates who can recite lengthy metrical works on demand have memorized them verbatim from texts. Parry (1928, in Parry 1971), however, laid the grounds for a new approach that could account for such production very well without verbatim memorization. As has been seen in Chapter 2, he showed that the hexameters were made up not simply of word-units but of formulas, groups of words for dealing with traditional materials, each formula shaped to ﬁt into a hexameter line. The poet had a massive vocabulary of hexameterized phrases. With his hexameterized vocabulary, he could fabricate correct metrical lines without end, so long as he was dealing with traditional materials.

因此，在荷马史诗中，对于奥德修斯、赫克托、雅典娜、阿波罗和其他人物，诗人都有绰号和动词，这些绰号和动词可以将他们整齐地融入到韵律中，例如，当他们中的任何一个人必须宣布说某事时。Meteph Polym tis Odysseus（说出了聪明的奥德修斯）或proseph polym tis Odysseus（说出了聪明的奥德修斯）在诗歌中出现了 72 次（Milman Parry 1971，第 51 页）。奥德修斯之所以被称为“Polym tis”（聪明），不仅因为他是这样的人物，还因为没有“ Polym tis”这个绰号。他不能轻易地进入米。如前所述，这些和其他荷马式绰号的恰当性被虔诚地夸大了。诗人还有数以千计的其他类似功能的格律公式，可以适应他几乎任何情况、人、事物或动作的不同格律需求。事实上，《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》中的大多数词语都是作为可识别公式的一部分出现的。

Thus in the Homeric poems, for Odysseus and Hector and Athena and Apollo and the other characters the poet had epithets and verbs which would ﬁt them into the meter neatly when, for example, any one of them had to be announced as saying something. Meteph polymtis Odysseus (there spoke up clever Odysseus) or proseph polymtis Odysseus (there spoke out clever Odysseus) occurs 72 times in the poems (Milman Parry 1971, p. 51). Odysseus is polymtis (clever) not just because he is this kind of character but also because without the epithet polymtis he could not be readily worked into the meter. As earlier noted, the appositeness of these and other Homeric epithets has been piously exaggerated. The poet had thousands of other similarly functioning metrical formulas that could ﬁt into his varying metrical needs almost any situation, person, thing, or action. Indeed, most words in the Iliad and the Odyssey occur as parts of identiﬁable formulas.

帕里的工作表明，按韵律定制的公式控制着古希腊史诗的构成，并且这些公式可以非常方便地进行转换，而不会干扰故事情节或史诗的基调。口语歌手是否真的改变了公式，使得同一故事的各个韵律规则的演绎在措辞上有所不同？或者故事是逐字掌握的，以便每次表演时都以相同的方式呈现？由于假托的荷马诗人都已去世两千多年，因此无法将他们录音作为直接证据。但直接证据可以从现代（前）南斯拉夫的现存叙事诗人那里获得，该国与古希腊相邻且部分重叠。帕里发现这样的诗人——提出口头史诗叙事，但没有文字。他们的叙事诗，就像荷马的诗一样，是格律和公式化的，尽管他们的诗韵恰好与古希腊的短音六音步不同。洛德继续并扩展了帕里的工作，建立了大量现代南斯拉夫叙事诗人的口述录音，现在哈佛大学的帕里收藏。

Parry’s work showed that metrically tailored formulas controlled the composition of the ancient Greek epic and that the formulas could be shifted around quite handily without interfering with the story line or the tone of the epic. Did oral singers actually shift the formulas, so that individual metrically regular renditions of the same story differed in wording? Or was the story mastered verbatim, so that it was rendered the same way at every performance? Since pretextual Homeric poets had all been dead for well over two thousand years, they could not be taped for direct evidence. But direct evidence was available from living narrative poets in modern (former) Yugoslavia, a country adjacent to and in part overlapping ancient Greece. Parry found such poets com- posing oral epic narrative, for which there was no text. Their narrative poems, like Homer’s, were metric and formulaic, although their verse meter happened to be a different one from the ancient Greek dactylic hexameter. Lord continued and extended Parry’s work, building up the massive collection of oral recordings of modern Yugoslav narrative poets now in the Parry Collection at Harvard University.

大多数现存的南斯拉夫叙事诗人——实际上是所有优秀的诗人——都是文盲。洛德发现，学习阅读和写作使口头诗人失去了能力：它在他的头脑中引入了控制叙事的文本概念，从而干扰了口头创作过程，而口头创作过程与文本无关，而是“对歌曲的记忆”宋”（Peabody 1975，第 216 页）。

Most of these living South Slavic narrative poets – and indeed all of the better ones – are illiterate. Learning to read and write disables the oral poet, Lord found: it introduces into his mind the concept of a text as controlling the narrative and thereby interferes with the oral composing processes, which have nothing to do with texts but are ‘the remembrance of songs sung’ (Peabody 1975, p. 216).

口头诗人对所唱歌曲的记忆是敏捷的：南斯拉夫吟游诗人“每分钟唱十到二十个十音节的诗句”是“并不罕见的”（Lord 1960，第17页）。然而，对录制的歌曲进行比较后发现，尽管韵律规则，但它们从未以相同的方式演唱两次。基本上相同的公式和主题反复出现，但即使是同一位诗人，在每次演绎中，它们也会以不同的方式缝合在一起或“狂想化”，这取决于观众的反应、诗人或场合的情绪以及其他社会和心理因素。

Oral poets’ memory of songs sung is agile: it was ‘not unusual’ to ﬁnd a Yugoslav bard singing ‘from ten to twenty ten-syllable lines a minute’ (Lord 1960, p. 17). Comparison of the recorded songs, however, reveals that, though metrically regular, they were never sung the same way twice. Basically the same formulas and themes recurred, but they were stitched together or ‘rhapsodized’ differently in each rendition even by the same poet, depending on audience reaction, the mood of the poet or of the occasion, and other social and psychological factors.

对二十世纪吟游诗人的口头采访记录补充了他们的表演记录。从这些采访和直接观察中，我们知道吟游诗人是如何学习的：通过数月甚至数年聆听其他吟游诗人的歌声，这些吟游诗人从不以同样的方式唱两次叙事，而是一遍又一遍地使用与标准主题相关的标准公式。当然，公式和主题一样是有变化的，一位诗人对叙事的狂想或“缝合”将与另一位诗人明显不同。某些短语的转折会很特殊。但本质上，材料、主题和公式以及它们的使用属于一个清晰可辨的传统。原创性不在于引入新材料，而在于将传统材料有效地融入每个个体，

Orally recorded interviews with the twentieth-century bards supplemented records of their performances. From these interviews, and from direct observation, we know how the bards learn: by listening for months and years to other bards who never sing a narrative the same way twice but who use over and over again the standard formulas in connection with the standard themes. Formulas are of course somewhat variable, as are themes, and a given poet’s rhapsodizing or ‘stitching together’ of narratives will differ recognizably from another’s. Certain turns of phrases will be idiosyncratic. But essentially, the materials, themes and formulas, and their use belong in a clearly identiﬁable tradition. Originality consists not in the introduction of new materials but in ﬁtting the traditional materials effectively into each individual, unique situation and/or audience.

这些口头吟游诗人的记忆能力是惊人的，但他们与那些与文本记忆相关的人不同。文人通常会惊讶地发现吟游诗人计划重述他所讲的故事只听过一次的故事在他听完之后往往要等一天左右，然后他自己才能重复一遍。在记忆书面文本时，推迟背诵通常会削弱记忆力。口头诗人不处理文本或文本框架。他需要时间让故事融入他自己的主题和公式中，需要时间“适应”这个故事。在回忆和重述这个故事时，他并没有从任何文字意义上“记住”另一位歌手版本中的韵律演绎——当新歌手为自己的演绎而仔细思考这个故事时，这个版本早已一去不复返了（Lord 1960，第 20-9 页）。吟游诗人记忆中的固定材料是一系列主题和公式，所有的故事都以不同的方式构建出来。

The memory feats of these oral bards are remarkable, but they are unlike those associated with memorization of texts. Literates are usually surprised to learn that the bard planning to retell the story he has heard only once wants often to wait a day or so after he had heard the story before he himself repeats it. In memorizing a written text, postponing its recitation generally weakens recall. An oral poet is not working with texts or in a textual framework. He needs time to let the story sink into his own store of themes and formulas, time to ‘get with’ the story. In recalling and retelling the story, he has not in any literate sense ‘memorized’ its metrical rendition from the version of the other singer–a version long gone forever when the new singer is mulling over the story for his own rendition (Lord 1960, pp. 20–9). The ﬁxed materials in the bard’s memory are a ﬂoat of themes and formulas out of which all stories are variously built.

洛德的工作中最有说服力的发现之一是，尽管歌手知道两个不同的歌手永远不会完全相同地唱同一首歌，但歌手会抗议他可以逐行逐字地演唱自己的歌曲版本。任何时候都可以这样说，事实上，“二十年后也一样”（Lord 1960，第 27 页）。然而，当他们所谓的逐字翻译被记录和比较时，结果发现它们从来都不相同，尽管这些歌曲是同一个故事的可识别版本。正如洛德所解释的（1960 年，第 28 页），“逐字逐行”只是一种强调“喜欢”的方式。“线”显然是一个基于文本的概念，甚至“词”作为与语音流无关的离散实体的概念似乎也有些基于文本。古迪（1977 年，第 17 页）115）指出，一种完全口头的语言，它有一个术语来表示一般的言语，或歌曲的节奏单位，或话语，或主题，可能没有现成的术语来表示“单词”作为孤立的项目，一段言语，如“这里的最后一句话由二十六个单词组成”。或者确实如此？也许有二十八个。如果你不会写，“基于文本”是一两个词吗？单独的单词作为明显离散的项目的感觉是通过写作而培养的，在这里和其他地方一样，写作是分辩的、分离的。（早期的手稿往往不会将单词彼此清楚地分开，而是将它们放在一起。）“最后一句有二十六个字”。或者确实如此？也许有二十八个。如果你不会写，“基于文本”是一两个词吗？单独的单词作为明显离散的项目的感觉是通过写作而培养的，在这里和其他地方一样，写作是分辩的、分离的。（早期的手稿往往不会将单词彼此清楚地分开，而是将它们放在一起。）“最后一句有二十六个字”。或者确实如此？也许有二十八个。如果你不会写，“基于文本”是一两个词吗？单独的单词作为明显离散的项目的感觉是通过写作而培养的，在这里和其他地方一样，写作是分辩的、分离的。（早期的手稿往往不会将单词彼此清楚地分开，而是将它们放在一起。）

One of the most telling discoveries in Lord’s work has been that, although singers are aware that two different singers never sing the same song exactly alike, nevertheless a singer will protest that he can do his own version of a song line for line and word for word any time, and indeed, ‘just the same twenty years from now’ (Lord 1960, p. 27). When, however, their purported verbatim renditions are recorded and compared, they turn out to be never the same, though the songs are recognizable versions of the same story. ‘Word for word and line for line’, as Lord interprets (1960, p. 28), is simply an emphatic way of saying ‘like’. ‘Line’ is obviously a text-based concept, and even the concept of a ‘word’ as a discrete entity apart from a ﬂow of speech seems somewhat text-based. Goody (1977, p. 115) has pointed out that an entirely oral language which has a term for speech in general, or for a rhythmic unit of a song, or for an utterance, or for a theme, may have no ready term for a ‘word’ as an isolated item, a ‘bit’ of speech, as in, ‘The last sentence here consists of twenty-six words’. Or does it? Maybe there are twenty-eight. If you cannot write, is ‘textbased’ one word or two? The sense of individual words as signiﬁcantly discrete items is fostered by writing, which, here as elsewhere, is diaeretic, separative. (Early manuscripts tend not to separate words clearly from each other, but to run them together.)

值得注意的是，在现代前南斯拉夫广泛识字的文化中，文盲歌手发展并表达了对写作的态度（Lord 1960，第28页）。他们钦佩识字能力，并相信一个识字的人可以做得更好，即在听过一遍后重新创作一首冗长的歌曲。这正是文人所不能做到的做，或者很难做。正如识字者将文学类成就归因于口头表演者一样，口头表演者也将口头类成就归因于识字者。

Signiﬁcantly, illiterate singers in the widely literate culture of mod-ern former Yugoslavia develop and express attitudes toward writing (Lord 1960, p. 28). They admire literacy and believe that a literate person can do even better what they do, namely, recreate a lengthy song after hearing it only once. This is precisely what literates cannot do, or can do only with difficulty. As literates attribute literate kinds of achievement to oral performers, so oral performers attribute oral kinds of achievement to literates.

洛德·早期 (1960) 证明了口语公式分析对古英语（贝奥武甫）的适用性）和其他人已经展示了口头公式方法有助于解释欧洲中世纪的德语、法语、葡萄牙语和其他语言的口头或残余口头成分的各种方式（参见 Foley 1980b）。全球各地的实地考察证实并扩展了帕里以及洛德在南斯拉夫所做的更广泛的工作。例如，Goody (1977, pp. 118-19) 报道了在加纳北部的 LoDagaa 中，巴格雷祈祷就像基督徒中的主祷文一样，是“每个人都“知道”的事情”，然而，调用绝不是稳定的。祈祷文仅由“十几行左右”组成，如果你像古迪一样了解该语言，并说出祈祷文的开头短语，那么你的听众可能会继续副歌，纠正他或她发现的任何错误制作。

Lord early showed (1960) the applicability of oral-formulaic analysis to Old English ( Beowulf ) and others have shown various ways in which oral-formulaic methods help explain oral or residually oral composition in the European Middle Ages, in German, French, Portuguese, and other languages (see Foley 1980b). Fieldwork across the globe has corroborated and extended the work done by Parry and, far more extensively, by Lord in Yugoslavia. For example, Goody (1977, pp. 118–19) reports how, among the LoDagaa of northern Ghana, where the Invocation to the Bagre, like the Lord’s Prayer among Christians, is ‘something everyone “knows” ’, the renditions of the invocation are nevertheless by no means stable. The Invocation consists of only ‘a dozen lines or so’, and, if you know the language, as Goody does, and pronounce the opening phrase of the Invocation, your hearer may take up the refrain, correcting any mistakes he or she ﬁnds you making. However, taping shows that the wording of the Invocation can vary signiﬁcantly from one recitation to the other, even in the case of recitations by the same individual, and even in individuals who will correct you when your version does not correspond to their (current) version.

古迪在这里的发现以及其他人的发现（Opland 1975；1976）清楚地表明，口头民族有时确实会尝试逐字重复诗歌或其他口头艺术形式。他们的成功是什么？大多数情况下，按照文学标准来看，它是最小的。来自南非的奥普兰（Opland，1976，第 114 页）报告了逐字重复的认真努力和结果：“社区中的任何诗人都会重复这首诗，在我有限的测试中，这首诗与其他版本至少有 60% 的相关性。” 在这里，成功很难与野心相匹配。百分之六十的记忆准确率在课堂背诵课文或演员表演戏剧剧本时会获得相当低的分数。

Goody’s ﬁndings here, and the ﬁndings of others (Opland 1975; 1976), make it clear that oral peoples at times do try for verbatim repetition of poems or other oral art forms. What is their success? Most often it is minimal by literate standards. From South Africa Opland (1976, p. 114) reports earnest efforts at verbatim repetition and the results: ‘Any poet in the community will repeat the poem which is in my limited testing at least sixty per cent in correlation with other versions.’ Success hardly matches ambition here. Sixty per cent accuracy in memorization would earn a pretty low mark in schoolroom recitation of a text or in an actor’s rendition of a play’s script.

许多口头诗歌的“记忆”实例被引述为诗人“先前创作”的证据，例如《芬尼根》（Finnegan，1977，第76-82页）中的实例，似乎并没有更高的逐字准确性。事实上，芬尼根仅声称“在相当于逐字重复的地方非常相似”（1977，第 76 页）和“更多的口头语言”和逐行重复超出了人们对南斯拉夫类比的预期”（1977，第78页；关于这些比较的价值以及芬尼根“口头诗歌”的模糊意义，参见Foley 1979）。

Many instances of ‘memorization’ of oral poetry adduced as evidence of ‘prior composition’ by the poet, such as the instances in Finnegan (1977, pp. 76–82), seem to be of no greater verbatim accuracy. In fact, Finnegan claims only ‘close similarity, in places amounting to word-for-word repetition’ (1977, p. 76) and ‘much more verbal and line-for-line repetition than one might expect from the Yugoslav analogy’ (1977, p. 78; on the value of these comparisons and the ambiguous signiﬁcance of ‘oral poetry’ in Finnegan, see Foley 1979).

然而，最近的研究揭示了口语民族中更准确的逐字记忆的一些例子。乔尔·谢尔泽 (Joel Sherzer，1982) 报道了巴拿马海岸附近教廷中的一个仪式语言实例。1970 年，谢尔泽录制了一个冗长的神奇青春期仪式公式，该公式由一名女孩青春期仪式专家教授给其他此类专家。1979 年，他带着自己根据该公式所做的转录回来，发现同一个人可以逐字匹配该转录，音素对音素。尽管谢尔泽没有说明所讨论的确切逐字公式在一段时间内在任何特定公式专家组中的广泛程度和持久性，但他给出的例子是逐字复制成功的明确例子。（Sherzer 1982 年引用的实例，第 3 期，来自 Finnegan 1977 年，

More recent work, however, has brought to light some instances of more exact verbatim memorization among oral peoples. One is an instance of ritual verbalization among the Curia, off the Panama coast, reported by Joel Sherzer (1982). In 1970 Sherzer had taped a lengthy magic puberty rite formula being taught by a man who was a girls’ puberty rite specialist to other such specialists. He returned in 1979 with a transcription he had made of the formula and found that the same man could match the transcription verbatim, phoneme for phoneme. Although Sherzer does not state how widespread or durable the exact verbatim formula in question was within any given group of formula experts over a period of time, the instance he gives is a clearcut one of success with verbatim reproduction. (The instances referred to by Sherzer 1982, n. 3, from Finnegan 1977, as already indicated here above, all appear ambiguous, at best, and thus not equatable with his own instance.)

另外两个与谢尔泽的例子类似的例子表明，口头材料的逐字复制不是通过仪式化的环境来促进的，而是通过特殊的语言或音乐限制来促进的。一种是来自索马里古典诗歌，它的韵律模式似乎比古希腊史诗更加复杂和僵化，因此语言不那么容易变化。约翰·威廉·约翰逊指出，索马里口头诗人“学习韵律规则的方式与他们学习语法本身的方式非常相似，甚至完全相同”（1979b，第 118 页；另见 Johnson 1979a）。他们无法说出格律规则，就像他们无法说出索马里语语法规则一样。索马里诗人通常不会同时作曲和表演，而是私下逐字创作一篇作品，然后他们自己在公共场合背诵或传给他人背诵。这又是口头逐字记忆的一个明显例子。言语在任何时间段（几年、十年左右）内的稳定性显然还有待研究。

Two other instances comparable to Sherzer’s show verbatim reproduction of oral materials fostered not by a ritualized setting but by special linguistic or musical constraints. One is from Somali classical poetry, which has a scansion pattern seemingly more complex and rigid than that of ancient Greek epic, so that the language cannot be varied so readily. John William Johnson notes that the Somali oral poets ‘learn the rules of prosody in a manner very similar, if not identical to the way they learn grammar itself’ (1979b, p. 118; see also Johnson 1979a). They can no more state what the metrical rules are than they can state the rules of Somali grammar. The Somali poets do not normally compose and perform at the same time, but work out a composition in private, word-for-word, which they afterwards recite in public themselves or pass on to another to recite.
