毫无疑问，关于字母表最引人注目的事实是它只被发明了一次。它是由一个或多个闪族人在公元前 1500 年左右发明的，在所有文字（楔形文字）出现的同一地理区域，但比楔形文字晚了两千年。（Diringer 1962，第 121-2 页，讨论了原始字母表的两种变体，北闪米特语和南闪米特语。）世界上的每一种字母表 – 希伯来语、乌加里特语、希腊语、罗马语、西里尔语、阿拉伯语、泰米尔语、马拉雅拉姆语、韩语——以某种方式源自最初的闪米特语的发展，不过，正如乌加里特语和韩语文字一样，字母的物理设计可能并不总是与闪米特语的设计相关。

The most remarkable fact about the alphabet no doubt is that it was invented only once. It was worked up by a Semitic people or Semitic peoples around the year 1500 BC, in the same general geographic area where the ﬁrst of all scripts appeared, the cuneiform, but two millennia later than the cuneiform. (Diringer 1962, pp. 121–2, discusses the two variants of the original alphabet, the North Semitic and the South Semitic.) Every alphabet in the world – Hebrew, Ugaritic, Greek, Roman, Cyrillic, Arabic, Tamil, Malayalam, Korean – derives in one way or another from the original Semitic development, though, as in Ugaritic and Korean script, the physical design of the letters may not always be related to the Semitic design.

希伯来语和其他闪族语言，例如阿拉伯语，至今还没有元音字母。今天希伯来语报纸或书籍仍然只印刷辅音（所谓的半元音 [j] 和 [w]，它们实际上是 [i] 和 [u] 的辅音形式）：如果我们遵循希伯来语的用法在英语中，我们会为“辅音”编写并打印“cnsnts”。字母 aleph 被古希腊人改编来表示元音 alpha，后来变成了我们的罗马字母“a”，它不是元音，而是希伯来语和其他闪米特字母中的辅音，代表声门塞音（英语中两个元音之间的声音）。英语“huh-uh”，意思是“不”）。在希伯来字母表的历史晚期，元音“点”、字母下方或上方的小点和破折号被添加到许多文本中，以指示正确的元音，通常是为了那些不太懂该语言的人的利益，今天在以色列，这些“要点”被添加到学习阅读的幼儿的单词中——直到三年级左右。语言以多种不同的方式组织，闪族语言的结构使得仅用辅音书写单词时很容易阅读。

Hebrew and other Semitic languages, such as Arabic, do not to this day have letters for vowels. A Hebrew newspaper or book still today prints only consonants (and so called semi–vowels [j] and [w], which are in effect the consonantal forms of [i] and [u]): if we were to follow Hebrew usage in English we would write and print ‘cnsnts’ for ‘consonants’. The letter aleph, adapted by the ancient Greeks to indicate the vowel alpha, which became our roman ‘a’, is not a vowel but a consonant in Hebrew and other Semitic alphabets, representing a glottal stop (the sound between the two vowel sounds in the English ‘huh-uh’, meaning ‘no’). Late in the history of the Hebrew alphabet, vowel ‘points’, little dots and dashes below or above the letters to indicate the proper vowel, were added to many texts, often for the beneﬁt of those who did not know the language very well, and today in Israel these ‘points’ are added to words for very young children learning to read – up to the third grade or so. Languages are organized in many different ways, and the Semitic languages are so constituted that they are easy to read when words are written only with consonants.

这种仅使用辅音和半辅音（“you”中的y ， w）的书写方式导致一些语言学家（Gelb 1963；Havelock 1963，第 129 页）将其他语言学家所称的希伯来字母表称为音节表，或者可能是音节表。无声或“简化”的音节表。然而，将希伯来字母 beth ( b )视为音节似乎有些尴尬，因为它实际上只代表音素 [b]，读者必须在其中添加单词和上下文所需的任何元音。此外，当使用元音点时，它们会添加到字母（在线上方或下方），就像元音添加到辅音一样。和现代以色列人和阿拉伯人在其他方面几乎没有达成一致，但都普遍认为都在用字母表书写字母。为了理解口头书写的发展，将闪米特文字简单地视为辅音（和半元音）字母表至少是无可争议的，读者在阅读时可以简单轻松地提供适当的元音。

This way of writing only with consonants and semi-consonants ( y as in ‘you’, w ) has led some linguists (Gelb 1963; Havelock 1963, p. 129) to call what other linguists call the Hebrew alphabet a syllabary, or perhaps an unvocalized or ‘reduced’ syllabary. However, it appears somewhat awkward to think of the Hebrew letter beth ( b ) as a syllable when it in fact simply represents the phoneme [b], to which the reader has to add whatever vowel sound the word and context call for. Besides, when vowel points are used, they are added to the letters (above or below the line) just as vowels are added to our consonants. And modern Israelis and Arabs, who agree on so little else, both generally agree that both are writing letters in an alphabet. For an understanding of the development of writing out of orality, it appears at least unobjectionable to think of the Semitic script simply as an alphabet of consonants (and semivowels) for which readers, as they read, simply and easily supply the appropriate vowels.

然而，总而言之，关于闪族字母表，希腊人在开发出第一个带有元音的字母表时，似乎确实做了一些具有重大心理意义的事情。哈夫洛克（Havelock，1976）认为，这个词从声音到视觉的这一至关重要的、几乎完全的转变赋予了古希腊文化相对于其他古代文化的知识优势。闪米特文字的读者必须利用非文本和文本数据：他必须知道他正在阅读的语言，才能知道在辅音之间提供什么元音。闪米特文字仍然非常沉浸在非文本的人类生活世界中。有声希腊字母与那个世界更加遥远（正如柏拉图的想法一样）。它将声音更抽象地分析为纯粹的空间成分。它甚至可以用来书写或阅读人们不知道的语言中的单词（考虑到由于语言之间的音素差异而导致的一些不准确）。小孩子在很小的时候就可以学习希腊字母，他们的词汇量有限。（刚刚注意到，对于以色列学童来说，大约三年级的元音“点”必须添加到普通的辅音希伯来文字中。）希腊字母表的民主化是因为它对每个人来说都很容易学习。它还国际化，因为它甚至提供了一种处理外语的方式。希腊人将难以捉摸的声音世界抽象地分析为视觉等价物（当然，并不完美，但实际上完全）的这一成就既预示并实现了他们进一步的分析探索。小孩子在很小的时候就可以学习希腊字母，他们的词汇量有限。（刚刚注意到，对于以色列学童来说，大约三年级的元音“点”必须添加到普通的辅音希伯来文字中。）希腊字母表的民主化是因为它对每个人来说都很容易学习。它还国际化，因为它甚至提供了一种处理外语的方式。希腊人将难以捉摸的声音世界抽象地分析为视觉等价物（当然，并不完美，但实际上完全）的这一成就既预示并实现了他们进一步的分析探索。小孩子在很小的时候就可以学习希腊字母，他们的词汇量有限。（刚刚注意到，对于以色列学童来说，大约三年级的元音“点”必须添加到普通的辅音希伯来文字中。）希腊字母表的民主化是因为它对每个人来说都很容易学习。它还国际化，因为它甚至提供了一种处理外语的方式。希腊人将难以捉摸的声音世界抽象地分析为视觉等价物（当然，并不完美，但实际上完全）的这一成就既预示并实现了他们进一步的分析探索。（刚刚注意到，对于以色列学童来说，大约三年级的元音“点”必须添加到普通的辅音希伯来文字中。）希腊字母表的民主化是因为它对每个人来说都很容易学习。它还国际化，因为它甚至提供了一种处理外语的方式。希腊人将难以捉摸的声音世界抽象地分析为视觉等价物（当然，并不完美，但实际上完全）的这一成就既预示并实现了他们进一步的分析探索。（刚刚注意到，对于以色列学童来说，大约三年级的元音“点”必须添加到普通的辅音希伯来文字中。）希腊字母表的民主化是因为它对每个人来说都很容易学习。它还国际化，因为它甚至提供了一种处理外语的方式。希腊人将难以捉摸的声音世界抽象地分析为视觉等价物（当然，并不完美，但实际上完全）的这一成就既预示并实现了他们进一步的分析探索。

When this is all said, however, about the Semitic alphabet, it does appear that the Greeks did something of major psychological importance when they developed the ﬁrst alphabet complete with vowels. Havelock (1976) believes that this crucial, more nearly total transformation of the word from sound to sight gave ancient Greek culture its intellectual ascendancy over other ancient cultures. The reader of Semitic writing had to draw on non-textual as well as textual data: he had to know the language he was reading in order to know what vowels to supply between the consonants. Semitic writing was still very much immersed in the non-textual human lifeworld. The vocalic Greek alphabet was more remote from that world (as Plato’s ideas were to be). It analyzed sound more abstractly into purely spatial components. It could be used to write or read words even from languages one did not know (allowing for some inaccuracies due to phonemic differences between languages). Little children could acquire the Greek alphabet when they were very young and their vocabulary limited. (It has just been noted that for Israeli schoolchildren to about the third grade vowel ‘points’ have to be added to the ordinary consonantal Hebrew script.) The Greek alphabet was democratizing in the sense that it was easy for everyone to learn. It was also internationalizing in that it provided a way of processing even foreign tongues. This Greek achievement in abstractly analyzing the elusive world of sound into visual equivalents (not perfectly, of course, but in effect fully) both presaged and implemented their further analytic exploits.

希腊语言的结构，即它并非基于像闪族语言那样允许在书写中省略元音的系统这一事实，似乎被证明是一个也许是偶然的，但却是至关重要的智力优势。Kerckhove (1981) 认为，与其他书写系统相比，完全拼音字母表更有利于大脑左半球的活动，因此从神经生理学角度来看，可以培养抽象的分析思维。

It appears that the structure of the Greek language, the fact that it was not based on a system like the Semitic that was hospitable to omission of vowels from writing, turned out to be a perhaps accidental but crucial intellectual advantage. Kerckhove (1981) has suggested that, more than other writing systems, the completely phonetic alphabet favors left-hemisphere activity in the brain, and thus on neurophysiological grounds fosters abstract, analytic thought.

如果我们反思声音的本质，就可以感觉到为什么字母表发明得这么晚以及为什么它只发明了一次。因为字母表比其他文字更直接地对声音进行操作，将声音直接简化为空间等价物，并且以比音节更小、更具分析性、更易于管理的单位：而不是一个声音符号 ba ，你有两个，b加一个.

The reason why the alphabet was invented so late and why it was invented only once can be sensed if we reﬂect on the nature of sound. For the alphabet operates more directly on sound as sound than the other scripts, reducing sound directly to spatial equivalents, and in smaller, more analytic, more manageable units than a syllabary: instead of one symbol for the sound ba, you have two, b plus a.

正如前面所解释的，声音只有在消失时才存在。我无法同时出现所有的单词：当我说“存在”时，当我到达“-时态”时，“存在-”已经消失了。字母表意味着事情并非如此，一个词是一个事物，而不是一个事件，它同时存在，并且它可以被切成小块，甚至可以向前写并向后发音：'par -t' 可以发音为“陷阱”。如果您将“part”一词放在录音带上并将磁带反转，您不会得到“trap”，而是完全不同的声音，既不是“part”也不是“trap”。例如，一张鸟的图片不会将声音减少到空间，因为它代表一个物体，而不是一个单词。它将相当于任意数量的单词，具体取决于用于解释它的语言：oiseau、乌切洛、帕哈罗、沃格尔、萨伊、托里，“鸟”。

Sound, as has earlier been explained, exists only when it is going out of existence. I cannot have all of a word present at once: when I say ‘existence’, by the time I get to the ‘-tence’, the ‘exis-’ is gone. The alphabet implies that matters are otherwise, that a word is a thing, not an event, that it is present all at once, and that it can be cut up into little pieces, which can even be written forwards and pronounced backwards: ‘p-a-r-t’ can be pronounced ‘trap’. If you put the word ‘part’ on a sound tape and reverse the tape, you do not get ‘trap’, but a completely different sound, neither ‘part’ nor ‘trap’. A picture, say, of a bird does not reduce sound to space, for it represents an object, not a word. It will be the equivalent of any number of words, depending on the language used to interpret it: oiseau, uccello, pájaro, Vogel, sae, tori, ‘bird’.

所有文字都以某种方式将文字表示为事物、静止的物体、可供视觉同化的静止标记。在一些象形文字中不规则地出现的画谜或表音文字，通过一个单词的图像来代表另一个单词的声音（在上面使用的虚构例子中，一只脚的“脚底”代表与身体配对的“灵魂”）。但是画画（留声机）虽然可能代表多种事物，但仍然是它所代表的其中一种事物的图画。字母表虽然可能源自象形文字，但它已经失去了与事物本身的所有联系。它将声音本身呈现为一种事物，将转瞬即逝的声音世界转变为静止的、准永久的空间世界。

All script represents words as in some way things, quiescent objects, immobile marks for assimilation by vision. Rebuses or phonograms, which occur irregularly in some pictographic writing, represent the sound of one word by the picture of another (the ‘sole’ of a foot representing the ‘soul’ as paired with body, in the ﬁctitious example used above). But the rebus (phonogram), though it may represent several things, is still a picture of one of the things it represents. The alphabet, though it probably derives from pictograms, has lost all connection with things as things. It represents sound itself as a thing, transforming the evanescent world of sound to the quiescent, quasi-permanent world of space.

由古代闪米特人发明并由古希腊人完善的拼音字母表是迄今为止所有书写系统中最能将声音简化为可见形式的书写系统。它或许也是所有主要书写系统中最不美观的：它可以设计精美，但永远不会像汉字那样精致。这是一个民主化的脚本，每个人都很容易学习。与许多其他书写系统一样，汉字书写本质上是精英主义的：要彻底掌握它需要长时间的闲暇。字母表的民主化品质可见一斑在韩国。在韩国书籍和报纸中，文本是按字母顺序拼写的单词和数百个不同的汉字的混合体。但所有的公共标志总是只用字母书写，几乎每个人都能读懂，因为小学低年级就完全掌握了字母，而除了字母外，阅读大多数韩文文学作品还最少需要1800 个汉字。 ，通常不会在中学毕业之前全部掌握。

The phonetic alphabet invented by ancient Semites and perfected by ancient Greeks, is by far the most adaptable of all writing systems in reducing sound to visible form. It is perhaps also the least aesthetic of all major writing systems: it can be beautifully designed, but never so exquisitely as Chinese characters. It is a democratizing script, easy for everybody to learn. Chinese character writing, like many other writing systems, is intrinsically élitist: to master it thoroughly requires protracted leisure. The democratizing quality of the alphabet can be seen in South Korea. In Korean books and newspapers the text is a mixture of alphabetically spelt words and hundreds of different Chinese characters. But all public signs are always written in the alphabet alone, which virtually everyone can read since it is completely mastered in the lower grades of elementary school, whereas the 1800 han, or Chinese characters, minimally needed besides the alphabet for reading most literature in Korean, are not commonly all mastered before the end of secondary school.

也许字母史上最引人注目的单一成就是在韩国，1443 年，李朝世宗国王下令为朝鲜语设计一种字母表。到那时，韩语只用汉字书写，费力地适应韩语词汇（并与之互动），韩语是一种与汉语完全无关的语言（尽管它有许多汉语外来词，大部分都韩语化了，以至于中国人都无法理解）。成千上万的韩国人——所有会写字的韩国人——已经或正在花费大半生的时间来掌握复杂的中韩书法。他们不太可能欢迎新的书写系统，因为新的书写系统会使他们辛苦获得的技能变得过时。但李朝是强大的，而世宗面对大规模的预期抵抗所颁布的法令表明他拥有相当强大的自我结构。字母表适应特定语言通常需要很多年或几代人的时间。世宗的学者们在三年内就准备好了韩文字母表，这是一项了不起的成就，它几乎完美地适应了韩文音素，并且经过美学设计，产生了一种具有汉字文本外观的字母文字。但这一非凡成就的受欢迎程度是可以预见的。字母表仅用于非学术的、实用的、粗俗的目的。“严肃的”作家继续使用他们辛辛苦苦训练出来的汉字写作。严肃的文学是精英主义的，也希望被称为精英主义的。直到二十世纪，随着韩国进一步民主化，字母表才取得了目前的（仍不是完全的）优势。

Perhaps the most remarkable single achievement in the history of the alphabet was in Korea, where in  1443 King Sejong of the Yi Dynasty decreed that an alphabet should be devised for Korean. Up to that time Korean had been written only with Chinese characters, laboriously adapted to ﬁt (and interact with) the vocabulary of Korean, a language not at all related to Chinese (though it has many Chinese loan words, mostly so Koreanized as to be incomprehensible to any Chinese). Thousands upon thousands of Koreans – all Koreans who could write – had spent or were spending the better part of their lives mastering the complicated Sino-Korean chirography. They were hardly likely to welcome a new writing system which would render their laboriously acquired skills obsolete. But the Yi Dynasty was powerful and Sejong’s decree in the face of massive anticipated resistance suggests that he had comparably powerful ego structures. The accommodation of the alphabet to a given language has generally taken many years, or generations. Sejong’s assembly of scholars had the Korean alphabet ready in three years, a masterful achievement, virtually perfect in its accommodation to Korean phonemics and aesthetically designed to produce an alphabetic script with something of the appearance of a text in Chinese characters. But the reception of this remarkable achievement was predictable. The alphabet was used only for unscholarly, practical, vulgarian purposes. ‘Serious’ writers continued to use the Chinese character writing in which they had so laboriously trained themselves. Serious literature was élitist and wanted to be known as élitist. Only in the twentieth century, with the greater democratization of Korea, did the alphabet achieve its present (still less than total) ascendancy.

识字的开始

THE ONSET OF LITERACY

当任何类型的完全成形的文字，无论是字母文字还是其他文字，首次从外部进入特定社会时，它首先必然是在受限制的领域内进行，并产生不同的影响和含义。写作通常首先被视为一种秘密和魔力的工具（Goody 1968b，第 236 页）。这种早期对写作的态度的痕迹仍然可以从词源上表现出来：中古英语的“grammarye”或语法，指的是书本学习，后来意味着神秘或魔法知识，并且通过一种苏格兰辩证形式出现在我们现在的英语词汇中，如“魅力（施法能力）。“魅力女孩”实际上是语法女孩。中世纪北欧的富萨克或符文字母通常与魔法联系在一起。文字碎片被用作魔法护身符（Goody 1968b，第 201-3 页），但它们也可以仅仅因为它们赋予词语奇妙的持久性而受到重视。尼日利亚小说家奇努阿·阿切贝 (Chinua Achebe) 描述了在伊博人的一个村庄里，一个懂得读书的人如何将他收到的每一点印刷材料——报纸、纸箱、收据——藏在家里（Achebe 1961，第 120-1 页）。这一切似乎太非凡了，无法丢弃。

When a fully formed script of any sort, alphabetic or other, ﬁrst makes its way from outside into a particular society, it does so necessarily at ﬁrst in restricted sectors and with varying effects and implications. Writing is often regarded at ﬁrst as an instrument of secret and magic power (Goody 1968b, p. 236). Traces of this early attitude toward writing can still show etymologically: the Middle English ‘grammarye’ or grammar, referring to book-learning, came to mean occult or magical lore, and through one Scottish dialectical form has emerged in our present English vocabulary as ‘glamor’ (spell-casting power). ‘Glamor girls’ are really grammar girls. The futhark or runic alphabet of medieval Northern Europe was commonly associated with magic. Scraps of writing are used as magic amulets (Goody 1968b, pp. 201– 3), but they also can be valued simply because of the wonderful permanence they confer on words. The Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe describes how in an Ibo village the one man who knew how to read hoarded in his house every bit of printed material that came his way – newspapers, cartons, receipts (Achebe 1961, pp. 120–1). It all seemed too remarkable to throw away.

一些识字能力有限的社会认为写作对于粗心的读者来说是危险的，需要一个像大师一样的人物在读者和文本之间进行调解（Goody and Watt 1968，p.13）。识字能力可能仅限于神职人员等特殊群体（Tambiah 1968，第 113-14 页）。文本可以被认为具有内在的宗教价值：文盲通过在额头上摩擦书或从旋转的转经筒上获得他们无法阅读的文本来获利（Goody 1968a，第15-16页）。西藏僧侣过去常常坐在溪边“用木刻版块在水面上印出咒语和公式”（Goody 1968a，第 16 页，引用 RB Eckvall）。南太平洋一些岛屿上仍然盛行的“货物崇拜”是众所周知的：文盲或半文盲认为商业票据——订单、提单、收据、等等——他们知道航运业务中的数字是让船只和货物从大洋彼岸运来的神奇工具，他们精心设计了各种操纵书面文本的仪式，希望货物能够为他们自己拥有和使用（梅吉特1968 年，第 300-9 页）。在古希腊文化中，哈夫洛克发现了限制读写能力的一般模式适用于许多其他文化：在书写引入后不久，“手工艺读写能力”就发展起来（Havelock 1963；参见 Havelock 和 Herschell 1978）。在这个阶段，写作是工匠从事的行业，其他人雇用工匠来写信或文件，就像他们雇用石匠建造房屋或造船匠建造船只一样。这就是从中世纪到二十世纪西非王国（例如马里）的情况（Wilks 1968；Goody 1968b）。在这样的手艺素养阶段，个人不需要比任何其他行业更多地了解阅读和写作。仅在古希腊柏拉图时代，即希腊字母引入三个多世纪后，

Some societies of limited literacy have regarded writing as dangerous to the unwary reader, demanding a guru-like ﬁgure to mediate between reader and text (Goody and Watt 1968, p. 13). Literacy can be restricted to special groups such as the clergy (Tambiah 1968, pp. 113– 14). Texts can be felt to have intrinsic religious value: illiterates proﬁt from rubbing the book on their foreheads, or from whirling prayerwheels bearing texts they cannot read (Goody 1968a, pp. 15–16). Tibetan monks used to sit on the banks of streams ‘printing pages of charms and formulas on the surface of the water with woodcut blocks’ (Goody 1968a, p. 16, quoting R. B. Eckvall). The still ﬂourishing ‘cargo cults’ of some South Paciﬁc islands are well known: illiterates or semiliterates think that the commercial papers – orders, bills of lading, receipts, and the like – that they know ﬁgure in shipping operations are magical instruments to make ships and cargo come in from across the sea, and they elaborate various rituals manipulating written texts in the hope that cargo will turn up for their own possession and use (Meggitt 1968, pp. 300–9). In ancient Greek culture Havelock discovers a general pattern of restricted literacy applicable to many other cultures: shortly after the introduction of writing a ‘craft literacy’ develops (Havelock 1963; cf. Havelock and Herschell 1978). At this stage writing is a trade practiced by craftsmen, whom others hire to write a letter or document as they might hire a stone-mason to build a house, or a shipwright to build a boat. Such was the state of affairs in West African kingdoms, such as Mali, from the Middle Ages into the twentieth century (Wilks 1968; Goody 1968b). At such a craft-literacy stage, there is no need for an individual to know reading and writing any more than any other trade. Only around Plato’s time in ancient Greece, more than three centuries after the introduction of the Greek alphabet, was this stage transcended when writing was ﬁnally diffused through the Greek population and interiorized enough to affect thought processes generally (Havelock 1963).

早期书写材料的物理特性促进了抄写文化的延续（参见 Clanchy 1979，第 88-115 页，关于“书写技术”）。早期作家没有使用表面均匀的机制纸和相对耐用的圆珠笔，而是使用了更顽固的技术设备。对于书写表面，他使用湿粘土砖、动物皮（羊皮纸、羊皮纸），刮去脂肪和毛发，通常用浮石平滑，用粉笔增白，经常通过刮掉早期的文本（重写）进行重新处理。或者他有树皮、纸莎草（比大多数表面更好，但按照高技术标准仍然粗糙）、干树叶或其他植被、蜡层在木板上，通常铰接形成双联画，戴在腰带上（这些蜡板用于对于笔记，蜡被再次平滑以供重复使用），木棒（Clanchy 1979，第 95 页）和其他各种木制和石头表面。街角没有卖垫纸的文具店。没有纸。作为书写工具，抄写员使用各种铁笔、鹅毛笔，必须用我们仍然称为“钢笔刀”、刷子（特别是在东亚）或各种其他用于切割表面的工具一遍又一遍地切割和磨尖它们。和/或涂抹油墨或油漆。液体墨水以各种方式混合，准备用于空心牛角（墨角）或其他耐酸容器中，或者，通常在东亚，将画笔润湿并涂抹在干墨块上，就像水彩画一样。作为书写工具，抄写员使用各种铁笔、鹅毛笔，必须用我们仍然称为“钢笔刀”、刷子（特别是在东亚）或各种其他用于切割表面的工具一遍又一遍地切割和磨尖它们。和/或涂抹油墨或油漆。液体墨水以各种方式混合，准备用于空心牛角（墨角）或其他耐酸容器中，或者，通常在东亚，将画笔润湿并涂抹在干墨块上，就像水彩画一样。作为书写工具，抄写员使用各种铁笔、鹅毛笔，必须用我们仍然称为“钢笔刀”、刷子（特别是在东亚）或各种其他用于切割表面的工具一遍又一遍地切割和磨尖它们。和/或涂抹油墨或油漆。液体墨水以各种方式混合，准备用于空心牛角（墨角）或其他耐酸容器中，或者，通常在东亚，将画笔润湿并涂抹在干墨块上，就像水彩画一样。

The physical properties of early writing materials encouraged the continuance of scribal culture (see Clanchy 1979, pp. 88–115, on ‘The technology of writing’). Instead of evenly surfaced machine-made paper and relatively durable ball-point pens, the early writer had more recalcitrant technological equipment. For writing surfaces, he had wet clay bricks, animal skins (parchment, vellum) scraped free of fat and hair, often smoothed with pumice and whitened with chalk, frequently reprocessed by scraping off an earlier text (palimpsests). Or he had the bark of trees, papyrus (better than most surfaces but still rough by high technology standards), dried leaves or other vegetation, wax layered onto wooden tablets often hinged to form a diptych worn on a belt (these wax tablets were used for notes, the wax being smoothed over again for re-use), wooden rods (Clanchy 1979, p. 95) and other wooden and stone surfaces of various sorts. There were no corner stationery stores selling pads of paper. There was no paper. As inscribing tools the scribes had various kinds of styli, goose quills which had to be slit and sharpened over and over again with what we still call a ‘pen knife’, brushes (particularly in East Asia), or various other instruments for incising surfaces and/or spreading inks or paints. Fluid inks were mixed in various ways and readied for use into hollow bovine horns (inkhorns) or in other acid resistant containers, or, commonly in East Asia, brushes were wetted and dabbed on dry ink blocks, as in watercolor painting.

使用此类书写材料需要特殊的机械技能，但并非所有“作家”都具备适合长时间写作的技能。纸使书写变得更容易。但是，纸可能在公元前二世纪在中国制造，并在公元八世纪由阿拉伯人传播到中东，直到十二世纪才在欧洲首次制造。

Special mechanical skills were required for working with such writing materials, and not all ‘writers’ had such skills suitably developed for protracted composition. Paper made writing physically easier. But paper, manufactured in China probably by the second century BC and diffused by Arabs to the Middle East by the eighth century of the Christian era, was ﬁrst manufactured in Europe only in the twelfth century.

长期的口头思考的口头思维习惯鼓励听写，但书写技术的状况也鼓励听写。中世纪英国人奥德里克·维塔利斯 (Orderic Vitalis) 说，在书写的身体动作中，“整个身体都在劳作”（Clanchy 1979，第 90 页）。整个中世纪的欧洲作家经常雇用抄写员。当然，书面写作，即用笔表达自己的思想，尤其是简短的写作，在某种程度上从古代就开始实行，但它在不同时期、不同文化中在文学和其他长篇写作中变得普遍。这在十一世纪的英国仍然很少见，而且当它发生时，即使是这么晚，也可以在口头上进行的心理环境中完成，以至于我们很难想象。十一世纪的圣奥尔本斯的埃德默说，当他写作时，他觉得他在对自己发号施令（Clanchy 1979，第 218 页）。圣托马斯·阿奎那亲自撰写了手稿，并组织了他的准口头形式的神学大全：每个部分或“问题”都以反对托马斯将采取的立场的反对意见开始，然后托马斯陈述他的立场，最后按顺序回答反对意见。同样，早期诗人会想象自己向观众朗诵一首诗，从而写下这首诗。如今，很少有小说家通过想象自己大声朗诵来写小说，尽管他们可能非常清楚单词的声音效果。高读写能力培养真正的书面写作，即作者撰写的文本正是文本，将他或她的文字放在纸上。这赋予思维与口头持续思维不同的轮廓。稍后我们将更多地谈论（即写下）关于读写能力对思维过程的影响。

Longstanding oral mental habits of thinking through one’s thoughts aloud encourage dictation, but so did the state of writing technology. In the physical act of writing, the medieval Englishman Orderic Vitalis says, ‘the whole body labors’ (Clanchy 1979, p. 90). Through the Middle Ages in Europe authors often employed scribes. Composition in writing, working out one’s thought pen-in-hand, particularly in briefer compositions, was, of course, practiced to some extent from antiquity, but it became widespread for literary and other prolonged composition at different times in different cultures. It was still rare in eleventh-century England, and, when it occurred, even this late, could be done in a psychological setting so oral that we ﬁnd it hard to imagine. The eleventh-century Eadmer of St Albans says that, when he composed in writing, he felt he was dictating to himself (Clanchy 1979, p. 218). St Thomas Aquinas, who wrote his own manuscripts, organizes his Summa theologiae in quasi-oral format: each section or ‘question’ begins with a recitation of objections against the position Thomas will take, then Thomas states his position, and ﬁnally answers the objections in order. Similarly, an early poet would write down a poem by imagining himself declaiming it to an audience. Few if any novelists today write a novel by imagining themselves declaiming it aloud, though they might be exquisitely aware of the sound effects of the words. High literacy fosters truly written composition, in which the author composes a text which is precisely a text, puts his or her words together on paper. This gives thought different contours from those of orally sustained thought. More will be said (that is, written) here later about the effects of literacy on thought processes.

从记忆到书面记录

FROM MEMORY TO WRITTEN RECORDS

在一种文化开始使用书写很久之后，它可能仍然不会给予书写很高的评价。当今的识字者通常认为书面记录比口头语言更能证明过去的事态，尤其是在法庭上。早期的文化知道识字，但还没有将其完全内化，他们的假设往往恰恰相反。毫无疑问，不同文化对书面记录的信任度有所不同，但克兰奇对 11 世纪英国（1979 年）将识字用于实际行政目的的详细案例历史提供了一个信息丰富的样本，说明口头语言可以在多大程度上保留下来。书写的存在，即使是在行政环境中。

Long after a culture has begun to use writing, it may still not give writing high ratings. A present-day literate usually assumes that written records have more force than spoken words as evidence of a long-past state of affairs, especially in court. Earlier cultures that knew literacy but had not so fully interiorized it, have often assumed quite the opposite. The amount of credence accorded to written records undoubtedly varied from culture to culture, but Clanchy’s careful case history of the use of literacy for practical administrative purposes in eleventhand twelfth-century England (1979) gives an informative sample of how much orality could linger in the presence of writing, even in an administrative milieu.

在他的研究期间，克兰奇发现“文件并没有立即激发信任”（Clanchy 1979，第 230 页）。必须让人们相信，写作足以改进旧的口头方法，值得其所涉及的所有费用和麻烦的技术。在使用文件之前，通常使用集体口头证词来确定封建继承人的年龄等。1127 年，为了解决桑威奇港的关税是否归坎特伯雷圣奥古斯丁修道院还是基督教堂这一争议，选出了一个由 12 名多佛人和 12 名桑威奇人组成的陪审团，他们是“成熟、明智的前辈”。多年来，有良好的见证”。然后每位陪审员宣誓，正如“我从我的祖先那里得到的，我从我年轻时看到和听到的”，通行费属于基督教会（Clanchy 1979，第 232-3 页）。

In the period he studies, Clanchy ﬁnds that ‘documents did not immediately inspire trust’ (Clanchy 1979, p. 230). People had to be persuaded that writing improved the old oral methods sufficiently to warrant all the expense and troublesome techniques it involved. Before the use of documents, collective oral testimony was commonly used to establish, for example, the age of feudal heirs. To settle a dispute in 1127 as to whether the customs dues at the port of Sandwich went to St Augustine’s Abbey at Canterbury or to Christ Church, a jury was chosen consisting of twelve men from Dover and twelve from Sandwich, ‘mature, wise seniors of many years, having good testimony’. Each juror then swore that, as ‘I have received from my ancestors, and I have seen and heard from my youth’, the tolls belong to Christ Church (Clanchy 1979, pp. 232–3). They were publicly remembering what others before them had remembered.

表面上看，证人比文本更可信，因为他们可以受到质疑并为自己的陈述辩护，而文本却不能（人们会记得，这正是柏拉图反对写作的原因之一）。认证文件的公证方法致力于将认证机制构建到书面文本中，但公证方法在文字文化中发展较晚，在英国比在意大利晚得多（Clanchy 1979，第235-6页）。书面文件本身通常不是通过书面形式而是通过象征性物体来验证（例如一把小刀，通过羊皮纸带固定在文件上 - Clanchy 1979，第 24 页）。事实上，仅象征性物体就可以作为转移财产的工具。在c。1130 年，托马斯·德·穆尚 (Thomas de Muschamps) 将他的剑放在祭坛上，将他的赫瑟斯瓦夫 (Hetherslaw) 庄园转让给达勒姆的僧侣 (Clanchy 1979, p. 25)。即使在《末日审判书》（1085-6）和随之而来的书面文献的增加之后，厄尔·沃伦的故事表明，古老的口头心态仍然存在：在爱德华一世（1272-1306 年在位）统治下的法官面前），沃伦伯爵展示的不是一份宪章，而是“一把古老而生锈的剑”，抗议他的祖先与征服者威廉一起用剑占领英格兰，而他将用剑保卫自己的土地。克兰奇指出（1979，第 21-2 页），由于某些不一致之处，这个故事有些值得怀疑，但他也指出，它的持续存在证明了一种熟悉象征性礼物的见证价值的早期心态。

Witnesses were prima facie more credible than texts because they could be challenged and made to defend their statements, whereas texts could not (this, it will be recalled, was exactly one of Plato’s objections to writing). Notarial methods of authenticating documents undertake to build authenticating mechanisms into written texts, but notarial methods developed late in literate cultures, and much later in England than in Italy (Clanchy 1979, pp. 235–6). Written documents themselves were often authenticated not in writing but by symbolic objects (such as a knife, attached to the document by a parchment thong – Clanchy 1979, p. 24). Indeed symbolic objects alone could serve as instruments transferring property. In c. 1130, Thomas de Muschamps conveyed his estate of Hetherslaw to the monks at Durham by offering his sword on an altar (Clanchy 1979, p. 25). Even after the Domesday Book (1085–6) and the accompanying increase in written documentation, the story of the Earle Warrenne shows how the old oral state of mind still persisted: before the judges in quo warranto procedures under Edward I (reigned 1272–1306), the Earle Warrenne exhibited not a charter but ‘an ancient and rusty sword’, protesting that his ancestors had come with William the Conqueror to take England by the sword and that he would defend his lands with the sword. Clanchy points out (1979, pp. 21–2) that the story is somewhat questionable because of certain inconsistencies, but notes also that its persistence attests to an earlier state of mind familiar with the witness value of symbolic gifts.

英格兰早期的土地转让特许状最初甚至没有注明日期（1979 年，第 231 页、236-41 页），可能是出于多种原因。克兰奇认为，最深刻的原因可能是“约会需要抄写员表达对他所处的时间位置的看法”（1979，第238页），这要求他选择一个参考点。什么点？他是要根据世界的创造来定位这份文件吗？走向受难？为了基督的诞生？从基督诞生起，教皇就以这种方式标注文件的日期，但是像教皇标注他们自己的文件一样标注世俗文件的日期是否自以为是？在当今的高科技文化中，每个人每天都生活在由数百万印刷日历、时钟和手表强制执行的抽象计算时间框架中。在十二世纪的英国，没有钟表、挂历或台历。

Early charters conveying land in England were originally not even dated (1979, pp. 231, 236–41), probably for a variety of reasons. Clanchy suggests that the most profound reason was probably that ‘dating required the scribe to express an opinion about his place in time’ (1979, p. 238), which demanded that he choose a point of reference. What point? Was he to locate this document by reference to the creation of the world? To the Cruciﬁxion? To the birth of Christ? Popes dated documents this way, from Christ’s birth, but was it presumptuous to date a secular document as popes dated theirs? In high technology cultures today, everyone lives each day in a frame of abstract computed time enforced by millions of printed calendars, clocks, and watches. In twelfth-century England there were no clocks or watches or wall or desk calendars.

在写作被印刷品深深内化之前，人们并不觉得自己生活中的每一刻都处于任何形式的抽象计算时间中。中世纪甚至文艺复兴时期西欧的大多数人通常不太可能知道当前日历年的数字——从基督诞生或过去的任何其他时间点开始。为什么他们应该这样？对于从哪个点计算的犹豫不决证明了这个问题的琐碎性。在一个没有报纸或其他当前过时材料影响意识的文化中，对于大多数人来说，了解当前的日历年有什么意义呢？抽象日历编号与现实生活中没有任何关系。大多数人不知道，甚至从未尝试去了解他们是哪一年出生的。

Before writing was deeply interiorized by print, people did not feel themselves situated every moment of their lives in abstract computed time of any sort. It appears unlikely that most persons in medieval or even Renaissance western Europe would ordinarily have been aware of the number of the current calendar year – from the birth of Christ or any other point in the past. Why should they be? Indecision concerning what point to compute from attested the trivialities of the issue. In a culture with no newspapers or other currently dated material to impinge on consciousness, what would be the point for most people in knowing the current calendar year? The abstract calendar number would relate to nothing in real life. Most persons did not know and never even tried to discover in what calendar year they had been born.

此外，宪章无疑在某种程度上被同化为象征性的礼物，例如刀或剑。这些人通过外表就可以辨认出来。事实上，特许状经常被伪造，以使其看起来像法院（无论多么错误）认为特许状应该是什么样子（Clanchy 1979，第 249 页，引用 PH Sawyer）。克兰奇指出，“伪造者”并不是“法律实践边缘偶尔出现的偏差”，而是“12世纪文学和知识文化中心根深蒂固的专家”。在现存的 164 份忏悔者爱德华的特许状中，有 44 份肯定是伪造的，只有 64 份肯定是真实的，其余的都不确定。

Moreover, charters were undoubtedly assimilated somewhat to symbolic gifts, such as knives or swords. These were identiﬁable by their looks. And indeed, charters were quite regularly forged to make them look like what a court (however erroneously) felt a charter should look like (Clanchy 1979, p. 249, citing P. H. Sawyer). ‘Forgers’, Clanchy points out, were not ‘occasional deviants on the peripheries of legal practice’ but ‘experts entrenched at the centre of literary and intellectual culture in the twelfth century.’ Of the 164 now extant charters of Edward the Confessor, 44 are certainly forged, only 64 certainly authentic, and the rest uncertainly one or the other.

克兰奇所报告的仍然是激进的口头经济和司法程序所造成的可验证错误是微乎其微的，因为更完整的过去大多是无法进入意识的。“记住的真相是……灵活且最新的”（Clanchy 1979，第 233 页）。正如现代尼日利亚和加纳的例子（Goody and Watt 1968，第 31-4 页）所示，在口头思想经济中，过去的事情与现在没有任何关联通常会被遗忘。习惯法，删除了不再使用的材料，自然而然地总是最新的，因此很年轻——这一事实，矛盾的是，使习惯法看起来不可避免，因此非常古老（参见Clanchy 1979，第233页）。世界观是由高文化水平形成的人需要提醒自己，在功能性口头文化中，过去并不被认为是一个逐项列出的领域，充满了可验证和有争议的“事实”或信息片段。它是祖先的领域，是更新当前存在意识的共鸣源，而它本身也不是一个逐项列出的领域。口语不知道列表、图表或数字。

The veriﬁable errors resulting from the still radically oral economic and juridical procedures that Clanchy reports were minimal because the fuller past was mostly inaccessible to consciousness. ‘Remembered truth was... ﬂexible and up to date’ (Clanchy 1979, p. 233). As has been seen in instances from modern Nigeria and Ghana (Goody and Watt 1968, pp. 31–4), in an oral economy of thought, matters from the past without any sort of present relevance commonly dropped into oblivion. Customary law, trimmed of material no longer of use, was automatically always up to date and thus youthful – a fact which, paradoxically, makes customary law seem inevitable and thus very old (cf. Clanchy 1979, p. 233). Persons whose world view has been formed by high literacy need to remind themselves that in functionally oral cultures the past is not felt as an itemized terrain, peppered with veriﬁable and disputed ‘facts’ or bits of information. It is the domain of the ancestors, a resonant source for renewing awareness of present existence, which itself is not an itemized terrain either. Orality knows no lists or charts or ﬁgures.

Goody（1977，第 52-111 页）详细研究了表格和列表的意念意义，日历就是其中一个例子。书写使这样的装置成为可能。事实上，从某种意义上说，文字的发明主要是为了制作类似列表的东西：到目前为止，我们所知的大多数最早的文字，即公元前 3500 年左右开始的苏美尔人的楔形文字，都是记账的。主要口头文化通常在叙述中放置相当于列表的内容，如《伊利亚特》中的船只和船长目录（ii. 461-879）——不是客观的统计，而是战争故事中的操作展示。在托拉的文本中，它以书面形式记录了基本上仍然是口头的思想形式，地理的等同物（建立一个地方与另一个地方的关系）被放入了公式化的行动叙述中（民数记 33:16 ff）：他们从西奈沙漠出发，在基博罗哈他瓦安营。他们从基博罗哈他瓦出发，在哈洗录扎营。他们从哈泽洛斯出发，在里斯玛扎营……”，等等，还有更多的经文。即使是这种口头框架传统的家谱实际上也通常是叙述性的。我们不是背诵名字，而是发现一系列“生”，即某人所做的事情的陈述：“以拉生米哈雅利，米哈雅利生玛土撒利，玛土撒利生拉麦”（创世记 4:18）。这种聚合部分源于使用公式的口头驱动力，

Goody (1977, pp. 52–111) has examined in detail the noetic signiﬁcance of tables and lists, of which the calendar is one example. Writing makes such apparatus possible. Indeed, writing was in a sense invented largely to make something like lists: by far most of the earliest writing we know, that in the cuneiform script of the Sumerians beginning around 3500 BC, is account-keeping. Primary oral cultures commonly situate their equivalent of lists in narrative, as in the catalogue of the ships and captains in the Iliad (ii. 461–879) – not an objective tally but an operational display in a story about a war. In the text of the Torah, which set down in writing thought forms still basically oral, the equivalent of geography (establishing the relationship of one place to another) is put into a formulary action narrative (Numbers 33:16 ff): ‘Setting out from the desert of Sinai, they camped at Kibroth-hattaavah. Setting out from Kibroth-hattaavah, they camped at Hazeroth. Setting out from Hazeroth, they camped at Rithmah...’, and so on for many more verses. Even genealogies out of such orally framed tradition are in effect commonly narrative. Instead of a recitation of names, we ﬁnd a sequence of ‘begats’, of statements of what someone did: ‘Irad begat Mehajael, Mehajael begat Methusael, Methusael begat Lamech’ (Genesis 4:18). This sort of aggregation derives partly from the oral drive to use formulas, partly from the oral mnemonic drive to exploit balance (recurrence of subject-predicate-object produces a swing which aids recall and which a mere sequence of names would lack), partly from the oral drive to redundancy (each person is mentioned twice, as begetter and begotten), and partly from the oral drive to narrate rather than simply to juxtapose (the persons are not immobilized as in a police line-up, but are doing something – namely, begetting).

这些圣经段落显然是书面记录，但它们来自口头构成的情感和传统。它们并不被感觉为类似事物，而是事件在时间中的重构。口头呈现的序列总是及时发生的，不可能“检查”，因为它们不是视觉上呈现的，而是听到的话语。在初级口头文化或带有大量口头残留的文化中，即使是家谱也不是数据的“列表”，而是“所唱歌曲的记忆”。文本就像东西一样，固定在视觉空间中，受到古迪所说的“向后扫描”的影响（1977，第49-50页）。古迪详细地展示了当人类学家在书面或印刷的表面上展示口头神话中发现的各种项目（氏族、地球区域、风的种类等）时，如何 它们实际上扭曲了神话本身存在的精神世界。神话所提供的满足感本质上并不以表格方式“连贯”。

These biblical passages obviously are written records, but they come from an orally constituted sensibility and tradition. They are not felt as thing-like, but as reconstitutions of events in time. Orally presented sequences are always occurrences in time, impossible to ‘examine’, because they are not presented visually but rather are utterances which are heard. In a primary oral culture or a culture with heavy oral residue, even genealogies are not ‘lists’ of data but rather ‘memory of songs sung’. Texts are thing-like, immobilized in visual space, subject to what Goody calls ‘backward scanning’ (1977, pp. 49–50). Goody shows in detail how, when anthropologists display on a written or printed surface lists of various items found in oral myths (clans, regions of the earth, kinds of winds, and so on), they actually deform the mental world in which the myths have their own existence. The satisfaction that myths provide is essentially not ‘coherent’ in a tabular way.

如果我们反思性地意识到古迪讨论的这类列表不可避免地带来的扭曲，那么它们当然是有用的。空间中语言材料的视觉呈现有其独特的经济性、其运动和结构的规律。各种文字的文本世界各地的人们以不同的方式阅读，从右到左，或从左到右，或从上到下，或像双螺旋书写一样同时使用所有这些方式，但据所知，从来没有任何地方是从下到上的。文本将话语同化为人体。他们在知识积累中引入了对“标题”的感觉：“章节”源自拉丁语caput，意思是头（如人体）。页面不仅有“头”，还有“脚”，用于脚注。当文本中的“上方”和“下方”指的是几页之前或更远的内容时，就会引用这些内容。文本中垂直和水平的意义值得认真研究。Kerckhove (1981) 认为，左半球优势的增长控制了早期希腊文字从右向左运动到牛耕运动（“牛耕”模式，一条线向右移动，然后转过一个拐角进入下一条线）的漂移。线向左移动，字母根据线的方向反转），到stoichedon样式（垂直线），最后在水平线上确定从左到右的移动。所有这些都与口头感受中的任何事物完全不同，它无法通过“标题”或言语线性进行操作。在世界各地，字母表作为声音到空间的无情高效还原器，被直接用于建立新的空间定义序列：项目被标记为a、b、c，等等来表示它们的顺序，甚至识字早期的诗歌也是按照字母顺序由连续行的第一个单词的第一个字母组成的。字母表作为简单的字母序列是口头助记符和文字助记符之间的主要桥梁：通常，字母表中的字母序列是口头记忆的，然后用于主要视觉检索材料，如索引。

Lists of the sort Goody discusses are of course useful if we are reﬂectively aware of the distortion they inevitably introduce. Visual presentation of verbalized material in space has its own particular economy, its own laws of motion and structure. Texts in various scripts around the world are read variously from right to left, or left to right, or top to bottom, or all these ways at once as in boustrophedon writing, but never anywhere, so far as is known, from bottom to top. Texts assimilate utterance to the human body. They introduce a feeling for ‘headings’ in accumulations of knowledge: ‘chapter’ derives from the Latin caput, meaning head (as of the human body). Pages have not only ‘heads’ but also ‘feet’, for footnotes. References are given to what is ‘above’ and ‘below’ in a text when what is meant is several pages back or farther on. The signiﬁcance of the vertical and the horizontal in texts deserves serious study. Kerckhove (1981) suggests that growth in lefthemisphere dominance governed the drift in early Greek writing from right-to-left movement, to boustrophedon movement (‘ox-plowing’ pattern, one line going right, then a turn around a corner into the next line going left, the letters inverted according to the direction of the line), to stoichedon style (vertical lines), and ﬁnally to deﬁnitive leftto-right movement on a horizontal line. All this is quite a different world of order from anything in the oral sensibility, which has no way of operating with ‘headings’ or verbal linearity. Across the world the alphabet, the ruthlessly efficient reducer of sound to space, is pressed into direct service for setting up the new space-deﬁned sequences: items are marked a, b, c, and so on to indicate their sequences, and even poems in the early days of literacy are composed with the ﬁrst letter of the ﬁrst word of successive lines following the order of the alphabet. The alphabet as a simple sequence of letters is a major bridge between oral mnemonic and literate mnemonics: generally the sequence of the letters of the alphabet is memorized orally and then used for largely visual retrieval of materials, as in indexes.

图表不仅将思想元素排列在一条线上，而且同时以水平和各种交叉顺序排列，它代表的思想框架比列表与图表应该代表的口头思维过程的距离还要远。列表的广泛使用，尤其是图表在我们的高科技文化中如此普遍，这不仅仅是书写的结果，而且是印刷品深度内在化的结果（Ong 1958b，第 307-18 页和 passim），它实现了使用修复了图表文字图表和中性空间的其他信息用途，远远超出了任何写作文化中可行的范围。

Charts, which range elements of thought not simply in one line of rank but simultaneously in horizontal and various cross-cross orders, represent a frame of thought even farther removed than lists are from the oral noetic processes which such charts are supposed to represent. The extensive use of lists and particularly of charts so commonplace in our high technology cultures is a result not simply of writing, but of the deep interiorization of print (Ong 1958b, pp. 307–18, and passim ), which implements the use of ﬁxed diagrammatic word-charts and other informational uses of neutral space far beyond anything feasible in any writing culture.

文本性的一些动态

SOME DYNAMICS OF TEXTUALITY

文本中的词语状况与口语话语中的词语状况有很大不同。虽然它们指的是声音，并且除非它们能够在外部或想象中与声音或更准确地说与它们编码的音素相关，否则毫无意义，但书面单词与口语单词形成的更完整的上下文是隔离的。这个词在其自然的、口头的栖息地中是真实的、存在的现在的一部分。口语是由一个真实的、活生生的人在特定的时间、在真实的环境中向另一个或多个真实的、活生生的人说出的，其中包含的内容永远不仅仅是言语。口语总是对整体情境的修饰，而不仅仅是言语。它们从来不会单独出现在文字的背景下。

The condition of words in a text is quite different from their condition in spoken discourse. Although they refer to sounds and are meaningless unless they can be related – externally or in the imagination – to the sounds or, more precisely, the phonemes they encode, written words are isolated from the fuller context in which spoken words come into being. The word in its natural, oral habitat is a part of a real, existential present. Spoken utterance is addressed by a real, living person to another real, living person or real, living persons, at a speciﬁc time in a real setting which includes always much more than mere words. Spoken words are always modiﬁcations of a total situation which is more than verbal. They never occur alone, in a context simply of words.

然而文字在文本中却是孤独的。此外，在撰写文本、“写”某物时，产生书面话语的人也是孤独的。写作是一种唯我论的操作。我正在写一本书，希望能被数十万人阅读，所以我必须与所有人隔离。在写这本书的时候，我留下了一句话，说我“出去”了几个小时和几天——这样没有人，包括那些可能会读这本书的人，可以打扰我的孤独。

Yet words are alone in a text. Moreover, in composing a text, in ‘writing’ something, the one producing the written utterance is also alone. Writing is a solipsistic operation. I am writing a book which I hope will be read by hundreds of thousands of people, so I must be isolated from everyone. While writing the present book, I have left word that I am ‘out’ for hours and days – so that no one, including persons who will presumably read the book, can interrupt my solitude.

在文本中，即使是其中的单词也缺乏其完整的语音品质。在口语中，一个词必须有一种或另一种语调或语气——活泼、兴奋、安静、愤怒、顺从等等。没有语调地口头说出一个词是不可能的。在文本中，标点符号可以最低程度地表示语气：例如，问号或逗号通常要求声音提高一点。熟练的批评家采用和改编的文学传统也可以为语调提供一些文本外的线索，但不是完整的线索。演员们花费数小时来确定如何实际说出面前文本中的单词。一个给定的段落可能由一个演员以喊叫的方式传达，而另一个则以低声的方式传达。

In a text even the words that are there lack their full phonetic qualities. In oral speech, a word must have one or another intonation or tone of voice – lively, excited, quiet, incensed, resigned, or whatever. It is impossible to speak a word orally without any intonation. In a text punctuation can signal tone minimally: a question mark or a comma, for example, generally calls for the voice to be raised a bit. Literate tradition, adopted and adapted by skilled critics, can also supply some extratextual clues for intonations, but not complete ones. Actors spend hours determining how actually to utter the words in the text before them. A given passage might be delivered by one actor in a shout, by another in a whisper.

不仅读者缺失了文本外的语境，作者也缺失了文本外的上下文。缺乏可验证的背景使得写作通常比向真正的观众进行口头演讲更加痛苦。“作家的读者永远是虚构的”（Ong 1977，第53-81页）。作家必须塑造一个缺席且经常出现的角色不知名的读者可以自行投稿。即使在写信给一位亲密的朋友时，我也必须为他虚构一种情绪，希望他能够遵守这种情绪。读者也必须虚构作者。当我的朋友读我的信时，我的心情可能与写信时完全不同。事实上，我很可能已经死了。对于传达其信息的文本来说，作者是死是活并不重要。今天现存的大多数书籍都是由已故的人写的。口语只来自于生者。

Extratextual context is missing not only for readers but also for the writer. Lack of veriﬁable context is what makes writing normally so much more agonizing an activity than oral presentation to a real audience. ‘The writer’s audience is always a ﬁction’ (Ong 1977, pp. 53–81). The writer must set up a role in which absent and often unknown readers can cast themselves. Even in writing to a close friend I have to ﬁctionalize a mood for him, to which he is expected to conform. The reader must also ﬁctionalize the writer. When my friend reads my letter, I may be in an entirely different frame of mind from when I wrote it. Indeed, I may very well be dead. For a text to convey its message, it does not matter whether the author is dead or alive. Most books extant today were written by persons now dead. Spoken utterance comes only from the living.

即使在写给我自己的个人日记中，我也必须虚构收件人。事实上，日记在某种程度上要求对说话者和接收者进行最大限度的虚构。写作永远是一种模仿说话，因此在日记中我假装我在自言自语。但我从来没有真正这样对自己说过。我也不能不写或实际上不印刷。个人日记是一种非常晚期的文学形式，实际上直到十七世纪才为人所知（Boerner 1969）。它所暗示的那种言语化的唯我主义幻想是印刷文化塑造的意识的产物。我是为谁而写？今天我自己吗？我想十年后我会怎样？正如我所希望的那样？为我自己想象自己，还是希望别人想象我？诸如此类的问题确实会让日记作者感到焦虑，并且常常导致日记的终止。日记作者不能再忍受他或她的小说。

Even in a personal diary addressed to myself I must ﬁctionalize the addressee. Indeed, the diary demands, in a way, the maximum ﬁctionalizing of the utterer and the addressee. Writing is always a kind of imitation talking, and in a diary I therefore am pretending that I am talking to myself. But I never really talk this way to myself. Nor could I without writing or indeed without print. The personal diary is a very late literary form, in effect unknown until the seventeenth century (Boerner 1969). The kind of verbalized solipsistic reveries it implies are a product of consciousness as shaped by print culture. And for which self am I writing? Myself today? As I think I will be ten years from now? As I hope I will be? For myself as I imagine myself or hope others may imagine me? Questions such as this can and do ﬁll diary writers with anxieties and often enough lead to discontinuation of diaries. The diarist can no longer live with his or her ﬁction.

读者被小说化的方式是文学史的底层，顶层是流派史以及人物和情节的处理。早期的写作为读者提供了显着的帮助，帮助他们想象自己的处境。它以对话形式呈现哲学材料，例如柏拉图的苏格拉底的对话，读者可以想象自己无意中听到的对话。或者将情节想象为连续几天向现场观众讲述。后来到了中世纪，写作会以反对与回应的形式呈现哲学和神学文本，让读者想象一场口头辩论。薄伽丘和乔叟将为读者提供虚构的一群男人和女人互相讲故事，即一个“框架故事”，这样读者就可以假装自己是倾听者中的一员。《傲慢与偏见》还是《红与黑》，还是《亚当·贝德》？十九世纪的小说家会自觉地一遍又一遍地吟诵“亲爱的读者”，以提醒自己：他们不是在讲述一个故事，而是在写一个作者和读者都难以定位自己的故事。写作的心理动力学在叙事中成熟得非常缓慢。

The ways in which readers are ﬁctionalized is the underside of literary history, of which the topside is the history of genres and the handling of character and plot. Early writing provides the reader with conspicuous help for situating himself imaginatively. It presents philosophical material in dialogues, such as those of Plato’s Socrates, which the reader can imagine himself overhearing. Or episodes are to be imagined as told to a live audience on successive days. Later, in the Middle Ages, writing will present philosophical and theological texts in objection-and-response form, so that the reader can imagine an oral disputation. Boccaccio and Chaucer will provide the reader with ﬁctional groups of men and women telling stories to one another, that is, a ‘frame story’, so that the reader can pretend to be one of the listening company. But who is talking to whom in Pride and Prejudice or in Le Rouge et le noir, or in Adam Bede ? Nineteenth-century novelists self-consciously intone, ‘dear reader’, over and over again to remind themselves that they are not telling a story but writing one in which both author and reader are having difficulty situating themselves. The psychodynamics of writing matured very slowly in narrative.

读者在《芬尼根守灵夜》中应该扮演什么角色？只是一个读者。但属于一种特殊的虚构类型。大多数英语读者不能或不会使自己成为乔伊斯要求的特殊读者。有些人在大学里学习如何像乔伊斯那样虚构自己。尽管乔伊斯的文字非常口头化，因为它朗读得很好，但声音和它的听众并不符合任何可以想象的现实生活环境，而只能符合《芬尼根守灵夜》的想象背景，而这只能通过写作和印刷来想象。那已经过去了。芬尼根守灵夜是用书面形式写成的，但对于印刷品来说：由于其特殊的拼写和用法，几乎不可能在手写副本中准确地复制它。除了讽刺之外，这里不存在亚里士多德意义上的模仿。写作确实是反讽的温床，写作（和印刷）传统持续的时间越长，反讽的生长就越重（Ong 1977，第272-302页）。

And what is the reader supposed to make himself out to be in Finnegans Wake ? Only a reader. But of a special ﬁctional sort. Most readers of English cannot or will not make themselves into the special kind of reader Joyce demands. Some take courses in universities to learn how to ﬁctionalize themselves à la Joyce. Although Joyce’s text is very oral in the sense that it reads well aloud, the voice and its hearer do not ﬁt into any imaginable real-life setting, but only the imaginative setting of Finnegans Wake, which is imaginable only because of the writing and print that has gone before it. Finnegans Wake was composed in writing, but for print: with its idiosyncratic spelling and usages, it would be virtually impossible to multiply it accurately in handwritten copies. There is no mimesis here in Aristotle’s sense, except ironically. Writing is indeed the seedbed of irony, and the longer the writing (and print) tradition endures, the heavier the ironic growth becomes (Ong 1977, pp. 272–302).

距离、精度、图形和词汇表

DISTANCE, PRECISION, GRAPHOLECTS AND MAGNAVOCABULARIES

写作所产生的距离感通过将语言从大量口头表达的丰富但混乱的存在语境中移除，从而发展了一种新的语言精确性。口头表演的华丽言辞和共同智慧都令人印象深刻，无论是正式叙述中的冗长，还是谚语中的简短和警句。然而，智慧与整体且相对脆弱的社会环境有关。口头管理的语言和思想并不以分析精确性着称。

The distancing which writing effects develops a new kind of precision in verbalization by removing it from the rich but chaotic existential context of much oral utterance. Oral performances can be impressive in their magniloquence and communal wisdom, whether they are lengthy, as in formal narrative, or brief and apophthegmatic, as in proverbs. Yet wisdom has to do with a total and relatively infrangible social context. Orally managed language and thought are not noted for analytic precision.

当然，所有的语言和思想在某种程度上都是分析性的：它们将经验的密集连续体（威廉·詹姆斯的“大的、盛开的、嗡嗡作响的混乱”）分解成或多或少独立的部分，有意义的片段。但书面文字可以使分析变得更加敏锐，因为单个文字被要求做更多的事情。为了在没有手势、没有面部表情、没有语调、没有真正的听者的情况下清楚地表达自己，你必须谨慎地预见到所有可能的含义陈述可能对任何可能的情况下的任何可能的读者都有影响，并且你必须使你的语言发挥作用，以便在没有存在背景的情况下完全清楚地表达出来。对这种精致谨慎的需要使得写作通常成为一项令人痛苦的工作。

Of course, all language and thought are to some degree analytic: they break down the dense continuum of experience, William James’s ‘big, blooming, buzzing confusion’, into more or less separate parts, meaningful segments. But written words sharpen analysis, for the individual words are called on to do more. To make yourself clear without gesture, without facial expression, without intonation, without a real hearer, you have to foresee circumspectly all possible meanings a statement may have for any possible reader in any possible situation, and you have to make your language work so as to come clear all by itself, with no existential context. The need for this exquisite circumspection makes writing the agonizing work it commonly is.

Goody (1977, p. 128) 所说的“向后扫描”使得在写作中消除不一致成为可能（Goody 1977, p. 49-50），在具有反思性选择性的词语之间进行选择，这种选择性赋予思想和词语新的歧视性力量。在口头文化中，词语的流动，相应的思想洪流，从古典时期到文艺复兴时期的修辞学家在欧洲所提倡的copia ，倾向于通过掩盖差异来管理差异——这里的词源很能说明问题， glossa，舌头，通过“舌头”将它们覆盖。通过书写，单词一旦“说出”、被表达、被写在表面上，就可以被消除、抹去、改变。在口头表演中没有类似的东西，也没有办法消除口语：更正并不能消除不恰当或错误，它们只是用否认和拼凑来补充它。列维-斯特劳斯（Lévi-Strauss，1966，1970）认为“原始”或“野蛮”思维模式特征的拼凑或拼凑在这里可以被视为归因于口头意念情境。口头表演的纠正往往会适得其反，使演讲者缺乏说服力。因此，您可以将它们保持在最低限度或完全避免它们。在写作中，更正可以非常有效，因为读者怎么知道它们已经被做出了呢？

What Goody (1977, p. 128) calls ‘backward scanning’ makes it possible in writing to eliminate inconsistencies (Goody 1977, pp. 49–50), to choose between words with a reﬂective selectivity that invests thought and words with new discriminatory powers. In an oral culture, the ﬂow of words, the corresponding ﬂood of thought, the copia advocated in Europe by rhetoricians from classical antiquity through the Renaissance, tends to manage discrepancies by glossing them over – the etymology here is telling, glossa, tongue, by ‘tonguing’ them over. With writing, words once ‘uttered’, outered, put down on the surface, can be eliminated, erased, changed. There is no equivalent for this in an oral performance, no way to erase a spoken word: corrections do not remove an infelicity or an error, they merely supplement it with denial and patchwork. The bricolage or patchwork that Lévi-Strauss (1966, 1970) ﬁnds characteristic of ‘primitive’ or ‘savage’ thought patterns can be seen here to be due to the oral noetic situation. Corrections in oral performance tend to be counterproductive, to render the speaker unconvincing. So you keep them to a minimum or avoid them altogether. In writing, corrections can be tremendously productive, for how can the reader know they have even been made?

当然，一旦手写学引发的对精确性和分析准确性的感觉被内化，它就可以反馈到言语中，而且确实如此。尽管柏拉图的思想是以对话的形式表达的，但其精确性却是由于书写对意念过程的影响，因为对话实际上是书面文本。通过以对话形式表达的手写文本，他们辩证地走向对问题的分析澄清，苏格拉底和柏拉图以更“总体化”、非分析、叙述性、口头形式继承了这些问题。

Of course, once the chirographically initiated feel for precision and analytic exactitude is interiorized, it can feed back into speech, and does. Although Plato’s thought is couched in dialogue form, its exquisite precision is due to the effects of writing on the noetic processes, for the dialogues are in fact written texts. Through a chirographically managed text couched in dialogue form, they move dialectically toward the analytic clariﬁcation of issues which Socrates and Plato had inherited in more ‘totalized’, non-analytic, narratized, oral form.

在《希腊的正义概念：从荷马的影子到柏拉图的实质》（1978a）一书中，哈夫洛克论述了柏拉图著作所带来的运动。在任何已知的纯粹口头文化中都找不到柏拉图针对抽象正义概念的分析。同样，西塞罗演讲中对问题和对手弱点的致命攻击是有文化的头脑的工作，尽管我们知道西塞罗在发表演讲之前并没有将其写成脚本，而是后来写下了我们现在拥有的文本（Ong 1967b，第 56-7 页）。中世纪大学和本世纪后期学术传统中精致的分析性口头辩论（Ong 1981，第137-8页）是通过口头和书面写作文本以及阅读和评论文本来磨练思想的作品。

In The Greek Concept of Justice: From Its Shadow in Homer to Its Substance in Plato (1978a), Havelock has treated the movement which Plato’s work brought to a head. Nothing of Plato’s analytic targeting on an abstract concept of justice is to be found in any known purely oral cultures. Similarly, the deadly targeting on issues and on adversaries’ weaknesses in Cicero’s orations is the work of a literate mind, although we know that Cicero did not compose his orations in script before he gave them but wrote down afterwards the texts that we now have (Ong 1967b, pp. 56–7). The exquisitely analytic oral disputations in medieval universities and in later scholastic tradition into the present century (Ong 1981, pp. 137–8) were the work of minds honed by writing texts and by reading and commenting on texts, orally and in writing.

通过将认知者与已知者分开（Havelock 1963），写作使日益清晰的内省成为可能，以前所未有的方式不仅向与自身截然不同的外部客观世界开放心灵，而且向与客观世界相对立的内在自我开放。写作使佛教、犹太教、基督教和伊斯兰教等伟大的内省宗教传统成为可能。所有这些都有神圣的文本。古希腊人和罗马人懂得文字，并用它来阐述哲学和科学知识，尤其是希腊人。但他们没有发展出与《吠陀经》、《圣经》或《古兰经》相媲美的神圣文本，他们的宗教也未能在文字为他们打开的心灵深处建立起来。就变成了只有文雅，

By separating the knower from the known (Havelock 1963), writing makes possible increasingly articulate introspectivity, opening the psyche as never before not only to the external objective world quite distinct from itself but also to the interior self against whom the objective world is set. Writing makes possible the great introspective religious traditions such as Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. All these have sacred texts. The ancient Greeks and Romans knew writing and used it, particularly the Greeks, to elaborate philosophical and scientiﬁc knowledge. But they developed no sacred texts comparable to the Vedas or the Bible or the Koran, and their religion failed to establish itself in the recesses of the psyche which writing had opened for them. It became only a genteel, archaic literary resource for writers such as Ovid and a framework of external observances, lacking urgent personal meaning.

书写所用的语言与同一种语言所用的口头代码不同。巴兹尔·伯恩斯坦（Basil Bernstein，1974，第 134-5、176、181、197-8）区分了英国下层英语方言的“受限语言代码”或“公共语言”和“详细语言代码”或“私人语言”。中上层阶级方言的“语言”。沃尔特·沃尔夫勒姆（Walt Wolfram，1972）早些时候曾像伯恩斯坦那样指出黑人美式英语和标准美式英语之间的区别。受限语言代码至少可以与说话者和听者熟悉并共享的上下文中的详细代码一样具有表达力和精确性。然而，为了表达性和精确地处理不熟悉的事物，有限的语言代码是不够的。绝对需要详尽的语言代码。受限制的语言代码显然在起源和使用上主要是口头的，并且像一般的口头思维和表达一样，在上下文中运作，接近人类生活世界：伯恩斯坦发现使用该代码的群体是没有受过文法学校教育的信使男孩。他们的表达有公式般的品质，不小心地将思想串在一起服从，但“就像框架上的珠子”（1974年，第134页）——公认的口头文化的公式化和聚合模式。详细的代码是在必要的书写和印刷的帮助下形成的代码。伯恩斯坦发现使用此代码的团体来自英国提供最强化阅读和写作教育的六所主要公立学校（1974 年，第 83 页）。伯恩斯坦的“受限”和“详细”语言代码可以分别重新标记为“基于口头”和“基于文本”代码。奥尔森（Olson，1977）已经展示了口头表达如何将意义很大程度上归咎于语境，而写作则将意义集中在语言本身。

Writing develops codes in a language different from oral codes in the same language. Basil Bernstein (1974, pp. 134–5, 176, 181, 197–8) distinguishes the ‘restricted linguistic code’ or ‘public language’ of the lower-class English dialects in Britain and the ‘elaborated linguistic code’ or ‘private language’ of the middleand upper-class dialects. Walt Wolfram (1972) had earlier noted distinctions like Bernstein’s between Black American English and standard American English. The restricted linguistic code can be at least as expressive and precise as the elaborated code in contexts which are familiar and shared by speaker and hearer. For dealing with the unfamiliar expressively and precisely, however, the restricted linguistic code will not do; an elaborated linguistic code is absolutely needed. The restricted linguistic code is evidently largely oral in origin and use and, like oral thought and expression generally, operates contextually, close to the human lifeworld: the group whom Bernstein found using this code were messenger boys with no grammar school education. Their expression has a formula-like quality and strings thoughts together not in careful subordination but ‘like beads on a frame’ (1974, p. 134) – recognizably the formulaic and aggregative mode of oral culture. The elaborated code is one which is formed with the necessary aid of writing, and, for full elaboration, of print. The group Bernstein found using this code were from the six major public schools that provided the most intensive education in reading and writing in Britain (1974, p. 83). Bernstein’s ‘restricted’ and ‘elaborated’ linguistic codes could be relabeled ‘oralbased’ and ‘text-based’ codes respectively. Olson (1977) has shown how orality relegates meaning largely to context whereas writing concentrates meaning in language itself.

书写和印刷发展出了特殊的方言。正如我们所见（上文第 7 页），大多数语言根本就没有致力于书写。但某些语言，或者更准确地说是方言，在书写方面投入了大量资金。通常，就像在英国、德国或意大利一样，那里发现了一系列方言，出于经济、政治、宗教或其他原因，一种区域方言在手写学上的发展超越了所有其他方言，并最终成为一种民族语言。在英国，这种情况发生在上层阶级的伦敦英语方言中，在德国，发生在Hochdeutsch（南部高地的德语）中，在意大利发生在托斯卡纳。虽然这些确实都是地区和/或阶级方言的根源，它们作为受文字控制的民族语言的地位，使其成为与非大规模书写的方言或语言不同的方言或语言。正如古克斯曼所指出的（1970年，第773-6页），一种民族书面语言必须与其原始方言基础分离，抛弃了某些方言形式，从根本不是方言的来源中发展出不同层次的词汇，并且还发展了某些句法特性。这种既定的书面语言豪根（Haugen，1966，第 50-71 页）恰如其分地称为“grapholect”。并且还发展了某些句法特性。这种既定的书面语言豪根（Haugen，1966，第 50-71 页）恰如其分地称为“grapholect”。并且还发展了某些句法特性。这种既定的书面语言豪根（Haugen，1966，第 50-71 页）恰如其分地称为“grapholect”。

Writing and print develop special kinds of dialects. Most languages have never been committed to writing at all, as has been seen (p. 7 above). But certain languages, or more properly dialects, have invested massively in writing. Often, as in England or Germany or Italy, where a cluster of dialects is found, one regional dialectic has developed chirographically beyond all others, for economic, political, religious, or other reasons, and has eventually become a national language. In England this happened to the upper-class London English dialect, in Germany, to Hochdeutsch (the German of the highlands to the south), in Italy to Tuscan. While it is true that these were all at root regional and/ or class dialects, their status as chirographically controlled national languages has made them different kinds of dialects or language from those which are not written on a large scale. As Guxman has pointed out (1970, pp. 773–6), a national written language has had to be isolated from its original dialect base, has discarded certain dialectal forms, has developed various layers of vocabulary from sources not dialectal at all, and has developed also certain syntactical peculiarities. This kind of established written language Haugen (1966, pp. 50–71) has aptly styled a ‘grapholect’.

诸如“英语”之类的现代字词（使用通常用来指代这种字词的简单术语）已经被研究了几个世纪，似乎是由亨利五世的大法官首先也是最深入地研究的（Richardson 1980），然后是规范理论家、语法学家、词典编纂者和其他人。它已被大量地以书面和印刷形式记录下来，现在又被记录在计算机上，以便当今那些精通笔墨的人不仅可以与数以百万计的其他人建立轻松的联系，而且还可以与过去几个世纪的思想建立轻松的联系。英语的其他方言以及数以千计的外语都以图语进行解释。从这个意义上说，字语包括所有其他方言：它解释它们，就像它们无法解释自己一样。文字语言带有数以百万计的思想的印记，他们用它来相互分享他们的意识。其中包含了大量的词汇，其数量级对于口语来说是不可能的。韦氏第三本新国际词典(1971) 在其序言中指出，它的内容本可以比它所包含的 450,000 个单词多“很多倍”。假设“很多次”必须意味着至少三次，并对数字进行四舍五入，我们可以理解编辑手头上有大约一百万个半字的英文印刷品记录。口头语言和口语方言只能与这个数字中的一小部分相处。

A modern grapholect such as ‘English’, to use the simple term which is commonly used to refer to this grapholect, has been worked over for centuries, ﬁrst and most intensively, it seems, by the chancery of Henry V (Richardson 1980), then by normative theorists, grammarians, lexicographers, and others. It has been recorded massively in writing and print and now on computers so that those competent in the grapholect today can establish easy contact not only with millions of other persons but also with the thought of centuries past, for the other dialects of English as well as thousands of foreign languages are interpreted in the grapholect. In this sense, the grapholect includes all the other dialects: it explains them as they cannot explain themselves. The grapholect bears the marks of the millions of minds which have used it to share their consciousnesses with one another. Into it has been hammered a massive vocabulary of an order of magnitude impossible for an oral tongue. Webster’s Third New International Dictionary (1971) states in its Preface that it could have included ‘many times’ more than the 450,000 words it does include. Assuming that ‘many times’ must mean at least three times, and rounding out the ﬁgures, we can understand that the editors have on hand a record of some million and a half words used in print in English. Oral languages and oral dialects can get along with a small fraction of this number.

字语词汇的丰富性始于书写，但其丰富性则源于印刷。现代笔墨的资源主要可以通过词典获得。从写作历史的早期开始，各种类型的单词列表就很有限（Goody 1977，第 74-111 页），但在印刷术得到充分发展之前，还没有字典对任何语言中使用的单词进行概括性的综合描述。 。如果你想想制作几十本相对准确的《韦伯斯特第三版》甚至是小得多的《韦伯斯特新大学词典》手写本意味着什么，就很容易理解为什么会这样。。诸如此类的词典与口述文化的世界相距数光年。没有什么比书写和印刷如何改变意识状态更引人注目的了。

The lexical richness of grapholects begins with writing, but its fullness is due to print. For the resources of a modern grapholect are available largely through dictionaries. There are limited word lists of various sorts from very early in the history of writing (Goody 1977, pp. 74–111), but until print is well established there are no dictionaries that undertake generalized comprehensive accounts of the words in use in any language. It is easy to understand why this is so if you think of what it would mean to make even a few dozen relatively accurate handwritten copies of Webster’s Third or even of the much smaller Webster’s New Collegiate Dictionary. Dictionaries such as these are light-years away from the world of oral cultures. Nothing illustrates more strikingly how it is that writing and print alter states of consciousness.

在存在字词的地方，“正确的”语法和用法通常被解释为字词本身的语法和用法，排除其他方言的语法和用法。秩序这一概念的感官基础很大程度上是视觉的（Ong 1967b, pp. 108, 136-7），而且事实上，字词是书面的，更不用说，印刷鼓励赋予它一种保持语言秩序的特殊规范力量。但是，当除字语之外的给定语言的其他方言与字语的语法不同时，它们并不是不语法的：它们只是使用不同的语法，因为语言是结构，没有语法就不可能使用语言。鉴于这一事实，今天的语言学家普遍认为所有方言都是平等的，因为没有一种方言具有语法本质上比其他人的更“正确”。但赫希（Hirsch，1977，第 43-50 页）进一步指出，从深刻的意义上来说，没有其他方言，例如英语、德语或意大利语，拥有与字形语言资源相近的东西。坚持认为因为其他方言没有什么“问题”，所以说另一种方言的人是否学习笔语并没有什么区别，这是糟糕的教育学，因为笔语拥有完全不同数量级的资源。

Where grapholects exist, ‘correct’ grammar and usage are popularly interpreted as the grammar and usage of the grapholect itself to the exclusion of the grammar and usage of other dialects. The sensory bases of the very concept of order are largely visual (Ong 1967b, pp. 108, 136–7), and the fact that the grapholect is written or, a fortiori, printed encourages attributing to it a special normative power for keeping language in order. But when other dialects of a given language besides the grapholect vary from the grammar of the grapholect, they are not ungrammatical: they are simply using a different grammar, for language is structure, and it is impossible to use language without a grammar. In the light of this fact, linguists today commonly make the point that all dialects are equal in the sense that none has a grammar intrinsically more ‘correct’ than that of others. But Hirsch (1977, pp. 43–50) makes the further point that in a profound sense no other dialect, for example, in English or German or Italian, has anything remotely like the resources of the grapholect. It is bad pedagogy to insist that because there is nothing ‘wrong’ with other dialects, it makes no difference whether or not speakers of another dialect learn the grapholect, which has resources of a totally different order of magnitude.

互动：修辞与场所

INTERACTIONS: RHETORIC AND THE PLACES

西方的两个特殊的重大发展源于并影响着书写和口头的相互作用。这些是学术修辞和博学的拉丁语。

Two special major developments in the West derive from and affect the interaction of writing and orality. These are academic rhetoric and Learned Latin.

在他的《牛津英国文学史》第三卷中，CS Lewis 观察到“修辞是我们和我们的祖先之间最大的障碍”（1954 年，第 60 页）。刘易斯通过拒绝对待这个主题来尊重这个主题的重要性，尽管它与所有年龄段的文化具有压倒性的相关性，至少直到浪漫主义时代（Ong 1971，第1-22页，255-83）。在此之前，对修辞学的研究在所有西方文化中占主导地位，它已开始成为古希腊教育和文化的核心。在古希腊，以苏格拉底、柏拉图和亚里士多德为代表的“哲学”研究，尽管其后来的丰富性，在整个希腊文化中只是一个相对次要的元素，无论是在实践者的数量上还是在其影响力上都无法与修辞学竞争。直接的社会影响（Marrou 1956，第 194-205 页），正如苏格拉底不幸的命运所表明的那样。

In his Volume III of the Oxford History of English Literature, C. S. Lewis observed that ‘rhetoric is the greatest barrier between us and our ancestors’ (1954, p. 60). Lewis honors the magnitude of the subject by refusing to treat it, despite its overwhelming relevance for the culture of all ages at least up to the Age of Romanticism (Ong 1971, pp. 1–22, 255–83). The study of rhetoric dominant in all western cultures until that time had begun as the core of ancient Greek education and culture. In ancient Greece, the study of ‘philosophy’, represented by Socrates, Plato and Aristotle, for all its subsequent fecundity, was a relatively minor element in the total Greek culture, never competitive with rhetoric either in the number of its practitioners or in its immediate social effects (Marrou 1956, pp. 194–205), as Socrates’ unhappy fate suggests.

修辞学本质上是公共演讲、口头演讲、说服（法庭和审议修辞）或阐述（流行修辞）的艺术。希腊语修辞者与拉丁语演说者同源，意为公开演讲者。在哈夫洛克（Havelock，1963）提出的观点中，很明显，在非常深刻的意义上，修辞传统代表了旧的口头世界，而哲学传统则代表了新的手写思想结构。和柏拉图一样，CS 刘易斯实际上在不知不觉中背弃了旧的口头世界。几个世纪以来，直到浪漫主义时代（当时修辞的主旨从口头上转移，即使不是完全转移，也是绝对转移）写作的表现），对修辞学的正式学习和正式实践的明确或什至隐含的承诺是特定文化中残留的初级口语数量的指标（Ong 1971，第23-103页）。

Rhetoric was at root the art of public speaking, of oral address, for persuasion (forensic and deliberative rhetoric) or exposition (epideictic rhetoric). The Greek rhetor is from the same root as the Latin orator and means a public speaker. In the perspectives worked out by Havelock (1963) it would appear obvious that in a very deep sense the rhetorical tradition represented the old oral world and the philosophical tradition the new chirographic structures of thought. Like Plato, C. S. Lewis was in effect unwittingly turning his back on the old oral world. Over the centuries, until the Age of Romanticism (when the thrust of rhetoric was diverted, deﬁnitively if not totally, from oral performance to writing), explicit or even implicit commitment to the formal study and formal practice of rhetoric is an index of the amount of residual primary orality in a given culture (Ong 1971, pp. 23–103).

荷马和前荷马时期的希腊人，就像一般的口语民族一样，早在他们的技能被简化为“艺术”之前就已经以高超的技巧练习公开演讲，也就是说，早在他们的技能被简化为一系列按顺序组织的科学原理，这些原理解释和教唆了口头说服时这种“艺术”在亚里士多德的《修辞艺术》（techn rh torik）中有所体现。正如我们所看到的，口头文化不可能有这种科学组织的“艺术”。没有人能够或能够简单地即兴背诵像亚里士多德的《修辞艺术》这样的论文，如果要实现这种理解，口头文化中的人就必须这样做。冗长的口述作品遵循更多的聚合性、更少的分析性模式。修辞的“艺术”虽然与口头演讲有关，但与其他“艺术”一样，也是写作的产物。

Homeric and the pre-Homeric Greeks, like oral peoples generally, practiced public speaking with great skill long before their skills were reduced to an ‘art’, that is, to a body of sequentially organized, scientiﬁc principles which explained and abetted what verbal persuasion consisted in. Such an ‘art’ is presented in Aristotle’s Art of Rhetoric ( techn rhtorik ). Oral cultures, as has been seen, can have no ‘arts’ of this scientiﬁcally organized sort. No one could or can simply recite extempore a treatise such as Aristotle’s Art of Rhetoric, as someone in an oral culture would have to do if this sort of understanding were to be implemented. Lengthy oral productions follow more agglomerative, less analytic, patterns. The ‘art’ of rhetoric, though concerned with oral speech, was, like other ‘arts’, the product of writing.

来自高科技文化的人，了解过去有关修辞学的大量文献，从古典时期到中世纪、文艺复兴，一直到启蒙时代（例如Kennedy 1980；Murphy 1974；Howell 1956， 1971），多年来人们对这个主题普遍而着迷的兴趣以及花在研究它上的时间，以及对希腊语和拉丁语中数百个修辞格进行分类的庞大而复杂的术语——antomasia或pronominatio，paradiastole或distinctio，反范畴或指控协奏曲等等——（Lanham 1968；Sonnino 1968）可能会这样反应：“真是浪费时间！” 但对于它的第一批发现者或发明者，即五世纪希腊的诡辩家来说，修辞学是一件了不起的事情。它为他们心中最珍视的东西、有效且常常华丽的口头表演提供了理由，这种表演多年来一直是人类生存中独特的人类部分，但在写作之前，永远不可能如此经过反思地准备或解释。

Persons from a high technology culture who become aware of the vast literature of the past dealing with rhetoric, from classical antiquity through the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, and on into the Age of the Enlightenment (e.g. Kennedy 1980; Murphy 1974; Howell 1956, 1971), of the universal and obsessive interest in the subject through the ages and the amount of time spent studying it, of its vast and intricate terminology for classifying hundreds of ﬁgures of speech in Greek and Latin – antinomasia or pronominatio, paradiastole or distinctio, anticategoria or accusatio concertativa, and so on and on and on – (Lanham 1968; Sonnino 1968) are likely to react with, ‘What a waste of time!’ But for its ﬁrst discoverers or inventors, the Sophists of ﬁfth-century Greece, rhetoric was a marvelous thing. It provided a rationale for what was dearest to their hearts, effective and often showy oral performance, something which had been a distinctively human part of human existence for ages but which, before writing, could never have been so reﬂectively prepared for or accounted for.

修辞保留了许多古老的口头思想和表达感觉，基本上是竞争性的和公式化的。这在有关“地点”的修辞教学中清晰可见（Ong 1967b，第 56-87 页；1971 年，第 147-87 页；Howell 1956，索引）。凭借其竞争性的传统，修辞教学假定所有话语的目的或多或少都是为了证明或反驳某个观点，反对某些反对意见。开发一个主题被认为是一个“发明”的过程，即在论据存储中发现其他人一直利用的那些适用于你的情况的论据。这些论点被认为是在“地方”（希腊语中的topoi，拉丁语中的loci）中提出或“就座”（昆体良的术语），并且当它们被认为提供了任何事物所共有的论点时，通常被称为“位点公社”或“共同点”。以及所有主题。

Rhetoric retained much of the old oral feeling for thought and expression as basically agonistic and formulaic. This shows clearly in rhetorical teaching about the ‘places’ (Ong 1967b, pp. 56–87; 1971, pp. 147–87; Howell 1956, Index). With its agonistic heritage, rhetorical teaching assumed that the aim of more or less all discourse was to prove or disprove a point, against some opposition. Developing a subject was thought of as a process of ‘invention’, that is, of ﬁnding in the store of arguments that others had always exploited those arguments which were applicable to your case. These arguments were considered to be lodged or ‘seated’ (Quintilian’s term) in the ‘places’ ( topoi in Greek, loci in Latin), and were often called the loci communes or commonplaces when they were thought of as providing arguments common to any and all subject matter.

至少从昆体良时代开始，“位点公社”就有两种不同的含义。首先，它指的是论证的“位置”，在今天的用语中被视为抽象的“标题”，例如定义、原因、结果、对立、相似性等等（不同作者的分类长度不同）。想要提出一个“证据”——我们应该简单地说是提出一条思路——关于任何主题，例如忠诚、邪恶、被指控的罪犯的罪行、友谊、战争或其他什么，人们总能找到话可说。通过定义、寻找原因、结果、对立面以及所有其他的东西。这些标题可以称为“分析常识”。其次，地点公社俗语或俗语指的是有关各种主题的谚语（实际上是公式）的集合——例如忠诚、颓废、友谊或其他任何东西——可以运用到一个人自己的演讲或写作中。从这个意义上说，场所公社可以被称为“累积的常识”。很明显，无论是分析性的还是累积性的老生常谈，都使古老的口头思想和表达感觉保持活力，这些感觉和表达基本上是由从过去继承的公式化或其他固定材料组成的。这样说并不是要解释整个复杂的学说，它本身就是庞大的修辞艺术的组成部分。

From at least the time of Quintilian, loci communes was taken in two different senses. First, it referred to the ‘seats’ of arguments, considered as abstract ‘headings’ in today’s parlance, such as deﬁnition, cause, effect, opposities, likenesses, and so on (the assortment varied in length from one author to another). Wanting to develop a ‘proof ’ – we should say simply to develop a line of thought – on any subject, such as loyalty, evil, the guilt of an accused criminal, friendship, war, or whatever, one could always ﬁnd something to say by deﬁning, looking to causes, effects, opposites, and all the rest. These headings can be styled the ‘analytic commonplaces’. Secondly, loci communes or commonplaces referred to collections of sayings (in effect, formulas) on various topics – such as loyalty, decadence, friendship, or whatever – that could be worked into one’s own speech-making or writing. In this sense the loci communes can be styled ‘cumulative commonplaces’. Both the analytic and the cumulative commonplaces, it is clear, kept alive the old oral feeling for thought and expression essentially made up of formulaic or otherwise ﬁxed materials inherited from the past. To say this is not to explicate the whole of the complex doctrine, which itself was integral to the massive art of rhetoric.

当然，修辞本质上是对立的（Durand 1960, pp. 451, 453-9），因为演说者至少面对隐含的对手。演讲有着深刻的竞争根源（Ong 1967b，第 192-222 页；1981，第 119-48 页）。庞大的修辞传统的发展是西方特有的，并且无论是作为原因还是结果或两者兼而有之，都与希腊人和他们的文化追随者在精神世界和精神外世界中最大化对立的倾向有关：相比之下印度人和中国人有计划地最小化它们（Lloyd 1966；Oliver 1971）。

Rhetoric of course is essentially antithetical (Durand 1960, pp. 451, 453–9), for the orator speaks in the face of at least implied adversaries. Oratory has deep agonistic roots (Ong 1967b, pp. 192–222; 1981, pp. 119–48). The development of the vast rhetorical tradition was distinctive of the West and was related, whether as cause or effect or both, to the tendency among the Greeks and their cultural epigoni to maximize oppositions, in the mental as in the extramental world: this by contrast with Indians and Chinese, who programmatically minimized them (Lloyd 1966; Oliver 1971).

从古希腊开始，修辞学在学术背景中占据主导地位，给整个文学界留下了这样的印象：尽管常常含糊不清，但这种演讲是真实的，它是所有言语表达的典范，并且以当今的标准来看，使话语的激烈程度保持在极高的水平。诗歌本身经常被同化为流行的演讲，并且被认为基本上与赞美或谴责有关（即使在今天，口头诗歌甚至书面诗歌也是如此）。

From Greek antiquity on, the dominance of rhetoric in the academic background produced throughout the literate world an impression, real if often vague, that oratory was the paradigm of all verbal expression, and kept the agonistic pitch of discourse exceedingly high by present-day standards. Poetry itself was often assimilated to epideictic oratory, and was considered to be concerned basically with praise or blame (as much oral, and even written, poetry is even today).

进入十九世纪，整个西方的大多数文学风格都是由学术修辞以某种方式形成的，但有一个明显的例外：女性作家的文学风格。自 1600 年代以来，在成为出版作家的女性中，几乎没有人接受过任何此类培训。在中世纪及之后，女孩的教育往往是强化的，并培养出有效的家庭管理者，有时有五十到八十人，这些家庭往往是规模较大的企业（Markham 1675，The English House- Wife），但这种教育并不是在用拉丁语教授修辞学和所有其他科目的学术机构中获得的。十七世纪，当一定数量的女孩开始进入学校时，女孩们进入的不是主流的拉丁学校，而是较新的多语种学校。这些学校以实用性为导向，针对商业和内政事务，而以拉丁语为基础教学的老式学校是为那些有志成为神职人员、律师、医生、外交官和其他公务员的人而设。毫无疑问，女性作家受到了她们读过的源自拉丁语、学术、修辞传统的作品的影响，但她们自己通常以一种不同的、远不那么雄辩的声音来表达自己，这与女性作家的兴起有很大关系。小说。

Into the nineteenth century most literary style throughout the West was formed by academic rhetoric, in one way or another, with one notable exception: the literary style of female authors. Of the females who became published writers, as many did from the 1600s on, almost none had any such training. In medieval times and after, the education of girls was often intensive and produced effective managers of households, of sometimes ﬁfty to eighty persons, which were often sizable businesses (Markham 1675, The English House-Wife ), but this education was not acquired in academic institutions, which taught rhetoric and all other subjects in Latin. When they began to enter schools in some numbers during the seventeenth century, girls entered not the mainline Latin schools but the newer vernacular schools. These were practically oriented, for commerce and domestic affairs, whereas the older schools with Latin-based instruction were for those aspiring to be clergy, lawyers, physicians, diplomats, and other public servants. Women writers were no doubt inﬂuenced by works that they had read emanating from the Latin-based, academic, rhetorical tradition, but they themselves normally expressed themselves in a different, far less oratorical voice, which had a great deal to do with the rise of the novel.

互动：学习的语言

INTERACTIONS: LEARNED LANGUAGES

西方影响书写和口语互动的第二个大规模发展是拉丁语。学习拉丁语是写作的直接结果。大约在 550 至 700 英镑之间，欧洲各地作为方言使用的拉丁语已经演变成各种早期形式的意大利语、西班牙语、加泰罗尼亚语、法语和其他罗曼语言。到了 700 英镑，说这些拉丁语分支的人已经无法理解古老的书面拉丁语了，而他们的一些曾祖父母也许可以理解。他们的口语已经离它的起源太远了。但学校教育以及随之而来的教会或国家的大多数官方话语仍然以拉丁语进行。实在是别无选择。欧洲是数百种语言和方言的泥沼，其中大多数至今还没有文字。操着无数日耳曼语和斯拉夫语方言，甚至更具有异国情调的非印欧语系语言（如马扎尔语、芬兰语和土耳其语）的部落正在进入西欧。没有办法将学校和大学教授的文学、科学、哲学、医学或神学著作翻译成大量的口头语言，而这些语言在相距仅五十英里的人群中往往具有不同的、相互难以理解的形式。直到一种或另一种方言因经济或其他原因而占据主导地位，甚至能够获得来自其他方言地区的追随者（如英格兰的东米德兰方言或德国的上德语），唯一实际的政策是向有限数量的男孩教授拉丁语去上学。拉丁语曾经是一种母语，因此成为一种学校语言，不仅在课堂上使用，而且原则上（尽管事实上并非总是如此）在校舍的其他地方也使用。根据学校章程的规定，拉丁语已经成为学习拉丁语，一种完全由书写控制的语言，而新的罗曼白话则是从拉丁语发展而来，就像语言一直以口头形式发展一样。拉丁语经历了音视分裂。

The second massive development in the West affecting the interaction of writing and orality was Learned Latin. Learned Latin was a direct result of writing. Between about  550 and 700 the Latin spoken as a vernacular in various parts of Europe had evolved into various early forms of Italian, Spanish, Catalan, French, and the other Romance languages. By  700, speakers of these offshoots of Latin could no longer understand the old written Latin, intelligible perhaps to some of their great grand parents. Their spoken language had moved too far away from its origins. But schooling, and with it most official discourse of Church or state, continued in Latin. There was really no alternative. Europe was a morass of hundreds of languages and dialects, most of them never written to this day. Tribes speaking countless Germanic and Slavic dialects, and even more exotic, non-Indo-European languages such as Magyar and Finnish and Turkish, were moving into western Europe. There was no way to translate the works, literary, scientiﬁc, philosophical, medical or theological, taught in schools and universities, into the swarming, oral vernaculars which often had different, mutually unintelligible forms among populations perhaps only ﬁfty miles apart. Until one or another dialect for economic or other reasons became dominant enough to gain adherents even from other dialectical regions (as the East Midland dialect did in England or Hochdeutsch in Germany), the only practical policy was to teach Latin to the limited numbers of boys going to school. Once a mother tongue, Latin thus became a school language only, spoken not only in the classroom but also, in principle if far from always in fact, everywhere else on the school premises. By prescription of school statutes Latin had become Learned Latin, a language completely controlled by writing, whereas the new Romance vernaculars had developed out of Latin as languages had always developed, orally. Latin had undergone a sound-sight split.

由于它的基础是学术界，而学术界完全是男性——除了极其罕见的例外，可以忽略不计——除了其古典起源之外，学术拉丁语与修辞学还有另一个共同点。一千多年来，它与性别相关，是一种仅由男性书写和使用的语言，在家庭之外的部落环境中学习，这实际上是一种男性青春期仪式的环境，包括体罚和其他故意强加的形式（Ong 1971，第 113-41 页；1981，第 119-48 页）。它与任何人的无意识没有直接的联系，而母语是在婴儿期学到的，总是有这种联系。

Because of its base in academia, which was totally male – with exceptions so utterly rare as to be quite negligible – Learned Latin had another feature in common with rhetoric besides its classical provenance. For well over a thousand years, it was sex-linked, a language written and spoken only by males, learned outside the home in a tribal setting which was in effect a male puberty rite setting, complete with physical punishment and other kinds of deliberately imposed hardships (Ong 1971, pp. 113–41; 1981, pp. 119–48). It had no direct connection with anyone’s unconscious of the sort that mother tongues, learned in infancy, always have.

然而，学习的拉丁语与口语和读写能力之间存在着矛盾的关系。一方面，正如刚才所指出的，它是一种手写控制的语言。在接下来的 1400 年里，数百万说它的人中，每个人都能够写它。不存在纯粹口头使用者。但对学术拉丁语的手写控制并没有排除它与口头语言的联盟。矛盾的是，文本性使拉丁语植根于古典古代，因此也使其植根于口头，因为古典教育的理想不是培养有效的作家，而是培养修辞者。演说家，公众演说家。拉丁语的语法来自这个古老的口头世界。它的基本词汇也是如此，尽管像所有实际使用的语言一样，几个世纪以来它吸收了数千个新单词。

Learned Latin related to orality and literacy, however, in paradoxical ways. On the one hand, as just noted, it was a chirographically controlled language. Of the millions who spoke it for the next 1400 years, every one was able also to write it. There were no purely oral users. But chirographic control of Learned Latin did not preclude its alliance with orality. Paradoxically, the textuality that kept Latin rooted in classical antiquity thereby kept it rooted also in orality, for the classical ideal of education had been to produce not the effective writer but the rhetor, the orator, the public speaker. The grammar of Learned Latin came from this old oral world. So did its basic vocabulary, although, like all languages actually in use, it incorporated thousands of new words over the centuries.

没有儿语，与语言有着最深的心灵根源的童年生活隔绝，对于任何使用者来说，它都是第一语言，在欧洲各地的发音方式常常互相无法理解，但书写方式总是相同，学习拉丁语是一种引人注目的语言。写作对于孤立话语的力量以及这种孤立的无与伦比的生产力的例证。正如之前所见，写作的作用是将认识者和已知者分开并保持距离，从而建立客观性。有人提出（Ong 1977，第 24-9 页），学习拉丁语通过在与母语的情感深处隔离的媒介中建立知识，从而实现更大的客观性，从而减少了来自人类生活世界的干扰，并使中世纪经院哲学和继经院经验而产生的新数学现代科学的精致抽象世界成为可能。如果没有《博学的拉丁语》，现代科学如果真的能够起步的话，它的发展似乎会遇到更大的困难。现代科学在拉丁语的土壤中生长，艾萨克·牛顿爵士时代的哲学家和科学家通常都用拉丁语写作和进行抽象思维。

Devoid of baby-talk, insulated from the earliest life of childhood where language has its deepest psychic roots, a ﬁrst language to none of its users, pronounced across Europe in often mutually unintelligible ways but always written the same way, Learned Latin was a striking exempliﬁcation of the power of writing for isolating discourse and of the unparalleled productivity of such isolation. Writing, as has earlier been seen, serves to separate and distance the knower and the known and thus to establish objectivity.
