It has been suggested (Ong 1977, pp. 24–9) that Learned Latin effects even greater objectivity by establishing knowledge in a medium insulated from the emotion-charged depths of one’s mother tongue, thus reducing interference from the human lifeworld and making possible the exquisitely abstract world of medieval scholasticism and of the new mathematical modern science which followed on the scholastic experience. Without Learned Latin, it appears that modern science would have got under way with greater difficulty, if it had got under way at all. Modern science grew in Latin soil, for philosophers and scientists through the time of Sir Isaac Newton commonly both wrote and did their abstract thinking in Latin.

像学习拉丁语这样受手写控制的语言与各种方言（母语）之间的相互作用仍然远未完全被理解。没有办法简单地将诸如学习拉丁语之类的语言“翻译”成诸如白话文之类的语言。翻译就是转变。互动产生了各种特殊的结果。例如，Bäuml (1980, p. 264) 就提请注意当有意识地隐喻的拉丁语中的隐喻被转移到隐喻程度较低的母语中时所产生的一些影响。

Interaction between such a chirographically controlled language as Learned Latin and the various vernaculars (mother tongues) is still far from being completely understood. There is no way simply to ‘translate’ a language such as Learned Latin into languages like the vernaculars. Translation was transformation. Interaction produced all sorts of special results. Bäuml (1980, p. 264) has called attention, for example, to some of the effects when metaphors from a consciously metaphorical Latin were shifted into less metaphoricized mother tongues.

在此期间，其他受手写控制、与性别相关的男性语言在欧洲和亚洲发展起来，那里有大量识字人口希望分享共同的知识遗产。与学习拉丁语几乎同时代的是拉比希伯来语、古典阿拉伯语、梵语和古典汉语，拜占庭希腊语是第六种，更不明确的学习语言，因为白话希腊语与其保持着密切的联系（Ong 1977，第28-34页）。这些语言都没有作为母语使用的时间更长（也就是说，从简单的意义上讲，母亲在抚养孩子时不使用）。它们从来都不是任何个人的第一语言，完全由书写控制，仅由男性使用（除了可以忽略不计的例外，尽管古典汉语的例外可能比其他语言更多），并且只有那些能够书写和书写它们的人才使用它们。事实上，他们最初是通过书写来学习这些知识的。这样的语言已经不复存在，今天也很难感受到它们早期的力量。当今用于学术话语的所有语言也是母语（或者，就阿拉伯语而言，它们越来越多地同化为母语）。

During this period, other chirographically controlled, sexlinked male languages developed in Europe and Asia where sizable literate populations wanted to share a common intellectual heritage. Pretty much coeval with Learned Latin were Rabbinic Hebrew, Classical Arabic, Sanskrit, and Classical Chinese, with Byzantine Greek a sixth, much less deﬁnitively learned language, for vernacular Greek kept close contact with it (Ong 1977, pp. 28–34). These languages were all no longer in use as mother tongues (that is, in the straightforward sense, not used by mothers in raising children). They were never ﬁrst languages for any individual, were controlled exclusively by writing, were spoken by males only (with negligible exceptions, though perhaps with more exceptions for Classical Chinese than for the others), and were spoken only by those who could write them and who, indeed, had learned them initially by the use of writing. Such languages are no more, and it is difficult today to sense their earlier power. All languages used for learned discourse today are also mother tongues (or, in the case of Arabic, are more and more assimilating to themselves mother tongues). Nothing shows more convincingly than this disappearance of chirographically controlled language how writing is losing its earlier power monopoly (though not its importance) in today’s world.

口语的坚韧

TENACIOUSNESS OF ORALITY

正如修辞学和拉丁语中口语和读写能力的矛盾关系所表明的那样，从口语到读写能力的转变是缓慢的（Ong 1967b，第 53-87 页；1971 年，第 23-48 页）。中世纪对文本的使用远多于古希腊和罗马，教师在大学里以文本讲授，但从来没有通过写作来测试知识或智力能力，而总是通过口头辩论——这种做法在十九世纪和今天仍在不断减少。在越来越少的地方进行这种做法的博士论文答辩中，这种做法仍然残存下来。尽管文艺复兴时期的人文主义发明了现代文本学术并主导了凸版印刷术的发展，但它也追溯到古代，从而赋予了口头语言新的生命。都铎王朝时期的英式风格（Ong 1971，第 174 页）23-47），甚至在很久以后，它在绰号、平衡、对立、公式结构和常见材料的使用中都带有大量的口头残留。一般来说，西欧文学风格也是如此。

As the paradoxical relationships of orality and literacy in rhetoric and Learned Latin suggest, the transition from orality to literacy was slow (Ong 1967b, pp. 53–87; 1971, pp. 23–48). The Middle Ages used texts far more than ancient Greece and Rome, teachers lectured on texts in the universities, and yet never tested knowledge or intellectual prowess by writing, but always by oral dispute – a practice continued in diminishing ways into the nineteenth century and today still surviving vestigially in the defense of the doctoral dissertation in the fewer and fewer places where this is practiced. Though Renaissance humanism invented modern textual scholarship and presided over the development of letterpress printing, it also harked back to antiquity and thereby gave new life to orality. English style in the Tudor period (Ong 1971, pp. 23–47) and even much later carried heavy oral residue in its use of epithets, balance, antithesis, formulary structures, and commonplace materials. And so with western European literary styles generally.

在西方古典时期，人们理所当然地认为，任何有价值的书面文本都应该被大声朗读，并且大声朗读文本的做法在整个十九世纪持续存在，而且很常见，但有许多变化（Balogh 1926） ）。这种做法从古代到近代都强烈影响着文学风格（Balogh 1926；Crosby 1936；Nelson 1976-7；Ahern1982）。十九世纪仍然向往古老的口语，发展了“演讲”比赛，试图重新印刷印刷文本，使用仔细的艺术技巧逐字记忆文本并背诵它们，以便它们听起来像即兴的口头作品（Howell 1971，第144页） –256）。狄更斯在演说家的讲台上朗读他的小说选集。著名的《麦加菲读物》于 1836 年至 1920 年间在美国出版了约 1.2 亿册，它被设计为补习读本，其目的不是提高我们今天理想化的理解阅读能力，而是提高口头、朗诵式阅读。麦加菲专门研究与伟大英雄（“沉重的”口头人物）有关的“声音意识”文学中的段落。他们提供了无尽的口语发音和呼吸练习（Lynn 1973，第 16、20 页）。

In western classical antiquity, it was taken for granted that a written text of any worth was meant to be and deserved to be read aloud, and the practice of reading texts aloud continued, quite commonly with many variations, through the nineteenth century (Balogh 1926). This practice strongly inﬂuenced literary style from antiquity until rather recent times (Balogh 1926; Crosby 1936; Nelson 1976–7; Ahern 1982). Still yearning for the old orality, the nineteenth century developed ‘elocution’ contests, which tried to repristinate printed texts, using careful artistry to memorize the texts verbatim and recite them so that they would sound like extempore oral productions (Howell 1971, pp. 144–256). Dickens read selections from his novels on the orator’s platform. The famous McGuffey’s Readers, published in the United States in some 120 million copies between 1836 and 1920, were designed as remedial readers to improve not the reading for comprehension which we idealize today, but oral, declamatory reading. The McGuffey’s specialized in passages from ‘sound-conscious’ literature concerned with great heroes (‘heavy’ oral characters). They provided endless oral pronunciation and breathing drills (Lynn 1973, pp. 16, 20).

修辞本身逐渐但不可避免地从口头世界迁移到手写世界。从古典时期开始，修辞学中学到的言语技巧不仅应用于演讲，也应用于写作。到了十六世纪，修辞学教科书普遍省略了传统修辞学的五个部分（发明、安排、风格、记忆和表达）中的第四部分，即记忆，它不适用于写作。他们还最大限度地减少了最后一部分，交付（Howell 1956, pp. 146–72, 270, et passim）。总的来说，他们做出这些改变时给出了似是而非的解释，或者根本没有解释。如今，当课程将修辞学列为一门学科时，它通常意味着简单地学习如何有效地写作。但没有人有意识地发起一项计划来为修辞学提供新的方向：“艺术”只是跟随意识从口头经济转向写作经济的转变。还没等察觉到有什么事情发生，漂移就完成了。一旦完成，修辞学就不再像以前那样是一个无处不在的主题：教育不再像过去那样从根本上被描述为修辞学。三个Rs——阅读、“riting”和“rithmetic”——代表一种本质上非修辞性、书本性、商业性和家庭教育，逐渐取代了传统的口头基础、英雄式、竞争性教育，这种教育过去通常为年轻人做好教学和职业准备，教会或政治公共服务。在此过程中，随着修辞学和拉丁语的消失，女性越来越多地进入学术界，学术界也变得越来越商业化（Ong 1967b，第241-55页）。

Rhetoric itself gradually but inevitably migrated from the oral to the chirographic world. From classical antiquity the verbal skills learned in rhetoric were put to use not only in oratory but also in writing. By the sixteenth century rhetoric textbooks were commonly omitting from the traditional ﬁve parts of rhetoric (invention, arrangement, style, memory and delivery) the fourth part, memory, which was not applicable to writing. They were also minimizing the last part, delivery (Howell 1956, pp. 146–72, 270, et passim ). By and large, they made these changes with specious explanations or no explanation at all. Today, when curricula list rhetoric as a subject, it usually means simply the study of how to write effectively. But no one ever consciously launched a program to give this new direction to rhetoric: the ‘art’ simply followed the drift of consciousness away from an oral to a writing economy. The drift was completed before it was noticed that anything was happening. Once it was completed, rhetoric was no longer the allpervasive subject it had once been: education could no longer be described as fundamentally rhetorical as it could be in past ages. The three R s – reading, ’riting, and ’rithmetic – representing an essentially nonrhetorical, bookish, commercial and domestic education, gradually took over from the traditional orally grounded, heroic, agonistic education that had generally prepared young men in the past for teaching and professional, ecclesiastical, or political public service. In the process, as rhetoric and Latin went out, women entered more and more into academia, which also became more and more commercially oriented (Ong 1967b, pp. 241–55).

5

5

印刷、空间和闭合

PRINT, SPACE AND CLOSURE

听觉优势屈服于视力优势

HEARING-DOMINANCE YIELDS TO SIGHT-DOMINANCE

虽然本书主要关注口头文化以及写作带来的思想和表达的变化，但它必须对印刷品给予一些简短的关注，因为印刷品既加强又改变了写作对思想和表达的影响。由于从口头语言到书面语言的转变本质上是从声音空间到视觉空间的转变，因此印刷品对视觉空间使用的影响可能是中心，但不是唯一的关注焦点。这一焦点不仅揭示了印刷与书写之间的关系，也揭示了印刷与仍残留在书写和早期印刷文化中的口头语言的关系。此外，虽然印刷品的所有效果并不会减少其对视觉空间使用的影响，但许多其他效果确实以各种方式与这种使用相关。

Although this book attends chieﬂy to oral culture and to the changes in thought and expression introduced by writing, it must give some brief attention to print, for print both reinforces and transforms the effects of writing on thought and expression. Since the shift from oral to written speech is essentially a shift from sound to visual space, here the effects of print on the use of visual space can be the central, though not the only, focus of attention. This focus brings out not only the relationship between print and writing, but also the relationship of print to the orality still residual in writing and early print culture. Moreover, while all the effects of print do not reduce to its effects on the use of visual space, many of the other effects do relate to this use in various ways.

在如此规模的作品中，甚至无法列举印刷的所有效果。即使粗略地浏览一下伊丽莎白·爱森斯坦的两卷书《印刷机作为变革的推动者》（1979 年），也足以清楚地表明印刷的特殊影响是多么多样化和巨大。爱森斯坦详细阐述了印刷术如何使意大利文艺复兴成为永久的欧洲文艺复兴，它如何实施新教改革和重新定位天主教的宗教实践，它如何影响现代资本主义的发展，实施西欧对全球的探索，改变了家庭生活和政治，以前所未有的方式传播知识，使全民识字成为一个严肃的目标，使现代科学的兴起成为可能，并以其他方式改变了社会和知识生活。在《古腾堡星系》（1962）和《理解媒体》（1964）中，马歇尔·麦克卢汉呼吁人们关注印刷品影响意识的许多微妙方式，正如乔治·斯坦纳在《语言与沉默》（1967）中所做的那样，以及我在其他地方所做的那样（翁1958b；1967b；1971；1977）。印刷品对意识的这些微妙影响，而不是容易观察到的社会影响，在这里让我们特别关注。

In a work of this scope there is no way even to enumerate all the effects of print. Even a cursory glance at Elizabeth Eisenstein’s two volumes, The Printing Press as an Agent of Change (1979), makes abundantly evident how diversiﬁed and vast the particular effects of print have been. Eisenstein spells out in detail how print made the Italian Renaissance a permanent European Renaissance, how it implemented the Protestant Reformation and reoriented Catholic religious practice, how it affected the development of modern capitalism, implemented western European exploration of the globe, changed family life and politics, diffused knowledge as never before, made universal literacy a serious objective, made possible the rise of modern sciences, and otherwise altered social and intellectual life. In The Gutenberg Galaxy (1962) and Understanding Media (1964) Marshall McLuhan has called attention to many of the subtler ways print has affected consciousness, as George Steiner has also done in Language and Silence (1967) and as I have undertaken to do elsewhere (Ong 1958b; 1967b; 1971; 1977). These subtler effects of print on consciousness, rather than readily observable social effects, concern us particularly here.

几千年来，人类一直在各种雕刻表面上印刷图案，自七世纪或八世纪以来，中国人、韩国人和日本人一直在印刷口头文本，首先是用浮雕木版印刷（Carter 1955）。但全球印刷史上最重要的发展是十五世纪欧洲字母凸版印刷术的发明。字母书写将单词分解为音位单位的空间等价物（原则上，尽管这些字母从未完全作为完全音位指示符）。但书面中使用的字母并不存在于它们出现的文本之前。对于字母凸版印刷则不然。单词是由单元（类型）组成的，这些单元在它们将构成的单词之前就作为单元预先存在。

For thousands of years human beings have been printing designs from variously carved surfaces, and since the seventh or eighth century Chinese, Koreans and Japanese have been printing verbal texts, at ﬁrst from wood blocks engraved in relief (Carter 1955). But the crucial development in the global history of printing was the invention of alphabetic letterpress print in ﬁfteenth-century Europe. Alphabetic writing had broken the word up into spatial equivalents of phonemic units (in principle, though the letters never quite worked out as totally phonemic indicators). But the letters used in writing do not exist before the text in which they occur. With alphabetic letterpress print it is otherwise. Words are made out of units (types) which pre-exist as units before the words which they will constitute. Print suggests that words are things far more than writing ever did.

与字母表一样，字母凸版印刷也是一项临时发明（Ong 1967b，并引用了其中的参考文献）。中国人有活字印刷术，但没有字母，只有汉字，基本上是象形文字。1400年代中期之前，朝鲜人和维吾尔突厥人既有字母表，也有活字印刷术，但活字印刷术不是单独的字母，而是整个单词。字母凸版印刷，其中每个字母都铸造在单独的金属或字体上，标志着心理上的第一次突破。它将这个词本身深深嵌入到制造过程中，并使之成为一种商品。第一条装配线是一种制造技术，通过一系列设定的步骤生产由可更换零件组成的相同复杂物体，它不是生产炉子、鞋子或武器，而是生产印刷书籍。打印机使用了三百年的技术。尽管有许多符号结构主义者的假设，但有效地具体化了这个词的是印刷品，而不是文字，以及随之而来的意念活动（Ong 1958b，第306-18页）。

Like the alphabet, alphabetic letterpress print was a nonce invention (Ong 1967b, and references there cited). The Chinese had had movable type, but no alphabet, only characters, basically pictographic. Before the mid-1400s the Koreans and Uigur Turks had both the alphabet and movable type, but the movable types bore not separate letters but whole words. Alphabet letterpress printing, in which each letter was cast on a separate piece of metal, or type, marked a psychological breakthrough of the ﬁrst order. It embedded the word itself deeply in the manufacturing process and made it into a kind of commodity. The ﬁrst assembly line, a technique of manufacture which in a series of set steps produces identical complex objects made up of replaceable parts, was not one which produced stoves or shoes or weaponry but one which produced the printed book. In the late 1700s, the industrial revolution applied to other manufacturing the replaceable-part techniques which printers had worked with for three hundred years. Despite the assumptions of many semiotic structuralists, it was print, not writing, that effectively reiﬁed the word, and, with it, noetic activity (Ong 1958b, pp. 306–18).

即使在书写被深深内化很久之后，听觉而不是视觉在很大程度上主导了古老的心灵世界。西方的手稿文化始终处于边缘口头状态。米兰的安布罗斯在他对卢克的评论中捕捉到了早期的情绪(iv. 5)：“视觉常被欺骗，听觉为保证。” 在整个文艺复兴时期的西方，演说是所有口头作品中受教最多的，并且仍然隐含地是所有书面和口头话语的基本范式。书面材料对听觉的辅助作用在今天看来是很奇怪的。写作主要是为了将知识重新带回口头世界，例如在中世纪的大学辩论中，在向小组朗读文学和其他文本时（Crosby 1936；Ahern 1981；Nelson 1976-7），以及大声朗读（即使是自己朗读） 。至少到了十二世纪的英国，即使是书面财务账目的检查仍然是通过大声朗读来进行的。Clanchy (1979, pp. 215, 183) 描述了这种做法并提请注意这样一个事实：它仍然存在于我们的词汇中：即使在今天，我们仍然谈论“审计”，即“听”账簿，尽管今天会计师实际上所做的是亲眼检查账簿。早些时候，仅靠口头表达的人们通过听甚至比看还能更好地理解数字。

Hearing rather than sight had dominated the older noetic world in signiﬁcant ways, even long after writing was deeply interiorized. Manuscript culture in the West remained always marginally oral. Ambrose of Milan caught the earlier mood in his Commentary on Luke (iv. 5): ‘Sight is often deceived, hearing serves as guarantee.’ In the West through the Renaissance, the oration was the most taught of all verbal productions and remained implicitly the basic paradigm for all discourse, written as well as oral. Written material was subsidiary to hearing in ways which strike us today as bizarre. Writing served largely to recycle knowledge back into the oral world, as in medieval university disputations, in the reading of literary and other texts to groups (Crosby 1936; Ahern 1981; Nelson 1976–7), and in reading aloud even when reading to oneself. At least as late as the twelfth century in England, checking even written ﬁnancial accounts was still done aurally, by having them read aloud. Clanchy (1979, pp. 215, 183) describes the practice and draws attention to the fact that it still registers in our vocabulary: even today, we speak of ‘auditing’, that is, ‘hearing’ account books, though what an accountant actually does today is examine them by sight. Earlier, residually oral folk could understand even ﬁgures better by listening than by looking.

即使在检索文本中保存的材料时，手稿文化仍然主要是口头的。按照后来的印刷标准，手稿并不容易阅读，而且读者在手稿中发现的内容往往至少会在一定程度上记住。重新定位手稿中的材料并不总是那么容易。在高度口头手稿文化中，即使在书面文本中遇到的语言表达也经常延续口头助记模式，从而方便回忆，这一事实也鼓励和促进了记忆。此外，读者通常会发声、缓慢地大声朗读或低声朗读，即使是单独阅读时，这也有助于固定记忆中的内容。

Manuscript cultures remained largely oral-aural even in retrieval of material preserved in texts. Manuscripts were not easy to read, by later typographic standards, and what readers found in manuscripts they tended to commit at least somewhat to memory. Relocating material in a manuscript was not always easy. Memorization was encouraged and facilitated also by the fact that in highly oral manuscript cultures, the verbalization one encountered even in written texts often continued the oral mnemonic patterning that made for ready recall. Moreover, readers commonly vocalized, read slowly aloud or sotto voce, even when reading alone, and this also helped ﬁx matter in the memory.

印刷术发明后，听觉处理在一段时间内继续主导可见的印刷文本，尽管它最终被印刷术侵蚀了。可见听觉优势在诸如早期印刷的标题页之类的东西中尤为引人注目，在我们看来，它们常常因为对视觉单词单位的不注意而显得非常不稳定。十六世纪的标题页非常常见地用连字符分隔主要单词，包括作者姓名，在一行中以大字体显示单词的第一部分，而后半部分则以较小的字体显示，如托马斯·埃利奥特爵士的《The》的版本。 Boke 命名为 Gouernour，由 Thomas Berthelet 于 1534 年在伦敦出版（此处图 1；参见 Steinberg 1974，第 154 页）。无关紧要的单词可能会被设置在巨大的字体中：在此处显示的标题页上，首字母“THE”是迄今为止最突出的所有人的话。作为视觉设计，其结果通常是美观的，但它对我们目前的文本感造成了严重破坏。然而这个修行，不是我们的修行，是我们现在的修行所偏离的原始修行。我们的态度已经改变，因此需要解释。为什么原来的、大概更“自然”的程序对我们来说似乎是错误的？因为我们感觉面前的印刷文字是视觉单位（尽管我们在阅读时至少在想象中听起来如此）。显然，在处理文本意义时，十六世纪比我们更关注单词的视觉而不是单词的声音。所有文本都涉及视觉和声音。但是，尽管我们觉得阅读是一种视觉活动，为我们提供声音提示，但印刷品的早期时代仍然认为它主要是一种聆听过程，只需通过视觉即可启动。如果你觉得自己作为读者正在听文字，那么如果可见文本遵循自己的视觉美学方式，会有什么不同呢？人们会记得，预印本手稿通常将单词放在一起或将单词之间的间距保持在最小限度。

Well after printing was developed, auditory processing continued for some time to dominate the visible, printed text, though it was eventually eroded away by print. Auditory dominance can be seen strikingly in such things as early printed title pages, which often seem to us crazily erratic in the their inattention to visual word units. Sixteenth-century title pages very commonly divide even major words, including the author’s name, with hyphens, presenting the ﬁrst part of a word in one line in large type and the latter part in smaller type, as in the edition of Sir Thomas Elyot’s The Boke Named the Gouernour published in London by Thomas Berthelet in 1534 (Figure 1 here; see Steinberg 1974, p. 154). Inconsequential words may be set in huge type faces: on the title page shown here the initial ‘THE’ is by far the most prominent word of all. The result is often aesthetically pleasing as a visual design, but it plays havoc with our present sense of textuality. Yet this practice, not our practice, is the original practice from which our present practice has deviated. Our attitudes are the ones that have changed, and thus that need to be explained. Why does the original, presumably more ‘natural’ procedure seem wrong to us? Because we feel the printed words before us as visual units (even though we sound them at least in the imagination when we read). Evidently, in processing text for meaning, the sixteenth century was concentrating less on the sight of the word and more on its sound than we do. All text involves sight and sound. But whereas we feel reading as a visual activity cueing in sounds for us, the early age of print still felt it as primarily a listening process, simply set in motion by sight. If you felt yourself as reader to be listening to words, what difference did it make if the visible text went its own visually aesthetic way? It will be recalled that pre-print manuscripts commonly ran words together or kept spaces between them minimal.

图1

Figure 1

然而，最终，印刷品用视觉主导地位取代了思想和表达世界中挥之不去的听觉主导地位，视觉主导地位始于书写，但仅靠书写的支持无法蓬勃发展。印刷品比书写更无情地将文字置于空间中。书写将文字从声音世界转移到视觉空间世界，而印刷则将文字锁定在这个空间中的位置。对位置的控制就是印刷品的一切。手动“排版”类型（排版的原始形式）包括手动定位预先形成的字母类型，这些字母类型在使用后被仔细地重新定位，重新分配到案例中适当的隔间（大写字母或“大写”字母）以供将来使用上部隔间中为小写字母或“小写”字母，下部隔间中为小写字母）。在排版上进行排版包括使用机器来定位各个线条的单独矩阵，以便可以从正确定位的矩阵中铸造出一行字体。在计算机终端或文字处理程序上进行写作会定位先前编程到计算机中的电子图案（字母）。从“热金属”活字（即铸造活字——较旧的工艺）进行打印需要将活字锁定在模框中绝对刚性的位置，将模框牢固地锁定在印刷机上，然后将其固定并固定在印刷机上。压紧排版，用很大的压力将活字版压到与压板接触的纸张印刷面上。

Eventually, however, print replaced the lingering hearing-dominance in the world of thought and expression with the sight-dominance which had its beginnings with writing but could not ﬂourish with the support of writing alone. Print situates words in space more relentlessly than writing ever did. Writing moves words from the sound world to a world of visual space, but print locks words into position in this space. Control of position is everything in print. ‘Composing’ type by hand (the original form of typesetting) consists in positioning by hand preformed letter types, which, after use, are carefully repositioned, redistributed for future use into their proper compartments in the case (capitals or ‘upper case’ letters in the upper compartments, small or ‘lower case’ letters in the lower compartments). Composing on the linotype consists in using a machine to position the separate matrices for individual lines so that a line of type can be cast from the properly positioned matrices. Composing on a computer terminal or wordprocesser positions electronic patterns (letters) previously programmed into the computer. Printing from ‘hot metal’ type (that is, from cast type – the older process) calls for locking up the type in an absolutely rigid position in the chase, locking the chase ﬁrmly onto a press, affixing and clamping down the make ready, and squeezing the forme of type with great pressure onto the paper printing surface in contact with the platen.

大多数读者当然没有意识到所有这些产生了他们面前的印刷文本的运动。然而，从印刷文本的外观来看，他们感受到了与书写所传达的完全不同的空间词感。印刷文本看起来就像是机器制造的。书法对空间的控制往往是装饰性的、华丽的，就像书法一样。排版控制通常因其整洁和必然性而给人留下更深刻的印象：线条完全规则，所有内容都在右侧合理，一切都在视觉上清晰可见，并且没有手稿中经常出现的指南或规则边框的帮助。这是一个充满冷酷、非人类事实的世界。

Most readers are of course not consciously aware of all this locomotion that has produced the printed text confronting them. Nevertheless, from the appearance of the printed text they pick up a sense of the word-in-space quite different from that conveyed by writing. Printed texts look machine-made, as they are. Chirographic control of space tends to be ornamental, ornate, as in calligraphy. Typographic control typically impresses more by its tidiness and inevitability: the lines perfectly regular, all justiﬁed on the right side, everything coming out even visually, and without the aid of the guidelines or ruled borders that often occur in manuscripts. This is an insistent world of cold, nonhuman, facts. ‘That’s the way it is’ – Walter Cronkite’s television signature comes from the world of print that underlies the secondary orality of television (Ong 1971, pp. 284–303).

总的来说，印刷文本比手稿文本更容易阅读。印刷品的易读性提高所带来的影响是巨大的。更高的易读性最终有助于快速、默读。这样的阅读反过来又使读者和文本中作者的声音之间产生了不同的关系，并要求不同的写作风格。印刷品的制作过程中除了作者之外还涉及许多人——出版商、文学代理人、出版商的读者、文案编辑等。在经过这些人的审查之前和之后，印刷品写作通常需要作者进行艰苦的修改，其数量级在手稿文化中几乎是未知的。如今，来自手稿文化的长篇散文作品很少能作为原创作品通过编辑审查：它们的组织方式并不是为了从印刷的页面上快速吸收。手稿文化是以生产者为导向的，因为作品的每一份副本都代表着单个抄写员的大量时间消耗。中世纪的手稿中充斥着浮夸的缩写，这对抄写员来说是有利的，尽管它们给读者带来了不便。印刷品是面向消费者的，因为作品的单个副本代表的时间投入要少得多：花费几个小时来制作更具可读性的文本将立即改善成千上万的副本。印刷品对思想和风格的影响尚未得到充分评估。日记 尽管给读者带来不便，但它们对抄写者有利。印刷品是面向消费者的，因为作品的单个副本代表的时间投入要少得多：花费几个小时来制作更具可读性的文本将立即改善成千上万的副本。印刷品对思想和风格的影响尚未得到充分评估。日记 尽管给读者带来不便，但它们对抄写者有利。印刷品是面向消费者的，因为作品的单个副本代表的时间投入要少得多：花费几个小时来制作更具可读性的文本将立即改善成千上万的副本。印刷品对思想和风格的影响尚未得到充分评估。日记可见语言（以前称为《印刷研究杂志》）发表了许多有助于此类评估的文章。

By and large, printed texts are far easier to read than manuscript texts. The effects of the greater legibility of print are massive. The greater legibility ultimately makes for rapid, silent reading. Such reading in turn makes for a different relationship between the reader and the authorial voice in the text and calls for different styles of writing. Print involves many persons besides the author in the production of a work – publishers, literary agents, publishers’ readers, copy editors and others. Before as well as after scrutiny by such persons, writing for print often calls for painstaking revisions by the author of an order of magnitude virtually unknown in a manuscript culture. Few lengthy prose works from manuscript cultures could pass editorial scrutiny as original works today: they are not organized for rapid assimilation from a printed page. Manuscript culture is producer-oriented, since every individual copy of a work represents great expenditure of an individual copyist’s time. Medieval manuscripts are turgid with abbreviations, which favor the copyist although they inconvenience the reader. Print is consumer-oriented, since the individual copies of a work represent a much smaller investment of time: a few hours spent in producing a more readable text will immediately improve thousands upon thousands of copies. The effects of print on thought and style have yet to be assessed fully. The journal Visible Language (formerly called the Journal of Typographic Research ) published many articles contributory to such an assessment.

空间和意义

SPACE AND MEANING

写作在视觉空间中重构了最初的口头语言。印刷将单词更明确地嵌入到空间中。这可以从列表（尤其是字母索引）、使用单词（而不是图像符号）作为标签、使用各种印刷图画来传达信息以及使用抽象印刷空间来表达信息等方面看出。从拉米主义到具体诗歌，再到德里达与（印刷的，通常是，而不是简单的书面）文本的标识学，一系列发展路线与印刷文字进行几何互动。

Writing had reconstituted the originally oral, spoken word in visual space. Print embedded the word in space more deﬁnitively. This can be seen in such developments as lists, especially alphabetic indexes, in the use of words (instead of iconographic signs) for labels, in the use of printed drawings of all sorts to convey information, and in the use of abstract typographic space to interact geometrically with printed words in a line of development that runs from Ramism to concrete poetry and to Derrida’s logomachy with the (printed, typically, not simply written) text.

（一）索引

(i) Indexes

列表从书写开始。Goody 讨论了（1977 年，第 741 1 1 页）公元前 1300 年左右的乌加里特文字和其他早期文字中列表的使用。他指出（1977 年，第 87-8 页），列表中的信息是从它所嵌入的社会情境中抽象出来的（“养肥的孩子”、“放牧的母羊”等，没有进一步的说明），而且来自语言环境（通常在口头表达中，名词不像列表中那样自由浮动，而是嵌入句子中：我们很少听到简单的一串名词的口头背诵——除非它们是从书面或印刷的列表中读出的） 。从这个意义上说，列表本身“没有口头对应物”（1977，第86-7页），尽管各个书面单词当然在内耳中听起来会产生它们的含义。古迪还指出了最初尴尬的、临时的制作这些列表时利用空间的方式，使用分词器将项目与数字、格线、楔形线和拉长线分开。除了行政列表之外，他还讨论了事件列表、词汇列表（单词以不同的顺序列出，通常按含义分层——诸神，然后是众神的亲属，下一位神的仆人），以及埃及的名字列表或名字列表，这些列表通常是熟记以供口语背诵。仍然高度口头手稿文化认为，写出一系列可供口头回忆的东西本身就可以提高智力。（西方教育家直到最近也有同样的感觉，世界各地的大多数教育工作者可能仍然有这种感觉。）写作在这里再次为口头服务。

Lists begin with writing. Goody has discussed (1977, pp. 741 1 1) the use of lists in the Ugaritic script of around 1300 BC and in other early scripts. He notes (1977, pp. 87–8) that the information in the lists is abstracted from the social situation in which it had been embedded (‘fattened kids’, ‘pastured ewes’, etc., with no further speciﬁcations) and also from linguistic context (normally in oral utterance nouns are not free-ﬂoating as in lists, but are embedded in sentences: rarely do we hear an oral recitation of simply a string of nouns – unless they are being read off a written or printed list). In this sense, lists as such have ‘no oral equivalent’ (1977, pp. 86–7) though of course the individual written words sound in the inner ear to yield their meanings. Goody also notes the initially awkward, ad hoc way in which space was utilized in making these lists, with word-dividers to separate items from numbers, ruled lines, wedged lines, and elongated lines. Besides administrative lists, he discusses also event lists, lexical lists (words are listed in various orders, often hierarchically by meaning – gods, then kin of the gods, next gods’ servants), and Egyptian onomastica or name-lists, which were often memorized for oral recitation. Still highly oral manuscript culture felt that having written series of things readied for oral recall was of itself intellectually improving. (Educators in the West until recently had the same feeling, and across the world most educators probably still do.) Writing is here once more at the service of orality.

古迪的例子展示了手写文化中对语言材料的相对复杂的处理，以便使材料通过其空间组织更容易被检索。列出同一物理、视觉空间中相关项目的范围名称。印刷品在视觉组织和有效检索方面对空间的利用更加复杂。

Goody’s examples show the relatively sophisticated processing of verbalized material in chirographic cultures so as to make the material more immediately retrievable through its spatial organization. Lists range names of related items in the same physical, visual space. Print develops far more sophisticated use of space for visual organization and for effective retrieval.

索引是这里的主要发展。字母索引引人注目地显示了单词与话语的脱离以及它们在印刷空间中的嵌入。手稿可以按字母顺序索引。它们很少是（Daly 1967，第 81-90 页；Clanchy 1979，第 28-9、85 页）。由于给定作品的两份手稿，即使是从同一个听写复制而来，也几乎不会逐页对应，因此给定作品的每份手稿通常都需要单独的索引。建立索引并不值得付出努力。通过记忆进行听觉回忆更为经济，但并不彻底。对于手稿文本中材料的视觉定位，图形符号通常优于字母索引。最喜欢的符号是“段落”，它最初的意思是这个标记¶，根本不是一个话语单位。当字母索引出现时，它们很少见，即使在 13 世纪的欧洲，有时为一份手稿制作的索引会在不更改页码的情况下将其附加到另一页具有不同页码的手稿上（Clanchy 1979，第 144 页）。索引有时似乎因其美丽和神秘而不是其实用性而受到重视。1286 年，一位热那亚编纂者可能会惊叹于他所设计的字母目录，这不是由于他自己的能力，而是由于“上帝的恩典在我身上工作”（Daly 1967，第 73 页）。仅按第一个字母（或者更确切地说，按第一个声音）进行索引很长：例如，在迟至 1506 年在罗马出版的一本拉丁文作品中，因为在意大利语和意大利语使用者所说的拉丁语中，该字母 有时，为一份手稿制作的索引会在不更改页码的情况下附加到另一份具有不同页码的手稿（Clanchy 1979，第 144 页）。索引有时似乎因其美丽和神秘而不是其实用性而受到重视。1286 年，一位热那亚编纂者可能会惊叹于他所设计的字母目录，这不是由于他自己的能力，而是由于“上帝的恩典在我身上工作”（Daly 1967，第 73 页）。仅按第一个字母（或者更确切地说，按第一个声音）进行索引很长：例如，在迟至 1506 年在罗马出版的一本拉丁文作品中，因为在意大利语和意大利语使用者所说的拉丁语中，该字母 有时，为一份手稿制作的索引会在不更改页码的情况下附加到另一份具有不同页码的手稿（Clanchy 1979，第 144 页）。索引有时似乎因其美丽和神秘而不是其实用性而受到重视。1286 年，一位热那亚编纂者可能会惊叹于他所设计的字母目录，这不是由于他自己的能力，而是由于“上帝的恩典在我身上工作”（Daly 1967，第 73 页）。仅按第一个字母（或者更确切地说，按第一个声音）进行索引很长：例如，在迟至 1506 年在罗马出版的一本拉丁文作品中，因为在意大利语和意大利语使用者所说的拉丁语中，该字母 热那亚的编译者可能会惊叹于他所设计的字母目录，这不是由于他自己的能力，而是由于“上帝的恩典在我身上工作”（Daly 1967，第73页）。仅按第一个字母（或者更确切地说，按第一个声音）进行索引很长：例如，在迟至 1506 年在罗马出版的一本拉丁文作品中，因为在意大利语和意大利语使用者所说的拉丁语中，该字母 热那亚的编译者可能会惊叹于他所设计的字母目录，这不是由于他自己的能力，而是由于“上帝的恩典在我身上工作”（Daly 1967，第73页）。仅按第一个字母（或者更确切地说，按第一个声音）进行索引很长：例如，在迟至 1506 年在罗马出版的一本拉丁文作品中，因为在意大利语和意大利语使用者所说的拉丁语中，该字母h不发音，“Halyzones”列在a下（Ong 1977 年讨论，第 169-72 页）。在这里，甚至视觉检索也能通过听觉发挥作用。Ioannes Ravisius Textor 的Specimen epithetorum （巴黎，1518 年）将“阿波罗”按字母顺序排列在a下的所有其他条目之前，因为 Textor 认为在一部与诗歌有关的作品中，诗歌之神应该放在首位。显然，即使在印刷字母索引中，视觉检索的优先级也较低。个性化的口头世界仍然可能会否决将文字视为事物的处理。

Indexes are a prime development here. Alphabetic indexes show strikingly the disengagement of words from discourse and their embedding in typographic space. Manuscripts can be alphabetically indexed. They rarely are (Daly 1967, pp. 81–90; Clanchy 1979, pp. 28– 9, 85). Since two manuscripts of a given work, even if copied from the same dictation, almost never correspond page for page, each manuscript of a given work would normally require a separate index. Indexing was not worth the effort. Auditory recall through memorization was more economical, though not thorough-going. For visual location of materials in a manuscript text, pictorial signs were often preferred to alphabetic indexes. A favorite sign was the ‘paragraph’, which originally meant this mark ¶, not a unit of discourse at all. When alphabetic indexes occurred, they were rare, often crude, and commonly not understood, even in thirteenth-century Europe, when sometimes an index made for one manuscript was appended without change of page numbers to another manuscript with a different pagination (Clanchy 1979, p. 144). Indexes seem to have been valued at times for their beauty and mystery rather than for their utility. In 1286, a Genoese compiler could marvel at the alphabetical catalogue he had devised as due not to his own prowess but ‘the grace of God working in me’ (Daly 1967, p. 73). Indexing was long by ﬁrst letter only – or, rather, by ﬁrst sound: for example, in a Latin work published as late as 1506 in Rome, since in Italian and Latin as spoken by Italian-speakers the letter h is not pronounced, ‘Halyzones’ is listed under a (discussed in Ong 1977, pp. 169–72). Here even visual retrieval functions aurally. Ioannes Ravisius Textor’s Specimen epithetorum (Paris, 1518), alphabetizes ‘Apollo’ before all other entries under a, because Textor considers it ﬁtting that in a work concerned with poetry, the god of poetry should get top billing. Clearly, even in a printed alphabetic index, visual retrieval was given low priority. The personalized, oral world still could overrule processing words as things.

字母索引实际上是听觉文化和视觉文化之间的十字路口。“Index”是原始Index locorum或Index locorum commium、“地点索引”或“常见事物索引”的缩写形式。修辞提供了各种轨迹或“地点”——我们将它们命名为标题——在这些标题下可以找到各种“论点”，诸如原因、结果、相关事物、不同事物等标题。有了这种以口头为基础的文本公式设备，400 年前的索引器只是简单地记录了文本中的哪些页面上使用了一个或另一个位点，并列出了该位点以及索引位点中的相应页面。基因座最初被模糊地认为是大脑中存储思想的“地方”。在印刷书中，这些模糊的心灵“地方”变得相当物理化和明显本地化。一个新的思维世界正在形成，空间上有组织。

The alphabetic index is actually a crossroads between auditory and visualist cultures. ‘Index’ is a shortened form of the original index locorum or index locorum communium, ‘index of places’ or ‘index of commonplaces’. Rhetoric had provided the various loci or ‘places’ – headings, we would style them – under which various ‘arguments’ could be found, headings such as cause, effect, related things, unlike things, and so on. Coming with this orally based, formulary equipment to the text, the indexer of 400 years ago simply noted on what pages in the text one or another locus was exploited, listing there the locus and the corresponding pages in the index locorum. The loci had originally been thought of as, vaguely, ‘places’ in the mind where ideas were stored. In the printed book, these vague psychic ‘places’ became quite physically and visibly localized. A new noetic world was shaping up, spatially organized.

在这个新世界里，这本书不再是一种话语，而更像是一种事物。手稿文化保留了一种感觉，即书籍是一种话语，是谈话过程中发生的事情，而不是作为一个物体。由于缺乏扉页和标题，预印本的手稿文化通常按其“incipit”（拉丁语动词，意为“开始”）或正文的第一个词（将主祷文称为“开始”）进行分类。 “我们的父亲”是指它的开头，并表现出一定的残余口语性）。正如我们所看到的，随着印刷品的出现，标题页也出现了。标题页是标签。他们证明了对书作为一种事物或物体的感觉。通常在中世纪的西方手稿中，正文本身不是标题页，而是通过观察向读者介绍的，伊利亚特通过宣布“伊利亚特”。

In this new world, the book was less like an utterance, and more like a thing. Manuscript culture had preserved a feeling for a book as a kind of utterance, an occurrence in the course of conversation, rather than as an object. Lacking title pages and often titles, a book from pre-print, manuscript culture is normally catalogued by its ‘incipit’ (a Latin verb meaning ‘it begins’), or the ﬁrst words of its text (referring to the Lord’s Prayer as the ‘Our Father’ is referring to it by its incipit and evinces a certain residual orality). With print, as has been seen, come title pages. Title pages are labels. They attest a feeling for the book as a kind of thing or object. Often in medieval western manuscripts, instead of a title page the text proper might be introduced by an observation to the reader, just as a conversation might start with a remark of one person to another: ‘Hic habes, carissime lector, librum quem scripset quidam de....’ (Here you have, dear reader, a book which so-and-so wrote about....) The oral heritage is at work here, for, although oral cultures of course have ways of referring to stories or other traditional recitations (the stories of the Wars of Troy, the Mwindo stories, and so on), label-like titles as such are not very operational in oral cultures: Homer would hardly have begun a recitation of episodes from the Iliad by announcing ‘ The Iliad ’.

(ii) 书籍、内容和标签

(ii) Books, contents and labels

一旦印刷品被很好地内化，一本书就会被视为一种“包含”信息的物体，无论是科学的、虚构的还是其他的，而不是像之前那样，记录下来的话语（Ong 1958b，第313页）。印刷版中的每一本书在物理上都与另一本书相同，是一个相同的物体，而手稿书则不然，即使它们呈现相同的文本。现在，有了印刷品，一本给定作品的两份副本不仅说的是同一件事，而且它们是彼此作为对象的复制品。这种情况需要标签的使用，而印刷书籍作为一个有字母的物体，自然而然地采用了一个有字母的标签，即标题页（新印刷版 – Steinberg 1974，第 145-8 页）。与此同时，图像驱动力仍然强劲，正如在 1660 年代持续存在的高度象征性的雕刻标题页中所看到的那样，

Once print has been fairly well interiorized, a book was sensed as a kind of object which ‘contained’ information, scientiﬁc, ﬁctional or other, rather than, as earlier, a recorded utterance (Ong 1958b, p. 313). Each individual book in a printed edition was physically the same as another, an identical object, as manuscript books were not, even when they presented the same text. Now, with print, two copies of a given work did not merely say the same thing, they were duplicates of one another as objects. The situation invited the use of labels, and the printed book, being a lettered object, naturally took a lettered label, the title page (new with print – Steinberg 1974, pp. 145–8). At the same time the iconographic drive was still strong, as is seen in the highly emblematic engraved title pages that persisted through the 1660s, ﬁlled with allegorical ﬁgures and other nonverbal designs.

(iii) 有意义的表面

(iii) Meaningful surface

Ivins (1953, p. 31) 指出，尽管从各种雕刻表面印刷设计的艺术已经为人所知几个世纪，但直到 1400 年代中期活字印刷术发展之后，印刷品才被系统地用于传达信息。正如艾文斯（Ivins）所表明的那样（1953，第 14-16 页、第 40-5 页），手工绘制的技术图纸很快就会在手稿中恶化，因为即使是熟练的艺术家也会错过他们正在复制的插图的要点，除非他们受到插图领域专家的监督。参考。否则，由一系列不熟悉真正的白三叶草的艺术家复制的一枝白三叶草最终可能看起来像芦笋。版画可能已经解决了手稿文化中的问题，因为版画制作已经用于装饰目的几个世纪了。早在凸版印刷发明之前，为白三叶草切割精确的印刷版就已经是相当可行的，并且可以提供所需要的，“完全可重复的视觉陈述”。但手稿的制作并不适合这种制造。手稿是通过手写制作的，而不是根据预先存在的部分制作的。印刷很讨人喜欢。口头文本是从预先存在的部分复制而来的，印刷品也可以如此。印刷机可以打印 口头文本是从预先存在的部分复制而来的，印刷品也可以如此。印刷机可以打印 口头文本是从预先存在的部分复制而来的，印刷品也可以如此。印刷机可以打印“完全可重复的视觉陈述”就像从类型中设置模板一样容易。

Ivins (1953, p. 31) has pointed out that, although the art of printing designs from various carved surfaces had been known for centuries, only after the development of movable letterpress type in the mid-1400s were prints used systematically to convey information. Handdone technical drawings, as Ivins has shown (1953, pp. 14–16, 40–5) soon deteriorated in manuscripts because even skilled artists miss the point of an illustration they are copying unless they are supervised by an expert in the ﬁeld the illustrations refer to. Otherwise, a sprig of white clover copied by a succession of artists unfamiliar with real white clover can end up looking like asparagus. Prints might have solved the problem in a manuscript culture, since print-making had been practiced for centuries for decorative purposes. Cutting an accurate printing block for white clover would have been quite feasible long before the invention of letterpress printing, and would have provided just what was needed, an ‘exactly repeatable visual statement’. But manuscript production was not congenial to such manufacture. Manuscripts were produced by handwriting, not from pre-existing parts. Print was congenial. The verbal text was reproduced from pre-existing parts, and so could prints be. A press could print an ‘exactly repeatable visual statement’ as easily as a forme set up from type.

新的完全可重复的视觉陈述的结果之一就是现代科学。精确的观察并非始于现代科学。多年来，它一直对于猎人和各种工匠的生存至关重要。现代科学的独特之处在于精确观察和精确言语的结合：对仔细观察的复杂对象和过程进行精确的措辞描述。精心制作的技术印刷品（首先是木刻，后来是更精确详细的金属雕刻）的出现实现了这种措辞精确的描述。技术印刷和技术语言相互加强和改进。由此产生的超视觉化的思维世界是全新的。古代和中世纪的作家根本无法对复杂的物体进行精确的文字描述，这些描述完全接近印刷后出现的描述，事实上，这种描述主要是在浪漫主义时代，即工业革命时代成熟的。口头和残余口头言语将注意力集中在动作上，而不是物体、场景或人的视觉外观（Fritschi 1981，第 65-6 页；参见 Havelock 1963，第 61-96 页）。维特鲁威关于建筑的论文是出了名的含糊不清。长期修辞传统所追求的精确性并不是视觉-声音类型的。爱森斯坦（Eisenstein，1979，第 64 页）指出，今天要想象早期文化是多么困难，因为在早期文化中，相对较少的人见过任何事物的物理精确图像。事实上，这种成熟主要是在浪漫主义时代，即工业革命时代。口头和残余口头言语将注意力集中在动作上，而不是物体、场景或人的视觉外观（Fritschi 1981，第 65-6 页；参见 Havelock 1963，第 61-96 页）。维特鲁威关于建筑的论文是出了名的含糊不清。长期修辞传统所追求的精确性并不是视觉-声音类型的。爱森斯坦（Eisenstein，1979，第 64 页）指出，今天要想象早期文化是多么困难，因为在早期文化中，相对较少的人见过任何事物的物理精确图像。事实上，这种成熟主要是在浪漫主义时代，即工业革命时代。口头和残余口头言语将注意力集中在动作上，而不是物体、场景或人的视觉外观（Fritschi 1981，第 65-6 页；参见 Havelock 1963，第 61-96 页）。维特鲁威关于建筑的论文是出了名的含糊不清。长期修辞传统所追求的精确性并不是视觉-声音类型的。爱森斯坦（Eisenstein，1979，第 64 页）指出，今天要想象早期文化是多么困难，因为在早期文化中，相对较少的人见过任何事物的物理精确图像。不是物体、场景或人的视觉外观（Fritschi 1981，第 65-6 页；参见 Havelock 1963，第 61-96 页）。维特鲁威关于建筑的论文是出了名的含糊不清。长期修辞传统所追求的精确性并不是视觉-声音类型的。爱森斯坦（Eisenstein，1979，第 64 页）指出，今天要想象早期文化是多么困难，因为在早期文化中，相对较少的人见过任何事物的物理精确图像。不是物体、场景或人的视觉外观（Fritschi 1981，第 65-6 页；参见 Havelock 1963，第 61-96 页）。维特鲁威关于建筑的论文是出了名的含糊不清。长期修辞传统所追求的精确性并不是视觉-声音类型的。爱森斯坦（Eisenstein，1979，第 64 页）指出，今天要想象早期文化是多么困难，因为在早期文化中，相对较少的人见过任何事物的物理精确图像。

One consequence of the new exactly repeatable visual statement was modern science. Exact observation does not begin with modern science. For ages, it has always been essential for survival among, for example, hunters and craftsmen of many sorts. What is distinctive of modern science is the conjuncture of exact observation and exact verbalization: exactly worded descriptions of carefully observed complex objects and processes. The availability of carefully made, technical prints (ﬁrst woodcuts, and later even more exactly detailed metal engravings) implemented such exactly worded descriptions. Technical prints and technical verbalization reinforced and improved each other. The resulting hypervisualized noetic world was brand new. Ancient and medieval writers are simply unable to produce exactly worded descriptions of complex objects at all approximating the descriptions that appear after print and, indeed, that mature chieﬂy with the Age of Romanticism, that is, the age of the Industrial Revolution. Oral and residually oral verbalization directs its attention to action, not to the visual appearance of objects or scenes or persons (Fritschi 1981, pp. 65–6; cf. Havelock 1963, pp. 61–96). Vitruvius’ treatise on architecture is notoriously vague. The kinds of exactitude aimed at by the long-standing rhetorical tradition were not of a visual–vocal sort. Eisenstein (1979, p. 64) suggests how difficult it is today to imagine earlier cultures where relatively few persons had ever seen a physically accurate picture of anything.

由精确可重复的视觉陈述和相应的对物理现实的精确口头描述开启的新的思维世界不仅影响了科学，也影响了文学。没有任何前浪漫主义散文能够对杰拉德·曼利·霍普金斯的笔记本（1937）中的风景进行客观描述，也没有任何前浪漫主义诗歌能够像霍普金斯对一条急流的小溪的描述那样对自然现象进行密切、细致、临床的关注。在因弗奈德。就像达尔文的进化生物学或迈克尔逊的物理学一样，这种诗歌诞生于印刷世界。

The new noetic world opened by exactly repeatable visual statement and correspondingly exact verbal description of physical reality affected not just science but literature as well. No pre-Romantic prose provides the circumstantial description of landscape found in Gerard Manley Hopkins’s notebooks (1937) and no pre-Romantic poetry proceeds with the close, meticulous, clinical attention to natural phenomena found, for example, in Hopkins’s description of a plunging brook in Inversnaid. As much as Darwin’s evolutionary biology or Michelson’s physics this kind of poetry grows out of the world of print.

(iv) 印刷空间

(iv) Typographic space

因为视觉表面已经被赋予了强加的意义，而且因为印刷不仅控制着形成文本的文字，还控制着页面上文字的确切位置以及它们彼此之间的空间关系，印刷纸张上的空间本身——所谓的“空白”——具有直接通向现代和后现代世界的高度意义。古迪（Goody，1977，第 74-111 页）讨论过的手稿列表和图表可以将单词置于彼此之间特定的空间关系中，但如果空间关系极其复杂，复杂的情况将无法在连续复印机的变幻莫测中幸存下来。打印可以完全准确地复制任意数量的无限复杂的列表和图表。在印刷时代早期，等帕西姆）。

Because visual surface had become charged with imposed meaning and because print controlled not only what words were put down to form a text but also the exact situation of the words on the page and their spatial relationship to one another, the space itself on a printed sheet – ‘white space’ as it is called – took on high signiﬁcance that leads directly into the modern and post-modern world. Manuscript lists and charts, discussed by Goody (1977, pp. 74–111), can situate words in speciﬁc spatial relationships to one another, but if the spatial relationships are extremely complicated, the complications will not survive the vagaries of successive copiers. Print can reproduce with complete accuracy and in any quantity indeﬁnitely complex lists and charts. Early in the age of print, extremely complex charts appear in the teaching of academic subjects (Ong 1958b, pp. 80, 81, 202, et passim ).

印刷空间不仅作用于科学和哲学想象，还作用于文学想象，这展示了印刷空间呈现给心灵的一些复杂方式。乔治·赫伯特利用印刷空间在他的《复活节之翼》和《祭坛》中赋予意义，其中不同长度的线条赋予诗歌视觉化的形状，分别暗示翅膀和祭坛。在手稿中，这种视觉结构的可行性有限。在《项狄传》中（1760-7），劳伦斯·斯特恩（Laurence Sterne）使用经过精心设计的奇思妙想的印刷空间，包括在他的书中使用空白页，来表明他不愿意处理某个主题并邀请读者填写。这里的空间相当于沉默。很久以后，斯特凡·马拉梅 (Stéphane Mallarmé) 更加精巧地设计了他的诗《Un Coup de dés》，以不同的字体和字体大小设置，线条以一种印刷自由落体的方式精心散布在页面上，暗示着统治的机会掷骰子（这首诗在 Bruns 1974 年，第 115-38 页被转载和讨论）。马拉美宣称的目标是“避免叙事”和“间隔”诗歌的阅读，以便页面及其印刷空间，而不是行，成为诗歌的单位。EE 卡明斯的无题诗 No.一只蚱蜢令人眼花缭乱的飞行，直到他最终笔直地重新聚集在我们面前的草叶上。空白在卡明斯的诗中是如此不可或缺，以至于完全不可能大声朗读这首诗。字母暗示的声音必须存在于想象中，但它们的存在不仅仅是听觉上的：它与周围的视觉和动觉感知空间相互作用。

Typographic space works not only on the scientiﬁc and philosophic imagination, but also on the literary imagination, which shows some of the complicated ways in which typographic space is present to the psyche. George Herbert exploits typographic space to provide meaning in his ‘Easter Wings’ and ‘The Altar’, where the lines, of varying lengths, give the poems a visualized shape suggesting wings and an altar respectively. In manuscripts, this kind of visual structure would be only marginally viable. In Tristram Shandy (1760–7), Laurence Sterne uses typographic space with calculated whimsy, including in his book blank pages, to indicate his unwillingness to treat a subject and to invite the reader to ﬁll in. Space here is the equivalent of silence. Much later, and with greater sophistication, Stéphane Mallarmé designs his poem ‘Un Coup de dés’ to be set in varying fonts and sizes of type with the lines scattered calculatingly across the pages in a kind of typographical free-fall suggesting the chance that rules a throw of dice (the poem is reproduced and discussed in Bruns 1974, pp. 115–38). Mallarmé’s declared objective is to ‘avoid narrative’ and ‘space out’ the reading of the poem so that the page, with its typographic spaces, not the line, is the unit of verse. E. E. Cummings’s untitled Poem No. 276 (1968) about the grasshopper disintegrates the words of its text and scatters them unevenly about the page until at last letters come together in the ﬁnal word ‘grasshopper’ – all this to suggest the erratic and optically dizzying ﬂight of a grasshopper until he ﬁnally reassembles himself straightforwardly on the blade of grass before us. White space is so integral to Cummings’s poem that it is utterly impossible to read the poem aloud. The sounds cued in by the letters have to be present in the imagination but their presence is not simply auditory: it interacts with the visually and kinesthetically perceived space around them.

具体诗歌（Solt 1970）以某种方式将发音词与印刷空间的相互作用推向高潮。它呈现出极其复杂或极其简单的字母和/或单词的视觉显示，其中一些可以观看，但根本不能大声朗读，但如果没有对言语声音的某种认识，则无法使用其中的任何一个。即使具体的诗歌根本无法阅读，它仍然不仅仅是一幅图画。具体诗歌是一种小流派，通常只是噱头——这一事实使得更有必要解释创作它的动力。

Concrete poetry (Solt 1970) climaxes in a certain way the interaction of sounded words and typographic space. It presents exquisitely complicated or exquisitely uncomplicated visual displays of letters and/or words some of which can be viewed but not read aloud at all, but none of which can be appropriated without some awareness of verbal sound. Even when concrete poetry cannot be read at all, it is still not merely a picture. Concrete poetry is a minor genre, often merely gimmicky – a fact which makes it all the more necessary to explain the drive to produce it.

哈特曼（Hartman，1981，第 35 页）提出了具体诗歌与雅克·德里达持续不断的文本标识之间的联系。这种联系当然是真实的，值得更多关注。具体诗歌玩弄的是锁定在空间中的词的辩证法，而不是永远无法锁定在空间中的有声口头词（每个文本都是借口），也就是说，它玩弄了文本性的绝对局限性，这种局限性自相矛盾地揭示了构建的内容。 -也有口头语言的限制。这是德里达的地形，尽管他按照自己计算的步态在上面移动。正如我们已经看到的，具体诗歌不是写作的产物，而是印刷术的产物。解构主义与印刷术联系在一起，而不是像它的倡导者经常假设的那样，仅仅与写作联系在一起。

Hartman (1981, p. 35) has suggested a connection between concrete poetry and Jacques Derrida’s on-going logomachy with the text. The connection is certainly real and deserves more attention. Concrete poetry plays with the dialectic of the word locked into space as opposed to the sounded, oral word which can never be locked into space (every text is pretext), that is, it plays with the absolute limitations of textuality which paradoxically reveal the built-in limitations of the spoken word, too. This is Derrida’s terrain, though he moves over it at his own calculated gait. Concrete poetry is not the product of writing but of typography, as has been seen. Deconstruction is tied to typography rather than, as its advocates seem often to assume, merely to writing.

更多漫反射效果

MORE DIFFUSE EFFECTS

人们可以列举出印刷品对西方的思维经济或“心态”或多或少直接的额外影响。印刷品最终将古老的（口头的）修辞艺术从学术教育的中心移除。它通过数学分析和图表的使用，鼓励并使得大规模的知识量化成为可能。印刷品最终降低了图像在管理中的吸引力尽管早期的印刷术使图像插图以前所未有的方式流通。图像形象类似于口头话语中的“沉重”或类型特征，它们与口头知识管理所需的修辞和记忆艺术相关联（Yates 1966）。

One can list without end additional effects, more or less direct, which print had on the noetic economy or the ‘mentality’ of the West. Print eventually removed the ancient art of (orally based) rhetoric from the center of academic education. It encouraged and made possible on a large scale the quantiﬁcation of knowledge, both through the use of mathematical analysis and through the use of diagrams and charts. Print eventually reduced the appeal of iconography in the management of knowledge, despite the fact that the early ages of print put iconographic illustrations into circulation as they had never been before. Iconographic ﬁgures are akin to the ‘heavy’ or type characters of oral discourse and they are associated with rhetoric and with the arts of memory that oral management of knowledge needs (Yates 1966).

印刷术产生了详尽的词典，并激发了为语言“正确性”立法的愿望。这种愿望在很大程度上源于对拉丁语学习的语言感。学到的语言将语言的概念文本化，使其看起来像是书面的东西。印刷品强化了语言本质上是文本的感觉。印刷文本，而不是书面文本，是最完整、范例形式的文本。

Print produced exhaustive dictionaries and fostered the desire to legislate for ‘correctness’ in language. This desire in great part grew out of a sense of language based on the study of Learned Latin. Learned tongues textualize the idea of language, making it seem at root something written. Print reinforces the sense of language as essentially textual. The printed text, not the written text, is the text in its fullest, paradigmatic form.

印刷术奠定了词典发展的氛围。从十八世纪的起源到过去的几十年，英语词典通常仅将作家（而不是全部）为印刷文本制作的用法作为语言规范。所有其他的用法，如果偏离了这种印刷用法，则被视为“腐败”。韦伯斯特的第三本新国际词典（1961）是第一部彻底打破这种旧印刷惯例的主要词典编纂著作，并引用那些不为印刷品写作的人作为使用来源——当然，许多在旧意识形态中形成的人立即注销了这一令人印象深刻的词典编纂成就（Dykema 1963）被视为对“真实”或“纯粹”语言的背叛。

Print established the climate in which dictionaries grew. From their origins in the eighteenth century until the past few decades, dictionaries of English have commonly taken as their norm for language only the usage of writers producing text for print (and not quite all of them). The usage of all others, if it deviates from this typographic usage, has been regarded as ‘corrupt’. Webster’s Third New International Dictionary (1961) was the ﬁrst major lexicographical work to break cleanly with this old typographical convention and to cite as sources for usage persons not writing for print – and of course many persons, formed in the old ideology, immediately wrote off this impressive lexicographical achievement (Dykema 1963) as a betrayal of the ‘true’ or ‘pure’ language.

印刷品也是现代社会标志性的个人隐私意识发展的一个主要因素。它生产的书籍比手稿文化中常见的书籍更小、更便于携带，从心理上为在安静的角落里单独阅读以及最终完全默读奠定了基础。在手稿文化以及早期的印刷文化中，阅读往往是一种社交活动，一个人向一群人朗读。正如斯坦纳（Steiner，1967，第 383 页）所建议的，私人阅读需要一个足够宽敞的家，以提供个人隔离和安静。（当今贫困地区儿童的教师敏锐地意识到，表现不佳的主要原因通常是在拥挤的房子里没有地方可以让男孩或女孩有效学习。）

Print was also a major factor in the development of the sense of personal privacy that marks modern society. It produced books smaller and more portable than those common in a manuscript culture, setting the stage psychologically for solo reading in a quiet corner, and eventually for completely silent reading. In manuscript culture and hence in early print culture, reading had tended to be a social activity, one person reading to others in a group. As Steiner (1967, p. 383) has suggested, private reading demands a home spacious enough to provide for individual isolation and quiet. (Teachers of children from poverty areas today are acutely aware that often the major reason for poor performance is that there is nowhere in a crowded house where a boy or girl can study effectively.)

印刷创造了一种新的文字私有制意识。人员在初级口头文化中，人们可以对一首诗抱有一定的所有权意识，但这种意识很少见，而且通常会因为每个人所借鉴的共同知识、公式和主题而被削弱。随着写作的进行，人们对剽窃的怨恨开始滋生。古代拉丁诗人 Martial (i. 53.9) 使用“plagiarius”这个词，意思是折磨者、掠夺者、压迫者，指盗用他人作品的人。但没有一个特殊的拉丁词具有抄袭者或剽窃的唯一含义。口头的普遍传统仍然很牢固。然而，在印刷术的早期，通常会获得皇家法令或特权，禁止原出版商以外的其他人重印印刷书籍。理查德·宾森获得了这样的特权1518年从亨利八世手中夺取。1557 年，文具公司在伦敦成立，负责监督作者和印刷商或印刷出版商的权利，到 18 世纪，现代版权法正在西欧形成。印刷术使这个词变成了一种商品。旧的公共口头世界已经分裂成私人声称的自由财产。印刷术很好地促进了人类意识向更大的个人主义的转变。当然，言语并不完全是私有财产。他们在某种程度上仍然是共享财产。印刷书籍确实彼此呼应，不管愿意与否。在电子时代开始之际，乔伊斯直面影响力带来的焦虑，在《尤利西斯》和《芬尼根守灵夜》中，他有意回应每个人的观点。

Print created a new sense of the private ownership of words. Persons in a primary oral culture can entertain some sense of proprietary rights to a poem, but such a sense is rare and ordinarily enfeebled by the common share of lore, formulas, and themes on which everyone draws. With writing, resentment at plagiarism begins to develop. The ancient Latin poet Martial (i. 53.9) uses the word plagiarius, a torturer, plunderer, oppressor, for someone who appropriates another’s writing. But there is no special Latin word with the exclusive meaning of plagiarist or plagiarism. The oral commonplace tradition was still strong. In the very early days of print, however, a royal decree or privilegium was often secured forbidding the reprinting of a printed book by others than the original publisher. Richard Pynson secured such a privilegium in 1518 from Henry VIII. In 1557 the Stationers’ Company was incorporated in London to oversee authors’ and printers’ or printer-publishers’ rights, and by the eighteenth century modern copyright laws were shaping up over western Europe. Typography had made the word into a commodity. The old communal oral world had split up into privately claimed free holdings. The drift in human consciousness toward greater individualism had been served well by print. Of course, words were not quite private property. They were still shared property to a degree. Printed books did echo one another, willy-nilly. At the onset of the electronic age, Joyce faced up to the anxieties of inﬂuence squarely and in Ulysses and Finnegans Wake undertook to echo everybody on purpose.

通过将词语从最初起源于人类活跃交流的声音世界中移除，并将它们明确地降级到视觉表面，并通过以其他方式利用视觉空间来管理知识，印刷品鼓励人类思考自己的内在意识无意识资源越来越像事物、非个人化和宗教中立。印刷品鼓励人们意识到自己的财产被保存在某种惰性的心理空间中。

By removing words from the world of sound where they had ﬁrst had their origin in active human interchange and relegating them deﬁnitively to visual surface, and by otherwise exploiting visual space for the management of knowledge, print encouraged human beings to think of their own interior conscious and unconscious resources as more and more thing-like, impersonal and religiously neutral. Print encouraged the mind to sense that its possessions were held in some sort of inert mental space.

印刷和封口：互文性

PRINT AND CLOSURE: INTERTEXTUALITY

印刷品鼓励一种结束感，一种文本中发现的内容已经最终确定、已经达到完成状态的感觉。这种感觉影响文学创作，也影响分析哲学或科学工作。

Print encourages a sense of closure, a sense that what is found in a text has been ﬁnalized, has reached a state of completion. This sense affects literary creations and it affects analytic philosophical or scientiﬁc work.

在印刷之前，写作本身就鼓励某种心灵封闭感。通过将思想隔离在书面表面上，与任何对话者分离，使这种意义上的话语变得自主且不受攻击，写作将话语和思想呈现为不涉及其他一切，在某种程度上是独立的、完整的。印刷品以同样的方式将话语和思想置于与其他一切无关的表面上，但它在暗示自我封闭方面也走得更远。印刷品将思想封装在数千份具有完全相同的视觉和物理一致性的作品中。无需借助声音，而只需通过视觉即可检查同一印刷副本的口头对应关系：辛曼配页机将两份文本的相应页面叠加在一起，并用闪烁的灯光向观看者发出信号变化。

Before print, writing itself encouraged some sense of noetic closure. By isolating thought on a written surface, detached from any interlocutor, making utterance in this sense autonomous and indifferent to attack, writing presents utterance and thought as uninvolved with all else, somehow self-contained, complete. Print in the same way situates utterance and thought on a surface disengaged from everything else, but it also goes farther in suggesting self-containment. Print encloses thought in thousands of copies of a work of exactly the same visual and physical consistency. Verbal correspondence of copies of the same printing can be checked with no resort to sound at all but simply by sight: a Hinman collator superimposed corresponding pages of two copies of a text and signal variations to the viewer with a blinking light.

印刷文本应该以最终或“最终”形式代表作者的文字。因为只有最终结果才能使印刷感到舒适。一旦凸版印版被关闭、锁定，或者制作光刻版并印刷出纸张，文本就不能像书面文本那样容易地进行更改（擦除、插入）。相比之下，带有注释或旁注（通常会在后续副本的文本中添加）的手稿正在与自己边界之外的世界进行对话。他们仍然更接近口头表达的交换。与印刷品的读者相比，手稿的读者与作者的联系更少，缺席更少。印刷品所带来的封闭感或完整性有时是非常物理性的。报纸的页面通常都是填满的——某些类型的印刷材料被称为“填充物”——就像它的字体线条通常都是对齐的（即宽度完全相同）。奇怪的是，印刷品无法容忍物理上的不完整。它可以无意识地、微妙地但非常真实地传达这样的印象：文本所处理的材料同样完整或自洽。

The printed text is supposed to represent the words of an author in deﬁnitive or ‘ﬁnal’ form. For print is comfortable only with ﬁnality. Once a letterpress forme is closed, locked up, or a photolithographic plate is made, and the sheet printed, the text does not accommodate changes (erasures, insertions) so readily as do written texts. By contrast, manuscripts, with their glosses or marginal comments (which often got worked into the text in subsequent copies) were in dialogue with the world outside their own borders. They remained closer to the give-and-take of oral expression. The readers of manuscripts are less closed off from the author, less absent, than are the readers of those writing for print. The sense of closure or completeness enforced by print is at times grossly physical. A newspaper’s pages are normally all ﬁlled – certain kinds of printed material are called ‘ﬁllers’ – just as its lines of type are normally all justiﬁed (i.e. all exactly the same width). Print is curiously intolerant of physical incompleteness. It can convey the impression, unintentionally and subtly, but very really, that the material the text deals with is similarly complete or self-consistent.

印刷品造就了更加封闭的语言艺术形式，尤其是在叙事方面。在印刷之前，唯一线性绘制的冗长故事情节是戏剧，从古代起戏剧就由文字控制。欧里庇得斯的悲剧是用书面形式写成的文本，然后逐字背诵以口头呈现。随着印刷品的出现，从简·奥斯汀时代开始的小说，紧凑的情节延伸到了冗长的叙述，并在侦探小说中达到了顶峰。这些形式将在下一章中讨论。

Print makes for more tightly closed verbal art forms, especially in narrative. Until print, the only linearly plotted lengthy story line was that of the drama, which from antiquity had been controlled by writing. Euripides’ tragedies were texts composed in writing and then memorized verbatim to be presented orally. With print, tight plotting is extended to the lengthy narrative, in the novel from Jane Austen’s time on, and reaches its peak in the detective story. These forms will be discussed in the next chapter.

在文学理论中，印刷品最终导致了形式主义和新批评坚信，每件语言艺术作品都封闭在它自己的世界中，即“语言偶像”。值得注意的是，图标是一种看得见、听不到的东西。手稿文化认为言语艺术作品更接近口头全体会议，并且从未有效地区分诗歌和修辞。形式主义和新批评主义也在下一章中详细讨论。

In literary theory, print gives rise ultimately to Formalism and the New Criticism, with their deep conviction that each work of verbal art is closed off in a world of its own, a ‘verbal icon’. Signiﬁcantly, an icon is something seen, not heard. Manuscript culture felt works of verbal art to be more in touch with the oral plenum, and never very effectively distinguished between poetry and rhetoric. More will be said of Formalism and the New Criticism also in the next chapter.

印刷品最终引发了现代的互文性问题，这是当今现象学和批评界关注的核心问题（Hawkes 1977，p.144）。互文性是指文学和心理学上的一个普遍现象：文本不能仅仅根据生活经验来创造。小说家写小说是因为他或她熟悉这种经验的文本组织。

Print ultimately gives rise to the modern issue of intertextuality, which is so central a concern in phenomenological and critical circles today (Hawkes 1977, p. 144). Intertextuality refers to a literary and psychological commonplace: a text cannot be created simply out of lived experience. A novelist writes a novel because he or she is familiar with this kind of textual organization of experience.

手稿文化认为互文性是理所当然的。它仍然与旧口头世界的普遍传统联系在一起，故意从其他文本中创造文本，借用、改编、分享共同的、最初口头的公式和主题，尽管它将它们加工成没有书写就不可能的新鲜文学形式。印刷文化本身有不同的心态。它往往让人感觉一件作品是“封闭的”，与其他作品分开，本身就是一个整体。印刷文化催生了“原创性”和“创造力”的浪漫概念，这些概念将个人作品与其他作品进一步区分开来，将其起源和意义视为独立于外界影响，至少在理想情况下是这样。在过去的几十年里，当互文性学说的兴起来对抗浪漫印刷文化的孤立主义美学时，他们的出现让人感到震惊。它们更加令人不安，因为现代作家痛苦地意识到文学史和文学史他们自己的作品事实上的互文性，担心他们可能没有产生任何真正新的或新鲜的东西，他们可能完全受到其他文本的“影响”。哈罗德·布鲁姆的著作《影响力的焦虑》（1973）探讨了这位现代作家的痛苦。手稿文化很少担心影响力困扰他们，而口头文化则几乎没有。

Manuscript culture had taken intertextuality for granted. Still tied to the commonplace tradition of the old oral world, it deliberately created texts out of other texts, borrowing, adapting, sharing the common, originally oral, formulas and themes, even though it worked them up into fresh literary forms impossible without writing. Print culture of itself has a different mindset. It tends to feel a work as ‘closed’, set off from other works, a unit in itself. Print culture gave birth to the romantic notions of ‘originality’ and ‘creativity’, which set apart an individual work from other works even more, seeing its origins and meaning as independent of outside inﬂuence, at least ideally. When in the past few decades doctrines of intertextuality arose to counteract the isolationist aesthetics of a romantic print culture, they came as a kind of shock. They were all the more disquieting because modern writers, agonizingly aware of literary history and of the de facto intertextuality of their own works, are concerned that they may be producing nothing really new or fresh at all, that they maybe totally under the ‘inﬂuence’ of others’ texts. Harold Bloom’s work The Anxiety of Inﬂuence (1973) treats this modern writer’s anguish. Manuscript cultures had few if any anxieties about inﬂuence to plague them, and oral cultures had virtually none.

印刷品不仅在文学作品中创造了一种封闭感，而且在分析哲学和科学作品中也创造了一种封闭感。随着印刷品的出现，教义问答和“教科书”也随之问世，与之前针对特定学术主题的大多数介绍相比，它的话语性和争议性更少。教义问答和教科书呈现“事实”或类似内容：易于记忆的、简单的陈述它直接而包容地讲述了特定领域的情况。相比之下，口头文化和残余口头手稿文化的令人难忘的陈述往往是谚语式的，呈现的不是“事实”，而是反思，通常是一种格言式的反思，引发对它们所涉及的悖论的进一步反思。

Print creates a sense of closure not only in literary works but also in analytic philosophical and scientiﬁc works. With print came the catechism and the ‘textbook’, less discursive and less disputatious than most previous presentations of a given academic subject. Catechisms and textbooks presented ‘facts’ or their equivalents: memorizable, ﬂat statements that told straightforwardly and inclusively how matters stood in a given ﬁeld. By contrast, the memorable statements of oral cultures and of residually oral manuscript cultures tended to be of a proverbial sort, presenting not ‘facts’ but rather reﬂections, often of a gnomic kind, inviting further reﬂection by the paradoxes they involved.

彼得·拉穆斯（Peter Ramus，1515-72）创造了教科书类型的范式：几乎所有艺术科目（辩证法或逻辑、修辞学、语法、算术等）的教科书，都以冷血的定义和划分为基础，导致进一步的定义和分类。更多的划分，直到这个主题的每一个细节都被解剖和处理掉。拉米斯特教科书关于特定主题的教科书与自身以外的任何事物都没有公认的互换性。甚至没有出现任何困难或‘对手’。课程主题或“艺术”，如果按照拉米斯特方法正确呈现，根本不存在任何困难（拉米斯特认为）：如果你以正确的方式定义和划分，艺术中的一切都是完全不言而喻的，艺术本身是完整且独立的。scholae）关于辩证法、修辞学、语法、算术以及所有其他方面的知识。这些讲座超出了自我封闭的“艺术”范围。此外，每本拉米斯特教科书中的材料都可以以印刷的二分式大纲或图表的形式呈现，这些大纲或图表准确地显示了材料本身和头脑中的空间组织方式。每一种艺术本身都是完全独立的，就像中间有开放空间的房屋彼此分离一样，尽管艺术在“使用”中混合在一起——也就是说，在处理特定的话语段落时，同时使用一种艺术逻辑、语法、修辞以及可能的其他艺术（Ong 1958b，第 30-1、225-69、280 页）。

Peter Ramus (1515–72) produced the paradigms of the textbook genre: textbooks for virtually all arts subjects (dialectic or logic, rhetoric, grammar, arithmetic, etc.) that proceeded by cold-blooded deﬁnitions and divisions leading to still further deﬁnitions and more divisions, until every last particle of the subject had been dissected and disposed of. A Ramist textbook on a given subject had no acknowledged interchange with anything outside itself. Not even any difficulties or ‘adversaries’ appeared. A curriculum subject or ‘art’, if presented properly according to Ramist method, involved no difficulties at all (so Ramists maintained): if you deﬁned and divided in the proper way, everything in the art was completely self-evident and the art itself was complete and self-contained. Ramus relegated difficulties and refutations of adversaries to separate ‘lectures’ ( scholae ) on dialectic, rhetoric, grammar, arithmetic, and all the rest. These lectures lay outside the self-enclosed ‘art’. Moreover, the material in each of the Ramist textbooks could be presented in printed dichotomized outlines or charts that showed exactly how the material was organized spatially in itself and in the mind. Every art was in itself completely separate from every other, as houses with intervening open spaces are separate from one another, though the arts were mingled in ‘use’ – that is to say, in working up a given passage of discourse, one used simultaneously logic, grammar, rhetoric, and possible other arts as well (Ong 1958b, pp. 30–1, 225–69, 280).

与印刷品所培养的封闭感相关的是固定的观点，正如马歇尔·麦克卢汉指出的那样（1962年，第126-7页、135-6页），它是随着印刷品而产生的。有了固定的观点，整个长篇散文就可以保持固定的基调。固定的观点、固定的语气，一方面表明了作者与读者之间更大的距离，另一方面也表明了更大的默契。作者可以自信地走自己的路（距离更远，不关心）。没有必要把一切都变成梅尼普式的讽刺，混合不同的观点和语气适合不同的情感。作者可以确信读者会调整（更好的理解）。此时，“阅读大众”应运而生——一大批作者本人不认识的读者，但能够接受某些或多或少既定的观点。

A correlative of the sense of closure fostered by print was the ﬁxed point of view, which as Marshall McLuhan pointed out (1962, pp. 126–7, 135–6), came into being with print. With the ﬁxed point of view, a ﬁxed tone could now be preserved through the whole of a lengthy prose composition. The ﬁxed point of view and ﬁxed tone showed in one way a greater distance between writer and reader and in another way a greater tacit understanding. The writer could go his or her own way conﬁdently (greater distance, lack of concern). There was no need to make everything a kind of Menippean satire, a mixture of various points of view and tone for various sensibilities. The writer could be conﬁdent that the reader would adjust (greater understanding). At this point, the ‘reading public’ came into existence – a sizable clientele of readers unknown personally to the author but able to deal with certain more or less established points of view.

印刷后：电子

POST-TYPOGRAPHY: ELECTRONICS

口头表达的电子化转变既加深了文字对空间的承诺（由书写发起并由印刷品强化），也将意识带入了第二次口头的新时代。尽管电子处理的单词与本书所关注的口语-读写极性之间的完整关系是一个太大的主题，无法在这里全面考虑，但仍需要提出几点。

The electronic transformation of verbal expression has both deepened the commitment of the word to space initiated by writing and intensiﬁed by print and has brought consciousness to a new age of secondary orality. Although the full relationship of the electronically processed word to the orality–literacy polarity with which this book concerns itself is too vast a subject to be considered in its totality here, some few points need to be made.

不管有时怎么说，电子设备并没有消除印刷书籍，实际上正在生产更多的书籍。电子录音采访产生了数以千计的“谈话”书籍和文章，而在录音成为可能之前，这些书籍和文章永远不会被印刷出来。这里的新媒介强化了旧媒介，但当然也改变了它，因为它培育了一种新的、自觉的非正式风格，因为印刷术人士认为口头交流通常应该是非正式的（口头人士认为它通常应该是正式的——Ong 1977，第. 82–91）。此外，如前所述，计算机终端上的排版正在取代旧形式的印刷排版，因此很快几乎所有印刷都将借助电子设备以某种方式完成。当然，以电子方式收集和/或处理的各种信息都会进入印刷品，以扩大印刷输出。最后，单词的顺序处理和空间化，由书写启动并通过打印提升到新的强度顺序，由计算机进一步强化，这最大限度地提高了单词对空间和（电子）局部运动的承诺，并优化了分析通过使其几乎是瞬时的来实现顺序性。

Despite what is sometimes said, electronic devices are not eliminating printed books but are actually producing more of them. Electronically taped interviews produce ‘talked’ books and articles by the thousands which would never have seen print before taping was possible. The new medium here reinforces the old, but of course transforms it because it fosters a new, self-consciously informal style, since typographic folk believe that oral exchange should normally be informal (oral folk believe it should normally be formal – Ong 1977, pp. 82–91). Moreover, as earlier noted, composition on computer terminals is replacing older forms of typographic composition, so that soon virtually all printing will be done in one way or another with the aid of electronic equipment. And of course information of all sorts electronically gathered and/or processed makes its way into print to swell the typographic output. Finally, the sequential processing and spatializing of the word, initiated by writing and raised to a new order of intensity by print, is further intensiﬁed by the computer, which maximizes commitment of the word to space and to (electronic) local motion and optimizes analytic sequentiality by making it virtually instantaneous.

同时，随着电话、广播、电视和各种录音带的出现，电子技术把我们带入了“二次口头”时代。这种新的口语与它的古老之处在于它的参与神秘感、它对公共意识的培养、它对当下时刻的关注，甚至它对公式的使用（Ong 1971，第284-303页；1977，第16-49页、305-41页）。但它本质上是一种更加深思熟虑和自觉的口头表达，永久基于书写和印刷的使用，这对于设备的制造和操作及其使用至关重要。

At the same time, with telephone, radio, television and various kinds of sound tape, electronic technology has brought us into the age of ‘secondary orality’. This new orality has striking resemblances to the old in its participatory mystique, its fostering of a communal sense, its concentration on the present moment, and even its use of formulas (Ong 1971, pp. 284–303; 1977, pp. 16–49, 305–41). But it is essentially a more deliberate and self-conscious orality, based permanently on the use of writing and print, which are essential for the manufacture and operation of the equipment and for its use as well.

次级口头语言与初级口头语言既非常相似又非常不同。与初级口头语言一样，次级口头语言也产生了强烈的群体意识，因为聆听口头语言将听众形成一个群体，一个真正的听众，就像阅读书面或印刷文本使个人变得自我封闭一样。但次要口头文化为比初级口头文化大得多的群体——麦克卢汉的“地球村”——产生了一种感觉。此外，在出现文字之前，口头上的人们都是有集体意识的，因为没有可行的替代方案。在我们这个次要口头语言的时代，我们自觉地、有计划地聚集在一起。个人认为他或她作为一个个体必须具有社会敏感性。与原始口头文化的成员不同，他们因为很少有机会向内转向而变得外向，我们转向外在，因为我们转向内在。同样，初级口头语言促进自发性，因为通过写作实现的分析反思性是不可用的，而次要口头语言则促进自发性，因为通过分析反思，我们认为自发性是一件好事。我们仔细计划我们的活动，以确保它们完全是自发的。

Secondary orality is both remarkably like and remarkably unlike primary orality. Like primary orality, secondary orality has generated a strong group sense, for listening to spoken words forms hearers into a group, a true audience, just as reading written or printed texts turns individuals in on themselves. But secondary orality generates a sense for groups immeasurably larger than those of primary oral culture – McLuhan’s ‘global village’. Moreover, before writing, oral folk were group-minded because no feasible alternative had presented itself. In our age of secondary orality, we are groupminded self-consciously and programmatically. The individual feels that he or she, as an individual, must be socially sensitive. Unlike members of a primary oral culture, who are turned outward because they have had little occasion to turn inward, we are turned outward because we have turned inward. In a like vein, where primary orality promotes spontaneity because the analytic reﬂectiveness implemented by writing is unavailable, secondary orality promotes spontaneity because through analytic reﬂection we have decided that spontaneity is a good thing. We plan our happenings carefully to be sure that they are thoroughly spontaneous.

过去和当今世界的演讲之间的对比很好地凸显了初级口语和次要口语之间的对比。广播和电视将主要政治人物作为公共演讲者带到了更广泛的公众面前，这在现代电子发展之前是不可能的。因此，从某种意义上说，口头语言比以往任何时候都更加发挥作用。但这不是旧的口头说法。来自初级口头的旧式演讲已经一去不复返了。在 1858 年的林肯-道格拉斯辩论中，双方——因为这就是他们的真实身份——经常在伊利诺伊州炎热的夏日阳光下在户外面对面，面对着多达 12,000 或 15,000 名反应热烈的观众（在渥太华和分别是伊利诺伊州弗里波特 – Sparks 1908，第 137-8 页、第 189-90 页），每次演讲一个半小时。第一个演讲者有一个小时，又是半个小时的反驳——这一切都没有扩音设备。初级口语表现在附加的、多余的、精心平衡的、高度竞争的风格以及演讲者和听众之间的强烈互动中。每场比赛结束时，辩手们都声嘶力竭，体力透支。今天的电视总统辩论完全脱离了这个古老的口头世界。观众缺席、看不见、听不见。候选人们坐在狭窄的小隔间里，做简短的演讲，互相进行简短的对话，其中任何竞争的边缘都被刻意保持平淡。电子媒体不能容忍公开对抗的表现。尽管这些媒体具有自发性，但它们完全被一种封闭感所主导，这是印刷品的遗产：表现出敌意可能会打破封锁和严格控制。候选人要适应媒体的心理。文雅、有文化的家庭生活十分盛行。今天，只有上了年纪的人才能记得当演讲仍然与其原始口腔根源保持联系时是什么样子。其他人可能会从主要公众人物那里听到更多的演讲，或者至少比一个世纪前人们通常听到的更多的谈话。但他们所听到的内容并不会让他们了解从前电子时代追溯到两千年甚至更久远的古老演讲，也不了解产生这种演讲的口头生活方式和口头思维结构。今天，只有上了年纪的人才能记得当演讲仍然与其原始口腔根源保持联系时是什么样子。其他人可能会从主要公众人物那里听到更多的演讲，或者至少比一个世纪前人们通常听到的更多的谈话。但他们所听到的内容并不会让他们了解从前电子时代追溯到两千年甚至更久远的古老演讲，也不了解产生这种演讲的口头生活方式和口头思维结构。今天，只有上了年纪的人才能记得当演讲仍然与其原始口腔根源保持联系时是什么样子。其他人可能会从主要公众人物那里听到更多的演讲，或者至少比一个世纪前人们通常听到的更多的谈话。但他们所听到的内容并不会让他们了解从前电子时代追溯到两千年甚至更久远的古老演讲，也不了解产生这种演讲的口头生活方式和口头思维结构。

The contrast between oratory in the past and in today’s world well highlights the contrast between primary and secondary orality. Radio and television have brought major political ﬁgures as public speakers to a larger public than was ever possible before modern electronic developments. Thus in a sense orality has come into its own more than ever before. But it is not the old orality. The old-style oratory coming from primary orality is gone forever. In the Lincoln-Douglas debates of 1858, the combatants – for that is what they clearly and truly were – faced one another often in the scorching Illinois summer sun outdoors, before wildly responsive audiences of as many as 12,000 or 15,000 persons (at Ottawa and Freeport, Illinois, respectively – Sparks 1908, pp. 137–8, 189–90), speaking for an hour and a half each. The ﬁrst speaker had one hour, the second an hour and a half, and the ﬁrst another half hour of rebuttal – all this with no amplifying equipment. Primary orality made itself felt in the additive, redundant, carefully balanced, highly agonistic style, and the intense interplay between speaker and audience. The debaters were hoarse and physically exhausted at the end of each bout. Presidential debates on television today are completely out of this older oral world. The audience is absent, invisible, inaudible. The candidates are ensconced in tight little booths, make short presentations, and engage in crisp little conversations with each other in which any agonistic edge is deliberately kept dull. Electronic media do not tolerate a show of open antagonism. Despite their cultivated air of spontaneity, these media are totally dominated by a sense of closure which is the heritage of print: a show of hostility might break open the closure, the tight control. Candidates accommodate themselves to the psychology of the media. Genteel, literate domesticity is rampant. Only quite elderly persons today can remember what oratory was like when it was still in living contact with its primary oral roots. Others perhaps hear more oratory, or at least more talk, from major public ﬁgures than people commonly heard a century ago. But what they hear will give them very little idea of the old oratory reaching back from pre-electronic times through two millennia and far beyond, or of the oral lifestyle and oral thought structures out of which such oratory grew.

6

6

口头记忆、故事情节和人物塑造

ORAL MEMORY, THE STORY LINE AND CHARACTERIZATION

故事情节的首要性

THE PRIMACY OF THE STORY LINE

从口头到读写的转变体现在言语艺术的许多类型中——抒情、叙事、描述性话语、演讲（通过手写组织的演讲到电视风格的公共演讲的纯口头）、戏剧、哲学和科学作品、史学和传记，仅举几个。其中，在口头-读写转变方面研究最多的类型是叙事。这里考虑一些在叙事方面所做的工作是有用的，以提出口语读写研究提供的一些新见解。为了当前的目的，我们可以将戏剧同化为叙事，虽然它呈现没有叙事声音的动作，但仍然有一个故事情节，就像叙事一样。

The shift from orality to literacy registers in many genres of verbal art – lyric, narrative, descriptive discourse, oratory (purely oral through chirographically organized oratory to television-styled public address), drama, philosophical and scientiﬁc works, historiography, and biography, to mention only a few. Of these, the genre most studied in terms of the orality–literacy shift has been narrative. It will be of use here to consider some of the work done on narrative to suggest some newer insights offered by orality–literacy studies. To narrative we can for present purposes assimilate drama, which, while it presents action with no narrative voice, still has a story line, as narrative does.

显然，除了口语-读写能力的转变之外，社会的其他发展也有助于决定历代叙事的发展——不断变化的政治组织、宗教发展、跨文化交流等等，包括其他语言流派的发展。这种对叙事的处理并不是为了减少口语-读写能力转变的所有因果关系，而只是为了显示这种转变产生的一些影响。

Obviously, other developments in society besides the orality–literacy shift help determine the development of narrative over the ages – changing political organization, religious development, intercultural exchanges, and much else, including developments in the other verbal genres. This treatment of narrative is not intended to reduce all causality to the orality–literacy shift but only to show some of the effects which this shift produces.

叙事无处不在，是语言艺术的一个主要流派，发生在所有的地方。从初级口头文化到高级识字和电子信息处理的方式。从某种意义上说，叙事在所有语言艺术形式中至关重要，因为它是许多其他艺术形式（甚至通常是最抽象的艺术形式）的基础。人类的知识源于时间。即使在科学抽象的背后，也存在着对观察的叙述，抽象是在此基础上形成的。科学实验室的学生必须“写出”实验，也就是说，他们必须叙述他们做了什么以及做实验时发生了什么。从叙述中可以得出某些概括或抽象结论。谚语、警句、哲学思辨和宗教仪式的背后，是人类经历的记忆，随着时间的推移而排列，并受到叙事处理。抒情诗意味着一系列事件，其中嵌入了抒情诗中的声音或与之相关。所有这一切都是在说，知识和话语来自人类经验，而以语言方式处理人类经验的基本方式是或多或少地对它真正产生和存在的情况进行描述，嵌入在时间的流动中。 。开发故事情节是处理这种流程的一种方法。

Narrative is everywhere a major genre of verbal art, occurring all the way from primary oral cultures into high literacy and electronic information processing. In a sense narrative is paramount among all verbal art forms because of the way it underlies so many other art forms, often even the most abstract. Human knowledge comes out of time. Behind even the abstractions of science, there lies narrative of the observations on the basis of which the abstractions have been formulated. Students in a science laboratory have to ‘write up’ experiments, which is to say, they have to narrate what they did and what happened when they did it. From the narration, certain generalizations or abstract conclusions can be formulated. Behind proverbs and aphorisms and philosophical speculation and religious ritual lies the memory of human experience strung out in time and subject to narrative treatment. Lyric poetry implies a series of events in which the voice in the lyric is embedded or to which it is related. All of this is to say that knowledge and discourse come out of human experience and that the elemental way to process human experience verbally is to give an account of it more or less as it really comes into being and exists, embedded in the ﬂow of time. Developing a story line is a way of dealing with this ﬂow.

叙事和口头文化

NARRATIVE AND ORAL CULTURES

尽管叙事存在于所有文化中，但在某些方面，叙事在初级口头文化中的作用比在其他文化中更为广泛。首先，正如哈夫洛克指出的（1978a；参见1963），在初级口头文化中，知识不能以复杂的、或多或少科学抽象的类别来管理。口头文化无法产生这样的类别，因此它们使用人类行为的故事来存储、组织和交流它们所知道的大部分内容。大多数（如果不是全部）口头文化都会产生相当丰富的叙事或一系列叙事，例如古希腊人之间的特洛伊战争故事、美洲原住民中的土狼故事、伯利兹和其他加勒比海地区的阿纳西（蜘蛛）故事带有一些非洲遗产的文化、古马里的Sunjata故事、Nyanga的Mwindo故事等等。

Although it is found in all cultures, narrative is in certain ways more widely functional in primary oral cultures than in others. First, in a primary oral culture, as Havelock pointed out (1978a; cf. 1963), knowledge cannot be managed in elaborate, more or less scientiﬁcally abstract categories. Oral cultures cannot generate such categories, and so they use stories of human action to store, organize, and communicate much of what they know. Most, if not all, oral cultures generate quite substantial narratives or series of narratives, such as the stories of the Trojan wars among the ancient Greeks, the coyote stories among various Native American populations, the Anansi (spider) stories in Belize and other Caribbean cultures with some African heritage, the Sunjata stories of old Mali, the Mwindo stories among the Nyanga, and so on. Because of their size and complexity of scenes and actions, narratives of this sort are often the roomiest repositories of an oral culture’s lore.

其次，叙事在原始口头文化中尤为重要，因为它可以以相当持久的相对充实、冗长的形式将大量的知识联系起来——这在口头文化中意味着形式可以重复。格言、谜语、谚语等当然也经久不衰，但它们通常很简短。仪式公式可能很长，但通常具有专门的内容。家谱可能相对较长，仅提供高度专业化的信息。在初级口头文化中，其他冗长的言语表演往往是话题性的、偶然发生的。因此，一篇演讲可能与一次主要叙述一样充实和冗长，或者是一次性发表的叙述的一部分，但演讲并不持久：它通常不会被重复。它针对特定情况，并且，在完全没有书写的情况下，它会随着情境本身从人类场景中永远消失。歌词往往是简短的或主题性的或两者兼而有之。其他形式也是如此。

Second, narrative is particularly important in primary oral cultures because it can bond a great deal of lore in relatively substantial, lengthy forms that are reasonably durable – which in an oral culture means forms subject to repetition. Maxims, riddles, proverbs, and the like are of course also durable, but they are usually brief. Ritual formulas, which may be lengthy, have most often specialized content. Genealogies, which can be relatively long, present only highly specialized information. Other lengthy verbal performance in a primary oral culture tends to be topical, a nonce occurrence. Thus an oration might be as substantial and lengthy as a major narrative, or a part of a narrative that would be delivered at one sitting, but an oration is not durable: it is not normally repeated. It addresses itself to a particular situation and, in the total absence of writing, disappears from the human scene for good with the situation itself. Lyric tends to be either brief or topical or both. And so with other forms.

在书写或印刷文化中，文本以物理方式将其所包含的内容粘合在一起，并使检索任何类型的思想组织作为一个整体成为可能。在没有文本的初级口头文化中，叙事比其他类型更广泛、更持久地结合思想。

In a writing or print culture, the text physically bonds whatever it contains and makes it possible to retrieve any kind of organization of thought as a whole. In primary oral cultures, where there is no text, the narrative serves to bond thought more massively and permanently than other genres.

口头记忆和故事情节

ORAL MEMORY AND THE STORY LINE

叙事本身有历史。斯科尔斯和凯洛格（Scholes and Kellogg，1966）调查并概括了西方叙事从一些古老的口头起源发展到现在的一些方式，充分关注复杂的社会、心理、审美和其他因素。承认整个叙事历史的复杂性，本文将简单地提请注意一些显着的差异，这些差异将完全口头文化背景下的叙事与文字叙事区分开来，特别关注记忆的功能。

Narrative itself has a history. Scholes and Kellogg (1966) surveyed and schematized some of the ways in which narrative in the West has developed from some of its ancient oral origins into the present, with full attention to complex social, psychological, aesthetic, and other factors. Acknowledging the complexities of the full history of narrative, the present account will simply call attention to some salient differences that set off narrative in a totally oral cultural setting from literate narrative, with particular attention to the functioning of memory.

第 3 章中描述的初级口头文化中知识的保留和回忆需要一种我们非常不熟悉并且经常被我们鄙视的思维结构和程序。口头助记结构和程序最引人注目的地方之一是它们对叙事情节的影响，而在口头文化中，这并不完全是我们通常认为的情节。来自的人当今的文学和印刷文化可能会认为有意识地设计的叙事通常是在高潮线性情节中设计的，通常被描绘成著名的“弗莱塔格金字塔”（即向上倾斜，然后向下倾斜）：上升的动作会产生张力，上升到一个高潮点，这通常包括一个认识或其他事件导致行动的回旋或逆转，然后是结局或解开——因为这个标准的高潮线性情节被比作捆绑和解开一个结。这就是亚里士多德在戏剧中发现的情节（《诗学》1451b–1452b）——这种情节的一个重要场所，因为希腊戏剧虽然是口头表演的，但却是作为书面文本组成的，在西方是第一个口头流派，并且几个世纪以来是唯一完全受控制的口头流派。写作。

The retention and recall of knowledge in primary oral culture, described in Chapter 3, calls for noetic structures and procedures of a sort quite unfamiliar to us and often enough scorned by us.
