One of the places where oral mnemonic structures and procedures manifest themselves most spectacularly is in their effect on narrative plot, which in an oral culture is not quite what we take plot typically to be. Persons from today’s literate and typographic cultures are likely to think of consciously contrived narrative as typically designed in a climactic linear plot often diagramed as the well-known ‘Freytag’s pyramid’ (i.e. an upward slope, followed by a downward slope): an ascending action builds tension, rising to a climactic point, which consists often of a recognition or other incident bringing about a peripeteia or reversal of action, and which is followed by a dénouement or untying – for this standard climactic linear plot has been likened to the tying and untying of a knot. This is the kind of plot Aristotle ﬁnds in the drama ( Poetics 1451b–1452b) – a signiﬁcant locale for such plot, since Greek drama, though orally performed, was composed as a written text and in the West was the ﬁrst verbal genre, and for centuries was the only verbal genre, to be controlled completely by writing.

古希腊的口头叙事，即史诗，并不是这样绘制的。贺拉斯在他的《诗学》中写道，史诗诗人“匆忙采取行动，让听者陷入事物的中心”（第 148-9 行）。贺拉斯主要想到的是史诗诗人对时间顺序的漠视。诗人会报告一种情况，然后才解释（通常是详细的）情况是如何发生的。他可能还考虑到荷马的简洁和活力（Brink 1971，第221-2页）：荷马希望立即到达“行动所在”。不管情况如何，有文化的诗人最终将贺拉斯的媒体资源解释为使史诗中的歇斯底里·普特隆成为必然。约翰·弥尔顿在《失乐园》第一卷的“论证”中如此解释在简要提出这首诗的“整个主题”并触及亚当堕落的“主要原因”之后，“这首诗就进入了事物的中间”。

Ancient Greek oral narrative, the epic, was not plotted this way. In his Ars Poetica, Horace writes that the epic poet ‘hastens into the action and precipitates the hearer into the middle of things’ (lines 148–9). Horace has chieﬂy in mind the epic poet’s disregard for temporal sequence. The poet will report a situation and only much later explain, often in detail, how it came to be. He probably has also in mind Homer’s conciseness and vigor (Brink 1971, pp. 221–2): Homer wants to get immediately to ‘where the action is’. However this may be, literate poets eventually interpreted Horace’s in medias res as making hysteron proteron obligatory in the epic. Thus John Milton explains in the ‘Argument’ to Book I of Paradise Lost that, after proposing ‘in brief the whole subject’ of the poem and touching upon ‘the prime cause’ of Adam’s fall ‘the Poem hasts into the midst of things.’

弥尔顿在这里的话表明，他从一开始就能够控制他的主题以及推动其行动的原因，这是任何口头诗人都无法控制的。弥尔顿心中有一个高度组织的情节，有开头、中间和结尾（亚里士多德，《诗学》 1450b），其顺序在时间上与他所报道的事件相对应。他故意肢解这个情节，以便以一种有意识地设计的不合时宜的模式重新组合它的各个部分。

Milton’s words here show that he had from the start a control of his subject and of the causes powering its action that no oral poet could command. Milton has in mind a highly organized plot, with a beginning, middle and end (Aristotle, Poetics 1450b) in a sequence corresponding temporally to that of the events he was reporting. This plot he deliberately dismembered in order to reassemble its parts in a consciously contrived anachronistic pattern.

过去文人对口头史诗的注释通常被视为口头史诗诗人在做同样的事情，将其归咎于他们有意识地偏离了实际上没有写作就无法实现的组织。这种注释带有同样的手写偏见，这在《圣经》中也很明显。术语“口头文学”。由于口头表演被认为是写作的一种变体，因此口头史诗情节也被认为是戏剧写作中制定的情节的一种变体。亚里士多德在他的《诗学》（1447-1448a、1451a 和其他著作）中已经有了这样的思考，出于明显的原因，他对以他自己的手写文化编写和表演的戏剧比对史诗（史诗）有更好的理解。原始的口头文化早已消失。

Exegesis of oral epic by literates in the past has commonly seen oral epic poets as doing this same thing, imputing to them conscious deviation from an organization which was in fact unavailable without writing. Such exegesis smacks of the same chirographic bias evident in the term ‘oral literature’. As oral performance is thought of as a variant of writing, so the oral epic plot is thought of as a variant of the plot worked out in writing for drama. Aristotle was already thinking this way in his Poetics (1447–1448a, 1451a, and elsewhere), which for obvious reasons shows a better understanding of the drama, written and acted in his own chirographic culture, than of the epic, the product of a primary oral culture long vanished.

事实上，口头文化没有经历过冗长的、史诗般的或小说般的高潮线性情节。它无法以勤奋、不懈的高潮方式组织更短的叙事，而过去200年来，文学读者已经越来越多地期待——并且在近几十年来，自觉地贬低了这种方式。如果将口头作文描述为与它不了解且无法想象的组织不同，这对口头作文来说是不公平的。除了简短的段落之外，动作应该在中间开始的“事情”从来没有按照时间顺序排列来建立“情节”。贺拉斯的资源是识字的一种建构。你在人们的生活中找不到现成的高潮线性情节，尽管现实生活可能提供材料，通过无情地消除除了少数精心突出的事件之外的所有事件来构建这样的情节。奥赛罗一生中所有事件的完整故事将是完全无聊的。

In fact, an oral culture has no experience of a lengthy, epic-size or novel-size climactic linear plot. It cannot organize even shorter narrative in the studious, relentless climactic way that readers of literature for the past 200 years have learned more and more to expect – and, in recent decades, self-consciously to depreciate. It hardly does justice to oral composition to describe it as varying from an organization it does not know, and cannot conceive of. The ‘things’ that the action is supposed to start in the middle of have never, except for brief passages, been ranged in a chronological order to establish a ‘plot’. Horace’s res is a construct of literacy. You do not ﬁnd climactic linear plots ready-formed in people’s lives, although real lives may provide material out of which such a plot may be constructed by ruthless elimination of all but a few carefully highlighted incidents. The full story of all the events in Othello’s whole life would be a complete bore.

口头诗人在创作歌曲时通常会遇到困难：赫西奥德的《神谱》处于口头表演和书面创作之间的边缘，对同一材料进行了三次尝试才能开始（Peabody 1975，第432-3页）。口头诗人通常让读者陷入媒体研究中不是因为任何宏伟的设计，而是出于必然。他们别无选择，别无选择。荷马听过几十位歌手演唱了数百首不同长度的有关特洛伊战争的歌曲，荷马有大量的剧集可以串联起来，但如果没有写作，绝对没有办法按照严格的时间顺序组织它们。没有剧集清单，在没有文字记录的情况下，甚至没有可能构思出这样一个清单。如果他试图按照严格的时间顺序进行，那么口头诗人在任何特定的场合都一定会在应该按时间顺序排列的地方省略一个或另一个情节，并且必须稍后将其放入。如果下次他记得按正确的时间顺序排列这一集，他就确信遗漏其他剧集或按错误的时间顺序排列它们。

Oral poets characteristically experience difficulty in getting a song under way: Hesiod’s Theogony, on the borderline between oral performance and written composition, makes three tries at the same material to get going (Peabody 1975, pp. 432–3). Oral poets commonly plunged the reader in medias res not because of any grand design, but perforce. They had no choice, no alternative. Having heard perhaps scores of singers singing hundreds of songs of variable lengths about the Trojan War, Homer had a huge repertoire of episodes to string together but, without writing, absolutely no way to organize them in strict chronological order. There was no list of the episodes nor, in the absence of writing, was there any possibility even of conceiving of such a list. If he were to try to proceed in strict chronological order, the oral poet would on any given occasion be sure to leave out one or another episode at the point where it should ﬁt chronologically and would have to put it in later on. If, on the next occasion, he remembered to put the episode in at the right chronological order, he would be sure to leave out other episodes or get them in the wrong chronological order.

此外，史诗中的材料本身并不是那种能够轻易产生高潮线性情节的东西。如果将《伊利亚特》或《奥德赛》中的情节按照严格的时间顺序重新排列，整体有一个进展，但它不具有典型戏剧那种紧密的高潮结构。惠特曼的《伊利亚特》（1965）的组织图表明了由主题重复创建的盒子中的盒子，而不是弗雷塔格的金字塔。

Moreover, the material in an epic is not the sort of thing that would of itself readily yield a climactic linear plot. If the episodes in the Iliad or the Odyssey are rearranged in strict chronological order, the whole has a progression, but it does not have the tight climactic structure of the typical drama. Whitman’s chart of the organization of the Iliad (1965) suggests boxes within boxes created by thematic recurrences, not Freytag’s pyramid.

成为优秀史诗诗人的并不是对高潮线性情节的掌握，他通过一种复杂的技巧来解构这种情节，这种技巧被称为“让听众沉浸在媒体资源中”。当然，成为优秀史诗诗人的原因之一是，首先，默许这样一个事实：情节结构是想象和处理冗长叙事的唯一方式，也是完全自然的方式；其次，拥有管理叙事的最高技巧。闪回和其他情景技巧。从“事情的中间”开始并不是一种有意识的策略，而是一个口头诗人接近长篇叙事的原始的、自然的、不可避免的方式（非常短的记述也许是另一回事）。如果我们以高潮线性情节为情节范式，史诗就没有情节。长篇叙事的严格情节伴随着写作。

What made a good epic poet was not mastery of a climactic linear plot which he deconstructed by dint of a sophisticated trick called plunging his hearer in medias res. What made a good epic poet was, among other things of course, ﬁrst, tacit acceptance of the fact that episodic structure was the only way and the totally natural way of imagining and handling lengthy narrative, and, second, possession of supreme skill in managing ﬂashbacks and other episodic techniques. Starting in ‘the middle of things’ is not a consciously contrived ploy but the original, natural, inevitable way to proceed for an oral poet approaching a lengthy narrative (very short accounts are perhaps another thing). If we take the climactic linear plot as the paradigm of plot, the epic has no plot. Strict plot for lengthy narrative comes with writing.

为什么冗长的高潮情节只能在文字中出现，首先出现在没有叙述者的戏剧中，直到两千多年后的小说时代才出现在长篇叙事中。简·奥斯汀？早期所谓的“小说”或多或少都是情节性的，尽管德拉法耶特夫人的《克莱维斯公主》（La Princesse de Clèves，1678）和其他几部小说的情节程度比大多数小说要少。高潮的线性情节在侦探故事中达到了完整的形式——不断上升的紧张气氛、精致整齐的发现和逆转、完美解决的结局。一般认为，侦探故事始于 1841 年埃德加·爱伦·坡的《莫格街谋杀案》。据我们所知，为什么 1800 年代初期之前的所有长篇叙事在世界各地都或多或少是情节性的（甚至是紫式部夫人早熟的《源氏物语》）？为什么 1841 年之前没有人写出一篇简洁的侦探小说？这些问题的一些答案——当然不是所有答案——可以找到更深入地了解口语-读写能力转变的动态。

Why is it that lengthy climactic plot comes into being only with writing, comes into being ﬁrst in the drama, where there is no narrator, and does not make its way into lengthy narrative until more than 2000 years later with the novels of the age of Jane Austen? Earlier so called ‘novels’ were all more or less episodic, although Mme de la Fayette’s La Princesse de Clèves (1678) and a few others are less so than most. The climactic linear plot reaches a plenary form in the detective story – relentlessly rising tension, exquisitely tidy discovery and reversal, perfectly resolved dénouement. The detective story is generally considered to have begun in 1841 with Edgar Allan Poe’s The Murders in the Rue Morgue. Why was all lengthy narrative before the early 1800s more or less episodic, so far as we know, all over the world (even Lady Murasaki Shikibu’s otherwise precocious The Tale of Genji )? Why had no one written a tidy detective story before 1841? Some answers to these questions – though of course not all the answers – can be found in a deeper understanding of the dynamics of the orality–literacy shift.

伯克利·皮博迪在他的长篇著作《有翼的词：主要通过赫西奥德的著作和时代看待古希腊口语写作技巧的研究》中，对记忆与情节的关系提出了新的见解。（1975）。皮博迪不仅建立在帕里、洛德和哈夫洛克的工作以及相关工作的基础上，而且还建立在早期欧洲人的工作基础上，例如安托万·梅耶、西奥多·伯格克、赫尔曼·乌塞纳和乌尔里希·冯·维拉莫维茨-莫伦多夫，以及一些控制论和结构主义文献。他将希腊史诗的心理动力学置于印欧传统中，展示了希腊韵律与阿维斯坦、印度吠陀和其他梵文韵律之间的密切联系，以及六音步线的演变与意念过程之间的联系。皮博迪得出结论的这种更大的氛围表明了更广阔的视野。很可能，他所说的关于古希腊叙事歌曲中情节​​的位置和相关事项的内容将以各种方式适用于全世界文化中的口头叙事。

Berkley Peabody opened new insights into the relationship of memory and plot in his lengthy work, The Winged Word: A Study in the Technique of Ancient Greek Oral Composition as Seen Principally through Hesiod’s Works and Days (1975). Peabody builds not only on the work of Parry, Lord and Havelock, and related work, but also on work of earlier Europeans such as Antoine Meillet, Theodor Bergk, Hermann Usener, and Ulrich von Wilamowitz-Moellendorff, and upon some cybernetic and structuralist literature. He situates the psychodynamics of Greek epos in the Indo-European tradition, showing intimate connections between Greek metrics and Avestan and Indian Vedic and other Sanskrit metrics and the connections between the evolution of the hexameter line and noetic processes. This larger ambience in which Peabody situates his conclusions suggests still wider horizons beyond. Very likely, what he has to say about the place of plot and about related matters in ancient Greek narrative song will be found to apply in various ways to oral narrative in cultures around the entire world. And indeed, in his abundant notes, Peabody makes reference from time to time to Native American and other non-Indo-European traditions and practices.

皮博迪部分明确地、部分暗示地指出了线性图（弗雷塔格金字塔）和口头记忆之间的某种不相容性，这是早期作品无法做到的。他明确指出，古希腊口头史诗的真正“思想”或内容存在于记忆中的传统公式和诗节模式中，而不是歌手以某种记忆方式组织或“情节”叙事的有意识意图（1975，第 172-9 页）。“歌手的效果不是他自己意图的转移，而是为他的听众（包括他自己）传统思想的传统实现”（1975，第176页）。歌手传达的“信息”并不是我们通常意义上的从歌手到听众的数据“管道传输”。基本上，歌手以一种奇怪的公开方式进行记忆——记住的不是背下来的文本，因为除了他听过其他歌手唱过的主题和公式之外，没有这样的东西，也没有任何逐字连续的单词。他对这些的记忆总是不同的，在这个特殊的场合，为这个特殊的观众，以他自己的方式狂想或缝合在一起。“歌曲是对所唱歌曲的回忆”（1975，第216页）。

In part explicitly and in part by implication, Peabody brings out a certain incompatibility between linear plot (Freytag’s pyramid) and oral memory, as earlier works were unable to do. He makes it clear that the true ‘thought’ or content of ancient Greek oral epos dwells in the remembered traditional formulaic and stanzaic patterns rather than in the conscious intentions of the singer to organize or ‘plot’ narrative in a certain remembered way (1975, pp. 172–9). ‘A singer effects, not a transfer of his own intentions, but a conventional realization of traditional thought for his listeners, including himself’ (1975, p. 176). The singer is not conveying ‘information’ in our ordinary sense of ‘a pipeline transfer’ of data from singer to listener. Basically, the singer is remembering in a curiously public way – remembering not a memorized text, for there is no such thing, nor any verbatim succession of words, but the themes and formulas that he has heard other singers sing. He remembers these always differently, as rhapsodized or stitched together in his own way on this particular occasion for this particular audience. ‘Song is the remembrance of songs sung’ (1975, p. 216).

口头史诗（以及通过假设的延伸，口头文化中的其他叙事形式）与应用于书面作品的现代意义上的创造性想象力无关。“我们在刻意形成新的概念、抽象和幻想模式时所获得的乐趣绝不能归因于传统歌手”（1975年，第216页）。当吟游诗人添加新材料时，他会以传统方式对其进行处理。吟游诗人总是陷入一种不完全由他控制的境地：这些人在这个场合希望他唱歌（1975，第174页）。（从现在的经验中我们知道，一个表演者在意外地被一群人强迫表演时，通常会首先提出异议，从而引发新的邀请，直到最后他与观众建立了可行的关系：“好吧。如果你坚持的话。” ..'。）口头歌曲（或其他叙事）是歌手、在场听众以及歌手对所唱歌曲的记忆之间互动的结果。在处理这种互动时，吟游诗人在与作家截然不同的基础上具有原创性和创造性。

The oral epic (and by hypothetical extension other forms of narrative in oral cultures) has nothing to do with creative imagination in the modern sense of this term, as applied to written composition. ‘Our own pleasure in deliberately forming new concepts, abstractions and patterns of fancy must not be attributed to the traditional singer’ (1975, p. 216). When a bard adds new material, he processes it in the traditional way. The bard is always caught in a situation not entirely under his control: these people on this occasion want him to sing (1975, p.174). (We know from present-day experience how a performer, unexpectedly pressed by a group to perform, will normally at ﬁrst demur, thereby provoking renewed invitations until ﬁnally he has established a workable relationship with his audience: ‘All right. If you insist...’.) The oral song (or other narrative) is the result of interaction between the singer, the present audience, and the singer’s memories of songs sung. In working with this interaction, the bard is original and creative on rather different grounds from those of the writer.

例如，由于没有人按照完整的时间顺序演唱特洛伊战争的歌曲，因此荷马甚至不会想到以这种方式演唱它们。吟游诗人的目标并不是按照紧凑的总体情节来制定的。在现代的扎伊尔（当时的刚果民主共和国），坎迪·鲁雷克（Candi Rureke）在被要求讲述尼扬加英雄姆温多（Mwindo）的所有故事时感到惊讶（Biebuyck and Mateene 1971，第 14 页）：他抗议说，从来没有人表演过所有 Mwindo 剧集均按顺序排列。我们知道鲁雷克的这种表现是如何产生的。作为之前与比布克和马泰内谈判的结果，他以三名抄写员、两名尼扬加和一位比利时人记下了他的话。这与写小说或诗歌不太一样。每天的表演都让鲁雷克身心俱疲，十二天下来他已经筋疲力尽了。

Since no one had ever sung the songs of the Trojan wars, for example, in full chronological sequence, no Homer could even think of singing them that way. Bardic objectives are not framed in terms of a tight over-all plot. In modern Zaïre (then the Democratic Republic of the Congo), Candi Rureke, when asked to narrate all the stories of the Nyanga hero Mwindo, was astonished (Biebuyck and Mateene 1971, p. 14): never, he protested, had anyone performed all the Mwindo episodes in sequence. We know how this performance was elicited from Rureke. As the result of previous negotiations with Biebuyck and Mateene, he narrated all the Mwindo stories, now in prose, now in verse, with occasional choral accompaniment, before a (somewhat ﬂuid) audience, for twelve days, as three scribes, two Nyanga and one Belgian, took down his words. This is not much like writing a novel or a poem. Each day’s performance tired Rureke both psychologically and physically, and after the twelve days he was totally exhausted.

皮博迪对记忆的深刻论述为我们前面在第三章中讨论过的基于口头的思想和表达的许多特征提供了新的视角，特别是它的附加性、聚合性特征、它的保守性、它的冗余或复制以及它的参与性经济。

Peabody’s profound treatment of memory throws bright new light on many of the characteristics of orally based thought and expression earlier discussed here in Chapter 3, notably on its additive, aggregative character, its conservatism, its redundancy or copia, and its participatory economy.

当然，叙事与事件的时间顺序有关，因此在所有叙事中都有某种故事情节。由于一系列事件的结果，最后的情况是继开始时的情况之后的。然而，记忆在引导口头诗人时，通常与按时间顺序严格线性地呈现事件无关。诗人会陷入对英雄盾牌的描写而完全失去叙事轨道。在我们的印刷和电子文化中，我们今天发现自己对话语中元素的线性顺序与指称顺序（话语所指的世界的时间顺序）之间的精确对应感到高兴。我们喜欢口头报告中的顺序与我们所经历或可以安排经历的事情完全一致。马里昂巴德或胡里奥·科塔萨尔的《瑞尤埃拉》，其效果显然是自觉的：人们意识到通常预期的并行性的缺失。

Of course, narrative has to do with the temporal sequence of events, and thus in all narrative there is some kind of story line. As the result of a sequence of events, the situation at the end is subsequent to what it was at the beginning. Nevertheless, memory, as it guides the oral poet, often has little to do with strict linear presentation of events in temporal sequence. The poet will get caught up with the description of the hero’s shield and completely lose the narrative track. In our typographic and electronic culture, we ﬁnd ourselves today delighted by exact correspondence between the linear order of elements in discourse and the referential order, the chronological order in the world to which the discourse refers. We like sequence in verbal reports to parallel exactly what we experience or can arrange to experience. When today narrative abandons or distorts this parallelism, as in Robbe-Grillet’s Marienbad or Julio Cortázar’s Rayuela, the effect is clearly self-conscious: one is aware of the absence of the normally expected parallelism.

口头叙述并不十分关心叙述中的顺序与叙述外所指对象中的顺序之间的精确顺序平行性。只有当头脑将识字内在化时，这种平行性才成为主要目标。皮博迪指出，萨福早熟地利用了这一点，这给她的诗歌带来了好奇的现代性，作为对暂时生活的个人经历的报道（1975，第221页）。当然，到了萨福的时代（公元前600年），写作已经开始构建希腊人的心灵。

Oral narrative is not greatly concerned with exact sequential parallelism between the sequence in the narrative and the sequence in extranarrative referents. Such a parallelism becomes a major objective only when the mind interiorizes literacy. It was precociously exploited, Peabody points out, by Sappho, and it gives her poems their curious modernity as reports on temporally lived personal experience (1975, p. 221). Of course by Sappho’s time (ﬂ. c. 600 BC) writing was already structuring the Greek psyche.

情节结束：侦探故事游记

CLOSURE OF PLOT: TRAVELOGUE TO DETECTIVE STORY

识字和后来的印刷对叙事情节的影响太大，无法在此详细讨论。但是，通过考虑从口头到识字的转变，可以阐明一些更普遍的影响。随着将文本作为文本处理的经验的成熟，文本的制作者，现在正确的“作者”，获得了一种与现场观众面前的口头表演者明显不同的表达和组织感觉。“作者”可以独自阅读别人的故事，可以根据笔记工作，甚至可以在写作之前勾勒出故事的轮廓。尽管灵感仍然源自无意识的来源，但作家可以将无意识的灵感置于更大的有意识的灵感之下。比口头叙述者更能控制。作者发现他的书面文字可以重新考虑、修改和其他操作，直到它们最终被释放来完成他们的工作。在作者的眼前，文本列出了开头、中间和结尾，这样作者就被鼓励将他的作品视为一个独立的、离散的单元，由封闭来定义。

The effects of literacy and later of print on the plotting of narrative are too vast to treat here in full detail. But some of the more generic effects are illuminated by considering the transit to literacy from orality. As the experience of working with text as text matures, the maker of the text, now properly an ‘author’, acquires a feeling for expression and organization notably different from that of the oral performer before a live audience. The ‘author’ can read the stories of others in solitude, can work from notes, can even outline a story in advance of writing it. Though inspiration continues to derive from unconscious sources, the writer can subject the unconscious inspiration to far greater conscious control than the oral narrator. The writer ﬁnds his written words accessible for reconsideration, revision, and other manipulation until they are ﬁnally released to do their work. Under the author’s eyes the text lays out the beginning, the middle and the end, so that the writer is encouraged to think of his work as a self-contained, discrete unit, deﬁned by closure.

由于意识控制的增强，故事情节发展出越来越紧凑的高潮结构，取代了旧的口头情节情节。正如前面所指出的，古希腊戏剧是第一个完全受文字控制的西方语言艺术形式。这是第一个——也是几个世纪以来唯一的——具有典型的紧密的弗雷塔金字塔结构的流派。矛盾的是，虽然这部戏剧是口头呈现的，但它在呈现之前就已被写成书面文本。戏剧性的呈现缺乏叙事声音，这一点很重要。叙述者将自己完全埋没在文本中，消失在人物的声音之下。正如我们所看到的，口头文化中的叙述者通常和自然地以情景模式运作，消除叙事声音似乎对于消除故事情节的这种模式至关重要。我们不能忘记，情节结构是讲述冗长故事情节的自然方式，因为现实生活的经历更像是一连串的情节，而不是弗莱塔格金字塔。精心的选择性产生了紧密的金字塔情节，而这种选择性是通过写作在表达与现实生活之间建立的距离来实现的。

Because of increased conscious control, the story line develops tighter and tighter climactic structures in place of the old oral episodic plot. The ancient Greek drama, as has earlier been noted, was the ﬁrst western verbal art form to be fully controlled by writing. It was the ﬁrst – and for centuries the only – genre to have typically a tight, Freytagpyramid structure. Paradoxically, although the drama was presented orally, it had been composed before presentation as a written text. It is signiﬁcant that dramatic presentation lacks a narrative voice. The narrator has buried himself completely in the text, disappeared beneath the voices of his characters. A narrator in an oral culture, as has been seen, normally and naturally operated in episodic patterning, and the elimination of narrative voice appears to have been essential at ﬁrst to rid the story line of such patterning. We must not forget that episodic structure was the natural way to talk out a lengthy story line if only because the experience of real life is more like a string of episodes than it is like a Freytag pyramid. Careful selectivity produces the tight pyramidal plot, and this selectivity is implemented as never before by the distance that writing establishes between expression and real life.

在戏剧之外，在叙事本身中，口头叙述者的原始声音在成为作家的无声声音时呈现出各种新的形式，因为写作所造成的距离邀请了脱离语境的读者和作家的各种虚构（Ong 1977，第. 53–81）。但是，直到印刷品出现并最终产生更充分的效果之前，声音对情节的忠诚始终保持坚定。

Outside drama, in narrative as such, the original voice of the oral narrator took on various new forms when it became the silent voice of the writer, as the distancing effected by writing invited various ﬁctionalizations of the decontextualized reader and writer (Ong 1977, pp. 53–81). But, until print appeared and eventually had its fuller effects, the voice’s allegiance to episode always remained ﬁrm.

正如我们所看到的，印刷从机械上和心理上将文字锁定在空间中，从而建立了比书写更牢固的封闭感。印刷世界催生了小说，小说最终与情节结构彻底决裂，尽管小说可能并不总是像许多戏剧那样以高潮形式组织得如此紧密。小说家更具体地关注文本，而不是与想象的或真实的审计员（对于印刷品）散文浪漫故事通常是为了大声朗读而写的）。但他或她的立场仍然有点不稳定。这位十九世纪小说家反复出现的“亲爱的读者”揭示了调整的问题：作者仍然倾向于在某个地方感受到观众、听众，并且必须经常记住，这个故事不是为听众而写的，而是为读者而写的，每个人都独自在他或他的故事中。她自己的世界。狄更斯和其他十九世纪小说家沉迷于朗诵他们的小说选段，也揭示了对古老口头叙述者世界的挥之不去的感觉。来自这个世界的一个特别持久的幽灵是巡回英雄，他的旅行将情节串在一起，并在中世纪的浪漫史中幸存下来，甚至在塞万提斯令人难以置信的早熟的堂吉诃德中幸存下来笛福（鲁滨逊漂流记是一个搁浅的流浪者）和菲尔丁的汤姆·琼斯，斯莫列特的情景叙事，甚至狄更斯的一些作品，例如《匹克威克外传》。

Print, as has been seen, mechanically as well as psychologically locked words into space and thereby established a ﬁrmer sense of closure than writing could. The print world gave birth to the novel, which eventually made the deﬁnitive break with episodic structure, though the novel may not always have been so tightly organized in climactic form as many plays. The novelist was engaged more speciﬁcally with a text and less with auditors, imagined or real (for printed prose romances were often written to be read aloud). But his or her position was a bit unsettled still. The nineteenth-century novelist’s recurrent ‘dear reader’ reveals the problem of adjustment: the author still tends to feel an audience, listeners, somewhere, and must frequently recall that the story is not for listeners but for readers, each one alone in his or her own world. The addiction of Dickens and other nineteenth-century novelists to declamatory reading of selections from their novels also reveals the lingering feeling for the old oral narrator’s world. An especially persistent ghost from this world was the itinerant hero, whose travels served to string episodes together and who survived through medieval romances and even through Cervantes’ otherwise unbelievably precocious Don Quixote into Defoe (Robinson Crusoe was a stranded itinerant) and into Fielding’s Tom Jones, Smollett’s episodic narratives, and even some of Dickens, such as The Pickwick Papers.

正如我们所看到的，金字塔结构的叙事在侦探小说中达到了顶峰，从坡的《莫格街谋杀案》开始，出版于 1841 年。在理想的侦探故事中，上升的动作无情地营造出令人难以忍受的紧张气氛，高潮的认知和反转以爆炸性的突然性释放了紧张气氛，结局彻底解开了一切——故事中的每一个细节都具有至关重要——而且，直到高潮和结局，实际上都具有误导性。中国的“侦探小说”始于十七世纪，成熟于十八、十九世纪，与坡共享叙事材料，但从未达到坡的高潮简洁，其文本中夹杂着“长诗、哲学题外话等等”（古里克） 1949 年，第 iii 页）。

The pyramidally structured narrative, as has been seen, reaches its peak in the detective story, beginning with Poe’s The Murders in the Rue Morgue, published in 1841. In the ideal detective story, ascending action builds relentlessly to all but unbearable tension, the climactic recognition and reversal releases the tension with explosive suddenness, and the dénouement disentangles everything totally – every single detail in the story turns out to have been crucial – and, until the climax and dénouement, effectively misleading. Chinese ‘detective novels’, which began in the seventeenth century and matured in the eighteenth and nineteenth, share narrative materials with Poe, but never achieved Poe’s climactic concision, interlarding their texts with ‘lengthy poems, philosophical digressions, and what not’ (Gulik 1949, p. iii).

侦探故事的情节具有深刻的内在性，因为通常首先在其中一个人物的内心中实现完全的结局，然后传播给读者和其他虚构人物。夏洛克·福尔摩斯在其他人（尤其是读者）之前就已经在头脑中弄清楚了这一切。这是侦探故事的典型特征，与简单的“悬疑”故事不同，后者没有如此整洁的封闭组织。用卡勒的术语（1973）来说，“叙事的内向转向”在这里通过与旧的口头叙事的对比得到了引人注目的阐释。口头叙述者的主角通常因其外在功绩而闻名，但已被印刷主角的内在意识所取代。

Detective-story plots are deeply interior in that a full closure is commonly achieved inside the mind of one of the characters ﬁrst and then diffused to the reader and the other ﬁctional characters. Sherlock Holmes had it all ﬁgured out in his head before anyone else did, including especially the reader. This is typical of the detective story as against the simple ‘mystery’ story, which does not have so tidy a closed organization. The ‘inward turn of narrative’, in Kahler’s term (1973), is strikingly illustrated here by contrast with the old oral narrative. The oral narrator’s protagonist, distinguished typically for his external exploits, has been replaced by the interior consciousness of the typographic protagonist.

侦探故事经常表现出情节和文本之间的某种直接联系。在金甲虫中（1843），埃德加·爱伦·坡不仅将行动的关键放在罗格朗的头脑中，而且还提出了作为其外部等同物的文本，即解释定位隐藏宝藏的地图的书面代码。罗格朗直接解决的直接问题不是存在性问题（宝藏在哪里？），而是文本性问题（如何解释这篇文章？）。一旦文本问题解决了，其他的事情就迎刃而解了。而且，正如托马斯·J·法雷尔（Thomas J. Farrell）曾经向我指出的那样，尽管文本是手写的，但文本中的代码很大程度上是印刷的，不仅由字母表字母组成，还由标点符号组成，而标点符号在手稿中很少或根本不存在但印刷丰富。这些标记与口头世界的距离甚至比字母表中的字母还要远：尽管它们是文本的一部分，但它们无法发音，非音位的。印刷品在最大化隔离感和封闭感方面的作用是显而易见的。文字与心灵是一个完整的整体，自成一体，有其无声的内在逻辑。后来，亨利·詹姆斯在一种准侦探故事中改变了同一主题，在《阿斯彭文件》（1888）是一个神秘的中心人物，他的整个身份都被捆绑在他未发表的信件中，这些信件在故事的结尾被焚毁，没有被那个毕生致力于追寻这些信件以发现其真相的人阅读。杰弗里·阿斯彭确实是一个人。有了这些文件，阿斯彭在他的追随者心中的神秘面纱就烟消云散了。文本性体现在这个令人难忘的故事中。'这封信杀人；灵赐人生命”（哥林多后书 3:6）。

Not infrequently the detective story shows some direct connection between plot and textuality. In The Gold-Bug (1843), Edgar Allan Poe not only places the key to the action inside Legrand’s mind but also presents as its external equivalent a text, the written code that interprets the map locating the hidden treasure. The immediate problem that Legrand directly solves is not an existential problem (Where is the treasure?) but a textual one (How is this writing to be interpreted?). Once the textual problem is solved, everything else falls into place. And, as Thomas J. Farrell once pointed out to me, although the text is handwritten, the code in the text is largely typographic, made up not simply of letters of the alphabet but also of punctuation marks, which are minimal or nonexistent in manuscript but abundant in print. These marks are even farther from the oral world than letters of the alphabet are: though part of a text, they are unpronounceable, nonphonemic. The effect of print in maximizing the sense of isolation and closure is evident. What is inside the text and the mind is a complete unit, self-contained in its silent inner logic. Later, varying this same theme in a kind of quasi-detective story, Henry James creates in The Aspern Papers (1888) a mysterious central character whose entire identity is bound up in a cache of his unpublished letters, which at the end of the story are incinerated, unread by the man who had dedicated his life to pursuing them to discover what sort of person Jeffrey Aspern really was. With the papers, the mystery of Aspern’s person in his pursuivant’s mind goes up in smoke. Textuality is incarnated in this haunting story. ‘The letter kills; the spirit gives life’ (2 Corinthians 3:6).

写作的反思性——与口头表达相比，写作过程缓慢，以及与口头表演者相比，作者的孤立性加强了这种反思性——鼓励意识从无意识中成长。正如埃德加·爱伦·坡自己的理论所证明的那样，侦探小说作家比皮博迪的史诗叙述者具有更加敏锐的反思意识。

The very reﬂectiveness of writing – enforced by the slowness of the writing process as compared to oral delivery as well as by the isolation of the writer as compared to the oral performer – encourages growth of consciousness out of the unconscious. A detective-story writer is exquisitely more reﬂectively conscious than one of Peabody’s epic narrators, as Edgar Allan Poe’s own theorizing makes evident.

正如我们所看到的，写作本质上是一种提高意识的活动。组织严密、情节经典的故事既源于意识的提高，又鼓励意识的提高，这一事实象征性地表达了自己，随着侦探故事中完美金字塔情节的到来，行动被视为集中在主角的意识中——侦探。近几十年来，随着印刷文化已转变为电子文化，情节紧凑的故事因对作者和读者来说过于“容易”（即过于完全受意识控制）而失宠。先锋派文学现在不得不淡化其叙事或掩盖其情节。但电子时代的情节故事并不是情节叙述。它们是之前情节故事的印象派和意象派的变体。叙事情节现在永久带有书写和排版的标记。当它在记忆和回响中构建自身时，暗示着早期初级口头叙事及其对无意识的严重依赖（Peabody 1975），它不可避免地以一种自我意识的、典型的文学方式来实现，就像阿兰·罗伯-格里耶的《La Jalousie》或《La Jalousie》中那样。詹姆斯·乔伊斯的尤利西斯.

Writing, as has been seen, is essentially a consciousness-raising activity. The tightly organized, classically plotted story both results from and encourages heightened consciousness, and this fact expresses itself symbolically when, with the arrival of the perfectly pyramidal plot in the detective story, the action is seen to be focused within the consciousness of the protagonist – the detective. In recent decades, as typographic culture has been transmuted into electronic culture, the tightly plotted story has fallen out of favor as too ‘easy’ (that is, too fully controlled by consciousness) for author and reader. Avantgarde literature is now obliged to deplot its narratives or to obscure their plots. But deplotted stories of the electronic age are not episodic narratives. They are impressionistic and imagistic variations on the plotted stories that preceded them. Narrative plot now permanently bears the mark of writing and typography. When it structures itself in memories and echoes, suggestive of early primary oral narrative with its heavy reliance on the unconscious (Peabody 1975), it does so inevitably in a self-conscious, characteristically literate way, as in Alain Robbe-Grillet’s La Jalousie or James Joyce’s Ulysses.

“圆形”字符、书写和印刷

THE ‘ROUND’ CHARACTER, WRITING AND PRINT

现代读者通常将叙事或戏剧中有效的“人物塑造”理解为“圆形”角色的产生，用 EM Forster 的术语（1974 年，第 46-54 页）来说，这个角色“具有无法估量的生命力”。 '。与“圆”字相对的是“扁”字，这类字不会让读者感到惊讶，而是会因大量满足期望而感到高兴。我们现在知道，“重”（或“平”）人物类型最初源自初级口头叙述，它无法提供其他类型的人物。类型角色既可以组织故事情节本身，也可以管理叙事中出现的非叙事元素。围绕奥德修斯（或者在其他文化中，兔子兄弟或蜘蛛阿南西）可以利用有关聪明的传说，

The modern reader has typically understood effective ‘characterization’ in narrative or drama as the production of the ‘round’ character, to use E. M. Forster’s term (1974, pp. 46–54), the character that ‘has the incalculability of life about it’. Opposed to the ‘round’ character is the ‘ﬂat’ character, the type of character that never surprises the reader but, rather, delights by fulﬁlling expectations copiously. We know now that the type ‘heavy’ (or ‘ﬂat’) character derives originally from primary oral narrative, which can provide characters of no other kind. The type character serves both to organize the story line itself and to manage the non-narrative elements that occur in narrative. Around Odysseus (or, in other cultures, Brer Rabbit or the spider Anansi) the lore concerning cleverness can be made use of, around Nestor the lore about wisdom, and so on.

随着话语从初级口头转向越来越强大的手写和印刷控制，扁平的、“沉重的”或字体字符屈服于变得越来越“圆”的字符，也就是说，其表现方式乍一看不可预测，但最终是一致的从圆形人物所赋予的复杂的人物结构和复杂的动机来看。随着时间的推移，动机的复杂性和内在心理的成长使圆形人物像一个“真人”。小说中出现的圆形人物的外表取决于很多因素。事态发展。斯科尔斯和凯洛格（Scholes and Kellogg，1966，第165-77页）提出了诸如《旧约》中的内在化驱动力及其在基督教中的强化、希腊戏剧传统、奥维德和奥古斯丁的内省传统以及中世纪凯尔特人所培养的内在性等影响。浪漫主义和宫廷爱情传统。但他们也指出，直到小说出现时，个人性格特征的衍生才得以完善，其时间感不仅作为一个框架，而且作为人类行为的一个组成部分。

As discourse moves from primary orality to greater and greater chirographic and typographic control, the ﬂat, ‘heavy’ or type character yields to characters that grow more and more ‘round’, that is, that perform in ways at ﬁrst blush unpredictable but ultimately consistent in terms of the complex character structure and complex motivation with which the round character is endowed. Complexity of motivation and internal psychological growth with the passage of time make the round character like a ‘real person’. The round character that emerged out of the novel depended for its appearance upon a great many developments. Scholes and Kellogg (1966, pp. 165–77) suggest such inﬂuences as the interiorizing drive in the Old Testament and its intensiﬁcation in Christianity, the Greek dramatic tradition, the Ovidian and Augustinian traditions of introspection, and the inwardness fostered by the medieval Celtic romances and the courtly-love tradition. But they also point out that the ramiﬁcation of personal character traits was not perfected until the novel appeared with its sense of time not simply as a framework but as a constituent of human action.

所有这些发展在原始口头文化中都是不可想象的，事实上，它们出现在一个以书写为主导的世界中，它的驱动力是仔细逐项的内省，并对灵魂的内在状态及其内在结构的顺序关系进行精心的分析。对“圆”字出现的更全面的解释必须包括认识到书写和后来的印刷对旧的思维经济的影响。我们对圆形人物的第一个近似是在希腊悲剧中，这是第一个完全由写作控制的语言体裁。这些内容本质上仍然是针对公共领导人，而不是小说中可能盛行的普通家庭人物，但索福克勒斯的俄狄浦斯，甚至更多，欧里庇得斯悲剧中的彭透斯、龙舌兰、伊菲革涅亚和俄瑞斯忒斯比荷马笔下的任何人物都要复杂得多，内心也更加痛苦。从口语读写能力的角度来看，我们在这里面对的是写作所开辟的世界的日益内在化。瓦特（Watt，1967，第75页）提请人们注意笛福身上已经存在的“良心的内化”和产生对人性的感觉的内省习惯，并将其追溯到笛福的加尔文主义清教徒背景。笛福笔下的内省人物与世俗世界的联系方式带有某种独特的加尔文主义色彩。但是内省和良心越来越大的内化标志着基督教禁欲主义的整个历史，它们的强化显然与圣奥古斯丁的写作有关。我们在这里面对的是写作所开辟的世界的日益内在化。瓦特（Watt，1967，第75页）提请人们注意笛福身上已经存在的“良心的内化”和产生对人性的感觉的内省习惯，并将其追溯到笛福的加尔文主义清教徒背景。笛福笔下的内省人物与世俗世界的联系方式带有某种独特的加尔文主义色彩。但是内省和良心越来越大的内化标志着基督教禁欲主义的整个历史，它们的强化显然与圣奥古斯丁的写作有关。我们在这里面对的是写作所开辟的世界的日益内在化。瓦特（Watt，1967，第75页）提请人们注意笛福身上已经存在的“良心的内化”和产生对人性的感觉的内省习惯，并将其追溯到笛福的加尔文主义清教徒背景。笛福笔下的内省人物与世俗世界的联系方式带有某种独特的加尔文主义色彩。但是内省和良心越来越大的内化标志着基督教禁欲主义的整个历史，它们的强化显然与圣奥古斯丁的写作有关。75）提请人们注意笛福身上已经存在的“良心的内化”和产生对人性的感觉的内省习惯，并将其追溯到笛福的加尔文清教徒背景。笛福笔下的内省人物与世俗世界的联系方式带有某种独特的加尔文主义色彩。但是内省和良心越来越大的内化标志着基督教禁欲主义的整个历史，它们的强化显然与圣奥古斯丁的写作有关。75）提请人们注意笛福身上已经存在的“良心的内化”和产生对人性的感觉的内省习惯，并将其追溯到笛福的加尔文清教徒背景。笛福笔下的内省人物与世俗世界的联系方式带有某种独特的加尔文主义色彩。但是内省和良心越来越大的内化标志着基督教禁欲主义的整个历史，它们的强化显然与圣奥古斯丁的写作有关。利雪圣德蕾莎自传的忏悔录（1873-97 ）。瓦特引用米勒和约翰逊（Miller and Johnson，1938，第 461 页）指出，“几乎每个有文化的清教徒都保留某种日记”。印刷术的出现强化了文字所培养的内在性。在新教圈子里，印刷时代的标志是提倡对《圣经》进行私人的、个人的解释，而在天主教圈子里，印刷时代的标志是私下认罪的现象增多，随之而来的是对良心省察的强调。文字和印刷品对基督教禁欲主义的影响亟待研究。

All these developments are inconceivable in primary oral cultures and in fact emerge in a world dominated by writing with its drive toward carefully itemized introspection and elaborately worked out analyses of inner states of soul and of their inwardly structured sequential relationships. Fuller explanation of the emergence of the ‘round’ character must include an awareness of what writing, and later print, did to the old noetic economy. The ﬁrst approximations we have of the round character are in the Greek tragedies, the ﬁrst verbal genre controlled entirely by writing. These deal still with essentially public leaders rather than with the ordinary, domestic characters that can ﬂourish in the novel, but Sophocles’ Oedipus and, even more, Pentheus and Agave and Iphigenia and Orestes in Euripides’ tragedies are incomparably more complex and interiorly anguished than any of Homer’s characters. In orality-literacy perspectives, what we are dealing with here is the increasing interiorization of the world opened up by writing. Watt (1967, p. 75) calls attention to the ‘internalization of conscience’ and the introspective habits that produced the feeling for human character found already in Defoe, and traces this to Defoe’s Calvinist Puritan background. There is something distinctively Calvinistic in the way Defoe’s introspective characters relate to the secular world. But introspection and greater and greater internalization of conscience mark the entire history of Christian asceticism, where their intensiﬁcation is clearly connected with writing, from St Augustine’s Confessions to the Autobiography of St Thérèse of Lisieux (1873–97). Miller and Johnson (1938, p. 461), quoted by Watt, note that ‘almost every literate Puritan kept some sort of journal’. The advent of print intensiﬁed the inwardness fostered by script. The age of print was immediately marked in Protestant circles by advocacy of private, individual interpretation of the Bible, and in Catholic circles was marked by the growth of frequent private confession of sins, and concomitantly a stress on the examination of conscience. The inﬂuence of writing and print on Christian asceticism cries for study.

正如我们所看到的，写作和阅读都是单独的活动（尽管一开始阅读通常是集体完成的）。他们将心灵投入到一种艰苦的、内化的、个性化的思想中，这是口耳相传的民间所无法企及的。在它们所产生的私人世界中，对“圆润”的人类性格的感觉诞生了——深深地内化在动机中，从内部神秘地但始终如一地提供动力。“圆”字最早出现在手写控制的古希腊戏剧中，在印刷术出现后的莎士比亚时代得到了进一步发展，并在小说中达到顶峰，而在浪漫主义时代出现后，印刷术更加充分。内部化（Ong 1971）。

Writing and reading, as has been seen, are solo activities (though reading at ﬁrst was often enough done communally). They engage the psyche in strenuous, interiorized, individualized thought of a sort inaccessible to oral folk. In the private worlds that they generate, the feeling for the ‘round’ human character is born – deeply interiorized in motivation, powered mysteriously, but consistently, from within. First emerging in chirographically controlled ancient Greek drama, the ‘round’ character is further developed in Shakespeare’s age after the coming of print, and comes to its peak with the novel, when, after the advent of the Age of Romanticism, print is more fully interiorized (Ong 1971).

书写和印刷并不能完全消除平面字符。按照新的文字技术强化旧的文字技术并同时改造旧文字技术的原则，文字文化实际上可能在某些时刻产生活体文字的缩影，即抽象文字。这些出现在中世纪晚期的道德剧中，这些戏剧使用抽象的美德和恶习作为人物——这种类型的人物被强化，因为只有写作才能强化它们——以及十七世纪的幽默戏剧，如本·琼森的《每个》幽默的人或Volpone，在更复杂的情节中引入稍微充实的美德和恶习作为角色。笛福、理查森、菲尔丁和其他早期小说家（Watt 1967，第 19-21 页），甚至有时简·奥斯汀，也给人物起了名字：Lovelace、Heart-free、Allworthy 或 Square。晚期高科技、电子文化仍然在西部片等回归流派中或在自我意识幽默的背景下（在这个词的现代意义上）产生类型角色。快乐的绿巨人在广告剧本中表现得很好，因为反英雄的绰号“快乐”向成年人宣传，他们不要认真对待这位近代生育之神。典型人物的故事以及他们将书面小说与口头传统联系起来的复杂方式尚未被讲述。

Writing and print do not entirely do away with the ﬂat character. In accordance with the principle that a new technology of the word reinforces the old while at the same time transforming it, writing cultures may in fact generate at certain points the epitome of type characters, that is, abstract characters. These occur in the morality plays of the late Middle Ages, which employ abstract virtues and vices as characters – type characters intensiﬁed as only writing can intensify them – and in the drama of the humors in the seventeenth century, which, as in Ben Jonson’s Every Man in His Humor or Volpone, introduce slightly ﬂeshed out virtues and vices as characters in more complex plots. Defoe, Richardson, Fielding, and other early novelists (Watt 1967, pp. 19–21), and even at times Jane Austen, give characters names that type them: Lovelace, Heart-free, Allworthy, or Square. Late high technology, electronic cultures still produce type characters in regressive genres such as Westerns or in contexts of self-conscious humor (in the modern sense of this word). The Jolly Green Giant works well enough in advertising script because the anti-heroic epithet ‘jolly’ advertises to adults that they are not to take this latterday fertility god seriously. The story of type characters and the complex ways they relate written ﬁction to oral tradition has not yet been told.

正如后期印刷或电子时代的故事情节建立在经典情节之上，并由于情节被掩盖或缺失的感觉而达到其效果一样，在同一时代，奇怪的空心化的故事也同样如此。代表极端意识状态的人物，如卡夫卡、塞缪尔·贝克特或托马斯·品钦的人物，之所以能达到这样的效果，是因为与他们的前身、古典小说中的“圆形”人物形成鲜明对比。如果叙事没有经过“圆形”人物阶段，这样的电子时代人物将是不可想象的。

Just as the deplotted story of the late-print or electronic age builds on classical plot and achieves its effect because of a sense that the plot is masked or missing, so in the same age the bizarrely hollowed characters that represent extreme states of consciousness, as in Kafka, Samuel Beckett or Thomas Pynchon, achieve their effects because of the contrast felt with their antecedents, the ‘round’ characters of the classical novel. Such electronic-age characters would be inconceivable had narrative not gone through a ‘round’ character stage.

圆形人物的发展记录了意识的变化，其范围远远超出了文学世界。自弗洛伊德以来，对所有人格结构的心理学尤其是精神分析的理解都以小说的“圆形”特征作为其模型。弗洛伊德认为，真实的人类在心理结构上就像戏剧人物俄狄浦斯，而不是像阿喀琉斯，而且实际上就像从十九世纪小说世界中诠释的俄狄浦斯，比古希腊文学中的任何东西都更加“圆润”。看来，现代深度心理学的发展与戏剧和小说中人物的发展是平行的，两者都依赖于写作产生并通过印刷品强化的心灵的内向转向。的确，正如深度心理学寻找隐藏在日常生活表面之下的一些晦涩但非常重要的深层意义一样，从简·奥斯汀到萨克雷和福楼拜的小说家都邀请读者去感受他们所描绘的有缺陷或欺诈的表面之下的一些更真实的意义。“深度”心理学的洞察力在早期是不可能的，其原因与十九世纪小说的完全“圆形”特征在其时代之前是不可能的相同。在这两种情况下，都需要意识的文本组织，尽管其他力量也在发挥作用——远离“旧”（巴斯德之前）医学的整体治疗的运动以及对新整体主义、民主化和文化私有化（本身是写作和后来印刷的影响），

The development of the round character registers changes in consciousness that range far beyond the world of literature. Since Freud, the psychological and especially the psychoanalytic understanding of all personality structure has taken as its model something like the ‘round’ character of ﬁction. Freud understands real human beings as psychologically structured like the dramatic character Oedipus, not like Achilles, and indeed like an Oedipus interpreted out of the world of nineteenth-century novels, more ‘round’ than anything in ancient Greek literature. It would appear that the development of modern depth psychology parallels the development of the character in drama and the novel, both depending on the inward turning of the psyche produced by writing and intensiﬁed by print. Indeed, just as depth psychology looks for some obscure but highly signiﬁcant deeper meaning hidden beneath the surface of ordinary life, so novelists from Jane Austen to Thackeray and Flaubert invite the reader to sense some truer meaning beneath the ﬂawed or fraudulent surface they portray. The insights of ‘depth’ psychology were impossible earlier for the same reasons that the fully ‘round’ character of the nineteenth-century novel was not possible before its time. In both cases, textual organization of consciousness was required, though of course other forces were also in play – the movement away from the holist therapy of the ‘old’ (pre-Pasteur) medicine and the need for a new holism, the democratization and privatization of culture (itself an effect of writing and, later, print), the rise of the so called ‘nuclear’ family or ‘family of affection’ in place of the extended family organized to preserve the ‘line’ of descent, advanced technology relating larger groups of persons more intimately to one another, and so on.

但无论深度心理学发展背后有哪些其他力量，其中一个主要力量是写作和印刷所引发的对人类生活世界和人类的新感觉。夸张地描述的人物并不能很好地接受精神分析批评，也不能很好地接受精神分析批评中描述的人物。“美德”和“恶习”相互竞争。就现代心理学和小说的“圆形”特征向当今意识所代表的人类存在而言，对人类存在的感觉已经通过写作和印刷得到了处理。这绝不是对当今人类生存感受的指责。恰恰相反。当今的现象学存在感在其有意识和清晰的反映方面比之前的任何事物都更加丰富。但认识到这种感觉是有益的，这种感觉依赖于书写和印刷技术，被深深地内化，成为我们自己的心理资源的一部分。如今，历史、心理和其他知识的巨大储备只能通过使用书写和印刷品（现在是电子产品）来积累，这些知识可以进入复杂的叙事和人物塑造。但这些世界上的技术不仅仅存储我们所知道的东西。他们以一种让我们所知道的东西在口头文化中变得难以接近甚至不可想象的方式来设计。

But whatever these other forces behind the development of depth psychology, one major force was the new feeling for the human lifeworld and the human person occasioned by writing and print. Epithetically delineated characters do not yield well to psychoanalytic criticism, nor do characters delineated in a faculty psychology of competing ‘virtues’ and ‘vices’. Insofar as modern psychology and the ‘round’ character of ﬁction represent to present-day consciousness what human existence is like, the feeling for human existence has been processed through writing and print. This is by no means to fault the present-day feeling for human existence. Quite the contrary. The present-day phenomenological sense of existence is richer in its conscious and articulate reﬂection than anything that preceded it. But it is salutary to recognize that this sense depends on the technologies of writing and print, deeply interiorized, made a part of our own psychic resources. The tremendous store of historical, psychological and other knowledge which can go into sophisticated narrative and characterization today could be accumulated only through the use of writing and print (and now electronics). But these technologies of the word do not merely store what we know. They style what we know in ways which made it quite inaccessible and indeed unthinkable in an oral culture.

7

7

一些定理

SOME THEOREMS

对口语和读写能力之间对比的研究很大程度上是一项未完成的工作。最近对这种对比的了解不仅继续扩大了对口头过去的理解，而且扩大了对现在的理解，解放了我们受文本束缚的思维，并将许多长期以来熟悉的东西置于新的视角中。在这里，我将提出一些看似更有趣的新观点和新见解，但只是一些，因为它不可能包罗万象，也不可能完整。我将以定理的形式来阐述这个问题；或多或少的假设性陈述以各种方式与这里已经解释的有关口头和口头-读写能力转变的内容联系起来。如果前面的章节取得了一定的成功，

Study of the contrast between orality and literacy is largely unﬁnished business. What has recently been learned about this contrast continues to enlarge understanding not only of the oral past, but also of the present, liberating our text-bound minds and setting much of what has long been familiar in new perspectives. Here I shall suggest some of the seemingly more interesting new perspectives and insights, but only some, for it is impossible to be inclusive or complete. I shall present the matter here in the form of theorems; more or less hypothetical statements that connect in various ways with what has already been explained here about orality and the orality–literacy shift. If the foregoing chapters have been even moderately successful, the reader should be able to carry the theorems farther as well as to generate his or her own theorems and supplementary insights.

其中一些定理将特别关注当今某些文学解释和/或哲学流派与口头-读写转变的关系。这些学校中的大多数都在霍克斯（1977）中进行了处理。为了方便读者，只要有可能，参考文献将直接提供给霍克斯，可以在霍克斯身上找到各种主要来源。

Some of these theorems will attend especially to the ways in which certain present-day schools of literary interpretation and/or philosophy relate to the orality–literacy shift. Most of these schools are treated in Hawkes (1977). For the reader’s convenience, wherever possible, references will be given directly to Hawkes, in whom the various primary sources can be traced.

文学史

LITERARY HISTORY

文学史已经开始探索口头文学研究所提供的可能性。重要的研究报告了广泛分散的具体传统，这些传统涉及他们的主要口头表演或文学文本中的口头元素。Foley (1980b) 引用了有关苏美尔神话、圣经诗篇、各种西非和中非口述作品、中世纪英语、法语和日耳曼文学的作品（参见 Curschmann 1967）、俄语bylina，以及美国民间的布道。海姆斯的列表（1973）增加了对阿伊努语、突厥语和其他传统的研究。但总体而言，文学史仍然很少意识到口语与文学的极性，尽管这些极性在流派、情节、人物塑造、作家与读者关系的发展中非常重要（参见 Iser 1978）以及文学关系社会、智力和心理结构。

Literary history has begun to exploit the possibilities which orality– literacy studies open to it. Important studies have reported on a wide scatter of speciﬁc traditions treating either their primary oral performances or the oral elements in their literary texts. Foley (1980b) cites works on Sumerian myth, biblical Psalms, various West and Central African oral productions, medieval English, French and Germanic literature (see Curschmann 1967), the Russian bylina, and American folk preaching. Haymes’s listings (1973) add studies on Ainu, Turkic, and still other traditions. But literary history on the whole still proceeds with little if any awareness of orality–literacy polarities, despite the importance of these polarities in the development of genres, plot, characterization, writer–reader relationships (see Iser 1978), and the relationship of literature to social, intellectual and psychic structures.

文本可以代表对口语与识字极性的各种不同调整。西方的手稿文化始终是口头的，即使在印刷之后，文本性也只是在大多数阅读都是无声的文化中逐渐达到了今天的地位。我们还没有完全接受这样一个事实：从古代到十八世纪，许多文学文本，即使是以书面形式写成的，也通常供公众朗诵；最初由作者本人撰写（Hadas 1954，第 40 页；Nelson 1976-7，第 77 页）。在二十世纪初，向家人和其他小组大声朗读仍然很常见，直到电子文化将这些小组动员到收音机和电视机周围，而不是围绕在场的小组成员周围。

Texts can represent all sorts of different adjustments to orality–literacy polarities. Manuscript culture in the West was always marginally oral, and, even after print, textuality only gradually achieved the place it has today in cultures where most reading is silent. We have not yet come to full terms with the fact that from antiquity well through the eighteenth century many literary texts, even when composed in writing, were commonly for public recitation; originally by the author himself (Hadas 1954, p. 40; Nelson 1976–7, p. 77). Reading aloud to family and other small groups was still common in the early twentieth century until electronic culture mobilized such groups around radio and television sets rather than around a present group member.

中世纪文学与口语的关系特别有趣，因为识字对中世纪心灵的压力更大，这不仅是由于圣经文本的中心地位所带来的（古希腊人和罗马人没有神圣的文本，他们的宗教实际上是空洞的）形式神学），但也受到中世纪学术界口头性（争论）和文本性（书面作品的评论）的奇怪新混合的影响（Hajnal 1954）。欧洲的大多数中世纪作家可能都延续了写作文学作品以供大声朗读的古典做法（Crosby 1936；Nelson 1976-7；Ahern1981）。这有助于确定始终的修辞风格以及情节和人物塑造的本质。

Medieval literature is particularly intriguing in its relation to orality because of the greater pressures of literacy on the medieval psyche brought about not only by the centrality of the biblical text (the ancient Greeks and Romans had had no sacred texts, and their religions are virtually empty of formal theology) but also by the strange new mixture of orality (disputations) and textuality (commentaries on written works) in medieval academia (Hajnal 1954). Probably most medieval writers across Europe continued the classical practice of writing their literary works to be read aloud (Crosby 1936; Nelson 1976–7; Ahern 1981). This helped determine the always rhetorical style as well as the nature of plot and characterization.

在整个文艺复兴时期，同样的做法在很大程度上持续存在。威廉·纳尔逊（William Nelson，1976-7，第119-20页）提请注意阿拉曼尼对他最初不成功的《吉隆·科尔特斯》的修改，使其更加具有情节性，从而更适合群体的口头朗读，就像阿里奥斯托成功的《奥兰多》一样。纳尔逊继续推测，同样的动机促使菲利普·西德尼爵士对旧阿卡迪亚进行了修改，适合口服给药。他还指出（1976-7，第 117 页），通过文艺复兴，口头阅读的实践使作者能够表达自己，“就好像真人……在听”他们一样——而不是向他们呈现的“假设”——日作者通常会自我介绍。这就是拉伯雷和托马斯·纳什的风格。纳尔逊的这项研究是最丰富的研究之一，它指出了从中世纪到十九世纪英国文学中口语-读写能力的动态，并表明在研究口语-读写能力的两极分化方面还有多少工作要做。谁评价过莉莉的《尤弗斯》是一部值得大声朗读的作品？

The same practice persisted to a notable degree through the Renaissance. William Nelson (1976–7, pp. 119–20) calls attention to Alamanni’s revision of his originally unsuccessful Giron Cortese to make it more episodic and thus better ﬁtted for oral reading to groups, as Ariosto’s successful Orlando had been. Nelson goes on to conjecture that the same motivation prompted Sir Philip Sidney’s revision of the Old Arcadia, suitable for oral delivery. He points out also (1976–7, p. 117) that through the Renaissance the practice of oral reading brings authors to express themselves ‘as though real people... were listening’ to them – not the ‘hypotheses’ to whom present-day authors normally address themselves. Hence the style of Rabelais and Thomas Nashe. This study of Nelson’s is one of the richest in pointing out orality– literacy dynamisms in English literature from the Middle Ages to the nineteenth century and in suggesting how much more there is to do in studying the orality–literacy polarities. Who has yet assessed Lyly’s Euphues as a work to read aloud?

浪漫主义运动标志着旧的以口语为基础的修辞终结的开始（Ong 1971），然而口语却以霍桑（Bayer 1980）等早期美国作家的风格呼应，有时令人难以忘怀，有时令人尴尬，更不用说美利坚合众国的开国元勋，它通过托马斯·巴宾顿·麦考利的史学与温斯顿·丘吉尔的史学清晰地相呼应。在这些作家身上，舞台化的概念化和半演讲风格体现了英国公立学校中高效的残余口语。文学史仍有待考察这里涉及的内容。

The Romantic Movement marks the beginning of the end of the old orality-grounded rhetoric (Ong 1971), yet orality echoes, sometimes hauntingly, sometimes awkwardly, in the style of early American writers such as Hawthorne (Bayer 1980), not to mention the Founding Fathers of the United States of America, and it echoes clearly through the historiography of Thomas Babington Macaulay into that of Winston Churchill. In these writers the stagey conceptualization and semioratorical style register the highly effective residual orality in British public schools. Literary history has still to examine what is involved here.

几个世纪以来，从口头通过书写和印刷到文字的电子处理的转变深刻地影响并实际上从根本上决定了口头艺术流派的演变，当然同时也决定了连续的人物塑造和情节模式。例如，在西方，史诗基本上是一种无可挽回的口头艺术形式。书面和印刷的史诗，即所谓的“艺术”史诗，是对口头讲故事的心理动力学所要求的程序的自觉的、古老的模仿——例如，从一开始就投入媒体资源，对盔甲和盔甲进行详尽的公式化描述。竞争行为，其他口头主题的其他公式化发展。随着口头表达随着写作和印刷而减少，尽管作者有最好的意图和努力，史诗还是不可抗拒地改变了形式。《伊利亚特》和《奥德赛》的叙述者迷失在口头共同体中：他从来不以“我”的身份出现。作家维吉尔以“Arma, virumque cano”开始他的《埃涅阿斯纪》，“我歌颂武器和男人”。斯宾塞写给沃尔特·罗利爵士的信，介绍了《仙后》表明斯宾塞实际上认为他正在创作一部像荷马的作品一样的作品：但写作和印刷已经确定他不能。最终，这部史诗甚至失去了想象中的可信度：它在口头文化的思维经济中的根源已经枯竭。十八世纪能够与史诗严肃地联系起来的唯一方式就是通过模仿史诗来取笑它。这些是由数百人生产的。在那之后，史诗实际上就死了。卡赞扎基斯对《奥德赛》的延续是一种外星文学形式。

Over the centuries, the shift from orality through writing and print to electronic processing of the word has profoundly affected and, indeed, basically determined the evolution of verbal art genres, and of course simultaneously the successive modes of characterization and of plot. In the West, for example, the epic is basically and irremediably an oral art form. Written and printed epics, the so called ‘art’ epics, are self-conscious, archaizing imitations of procedures demanded by the psychodynamics of oral storytelling – for example, plunging at the beginning in medias res, elaborate formulaic descriptions of armor and agonistic behavior, other formulary development of other oral themes. As orality diminishes with writing and print, the epic irresistibly changes shape despite the author’s best intentions and efforts. The narrator of the Iliad and the Odyssey is lost in the oral communalities: he never appears as ‘I’. The writer Virgil begins his Aeneid with ‘Arma, virumque cano’, ‘I sing of arms and the man’. Spenser’s letter to Sir Walter Raleigh introducing The Faerie Queene shows that Spenser actually thought he was composing a work like Homer’s: but writing and print had determined that he could not. Eventually, the epic loses even imaginary credibility: its roots in the noetic economy of oral culture are dried up. The only way the eighteenth century can relate seriously to the epic is by making fun of it in mock-epics. These are produced by the hundreds. After that, the epic in effect is dead. Kazantzakis’s continuation of the Odyssey is an alien literary form.

浪漫小说是手写文化的产物，是一种新的书面体裁的创作，严重依赖口头思维和表达方式，但不像“艺术”史诗那样有意识地模仿早期的口头形式。流行民谣，如英语和苏格兰语的边境民谣，是在口语的边缘发展起来的。这部小说显然是一种印刷体裁，具有深刻的内心世界，去英雄化，并且具有强烈的讽刺倾向。当今的情节叙述形式是电子时代的一部分，以深奥的代码（如计算机）巧妙地构建。等等。这些是一些一般的整体模式。详细的模式是什么，在很大程度上还没有人知道。但对它们的研究和理解不仅可以揭示过去的语言艺术形式和思想形式，而且可以揭示现在甚至未来的语言艺术形式和思想形式。

Romances are the product of chirographic culture, creations in a new written genre heavily reliant on oral modes of thought and expression, but not consciously imitating earlier oral forms as the ‘art’ epic did. Popular ballads, as the Border ballads in English and Scots, develop on the edge of orality. The novel is clearly a print genre, deeply interior, de-heroicized, and tending strongly to irony. Present-day deplotted narrative forms are part of the electronic age, deviously structured in abstruse codes (like computers). And so on. These are some general overall patterns. What the detailed patterns have been, for the most part no one yet knows. But study and understanding of them will throw light not only on verbal art forms and thought forms of the past but also on those of the present and possibly even of the future.

我们对女性对文学流派和风格的影响的理解存在巨大差距，可以通过关注口头-文学-印刷的转变来弥补或弥补。前面的章节指出，早期女性小说家和其他女性作家通常在口头传统之外进行创作，因为一个简单的事实是，女孩通常不会接受男孩在学校接受的口头修辞训练。女性作家的口头风格明显不如男性作家的正式风格，但据我所知，还没有重大研究检验过这一事实的后果，而这一事实肯定是巨大的。当然，适合女性作家的非修辞风格有助于使这部小说成为现实：更像是一场对话，而不是一场对话。平台性能。斯坦纳（1967，第387-9页）呼吁人们关注小说在商业生活中的起源。此生是彻底有文化的，但它的文化是白话，而不是以拉丁语修辞为基础的。持不同政见者的学校主要接受商业生活培训，是第一批招收女孩的学校。

A great gap in our understanding of the inﬂuence of women on literary genre and style could be bridged or closed through attention to the orality–literacy–print shift. An earlier chapter here noted that early women novelists and other women writers generally worked from outside the oral tradition because of the simple fact that girls were not commonly subjected to the orally based rhetorical training that boys got in school. The style of women writers was distinctively less formally oral than that of men, yet no major studies, so far as I know, have examined the consequences of this fact, which must certainly be massive. Certainly, non-rhetorical styles congenial to women writers helped make the novel what it is: more like a conversation than a platform performance. Steiner (1967, pp. 387–9) has called attention to the origins of the novel in mercantile life. This life was thoroughly literate, but its literacy was vernacular, not grounded in Latin rhetoric. The dissenters’ schools, which trained for business life, were the ﬁrst to admit girls to the classroom.

各种残余口语以及广播电视引发的次要口语文化的“文字口语”有待深入研究（Ong，1971，第284-303页；1977，第53-81页）。当今关于口语与读写能力对比的一些最有趣的工作是对现代英语西非文学的研究（Fritschi 1981）。

Various kinds of residual orality as well as the ‘literate orality’ of the secondary oral culture induced by radio and television await in-depth study (Ong 1971, pp. 284–303; 1977, pp. 53–81). Some of the most interesting work on orality–literacy contrasts today has been done in studies of modern anglophone West African literature (Fritschi 1981).

在更实际的层面上，我们对与写作心理动力学相关的口语心理动力学的更深入理解正在改善写作技能的教学，特别是在当今从几乎完全口语迅速转向读写的文化中，正如许多非洲文化正在做的那样（Essien 1978） ），以及在高识字率社会中残留的口头亚文化（Farrell 1978a；1978b），例如美国的城市黑人亚文化或奇卡诺亚文化。

At a more practical level our deeper understanding of the psychodynamics of orality in relation to the psychodynamics of writing is improving the teaching of writing skills, particularly in cultures today moving rapidly from virtually total orality into literacy, as many African cultures are doing (Essien 1978), and in residually oral subcultures in dominantly high-literacy societies (Farrell 1978a; 1978b) such as urban black subcultures or Chicano subcultures in the United States.

新批评与形式主义

NEW CRITICISM AND FORMALISM

口头到读写的转变清楚地阐明了新批评（Hawkes 1977，第 151-6 页）作为受文本束缚的思维的一个主要例子的意义。新批评坚持文本艺术个体作品的自主性。人们会记得，与口头话语相比，写作被称为“自主话语”，口头话语从来不是自主的，而是总是嵌入非语言的存在中。新批评家将言语艺术作品同化为文本的视觉对象世界，而不是口头听觉事件世界。他们坚持认为诗歌或其他文学作品应被视为一个物体，一个“语言偶像”。

The orality-to-literacy shift throws clear light on the meaning of the New Criticism (Hawkes 1977, pp. 151–6) as a prime example of text-bound thinking. The New Criticism insisted on the autonomy of the individual work of textual art. Writing, it will be remembered, has been called ‘autonomous discourse’ by contrast with oral utterance, which is never autonomous but always embedded in non-verbal existence. The New Critics have assimilated the verbal art work to the visual object-world of texts rather than to the oral–aural event-world. They have insisted that the poem or other literary work be regarded as an object, a ‘verbal icon’.

很难看出诗歌或其他言语创作的这种视觉触觉模型如何有效地应用于口头表演，而这可能是一首真正的诗歌。声音无法还原为“物体”或“图标”——正如我们所见，它是一个持续发生的事件。此外，在口头文化中，诗歌与语境之间的分离是很难想象的，因为诗歌作品的原创性在口头文化中是难以想象的。在于此时歌手或叙述者与观众的关系方式。虽然它在某种程度上当然是一个特殊的事件，与其他类型的事件不同，但在特殊的背景下，它的目标和/或结果很少是简单的审美：例如，口头史诗的表演也可以同时发挥作用作为一种庆祝行为，作为payeia或青年教育，作为群体认同的加强者，作为保存各种知识的一种方式——历史的、生物的、动物学的、社会学的、航海的、航海的、宗教的——等等。此外，叙述者通常会认同他所对待的角色，并与真正的观众自由互动，而观众的反应反过来又有助于确定他所说的内容——叙述的长度和风格。在他的表演中在《姆温多史诗》中，坎迪·鲁雷克不仅亲自向观众讲话，甚至还让英雄姆温多向正在记录鲁雷克表演的抄写员讲话，告诉他们赶紧继续工作（Biebuyck 和 Mateene 1971）。这几乎不是一个图标。在史诗的结尾，鲁雷克总结了他认为故事传达的现实生活信息（1971，第 44 页）。对“纯诗”的浪漫追求，与现实生活的关注隔绝，源于写作所创造的自主话语的感觉，更源于印刷所创造的封闭的感觉。没有什么比浪漫主义运动与技术之间紧密的、几乎是无意识的联盟更引人注目了。

It is hard to see how this visualist-tactile model of a poem or other verbal creation could apply effectively to an oral performance, which presumably could be a true poem. Sound resists reduction to an ‘object’ or an ‘icon’ – it is an on-going event, as has been seen. Moreover, the divorce between poem and context would be difficult to imagine in an oral culture, where the originality of the poetic work consists in the way this singer or narrator relates to this audience at this time. Although it is of course in some way a special event, distinguishable from other kinds of event, in a special setting, its aim and/or result is seldom if ever simply aesthetic: performance of an oral epic, for example, can serve also simultaneously as an act of celebration, as paideia or education for youth, as a strengthener of group identity, as a way of keeping alive all sorts of lore – historical, biological, zoological, sociological, venatic, nautical, religious – and much else. Moreover, the narrator typically identiﬁes with the characters he treats and interacts freely with his real audience, who by their responses in turn help determine what he says – the length and style of his narrative. In his performance of The Mwindo Epic, Candi Rureke not only himself addresses the audience but even has the hero, Mwindo, address the scribes who are recording Rureke’s performance in writing, telling them to hurry on with their work (Biebuyck and Mateene 1971). Hardly an icon, this. At the end of the epic, Rureke summarizes the real-life messages that he feels the story conveys (1971, p. 44). The romantic quest for ‘pure poetry’, sealed off from real-life concerns, derives from the feel for autonomous utterance created by writing and, even more, the feel for closure created by print. Nothing shows more strikingly the close, mostly unconscious, alliance of the Romantic Movement with technology.

稍微古老的俄罗斯形式主义（Hawkes 1977，第59-73页）与新批评主义采取了大致相同的立场，尽管这两个流派是独立发展的。形式主义者将诗歌视为“前景”语言，这种语言在诗歌的封闭范围内唤起人们对词语本身相互关系的关注，诗歌有其自主的内在存在。形式主义者在批评中最小化或消除对诗歌的“信息”、“来源”、“历史”或与其作者传记的关系的任何关注。显然，它们也受文本约束，只关注（并且大部分不加反思）书面创作的诗歌。

The slightly older Russian Formalism (Hawkes 1977, pp. 59–73) took much the same position as the New Criticism, although the two schools developed independently. Formalists have made much of poetry as ‘foregrounded’ language, language that calls attention to the words themselves in their relationship to one another within the closure that is the poem, which has its own autonomous, inner being. Formalists minimize or eliminate from criticism any concern with the poem’s ‘message’, ‘sources’, ‘history’, or relationship to the biography of its author. They are obviously also text-bound, too, focused exclusively (and unreﬂectively for the most part) on poems composed in writing.

说新批评家和俄罗斯形式主义者受文本束缚并不是贬低他们。因为他们实际上处理的是文本创作的诗歌。此外，考虑到先前的批评状态，批评的大部分内容都集中在传记和作者的心理，忽视了文本，他们有理由强调文本。前面的批评来自残留的口头修辞传统，实际上在处理自主的、适当的文本话语方面并不熟练。从口头与文学对比所暗示的视角来看，从早期批评到形式主义和新批评的转变，表现为从残留的口头（修辞、语境）心态到文本（非语境）心态的转变。但文本心态相对不具有反思性。因为，尽管与口头表达相比，文本是自主的，但最终没有任何文本能够独立于文本外的世界。每个文本都建立在借口之上。

To say that the New Critics and Russian Formalists have been text-bound is not to downgrade them. For they were in fact dealing with poems that were textual creations. Moreover, given the preceding state of criticism, which had devoted itself in great part to the biography and psychology of the author, to the neglect of the text, they had warrant to stress the text. The preceding criticism had come out of a residually oral, rhetorical tradition, and was in fact unskilled in treating autonomous, properly textual, discourse. Seen in the perspectives suggested by orality–literacy contrasts, the shift from earlier criticism to Formalism and the New Criticism thus appears as a shift from a residually oral (rhetorical, contextual) mentality to a textual (non-contextual) mentality. But the textual mentality was relatively unreﬂective. For, although texts are autonomous by contrast with oral expression, ultimately no text can stand by itself independent of the extratextual world. Every text builds on pretext.

因为所有文本都有文本外的支持。罗兰·巴特（Roland Barthes，Hawkes 1977，第154-5页）指出，对文本的任何解释都必须移出文本，以便与读者联系：文本没有任何意义，除非有人阅读并理解它。必须被解释，也就是说与读者的世界相关——这并不是说异想天开地阅读或与作者的世界无关。人们可以这样描述这种情况：由于任何给定的时间都位于所有时间的总体中，因此由其作者在给定的时间内存放的文本本身就是事实与所有时代相关，其含义只能随着时间的推移而展开，作者或作者同时代人的意识无法理解，但不一定不存在于他们的潜意识中。马克思主义批评（巴特部分源自于马克思主义批评——Hawkes 1977，第267-71页）认为，新批评家的自我指涉是阶级决定的和阿谀奉承的：它将文本的“客观”意义与实际上外部的东西等同起来。文本，即它所想象的由本质上是腐朽贵族的成熟、智慧、传统感和镇定所支持的解释（Hawkes 1977，p.155）。从这个观点来看，新批评在仰慕这种贵族环境的阿谀奉承的中产阶级中最为成功。

For all texts have extratextual supports. Roland Barthes (Hawkes 1977, pp. 154–5) has pointed out that any interpretation of a text has to move outside the text so as to refer to the reader: the text has no meaning until someone reads it, and to make sense it must be interpreted, which is to say related to the reader’s world – which is not to say read whimsically or with no reference to the writer’s world. One might describe the situation this way: since any given time is situated in the totality of all time, a text, deposited by its author in a given time, is ipso facto related to all times, having implications which can be unfolded only with the passage of time, inaccessible to the consciousness of the author or author’s coevals, though not necessarily absent from their subconscious. Marxist criticism (from which Barthes in part derives – Hawkes 1977, pp. 267–71) maintains that the self-reference of the New Critics is class-determined and sycophantic: it identiﬁes the ‘objective’ meaning of the text with something actually outside the text, namely the interpretations it imagines to be the ones supported by the sophistication, wit, sense of tradition and poise of what is essentially a decaying aristocracy (Hawkes 1977, p. 155). The New Criticism, in this view, proved most successful with the sycophantic middle classes who look up to this aristocratic milieu.

新批评也源于口头文学力量的另一次重大重组，这种重组是随着学术界从手写控制的拉丁文基础转向更自由的口头白话基础而发生的。尽管到 1850 年左右，美国学院和大学已经开设了一些零星的英国文学课程，但直到 1850 年早期，该学科才成为一个相当大的学术科目。二十世纪和第一次世界大战后才在研究生阶段（Parker 1967）。在牛津大学和剑桥大学，本科生的英语学习直到十九世纪末才开始小心翼翼地开始，直到第一次世界大战之后才成为一门自给自足的学科（Potter 1937；Tillyard 1958）。到了 20 世纪 30 年代，新批评正在兴起，它是新的英语学术研究的副产品，是在学术环境中发展起来的第一个主要的英语文学白话批评（Ong 1962，第 177-205 页）。学术界不知道对英语有什么“古老的批评”。早期对白话作品的批评，无论多么精明，都是超学术的、偶然的，而且往往是业余的，因为早期的学术、专业文学研究仅限于拉丁语，也有一些希腊语，并且植根于修辞学的研究。

The New Criticism also grew out of another major realignment of oral–literate forces, that which took place as academia shifted from a chirographically controlled Learned Latin base to a more freely oral vernacular base. Although there had been a few scattered courses in English literature in American colleges and universities by around 1850, the subject became a sizable academic subject only in the early twentieth century and at the graduate level only after World War I (Parker 1967). At Oxford and Cambridge Universities undergraduate study of English began timidly only in the late nineteenth century and became a self-sufficient subject also only after World War I (Potter 1937; Tillyard 1958). By the 1930s the New Criticism was under way, a spin-off from the new academic study of English, the ﬁrst major vernacular criticism of English-language literature to develop in an academic environment (Ong 1962, pp. 177–205). Academia had known no ‘old criticism’ of English. Earlier criticism of vernacular works, however astute, was extra-academic, occasional and often amateur, for earlier academic, professional study of literature had been restricted to Latin, with some Greek, and had been grounded in the study of rhetoric.

正如我们所看到的，一千多年来，拉丁语一直是一种受手写控制的语言，而不再是一种母语。尽管它与残余的口头心态联系在一起，但它无法像母语那样直接进入无意识。在这种情况下，拉丁文的文学文本，无论多么复杂，无论多么博学的理解，与用自己的母语写成的、由无意识和有意识元素更丰富地混合而成的文本相比，都注定是晦涩难懂的。鉴于拉丁文本相对内在的不透明性，对文本的评论应该在一定程度上从文本本身转向作者、他的心理、历史背景以及所有令新批评倡导者如此恼火的外部因素，这并不奇怪。

Latin, as has been seen, had for well over a thousand years been a chirographically controlled language, no longer a mother tongue. Although it was tied in to a residually oral mentality, it provided no direct access to the unconscious of the sort that a mother tongue provides. Under these conditions, a literary text in Latin, however complex, and however learnedly understood, was bound to be opaque by comparison with a text in one’s own mother’s tongue, written out of a richer mix of unconscious and conscious elements. Given the relative intrinsic opacity of Latin texts, it was not surprising that comment on the text should be deﬂected somewhat from the text itself to the author, his psychology, the historical background, and all the externals that so annoyed advocates of the New Criticism.

新批评本身从一开始就瞄准了英语文本，并且主要是在学术环境中进行的，与早期对白话作品的偶尔批评相比，这种讨论可以在更大范围、更连续和更有组织的范围内展开。文本从未以如此详尽的方式得到关注，部分原因是到了 20 世纪 30 年代和 1940 年代，深度心理学打开了意识之下的隐秘处，心灵以前所未有的方式反思性地转向自身，而且还因为白话文本这种语言与儿童早期口头世界的关系不同于一种语言的文本，这种语言已经有一千多年的历史了，没有人不知道如何书写它。据我所知，文本研究从未利用过这里的含义（Ong 1977，第 22-34 页）。其影响是巨大的。符号结构主义和解构主义通常完全不认识文本与其口头基础相关的各种方式。他们专门研究以浪漫主义时代、电子时代边缘的晚期印刷观点为标志的文本（1844 年标志着莫尔斯成功演示了电报）。

The New Criticism itself zeroed in from the ﬁrst on English-language texts and did so mostly in an academic setting where discussions could develop on a scale larger, more continuous, and more organized than that of earlier occasional criticism of vernacular works. Never before had texts been attended to in this exhaustive way, partly because by the 1930s and 1940s the recesses beneath consciousness had been opened by depth psychology and the psyche turned reﬂectively in on itself as never before, but also because a text in the vernacular had a different relationship to the early oral world of childhood than did a text in a language which for well over a millennium had been spoken by no one who did not know also how to write it. Textual studies, so far as I know, have never exploited the implications here (Ong 1977, pp. 22–34). The implications are massive. Semiotic structuralism and deconstructionism generally take no cognizance at all of the various ways that texts can relate to their oral substratum. They specialize in texts marked by the late typographic point of view developed in the Age of Romanticism, on the verge of the electronic age (1844 marked Morse’s successful demonstration of the telegraph).

结构主义

STRUCTURALISM

克劳德·列维-斯特劳斯（Claude Lévi-Strauss，1970；霍克斯 1977，第 32-58 页）发展的结构主义分析主要关注口头叙述，并通过用抽象的二元术语而不是用抽象的二元术语来分解口头叙述，从而在一定程度上摆脱了手写和印刷的偏见。书面叙述中发展的情节类型。列维-斯特劳斯对叙事的基本类比是语言本身及其对比元素系统：音素、语素等。他和他的许多追随者一般很少关注口头表达的特定心理动力学，正如帕里勋爵所提出的那样。尤其是哈夫洛克和皮博迪。对此类工作的关注将为结构主义分析增添另一个维度，这经常被指责过于抽象和倾向性——所有被识别的结构都是二元的（我们生活在计算机时代），而二元主义是通过忽略不适合二元模式的元素（通常是关键元素）来实现的。此外，二元结构，无论它们形成的抽象模式多么有趣，似乎都无法解释叙事的心理紧迫性，因此它们无法解释为什么这个故事是一个故事。

Structuralist analysis as developed by Claude Lévi-Strauss (1970; Hawkes 1977, pp. 32–58) has focused largely on oral narrative and has achieved a certain freedom from chirographic and typographic bias by breaking down oral narrative in abstract binary terms rather than in terms of the sort of plot developed in written narrative. Lévi-Strauss’s fundamental analogue for narrative is language itself with its system of contrastive elements: phoneme, morpheme, etc. He and his many followers generally have paid little if any attention to the speciﬁc psychodynamics of oral expression as worked out by Parry, Lord, and particularly Havelock and Peabody. Attention to such work would add another dimension to Structuralist analysis, which is often accused of being overly abstract and tendentious – all structures discerned turn out to be binary (we live in the age of the computer), and binarism is achieved by passing over elements, often crucial elements, that do not ﬁt binary patterning. Moreover, the binary structures, however interesting the abstract patterns they form, seem not to explain the psychological urgency of a narrative and thus they fail to account for why the story is a story.

对口语本身的研究表明，口语叙事并不总是以允许现成的结构主义二元分析的方式组合在一起，甚至也不能以普罗普（1968）应用于民间故事的严格的主题分析的方式组合在一起。口头叙述的结构有时会崩溃，尽管这一事实并不妨碍熟练掌握题外话和倒叙技巧的叙述者。正如皮博迪所明确指出的那样（1975 年，第 179 页、第 235 页和passim），直接的叙述“路线”在初级口头表演中的作用远不如在书面作文（或受书面作文影响的人的口头表演）中有效。口语作文与“信息核心”一起运作，其中公式“没有显示我们通常与思想联系在一起的组织程度”，尽管主题或多或少如此（Peabody 1975，p.179）。

Studies of orality as such have brought out that oral narrative is not always put together in terms which admit of ready Structuralist binary analysis, or even of the rigid thematic analysis which Propp (1968) applies to the folktale. The structure of oral narrative collapses at times, though this fact does not hamper a good narrator skilled in digression and ﬂashback techniques. The straightforward narrative ‘line’, as Peabody has made clear (1975, pp. 179, 235 and passim ), is much less operative in primary oral performance than in written composition (or in oral performance by persons inﬂuenced by written composition). Oral composition works with ‘informational cores’ in which the formulas do ‘not show the degree of organization that we commonly associate with thought’, although the themes do so more or less (Peabody 1975, p. 179).

口头表演者，尤其是但不限于诗歌表演者，经常受到干扰的困扰。一个词可能会引发一连串的联想，表演者会陷入死胡同，只有熟练的叙述者才能摆脱困境。荷马陷入这样的困境并不罕见——“荷马点头”。优雅地纠正错误并使它们看起来根本不是错误的能力是区分专业歌手和笨手笨脚的人的因素之一（Peabody 1975，第 235, 457-64 页；Lord 1960，第 109 页）。这里的组织和解组织模式似乎不仅仅是一个拼凑的问题（工匠的工作，即兴创作），这是结构主义符号学中最喜欢的术语，来自列维-斯特劳斯的图腾主义（1963）和野蛮心灵（1966）。“拼凑”是文学家的术语，指的是如果他创作了一首口头风格的诗歌，他自己就会犯下这样的罪行。但口头组织并不是临时拼凑起来的文字组织。例如，在古希腊的口头起源叙述中，六音步线的结构和思想形式本身之间可能存在微妙的联系。

Oral performers, especially but not exclusively performers in verse, are beset with distractions. A word may set off a chain of associations which the performer follows into a cul de sac from which only the skilled narrator can extricate himself. Homer gets himself into such predicaments not infrequently – ‘Homer nods’. The ability to correct mistakes gracefully and make them appear as not mistakes at all is one of the things that separates the expert singers from the bunglers (Peabody 1975, pp. 235, 457–64; Lord 1960, p. 109). The modes of organization and disorganization here seem not to be a matter of mere bricolage (handiman’s work, ad hoc improvization), a favorite term in structuralist semiotics, coming from Levi-Strauss’s Totemism (1963) and The Savage Mind (1966). Bricolage is the literate’s term for what he himself would be guilty of if he produced an oral-styled poem. But oral organization is not literate organization put together in makeshift fashion. Subtle connections can exist, for example, in ancient Greek narrative of oral provenance, between the structure of the hexameter line and thought forms themselves.

文本主义者和解构主义者

TEXTUALISTS AND DECONSTRUCTIONISTS

对口语和读写能力的心理动力学知识的不断增长也影响了我们这里称为文本主义者的群体的工作，特别是AJ·格雷马斯、茨维坦·托多罗夫、已故的罗兰·巴特、菲利普·索勒斯和雅克·德里达，以及米歇尔·福柯和雅克·拉康（霍克斯 1977）。这些批判哲学家主要源自胡塞尔传统，专门研究文本，实际上是印刷文本，而且大多是浪漫主义时代的近代印刷文本——当这个时代被认为标志着一个新的时代时，这是一个重要的专业化。与印刷的明确内在化和古代修辞传统的萎缩相关的意识状态（Ong 1971和1977）。大多数文本主义者很少关心历史的连续性（这也是心理的连续性）。科恩（1977 年，第 17 页）以自己的方式解释过去。同样，与结构主义和文本主义相关的马克思主义符号学和文学理论，例如在皮埃尔·马谢里（Pierre Macherey，1978）中所代表的，都依赖于所有来自十九世纪小说的详细例子，正如马谢里的译者所指出的（1978，p.lx） ）。

The growing knowledge of the psychodynamics of orality and literacy also cuts across the work of the group we may here call textualists, notably A. J. Greimas, Tzvetan Todorov, the late Roland Barthes, Philippe Sollers and Jacques Derrida, as well as Michel Foucault and Jacques Lacan (Hawkes 1977). These critic-philosophers, who derive largely from a Husserlian tradition, specialize in texts, and in fact in printed texts, and mostly in latter-day printed texts from the Age of Romanticism – a signiﬁcant specialization when this age is recognized as marking a new state of consciousness associated with the deﬁnite interiorization of print and the atrophy of the ancient rhetorical tradition (Ong 1971 and 1977). Most textualists show little concern with historical continuities (which are also psychological continuities). Cohen (1977, p. xxii) has noted how Foucault’s ‘archaeology’ is concerned chieﬂy with correcting modern views rather than with explaining the past on its own terms. Similarly, the Marxist semiotics and literary theory related to structuralism and textualism, as represented, for example, in Pierre Macherey (1978), rests on detailed examples all drawn from the nineteenth-century novel, as Macherey’s translator notes (1978, p. lx).

文本学家最喜欢的出发点是让·雅克·卢梭。雅克·德里达（Jacques Derrida）（1976 年，第 164-268 页和passim）与卢梭进行了长时间的对话。德里达坚持认为写作“不是口语的补充”，而是一种截然不同的表现。通过这种坚持，他和其他人在削弱手写和印刷偏见方面做出了巨大的贡献，这也是本书所关注的问题。在最糟糕的情况下，正如文本主义者所认为的那样，这种偏见可以采取以下形式：人们假设精神外世界中的项目与口语单词之间简单地存在一一对应关系，并且口语单词之间也存在类似的一一对应关系。文字和书面文字（似乎包括印刷品；文本主义者通常将书写和印刷品相互同化，并且很少甚至冒险看一眼电子通信）。在这种一一对应的假设下，

A favorite point of departure for textualists has been Jean-Jacques Rousseau. Jacques Derrida (1976, pp. 164–268 and passim ) has carried on a lengthy dialogue with Rousseau. Derrida insists that writing is ‘not a supplement to the spoken word’ but a quite different perform-ance. By this insistence, he and others have rendered a great service in undercutting the chirographic and typographic bias that has also been the concern of this book. At its worst, as textualists see it, this bias can take this form: one assumes that there simply is a one-to-one correspondence between items in an extramental world and spoken words, and a similar one-to-one correspondence between spoken words and written words (which seem to be taken to include print; the textualists generally assimilate writing and print to each other and seldom if ever venture even to glance at electronic communication). On this assumption of one-to-one correspondence, the naive reader presumes the prior presence of an extramental referent which the word presumably captures and passes on through a kind of pipeline to the psyche.

在康德本体现象主题的变体中（它本身与书写带来的视觉主导地位有关，并由印刷品证实——Ong 1967b，第74页），德里达严厉斥责了这种存在的形而上学。他将管道模型命名为“逻各斯中心主义”，并将其诊断为源自“语音中心主义”，即以逻各斯或发音单词为主要，从而通过与口头言语的比较来贬低写作。写作打破了管道模型，因为可以证明写作有其自身的经济性，因此它不能简单地原封不动地传输从语音中接收到的内容。此外，回顾书写造成的中断，我们可以看到，口头语言更早地打破了这条管道，而口头语言本身并不像透过透明玻璃那样传递一种超自然的存在世界。语言是结构，它的结构不是外在世界的结构。德里达的最终结果是，文学——实际上是语言本身——根本不“再现”或“表达”其自身之外的东西。由于它不以管道的方式引用任何内容，因此它不引用或表示任何内容。

In a variation on Kant’s noumenon-phenomenon theme (itself related to the sight-dominance brought on by writing and conﬁrmed by print – Ong 1967b, p. 74), Derrida excoriates this metaphysics of presence. He styles the pipeline model ‘logocentrism’ and diagnoses it as deriving from ‘phonocentrism’, that is, from taking the logos or sounded word as primary, and thereby debasing writing by comparison with oral speech. Writing breaks the pipeline model because it can be shown that writing has an economy of its own so that it cannot simply transmit unchanged what it receives from speech. Moreover, looking back from the break made by writing, one can see that the pipeline is broken even earlier by spoken words, which do not themselves transmit an extramental world of presence as through transparent glass. Language is structure, and its structure is not that of the extramental world. The end result for Derrida is that literature – and indeed language itself – is not at all ‘representational’ or ‘expressive’ of something outside itself. Since it does not refer to anything in the manner of a pipeline, it refers to, or means, nothing.

然而，很难说因为 A 不是 B，所以它什么都不是。卡勒（Culler，1975，第 241-54 页）讨论了许多文本主义者（正如我在这里对他们的风格）或结构主义者（如他对他们的风格）的作品，并表明，尽管他们否认文学具有代表性或指涉性，但结构主义者巴黎 Tel Quel 小组的成员（或文本主义者）（巴特、托多罗夫、索勒斯、朱莉娅·克里斯蒂娃等人）实际上——并且不可避免地——使用代表性的语言，因为他们“不想声称他们的分析并不更好”比任何其他人都重要”（1975 年，第 252 页）。

Yet it hardly follows that because A is not B, it is nothing. Culler (1975, pp. 241–54) discusses the work of many of the textualists, as I have styled them here, or structuralists, as he styles them, and shows that, despite their denial that literature is representational or referential, the structuralists (or textualists) who have made up the Tel Quel group in Paris (Barthes, Todorov, Sollers, Julia Kristeva, and others) actually – and unavoidably – use language representationally, for they ‘would not want to claim that their analyses are no better than any other’ (1975, p. 252).

另一方面，毫无疑问，今天许多人确实依赖以逻各斯为中心的模型来思考思维和沟通过程。在打破他所谓的语音中心主义和逻各斯中心主义的过程中，德里达正在做一场欢迎仪式，在马歇尔·麦克卢汉以其著名格言“媒介就是信息”席卷的同一领域。

There is little doubt, on the other hand, that today many persons do rely on a logocentric model in thinking about noetic and communication processes. In breaking up what he calls phonocentrism and logocentrism, Derrida is performing a welcome service, in the same territory that Marshall McLuhan swept through with his famous dictum, ‘The medium is the message’.

然而，本书中最近关于口语与读写能力对比的研究使语音中心主义和逻各斯中心主义的根源变得复杂化，超出了文本主义者的解释，特别是在柏拉图的例子中。柏拉图与口头的关系是完全模糊的。一方面，在《斐德罗篇》和《第七封信》中，他降低了文字的等级，转而支持口头语言，因此是以声音为中心的。另一方面，在他的共和国时期，他禁止诗人，正如哈夫洛克所表明的，他这样做是因为他们代表了古老的口述、记忆的模仿、聚合、冗余、丰富、传统主义、热情人性、参与性的世界——一个与分析、稀疏、精确、柏拉图所宣扬的抽象的、视觉主义的、不动的“观念”世界。柏拉图并没有有意识地将他对诗人的反感视为对旧的口头思维经济的反感，但正如我们现在可以看出的那样，事实就是如此。柏拉图之所以感到这种反感，是因为在他生活的时代，字母表第一次被充分内化，影响了希腊思想，包括他自己的思想，在这个时代，由于识字能力的实现，耐心分析、冗长连续的思维过程首次出现。处理数据的头脑。

However, recent work on the orality–literacy contrasts treated in the present book complicates the roots of phonocentrism and of logocentrism beyond the textualists’ account, especially in the case of Plato. Plato’s relationship to orality was thoroughly ambiguous. On the one hand, in the Phaedrus and the Seventh Letter he downgraded writing in favor of oral speech, and thus is phonocentric.
